text: 1:13 Mins Suffice it to say that I'm really impressed with this little mic. I run a podcast called Life is Story and frequently interview some of the top names in the Christian fiction and non-fiction world. I've balked at buying equipment other than my webcam because, frankly, I never really thought of myself as that successful. Then I started tracking how many people were listening and knew it was time to get serious. I'm not quite at the "needs professional podcasting equipment" stage yet, but did want to upgrade my mic. I use a lapel mic when I speak at church, so I'm familiar with that style and thought I'd give it a try here.The sound quality exceeded my expectations. In the video to the left, you can listen to me test the sound based on my distance from the mic. Sounds best up close (6-12"), but still has good, but quiet quality from farther back. I'll be using this for all my future podcasting needs!*Provided in exchange for an unbiased review*

My wife and I are getting ready for our first child. (We're adopting internationally.) Rather than run crazy to buy everything once we have our child, we're working now to check off a couple of indispensable items every month. We have a stroller, but how to make it carry everything we need? So when I had to opportunity to test this product, I jumped at it.TOP POCKETS - The three top pouches are meant to hold water bottles/juice pouches, whatever you might need. They are easily accessible and hold most normal sized water bottles (5.5" deep with a 3" diameter). The two outer pouches are insulated as well. The middle section is slightly larger and has a flap that velcros shut. Good for storing snacks or other small, loose items. The flap has a small zipper area for odds and ends.SIDE POUCHES - The left pouch is meant as a phone case, but at 5" x 3", it barely fits my iPhone 5 and will probably not hold much larger phones. The right pouch is zippered and meant to hold keys and other such things. Pretty basic.STRAPS - The velcro straps are long enough to be affixed to any stroller type and will hold securely.Much better than those built-in, one-giant-pouch deals. This is a winner! I would note that it's not a diaper bag substitute, but you could probably fit a diaper or two in, if needed.

This is one of the most stylish iPhone covers I've ever owned. The granite look is absolutely incredible and, unlike other cases of a similar style, the design wraps all the way to the case's edge.With that said, what the case puts forth in style, it lacks in protectiveness. I would not recommend this phone for it's safety features. It does have the typical raised bumper that provides some protection to the screen and will stop scratches and such from the back, but it really isn't made for protection.Another highlight is that the case is very open-access, meaning that you don't have to worry about the aux cable or lightning port not fitting with the case.Overall, a very good stylish case, but minus a star not being super-protective, and that's an important feature to me.*I received this product in exchange for a review*

This pocket chainsaw is designed with emergencies or hard to reach areas in mind. Some of the reviews here have compared this pocket chainsaw to a regular handsaw or even an electric chainsaw. Needless to say the electric chainsaw is OBVIOUSLY easier and a handsaw is more convenient. The appeal of the pocket chainsaw is its portability and the sheer fun of using one.In emergencies, this is an easy thing to have stashed in your truck, useful if you're hiking or camping. I've also found it useful to lop off specific branches in hard to reach areas that a handsaw can't get to.The cutting teeth are great, but it does require some amount of effort. Ye olde time lumberjacks aren't going to be trading their tools in for this any time soon. It's a product with its uses and, if you're the type to need something like this, you'll love it.

This battery operated grinder is the perfect addition to any cook's home kitchen. With just a simple press of a button, you can quickly and easily grind your own salt, pepper, or other seasonings.SIZE - The actual device is 8.5" tall and 6.5" in diameter. The grinding area is approximately 4.71 cubic inches, or roughly 1/3 cup. If you're making large batches, you may need to go for a larger device, but for a single meal for a family, this is great.FUNCTION - Simple push button grinder that runs on 4 AA batteries (not included). There's a small screw to twist at the bottom to adjust the fineness or coarseness of the grind.The mechanism seems to handle it very well, though it may take some time to get it all ground.DESIGN - I love the stainless steel look. My one complaint is the loading mechanism. To actually be able to put anything into the grinder, you have to take the large top piece off, exposing the battery compartment. Then you pop off the battery compartment, which acts as a lid to the grinder. I don't like the batteries are exposed every time you load this thing. I thought perhaps I was doing it incorrectly, and there was a way to take the whole thing (large silver top piece and inner battery compartment) off at once, but I haven't been able to do it. Furthermore, the battery compartment piece is separate from the motor piece, but snaps together. This wouldn't be a problem, except the snap doesn't stay half the time, meaning that 50% of the time I take the thing apart, I end up with exposed wiring. Just seems like there could be a better design.Overall, though, it does what it says and the design downfalls haven't reached a bothersome stage (though, we'll see how it holds up with continued use)

It's very rare to have an accessory that I think could either be used by the manliest of men or the hippiest of women, but this Vintage Waistpack manages to do it all. I'm envisioning myself as a carpenter, strapping this on, using the various compartments for my various types of bolts and such, but...who am I kidding...I was interested in this only for the steampunk cosplay. But whatever your reasons for getting this, from manliness to nerdiness to hippie chic, you wanna know about its quality.It holds up. Now one thing that the hippie chic crowd should know is that it's made with real leather (let all the men now grunt appreciatively). If that's not your style, go find an imitation leather alternative. I personally love the fact that this feels real and smells real because it IS REAL. Also, with real leather, the quality just seems a bit better.The three outside pouches are about 4 inches deep by 3 inches in length and about 1 inch wide. They have snaps, but also close magnetically, which helps keep them secure.The main zippered pocket is 5 inches deep by 10 inches in length and about 3-4 inches wide, depending on how far you want to stretch it. It has one internal pocket that's credit card sized, and an inner zippered pouch that's 5" x 3".The belt length is my only concern. It's plenty big enough at 50" at it's longest setting, but is 32" at it's smallest. If you are petite, you may have to do some finagling to get this to fit securely as a waist pack.

There are SO MANY OPTIONS for women's accessories. Why choose this one? Let me tell you:COLOR CHOICES - I love that this comes in a variety of colors. There's sure to be an option that matches with that perfect outfit, or, go with a neutral tone to make it an everyday hand purse.REAL LEATHER - Just to note, this is made with real leather. For me personally, that was a big selling point. Imitation leather just doesn't have the same smell or feel. But if you morally object, then that's your right and I bring it up just to say that this product isn't for you.SPACIOUS - Despite the small size, the wallet is deceptively spacious. It is a trifold, with space on the left for a driver's license/ID card and two other card slots. The right has four card slots, and the middle zippered section is perfect for little odds and ends (but nothing bulky). The wallet portion works like a typical trifold wallet, but it also includes a secret zippered compartment.Overall, it's stylish and practical...exactly the kind of thing you want!

You've got a sleek and sexy iPhone and a sleeker and sexier Apple Watch. But where do you put it? This sleekest and sexiest charging dock, that's where! Made out of high quality bamboo, this charging dock brings a sense of elegance to your nightstand as you put away your toys for the night.NOTE: One reviewer has mentioned the difficulty in removing the Apple Watch battery from the circular hole provided. Perhaps his model was slightly imperfect, but mine has a solid, but not impossible fit that easily pops out. If you really have concerns, drill a small hole through the middle of the docking port in order to create an emergency release.

You really don't need a product like this for everyday use, but if you're traveling internationally, or anywhere where you're carrying important documents (or money), it's best to keep things close to you. This travel wallet can function as a neck pouch to be concealed under your shirt or can be extended to work as a waist pouch as well.It is just about the size of a US passport inside, which ensures that things cannot accidentally fall out. It's not meant to be a purse or an everyday bag, but some place to keep your valuables on you while you travel.The RFID blocking mechanism is also a nice device.I only take off one star because the elastic strap is rather thin and uncomfortable. It's also just bulky enough that it's not really concealable under a shirt (if you're in a colder climate, then different story).

This is a must-have for anyone who camps, hikes, or spends any significant period of time away from electricity. It's also a should-have for anyone who drives, providing peace of mind that, if your car battery dies, you have a great backup system already in place.The selling point of this product is it's multi-functional use. Well worth the cost as just a jump starter, the USB connectivity and adapters for laptops makes this the Swiss Army knife of power banks.CAPACITY - The 12000mAh capacity is more than enough for anything you can throw at it. Theoretically, you could jump your car about 20 times on one full charge. You could easily take this on a week long camping trip, use all your electronic devices, jump your car, boat, and RV, and still have charging capacity left.SIZE - At 9.5 x 3.9 x 4.9 inches, the power bank is compact enough to fit into a larger glove box or in a trunk without any hassle.RUGGEDNESS - This thing is built to last. A sturdy carrying case provides even more protection, but the hard plastic exterior is built for the outdoors.COST - At $70, you should definitely shop around before you buy, but $70 to buy peace of mind that you can fix a dead battery anywhere anytime? Yeah, I'd pay that.Overall, I'm very impressed with this power bank. Does everything it claims and then some!

Two stories in one book! The Little Bible Heroes flip-over book series is an easy to read and fun to look at retelling of biblical stories in a way that even the youngest of children can understand.I absolutely loved this particular volume (I feel like I’m saying that about all the books in this series, though!) because of the story of Martha. Really, it’s the story of Mary and Martha, but I’ll let that detail slide. Martha is focused on doing things for Jesus; her sister, Mary, is focused on learning from Jesus. In the end, Martha learns that listening to Jesus is just as important as doing things for him. That’s such a great lesson for small kids (and us big kids) to learn.The story on Jesus’ Miracles is really just a brief summary of five different miracles Jesus performed. I’m not sure what went into the idea to mash all of these together in one half-book, because each story could easily have been an entire half-book in and of itself.Because of this, I feel like parents should take their time walking through this one. We look at Jesus’ miracles like it’s no big deal but our young children are rightly shocked and amazed. What do you mean he made a paralyzed man walk? In other words, the book rushes through the information so you, as the parent, will have to slow down and walk your child through it.Despite this small criticism, the book is an overall winner. The illustrations are fun, the colors vivid, and the stories memorable. Little Bible Heroes is a great way to introduce your little one to Scripture!

Two stories in one book! The Little Bible Heroes flip-over book series is an easy to read and fun to look at retelling of biblical stories in a way that even the youngest of children can understand.Little Bible Heroes is back with two new adaptations, this time taking us back to the conquest of the Promised Land and the stories of Joshua and Rahab. Victoria Kovacs continues to masterfully break down the biblical story into words and ideas that a preschooler can understand without losing the heart of the message.The Joshua story focuses on the battle of Jericho and Joshua’s leadership of the Israelites into the Promised Land. It brings up the themes of God’s presence and help and how we can do anything through the power of God.Rahab’s story comes in the middle of the Joshua storyline, something that you can point out to your children. The two spies mentioned in Joshua’s story are the same two spies in Rahab’s story! Rahab hides the spies and, in return, is spared from the destruction. Kovacs even mentions that Rahab becomes the ancestor of King David!(Quick mostly-irrelevant theological note. Kovacs specifically says that Rahab is the great-great-great grandma of David. Keen thinkers will realize that there is an almost 400 year period from Rahab to David, which means one of two things: it is possible that every person in these generations lived long lives and had children in their 80s and 90s, or there is a generational gap here. Either is possible.)As always, the Little Bible Heroes stories do well at lending themselves to interaction in the storyline. Ask, ask, ask questions. Don’t just read the words, get your child to interact with them and seek out their thoughts and have a conversation with them. It is so important to cultivate faith at a young age and the Little Bible Heroes series is perfect for doing just that.

Two stories in one book! The Little Bible Heroes flip-over book series is an easy to read and fun to look at retelling of biblical stories in a way that even the youngest of children can understand.This particular book includes the story of Joseph and the story of The Good Samaritan. As with the rest of the series, the language is very simple and sticks to 2-3 sentences per page. Author Victoria Kovacs does a great job distilling the story into its essentials and rephrasing it in an easy-to-understand way. Mike Krome’s illustrations will draw every reader into the story as well.The story of Joseph covers the events from Joseph’s coat of many colors all the way to their family’s restoration in Egypt. Through the story, you could talk to your child about God’s providence even in tough times. You could also focus on the power of lies—because Joseph’s brothers lied, Joseph’s dad believed his son was dead. Thirdly, and perhaps most importantly, you could focus on forgiveness. Joseph is able to forgive his brothers and they are reconciled in Egypt.The story of The Good Samaritan closely follows Jesus’ parable. Through it, our young ones will be taught the value of helping everyone, even those who you might see as enemies. Talk about why the priest and the Levite didn’t stop to help but the Samaritan did. Use each page to interact with your child about the story and ask good questions that make them think and learn.I especially love the Parent Connection at the end of each story. It includes a verse straight from Scripture (though I would prefer a version simpler in language than the HCSB). Always draw your child back to the reality that these are true stories from God’s word. It also includes two helpful discussion questions, and a one sentence takeaway thought to remember.Overall, the Little Bible Heroes series does exactly what it is supposed to do: provide children with a fun and engaging introduction to Scripture. Long live the Little Bible Heroes!

0:47 Mins This bath organizer is the perfect tool for keeping your little one's bath toys all in one place.SIZE - At 18" wide and 14' tall, the netted pouch is more than sufficient to hold a number of bath toys.SUCTION - Many, many negative reviews simply say that the suction cups do not stick. I did not have that experience. The video to the left shows a demonstration.WEIGHT - According to the product info, it will hold up to five pounds, but it pressed down with probably 20-30 lbs of force in the video and the suction stayed strong.PRICE - The price point is a bit more than I would be willing to pay, but it seems about normal for bath toy organizers.I received this product for free in exchange for a review.

Note: I'm not a hairstylist. I barely have a hairstyle. I'm just a guy with wet hair that needed it dry. I also received this product for free in exchange for my honest opinion and review.SPEED SETTINGS - The dryer has two speed settings: low and high. Low is a pleasant breeze. High is let's-get-this-done-quickly mode. The first dries a style, the second gives that tousled and messy look.HEAT SETTINGS - This is the first hair dryer I've seen where "cool" wasn't "room temperature." It actually seemed like the air was being cooled. Warm is typical hair dryer heat and hot is...well...don't put it too close for too long.ATTACHMENTS - Some reviews have mentioned that their attachments did stay on. Not sure what to say about that. Tested both at the highest speeds with no issue.This is fancier and nicer than anything I really need, but the price point makes it affordable for just about anyone. Highly recommend!

The Easy Gift (R) Potato Chip Slicer Potato Chips Veggie Chopper Waffle Cutter French Fries Maker was ostensibly named by an SEO manager who thought if they plugged in every possible semi-related phrase into the title they'd make more sales. Unfortunately, even if this is true, they'd only be left with disappointed customers.Simply put, it's too small for functionality. The listing says that it fits "most potatoes," but that's far from being the case. The most common type of potatoes, russet potatoes, will not fit. Even an apple, also pictured in the stock image, will need to be quartered first.The listing also says that it "doesn't require considerable pressure" to use, a statement I can only assume was written by a bodybuilder or someone insecure about their strength. I bench 300 and this still took some elbow grease. This is probably because the blades are incredibly dull. I leaned full force into the flimsy blades with the palm of my hand and was left with short-lived indentations. No wonder it wouldn't cut!There are surely better products out there. Go find one of those.*I received this product for free in exchange for an unbiased (obviously) review*

Simple. Elegant. Perfect for the soon-to-be grandparent. My mother jumped up and down and screamed for 15 minutes after I gave it to her for Mother's Day...or maybe it was because it held the portrait of her soon-to-be-adopted first grandchild.Thank you Haysom Interiors for being a part of our special day.

You never know when your phone battery will die...strike that, you do know: at the least convenient time possible. But, you know, it's the 21st century! You always have access to electricity somewhere, right? Right? Well, usually, so if you're not the outdoorsy type, you probably won't benefit from this product over a regular external battery or charger. But if you're a hiker, camper, or someone else potentially away from anywhere with a wall outlet, this product could save your life. Even if you just have a power outage, this can save your phone.CHARGING CAPACITY - The 5000mAh capacity is more than capable of completely charging your phone. The iPhone 6 has a 1810 mAh capacity. When depleted, a day in the sunlight recharges it to over 50% capacity, meaning that this is pretty much not going to give out on you so long as there's sun.CHARGING MECHANISM - One thing I did find interesting is that the manufacturer says to rely on solar power to charge the device only in the case of an emergency. In other words, when A/C power is to be had, use that. It has me curious as to the effects of long term usage, but the 5 stars stands until I see otherwise. This is something ONLY mentioned in the small print in the instruction manual, not on the sales page here on Amazon. I would have liked to have seen this information listed prominently on the sales page, as it seems rather important.SIZE - This device is roughly the same size and weight as my iPhone 5 in its waterproof case.DESIGN - Sleek and sexy. Quite cool looking. Also it's very rugged. Great for hiking.IN THE END - If you are a hiker/camper, you need this. Throw it in your backpack, don't leave without it. It guarantees that your GPS/phone/whatever else will stay charged and keep you safe.

I've owned a good number of bluebooth headsets in my day and am constantly amazed by the number of styles there are. On ear, over ear, earbud, neckband, wireless...the list goes on. I had never tried a neckband style headset before and wondered if this might solve the problem I always have with headphones: finding the volume and track skip buttons.FIT: If you have an exceptionally large neck or wear a collared shirt, you may have trouble getting this to fit comfortably. For my average sized neck (19"), the two end pieces nestled comfortably on my collarbone. The earpieces fit snugly and the design keeps the cords from getting in the way.SOUND: For a lower-priced model, I was impressed by the sound quality. I primarily used this for listening to podcasts, but even the audio tracks I put on sounded rich and full.PAIRING: Bluetooth pairing can be a pain, but not so here. Even better, it can connect to up two device simultaneously.Another neat feature is that the collar will vibrate softly if you get a call while paired to the device. It's enough to get your attention without being obnoxious. It'll do the same if you go out of approximately 22ft range the device carries.Overall, I'm really impressed with this headset and it just might replace the simpler, smaller, headset I've been using.*Product received for free in exchange for an honest review*

Obviously food particles are going to get stuck between the blades. Obviously. It's part design flaw, part what you get when you try to chop herbs faster. These super-scissors come with multiple blades for faster chopping power, and, if you're not put off by having to tap the scissors on your cutting board or brush the herbs out from between the blades, this'll work for you!Not much more to say about these. Most everything about it is average and they get the work done. They do what they were intended to do with no real frills or whistles, so four stars.*I received this product for free in exchange for an honest review.*

Having never had a golf travel bag before but finding I all of a sudden needed one I was very lucky to receive this one. An extremely well-made and very roomy bag. There are so many things to like here: The area where your club heads are is extremely padded. In fact when you hold up the empty bag the top is almost the same weight as the reinforced bottom. The wheels appear to be very durable. The bag has outside pockets as well for extra storage.This bag is so well-made that I fear my current golf club set is unworthy. I guess I just have to go out and buy a brand new set of clubs.

I received this "jug-O-sauce" from Amazon and just had to pop it open immediately to try. What I found is not what I would call a traditional sweet-n-sour sauce. The flavor is a bit stronger and not so sweet. However it has a nice flavor that seems to go well with chicken. In my opinion it's best used as a short-timed marinade. Just put a few chicken breast filets in a large Zip-Lock, pour in enough sauce to cover, seal, and refrigerate for just a couple of hours. Put chicken on grill (discarding remaining sauce in bag) and cook. You can also add a bit of the sauce from the bottle to enhance the flavor while eating if desired.We're pleased with the flavor. I'm just not sure if I would purchase a 72 oz. bottle.

An effective solution for mild mold issues. Powered by OxyClean it's easy to use but does require some strong scrubbing on older, more set-in stains. For those relatively new mold growth a quick spray, let it sit for a few minutes, and then a fairly easy wipe off. I can't say it's better than it's competitors but it does what it claims. I'm fine with it.

My daughters have been swearing by Contigo cups fr the past couple of years. I always laughed. I mean a cup is a cup, right? Well in this case, no. I had the opportunity to try out the Contigo Party Cup and decided to put it through the test. Does it really keep drinks colder longer? In short, yes. I was impressed.One thing to note, this is hand-wash only. Do notthrowit in the dishwasher. Rinse with warm water and a bit of dish soap and your good to go for he next round. I would recommend especially for the "right-from-the-tap" beer drinker.

For whatever reason I had not read any of Brian Aldiss' books even though I do love true sci-fi. Isaac Asimov, Frederik Pohl, Gordon R Dickson,and Kim Stanley Robinson are some of my favorites. So when I read the brief description of Finches of Mars I thought it was right up my alley.The book arrived and I was surprised how short it was, just about 180 pages. But that's fine, as long as it was a page-turner. This however was rather pedestrian. It really breaks down to a series of short stories revolving around a central theme/plot. And while at first I thought that could be interesting it ended up not being so. Perhaps it's because I like a central theme with main characters that progress through the plot that I had a hard time with it. This type of plot device could be great as proven by Asimov's great Foundation series where the first eight short stories were packaged together as one book. Bit the Finches of Mars falls way short, possibly not even in the same Galaxy, from that series.Personally I really have no desire to read Aldiss' previous works even though I hear he has some great stories. This one kind of burned me off of his efforts.

Just purchased this and it's going right back to the store for a refund. The main reason is that after assembling the unit we discovered the Gup Speeder was missing from the box. Unfortunately this is not the first Fisher Price toy we've bought for our three year old grandson that is missing parts. Earlier this year we bought the Fisher-Price Thomas The Train: Trackmaster Avalanche Escape Set and it was missing two pieces of track, pretty much making it useless. We went through FP customer service and while they tried to be accommodating it ended up taking us two months to get a product that had everything. Not going to go through that again.

I discovered the Old Guys Rule line in a small shop at Morro Bay, California. I found one I liked and bought it. Not only was the size (XL) a perfect fit, which seems to be an issue nowadays with many clothing lines, but the shirt is very high quality. These will not wear out quickly as many shirts do now. Over a year later I still wear it comfortably. On our next trip to Morro Bay I purchased two more along with a hat, which is also made well to last.So now I found out that Amazon has these and purchased the Untapped Potential version. As expected it fits perfectly and is of quality material. Seriously this has become my favorite line of what I call "Lazy-Wear", not just because of the message but especially for the quality. I will have no hesitation to purchase additional products and expect to do so in the very near future.Highly recommended!

Having been to Orlando a few times I questioned just how helpful this would be. Many travel guides tend to gloss over areas to visit. This book is wonderfully detailed and includes pull out maps. Really a must have if you plan to go to Orlando and especially if you're spending time at Disney World (as if anyone going to Orlando on vacation wouldn't visit Disney World/). Highly recommended!

Game of War - Fire Age is the (gasp!) first online game I've ever played. After being pounded into submission by all the TV commercials I finally logged on and started building my city. At first it was fun and interesting. I joined an alliance and quickly built my city and hero up. Within about five days I got my city up to a level 10 with a strong military force. When the leaders of the alliance wanted to eliminate weaker players I was one of the ones they invited to join their new alliance. I was cruising.Then a funny thing happened. I realized that I was basically playing a ramped up, multi-player version on steroids of the old Civilization game I played many years ago. The issue is the game play is just so repetitive. You just keep doing the same things over and over. The quests are nothing more than clicking on an icon and letting the time elapse so you can claim your reward. In other words, you really do nothing. Oh occasionally you can go attack someone else or some monster. But overall the game got rather boring. So after about a week I deleted the app and went on with my life.I may try another online game in the future. But it will have to be less repetitive and more stimulating. Otherwise what's the point?
Heard this on the Jeep commercial and just loved it.

The 14 piece Oceanique  bathroom set is a nice but no so inexpensive way to dress up a kids or guest bathroom. The kit is functional in that it includes the shower curtain, shower rings, and bath mat. Please note that the shower curtain is 100% polyester and machine washable which is nice. Also note that the shower curtain is water resistant, not water proof. What this means is with a slight indirect spray the water will bead up but any direct spray will eventually start to seep through. A shower liner is highly recommended but is not included with the set.The bath mat is kind of cheap looking but is non-skid which is great. The bath rings are also a bit on the cheap-looking side but works well. As long as you're not looking for high fashion but instead just want something that looks nice and (again) is functional, I would recommend this set.

Honestly I am not a huge gamer. I play some here and there so I really can't say how great this is during an 18-hour gaming marathon. First as a keyboard, it's decent. The unit itself is extremely sturdy and rather heavy compared to the standard keyboard today. Of course it is not wireless so you do have to mess with that pesky USB port wire.However I am experiencing one issue that prevents me from giving this five stars. I would label myself as a deliberate typist, not the fastest by any stretch. But as I speed up I find a keystroke will miss on occasion, especially if I'm capping the first letter of a word. I have no idea why this is but it does get frustrating. I could see if I were one of those lighting fast typist who can do a paragraph in a matter of seconds. But I'm not that talented. If anyone has any thoughts on the matter I'm all ears (or would that be eyes since I would be reading it?).

OK, I have to admit something. I don't have a baby in the house anymore. I do have a three-year old grandson living with us but currently he sleeps in his own bed in his Mom's room. So no, I'm not going to install this there. Plus when he's not in preschool he usually takes his naps on our bed and I have no intention of putting in that room. So I didn't get this to be a "baby" monitor although with all the extras included it would be a wonderful device for that.No, I needed a security cam for a blind section right by the front door. Although I have a cam that points out from the garage overlooking the driveway and street, the small front courtyard is not covered. I work from home so I can keep an eye out when we have UPS deliveries or those annoying realtors who come by and knock at  the most inconvenient times. I can also set it up when my grandson is playing in our small backyard to keep an eye on him.Most of the reviews here already cover all the great attributes this system has so I'm not going to go over them again. Instead I will say that it is a quality product that performs better than expected. While I initially thought the cost of the unit was high, being just under $300 as of this review, I have to say I came away very impressed with it's value. Highly recommended not just for a baby monitor but for many purposes where you might need an extra eye.

First off I'm a huge Kansas fan, otherwise known as a Wheathead. I fell in love with their music the very first time I heard the album Song for America when it was first released. I have all their albums, many on both vinyl (from the 70/80's) and CDs. I just went to their concert in Anaheim California. Loved it. I can say without any doubt that they are my favorite music group, bar none. So please understand that I'm really having a hard time with this review.I received my advanced copy of "Kansas: Miracles Out of Nowhere" direct from the Kansas site. It was nice in that you could pre-order direct from the band's site and along with the standard set you also received a bonus DVD. I received the set on Monday 3/16. After watching it I came away underwhelmed and a little disappointed. I think this is a great documentary for those who know Kansas only for Carry on Wayward Son  and Dust in the Wind. For those people this would be an informative and interesting film about the early days of the band. For anyone who has followed the band for years there really isn't much new here. Oh occasionally there is a surprise anecdote that you may not have known, my favorite being the time they opened for Aerosmith and Steven Tyler went nutso. But for the most part the documentary plays out as more of a fluffy marketing piece than a down-&-dirty history of a great band.The film starts at the very beginning and progresses album by album through Point of Know Return. However here is where the film ends. I would have loved for it to continue through Monolith and Audio Visions because that was time that the band began to splinter amid their waning popularity. It would have been interesting to hear what happened during those days and each player's reactions but alas, no. I mean I understand omitting the Elefante years and beyond because the film is about the original lineup. I get that. But to paint this rosy picture but not include some of the dark elements is disappointing. As I said in the title, mostly fluff not enough stuff.The CD that is included again provides nothing new. If you have purchased their albums you'll have all the songs here in their original recordings except "Can I Tell You" which was recorded live for the Don Kirshner Rock Concert series. But it's also not new as it was included on the DVD in Sail On: The 30th Anniversary Collection 1974-2004. The CD does include dialog between the songs but they're just excerpts from the documentary.If you're a casual Kansas fan who knows them just through their hits then I would highly recommend this. I truly believe you'll be entertained and informed by it. If you're a Wheathead, by all means purchase it to round out your collection. Just don't expect to learn much of anything new.

As an older gentleman I have found that while the hair on my head is getting thinner the opposite seems to be happening with my nose and ear hair. Using small clippers have been less that useful. So for the first time ever I had the opportunity to try a nose/ear hair trimmer, the Phillips Norelco Nose Trimmer, model NT3355/60, and came away quite impressed. Very effective, easy to use. The straight slim edge effectively removes the offending hairs without a problem and the devise is very easy to use. Now I'm wondering why the heck I never used one of these devices before.Highly recommended.

As a range extender it works fine once you get it completely set up. Set up though is not as straight forward as I would like. While I've used range extenders in the past they seemed much easier to get up and running. This one is a bit frustrating.But the main issues, as with most range extenders, is the impact it has on your network. It slows it down. So while you may be able to have wireless access in areas of the house that were dead zones before, the speed of your online experience is negatively impacted. It's a trade off I guess.

First off I'm a huge Kansas fan, otherwise known as a Wheathead. I fell in love with their music the very first time I heard the album Song for America when it was first released. I have all their albums, many on both vinyl (from the 70/80's) and CDs. I just went to their concert in Anaheim California last week (3/18). Loved it. I can say without any doubt that they are my favorite music group, bar none. So please understand that I'm really having a hard time with this review.I received my advanced copy of "Kansas: Miracles Out of Nowhere" direct from the Kansas site. It was nice in that you could pre-order direct from the band's site and along with the standard set you also received a bonus DVD. I received the set on Monday 3/16. After watching it I came away underwhelmed and a little disappointed. I think this is a great documentary for those who know Kansas only for Carry on Wayward Son  and Dust in the Wind. For those people this would be an informative and interesting film about the early days of the band. For anyone who has followed the band for years there really isn't much new here. Oh occasionally there is a surprise anecdote that you may not have known, my favorite being the time they opened for Aerosmith and Steven Tyler went nutso. But for the most part the documentary plays out as more of a fluffy marketing piece than a down-&-dirty history of a great band.The film starts at the very beginning and progresses album by album through Point of Know Return. However here is where the film ends. I would have loved for it to continue through Monolith and Audio Visions because that was time that the band began to splinter amid their waning popularity. It would have been interesting to hear what happened during those days and each player's reactions but alas, no. I mean I understand omitting the Elefante years and beyond because the film is about the original lineup. I get that. But to paint this rosy picture but not include some of the dark elements is disappointing. As I said in the title, mostly fluff not enough stuff.The CD that is included again provides nothing new. If you have purchased their albums you'll have all the songs here in their original recordings except "Can I Tell You" which was recorded live for the Don Kirshner Rock Concert series. But it's also not new as it was included on the DVD in Sail On: The 30th Anniversary Collection 1974-2004. The CD does include dialog between the songs but they're just excerpts from the documentary.If you're a casual Kansas fan who knows them just through their hits then I would highly recommend this. I truly believe you'll be entertained and informed by it. If you're a Wheathead, by all means purchase it to round out your collection. Just don't expect to learn much of anything new.

I have been a fan of Kim Stanley Robinson since I read his first book The Wild Shore: Three Californias (Wild Shore Triptych) back in the mid-1980's. His stories have always been very character driven and usually with a strong plot. For whatever reason I had missed the release of 2312 and was just about to start it when I had the opportunity to read the advanced reading copy of Aurora. So needless to say I jumped at it. Is it one of KSR's best? No, not hardly. But overall it's an interesting and (eventually) engaging novel.The basic plot revolves around a group of interstellar settlers aboard a generations ship that has been traveling toward a new planet for about 200 years. This particular generation is destined to land and settle the new world if all goes according to plan, which of course it doesn't. The book offers many interesting twists along with great character development and of course the proverbial rebellion. I did find many wonderful surprises on where KSR takes us in his imagination. But also I found a number of plot twists that seemed to have been put in for convenience, or to resolve an unresolvable dilemma. The solution provided for the group returning to earth seemed a bit contrived to say the least.But overall I enjoyed the book. It wasn't one of those finish-in-one-sitting types but enjoyable and somewhat engaging. I went back-and-forth between rating this at three stars or four. I settled on four mostly because of the author's ability to develop characters to the point where you care about them. If you're a KSR fan I think you'll enjoy this. If you're a first time reader of the author I might suggest starting with some of his earlier and arguably better works, like the Mars trilogy or the aforementioned "The Wild Shore."

I have to say I'm very impressed with the so-called Iron Grip duct tape.  It is much stronger tape than your standard version plus it really has a very strong adhesiveness to it. Personally I would have been happy with a normal everyday product and thought the current price point for two rolls was a bit high. But based on the quality of the tape along with the larger than normal roll I would have to say the value is definitely there. Highly recommended.

I do like to cook but by no stretch of the imagination would I consider my self a chef. My knife skills are, shall we say, amateurish ("Daddy, why is there blood all over the counter?"). So when I got the chance to try this I just had to jump. I mean you see these type of things advertised all the time on TV but you question if it really works. This one is impressive.It slices, it dices, it chops. It makes life easier so I don't have to lug out the huge food processor for small jobs. Seriously I can't believe I waited this long to try something like this. The only issue I have is storage. It's relatively small so not all the separate parts will fit in it between uses. But that is something I can live with because of the ease it brings into my cooking life. Highly recommended.

I love Belkin products. I have yet to receive one that has not functioned exactly as described. I am so impressed that I recently ordered the Belkin Kindle Keyboard Case for Fire HDX 8.9 (will fit 3rd and 4th generation) for my new Fire 8.9 even though there were a few not so great reviews. I look forward to reviewing that as well.In this case, the Belkin Apple MFi Certified Car Charger with Lightning Cable is a perfect companion for when you are on the road. It is your standard car charger that my wife can use to charge her iPad while driving. The charger itself is separate from the connector allowing for versatility. High quality item to say the least.

I have to admit when I was first introduced to Pandora I was rather skeptical. However without a doubt it has become my go to app for music. To be able to build music lists from categories, names, styles, genres, or even song titles is just plain awesome. Even though you can't pick the songs that are played on your list you can help it evolve by giving thumbs-up or thumbs-down ratings. I realize that since Pandora has come out there is newer and more sophisticated music apps coming out but so far I keep coming back to Pandora. Personally I subscribe to Pandora One which has been $36 per year and allows you to listen to music non-stop without commercial interruption. Highly recommended.

OK, so my almost three year-old grandson who lives with us loves the show Mickey Mouse Clubhouse on Disney Junior. Not a great fan of Mickey Mouse in person when we go to Disneyland but loves the show. So the other set of grandparents bought this for him last week, exactly seven days before Christmas mind you, and gave it to him to bring over to our house. Grrrr. So I got to assemble this disaster. Yeah...thanks so much for the privilege.So I take everything out of the box and spread it out. One nice thing...all parts are accounted for. OK we're off to a good start. Unfortunately this is where good goes away for a sabbatical and frustration shows up in full war regalia. First the instructions are 99.9% pictures only. In fact the only "helpful" words on the set-up pamphlet is "NOT INCLUDED" (written in 15 languages I kid you not) with arrows pointing to the required batteries. The unit requires two AA and two AG13 batteries. OK, AA's I have but what the heck are AG13's and do I have them? Nah, they appear to be like hearing aid size. I'm sorry but at over $65 those non-standard types should be included. The grandson didn't understand and was not amused that the attached flashlight didn't work.The product is cheaply made. You have to be really careful or as your snapping things together you could break the cheap plastic. Fortunately that didn't happen but as a consequence of my being careful one of ears keeps falling off. On the bring side the kid started using it as a bowling ball. On the not-so-bright side the dog was not amused at being used as a bowling pin. She left the room in a huff. Other assembly issues: The slide falls off if you look at it wrong, the stickers don't stay stuck for very long, the one ear that opens so you can put one of the figures in only fits Pluto even though the picture clearly shows Minnie in it (the kid spent five minutes trying to fit Minnie in and almost decapitated her), I still have no idea how the flag that goes up on top actually attaches as the hole for it is WAY too big, and when folded up to store not all the pieces fit in. It's like Rubic's Cube where maybe there is only one combination that is correct except no matter how you put the pieces in there is always ONE piece left that if you put in the unit it will not snap shut. It's just begging for you to lose something.However I did give it two stars because the kid loves it. At least for now as he's only been playing with it for one day. We'll see how long that lasts. But seriously at this price I would pass on it. It is SO overpriced as to make a $10 burger at McDonald's seem reasonable. Stay away, stay far away.

Great all purpose cable with decent length. Can be used to charge anything that fits the micro B plug, which I have way too many things that covers. The product comes in multiple colors so you can choose between Blue, Green, Yellow, Pink, Red, Orange and Purple. I choose red as I'm a St. Louis Cardinal fan. However what I received was not what I would call red but more of a dark salmon. Hence the docking of one star. If you are going to call it red then please make it red.But other than that, works wonderfully. Recommended.

I was too young to watch this when it first ran but over the years I've become so addicted to the series whenever I could find it in reruns. For years I've been begging for the powers that be to release it on DVD and for whatever reason they just waited. In fact they probably waited too long as most of us fans are beginning to go senile and forget the old shows. But finally here it is. So far I've purchased Season One and look forward to adding Season Two soon.What made this show special was of course James Garner and Jack Kelly, Kelly being added to the cast after about six shows. But you also have to credit the writers with great scripts as well. The show covered the spectrum of western situations with both intensity and tongue-in-cheek humor. Although most episodes starred either Garner or Kelly alone there were also some that included both. When that happened the chemistry was just perfect.Seriously if you enjoyed the old TV westerns then you just have to have this in your collection. Great characters coupled with wonderful writing equals a great show. My only concern is starting with the release of Season Three the shows are on DVD-Rs which to me spell lesser quality. Plus the price has gotten a bit high as of this review. We'll see when I get there just how much I want to spend.

This is my first HDMI projector. Actually it's my first projector of any kind since the days of 8mm. When reading the manufacturer,s description on Amazon that of course just raved about it I remained a bit skeptical. I was concerned about easy set-up, whether I would need to invest in new equipment, and if the HD images would truly be HD. I need not worry as I came away very impressed.First off, it's an easy set up. I don't have a permanent spot I can put it so it's a roving unit that gets to be used in multiple rooms. The only equipment I will need to invest in is a 3D Blu-ray player, if I want to watch something in 3D of course. I could also invest in a screen but honestly I truly don't need one. I have light colored walls and the images are perfect even in the day time although at night without outside lite sneaking in it's tremendous. One other thing I was concerned about was whether the speakers would provide a rich and robust sound. They don't quite meet that level but they are more than adequate.I have to say that even at the price it's a great investment for your home theater. Without a doubt I highly recommend the unit for anyone looking for that robust entertainment environment.

Being an older gent I have a ton of old negatives from days gone by. Unlike my grown up children we didn't have that magical image creator called digital. So when I had the chance to order this unit with the promise of taking all those negatives and slides and turning them into digital images I was both excited and skeptical. There also were already a couple of reviews that gave me pause that talked about grainy images. But I figured what did I have to lose? So we gave it a try and I'm glad we did.A couple of things to note; The unit is VERY easy to use although it takes a few tries to get the hang of it. The images are not grainy but they are definitely not high definition either. Not that I was expecting that but I think maybe some of the detractors were? But overall it's a decent solution to digitizing your old photo's at a very reasonable price. Highly recommended.

We just got introduced to the Magic Bullet through my wife's work. She had been using it there and found it so simple and effective that we decided to purchase our own. It is simply amazing. So easy to use and so easy to clean. It comes with a recipe book that includes all sorts of goodies. For us we use it for morning smoothies. We use it with the Shaklee 180 Energizing Smoothie Mix (strawberry) by adding ice, milk, and half a fresh banana. Easy, quick, and delicious. Highly recommended.

We've lived in our current house for about 11 years We installed a small fountain almost immediately. The first pump we had (unknown name) lasted about six years. When we went to replace it we were told that particular model was discontinued and this one is the best to replace based on size and power. Five years later we just bought our third and probably last one of this new pump. Both the first two lasted just over two years and died. I've looked but have yet to find a different one that fits the small area our fountain has for the pump.It's not from lack of cleaning. We clean both the pump and fountain at least once a month. In case of high winds when dirt and tree leaves possibly can clog the area we'll clean more often as needed. This particular pump appears to just be made shoddy. If this also dies quickly we're probably going to turn the fountain into a planter.One thing to note, if you do plan on buying this, definitely buy it online. It averages about $25 online versus around $54 if you buy it locally.

I just discovered Firefly last year. I was bored and looking for something, anything on Netflix to entertain me. The Netflix description said something like the "short-lived but highly loved sci-fi series" so I thought I would give the first episode, "Serenity" a chance. I was immediately grabbed and was never let go of as I watched episode after episode. After finishing up the final show I immediately watched the full length feature film Serenity which attempted to tie up all the loose ends. Since then I've watched it enough times to finally invest in the DVD sets of both the series and the movie.What I liked most about the series is that it was true science fiction without the fantasy elements so many other series throw in there. No weird looking aliens, no magical modes of transportation ("beam me up Scotty"), no ridiculously miraculous medical cures. Just an old fashion character and plot driven series about humans 500 years in the future. The ensemble cast is wonderful and perfectly chosen. Nathan Fillion (best known now from the TV show "Castle") as Captain Malcolm Reynolds plays the pivotal role as the leader of a ragtag group of not-so-legitimate space freighters. But as you watch the shows you truly care about each and every character in the crew. They are so wonderfully developed, each with their own special quirks. From the deeply loyal first mate Zoe, to the mercenary Jayne, to the very young female ship's engineer Kaylee, to the flippant pilot "Wash", to the registered companion Inara, all have just wonderful personalities that play so well off of each other. When you add the three "passengers", the Shepherd (a religious missionary), to the young Doctor and his sister who are fugitives from the authorities, your crew is complete and the plot devices are all in place.While each episode can stand on it's own there are a couple of sub-plots that run through most, if not all, of the episodes that link everything together. The problem with Fox never standing behind the project is that many of those sub-plots will never be resolved. Yes, the subsequent film "Serenity" ties up a number of the main loose ends. However we'll never know the Shepherd's background that was hinted as being violent and completely opposite of what he currently was portrayed as. We'll never know what led him to abandon that life and enter the Abbey. Jayne's quote to the Shepherd in the episode Our Mrs. Reynolds perfectly says it: "Someday you're going to have to tell us how a preacher knows so much about crime." To me it's one of the greatest mysteries left unrevealed by the quick cancellation.If you're a fan of great Sci-Fi you have to have this. If you're already a fan of the series and have not purchase this, you need to do so. It has some great special features including deleted scenes that add even more dimension to the characters and their motivations, along with the typical making of the series mini-documentary, the proverbial gag-reel, and other features as well. A must have especially at the low price you can now buy it for.

I have a confession to make. I had never read a single Sherlock Holmes book or story by sir Arthur Conan Doyle. I personally find this amazing and somewhat shameful as I love the old-style mysteries. I'm a huge Rex Stout fan, having read and kept every Nero Wolfe book he ever wrote. Raymond Chandler is another mystery author I enjoyed. But for some reason I never read Holmes.This changed when I got the chance to order The Hound of the Baskervilles, A Study in Scarlet, The Sign of Four (Everyman's Library (Cloth)), three of the four Holmes full length novels in one wonderfully packaged hard covered book. I'm not sure why the fourth Holmes novel, The Valley of Fear, is not included as I don't think it would have made this book format excessively large but what do I know? As mentioned earlier it currently is hard cover with a solid binding and includes the old fashion cloth to mark your place. Very nice construction.Of the stories what could I say that hasn't been said before? They are wonderful. The first, A Study in Scarlett, gives a great introduction to Holmes and Watson with great early character development. It's fun to read the arrogance of Holmes as he not only solves the impossible cases but takes delight in making sure everyone is aware of his genius. The plots are extremely well thought out with a number of characters trotted out as possible suspects only to have the real perpetrator pop up as a surprise. It's one of the reasons I always loved the Nero Wolfe books. You don't know the guilty party until the end, yet when it's explained you can look back and see the clues that should have tipped you off. It's also one of the reasons I have a hard time getting into the new mysteries as many of the newer books I've read you can figure out the guilty person half way through the story. One of the exceptions is the Ruth Galloway mysteries by Elly Griffiths. As a mystery they are very good. However they have their own issue as the plots then to slip in-and-out of being soap opera-ish.I would recommend this to ANY mystery fan. Great who-done-it's in a wonderful hardcover package makes this a must have to mystery book collectors.

I received this last week and have tried using it a few times. I have been using the SKLZ Quick Change Resistance Band System. Compared to that product the Perfect Fitness Bands Pro with Tendon Tech lacks versatility. My first impression out of the box was that it was a little short. At 26 inches it's a little awkward to use if you're standing on an end and using it for curls, etc. The only way to increase resistance is to move your hands closer together which of course shortens up the usage area more. I can see this for someone who is just beginning to do a resistance based workout. But if you've been already doing resistance training then this is probably not very functional.A couple of good points; price wise it's pretty reasonable compared to other products like the SKLZ Quick Change Resistance Band System for example. It is also latex free which I know many people are looking for. For those points plus it being an OK unit for a beginner I gave it three stars. But overall it's just not workable for me. My two and a half year-old grandson seems to like it if that means anything.

I'm not a "Dirt Devil" fan. I've tried quite a few of the vacuuming units and have found them wanting. To be blunt, they've sucked and not in a good way. However I really needed something for our downstairs flooring that would do some real deep cleaning. When I had the opportunity to try this I figured to give it a chance. I came away quite impressed.First off, it's very light weight. Second, VERY easy to use. Third, very very effective. I had not realized how ineffective our daily mopping truly was. But this cleaned dirt up that I didn't even know existed. Since we have both a dog and a 2 year-old grandson living with us I am thrilled with this product. It gave me trust again in the Dirt Devil product line. Well, almost.Seriously, I highly recommend this if you're looking for a effective way to clean flooring. With the Holidays coming up this is just a great way to prep the house.

I truly love real science fiction. You know, the kind with little, if any, fantasy elements. Some of my favorite authors include Isaac Asimov, Frederik Pohl, Kim Stanley Robinson, & Gordon R. Dickson, to name a few. Lately it's really been hard to find good sci-fi and for some reason Peter F. Hamilton has flown under my radar. But I had the chance to read his latest, The Abyss Beyond Dreams: A Novel of the Commonwealth, and jumped at it.First off, I was at a huge disadvantage as the book is part of the Commonwealth series of which I know nothing about. There is a rather detailed timeline at the beginning of the book which helped a little. But the story starts with a group of spaceships lost in what is called the void and it's expected the reader already knows all about the void and the issues revolving around it. I didn't. Add to that, the first part of the book is really sterile. It's introducing some of the important characters and the trouble they're in, which is really necessary as it's a long book. But it's done in a pretty dry manner so it was hard to plod through until I got to some of the good stuff. I can definitely see new readers to the series putting it down forever.However, as you get deeper into the story more background information is integrated and I began to understand the back story and how it affected current events. It still had its sterile moments making the reading experience at times not so enjoyable. But overall I can say I enjoyed the book. It's just not where I should have started.I would definitely recommend this to anyone already into Hamilton and his Commonwealth/Void stories. For the reader just being introduced to the author I would strongly suggest starting with some of his earlier works. It may make this book eventually a more enjoyable read.

I ordered what is considered level one of Crazy A's and was very curious about what I would receive. The product description on the Amazon page states "Crazy A's (formerly called Whizizzle Phonics) is a fast-paced phonics game series that teaches the sounds of the English language." I was interested to see how it taught those sounds.What I received was a deck of cards. Period. Nothing else. No tape or CD or anything that a young child can listen to that lets them hear the sounds. There is nothing, repeat nothing, that teaches sounds or how to blend those sounds into words. Instead the parent has a three-step written guide where the only phonics instruction is a total of 26 words long. It's up to the parent playing with a young child to truly know what the correct sounds are and then teach them to the child BEFORE playing the game. The cards themselves are just three letter words (bat, rod, rib, etc) and the game itself is just a version of crazy 8's. If anything this so-called phonics game motivates a child to memorize the words more than sound them out.Unless you are purchasing this for a school-aged child who already knows the sounds and just needs practice, pass on this. At best it is a reinforcement tool, not a teaching device. Personally even at the low cost I'm not sure it's worth the price.

Honestly, I hate this machine. There are very few things to like about it and in my opinion it's just not functional compared to what I already have (Dyson, Hoover). In vacuuming it doesn't seem to have the ability to pick up deep down dirt. It's no where close in that area to either stand up vacuum I have. For cleaning drapery it's somewhat functional but not very user friendly and actually pretty awkward.The few things I like: It has an auto-retractable power cord. Just push the button with your toe and it sucks it right up. Probably the best sucking feature on the unit. I also like that the user has the ability to adjust the power of the unit, Oh yeah, and it looks pretty cool too.However the negatives far outweigh those couple of positives. Out of the box, I took an instant dislike to the so-called manual. It's nice that it's in multiple languages only I wish each language had it's own section. Instead each instruction alternates in language forcing you to read over 10 pages when two pages per language would have been perfect. Add to that the printing is ridiculously small. My tired old eyes needed both my reading glasses and VERY bright light to read the thing. It is a bag unit VS canister (which I knew going in so my bad). No matter what the product page says, for it's size it's not light weight and it is definitely not easily maneuverable. It's actually a pain in the proverbial rear to pull along.I really don't like posting one-star reviews but with the lack of pickup-ability for deep cleaning, the awkwardness of the unit, and the the continued cost of bags makes this a no-go for me. Although as I sit here thinking about it, it might be a decent unit to vacuum out your cars with. Long retractable extension cord and decent length of wand might make it a decent machine for that job. OK, what the heck, I'll bump it to two stars.

When I ordered this I half expected a functional yet no-so-impressive piece of cloth. Instead I received a beautiful tablecloth that to me is perfect for the Christmas Holiday season. The damask pattern adds a touch of elegance to the fabric and the rich color brightens up any semi-formal family and/or Holiday meal. I'm very impressed to say the least and quite happy with  the product.

I remember when this made-for-TV was hyped prior to airing. The commercials kept touting the return of the Maverik brothers. I so looked forward to watching it. Probably based on how much I looked forward to it I remember being totally disappointed. The plot was weak and full of holes. Yes James Garner was the highlight of the show and it was great to see him as Bret again. But Charles Frank, who was going to star in the series this pilot was filmed for never seemed to fit into the role. Add to that the "reunion" of Bret & Bart Maverik occurred when Bart (Jack Kelly) shows up with about 15 minutes left in the film.Overall I would pass on this unless you are a Bret Maverik freak and want everything that was ever filmed with James Garner in the role. If you're looking for a revival of the old 1957-1962 series you will be very disappointed.

Why do I keep starting a book series in the middle? Yes, some series' you can start in the middle and you get caught up pretty quickly. This was not one of them. By itself Harbor Island is a good, well written mystery with a lot of twists and turns. However there are brief references to previous books throughout that don't go into any real detail so you're left to ponder how they relate to current situations. The other problem with starting in the middle is you're not invested in the main characters and without strong and early character development it takes a while before you get into each person.As I said, it's a great mystery that almost can stand on it's own. But I would highly recommend starting at the beginning (Saint's Gate (Sharpe and Donovan)) although a prequel was written later (Rock Point: A Sharpe & Donovan Series prequel novella). Personally I haven't decided yet if I want to do that. But knowing what I know now that is the direction I would go.

While I can't say I've read most of Terry Brooks Shannara books I have read enough to see the author has become somewhat formulaic in his efforts. It's one of the reasons I rarely pick up a Brooks book anymore. But occasionally I do revisit the land of Shannara like I would visit an old friend. There is something comforting about being reintroduced to familiar territory even if the story is a little predictable.This tale takes place about a 100-plus years after the end of the Dark Legacy series, which to be honest I didn't read. Paxon Leah discovers he's magically inclined and better yet; he also has the long-lost magical "Sword of Leah". His sister has been kidnapped so it's up to Paxon to rescue her. The story is straight forward and interesting, though not what I would call intense. It's also interesting to note that this appears to be a stand-alone novel as opposed to the typical Brooks trilogy.Overall a nice but typical Brooks-Shannara book. I would recommend it to the die-hard Terry Brooks fan. But also for someone like me who has read enough of his books to understand the lay-of-the-land. It's probably not the right book if you have not been previously introduced to the Shannara realm.

I was first introduced to Mark Sava by reading The Colonel's Mistake (A Mark Sava Spy Novel), which was the first book in the series. What I liked about it was that it was not trying to be a "James Bond" imitation. The author created a very different character, one who is highly trained and effective but far from the typical fictional spy. In my opinion "SPY FOR HIRE" is the best of the three books to date. I can't wait for book four.Sava is a former CIA section chief now out on his own. While he still has connections in the agency they are not always happy to hear from him. It's obvious he has made some enemies within the CIA who would be happy to take him down. We now find him in Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan having been kicked out of his previous location of Baku, Azerbaijan. His live-in girlfriend, a former spy in her own right, has now started running a orphanage. A 2-year old child is dropped off at the site and then taken by force by two armed men. She contacts Sava who is able to rescue the child from the kidnappers. However this is only the beginning of the story that eventually drags Sava into butting heads with the CIA, Bahrain intelligence, the commander of the U.S. Naval station in  Bahrain, and the Bahrain  royal family. Before he can give up the child he feels he must find out the truth that makes him so special that members of the intelligence community are willing to destroy anyone in their way.The book is a page turner that is hard to put down. Adding to the depth of the plot, the story becomes very personal for Sava as events unfold that reveal his own past and what drove him to join the CIA in his youth. It is one of the many surprises in the book, in fact the biggest.I absolutely loved this book and am looking forward to the next installment. Highly recommended for anyone into realistic spy stories.

Recently I've been on the lookout for a nice effective foot massager that would be a good value.  Not a cheap, inexpensive one but a unit that does what it claims without being over priced. Not an easy task to say the least. I had the opportunity to try Ucomfy Acupressure Foot Massager and came away somewhat impressed.  It has a number of settings for heat and massage so it can be adjusted to preference.  However the unit is larger than expected and weighs about 15 pounds. The word that comes to mind is bulky.  Plus the price point in my opinion is a bit high considering the limited options it provides.Overall a good product but maybe less of a value.

I was quite skeptical of the claim that the Degree Adrenaline Anti-Perspirant would truly last 48 hours. However right after I received the product I ended up in the hospital.  Believe it or not i have to say it does last.  Another great point is the scent is not over powering which is one of the issues I have with many deodorant sticks. Overall I would say I'm impressed with the product.

I was really looking forward to using my new foot massager. The uComfy Shiatsu Foot Massager boasts heated air massage that kneads and vibrates. It sounded wonderful.  Unfortunately it was not nice, relaxing, or even enjoyable. It was rather painful. Since there are five settings I fully expected it to be a matter of preference based on setting. Not for me. Even the lowest setting was uncomfortable.I thought maybe it was just me so I had my wife and daughter try it out. To different degrees they both felt the same as I did. The experience was not very pleasant.  I'm impressed with the quality of the construction of the unit but we won't be using it. Disappointed to say the least.

The "iPad: The Missing Manual" is something that would have been nice to have when we got our first iPad.  It provides pretty decent instructions and information for the semi-uninformed. However it is not much of a resource for those with a solid grasp of all that the iPad can do.Overall not a bad resource but seriously only for those who need step by step instructions on how to get started in the iPad world. If you are pretty tech savvy this would probably be a waste of time and money.

The SKLZ Roller Sport Performance Self Guided Foam Roller is effective for its design. It has all types of exercises printed on the product with basic instructions which is great. Take it step by step and you really can't miss.However for the price it really is very cheaply made. A roll of foam covered with a glued on cover. Nothing more, nothing less. It will be interesting to see how it holds up to daily use.  I rated it at four stars because it does what it is designed to do. I may update in the future based on durability.

I purchased this as a bit of a gag-gift for my father who is a Cal-State Fullerton Titan fanatic. Considering with the exception of baseball the school's sports program is basically a division two (maybe even three) program attempting to play division one and not being very successful I have to commend him for being a true fan. So in perusing the internet for something unique I stumbled on this unit. As stated in the title the head does not bobble from the body, the body bobbles from the stand. Not a big deal and actually kind of cool. The product is well made and reasonably priced.In checking out other Wacky Wobbler items I was surprised how many licensed items they have, including Funko Wacky Wobbler Edward Scissorhands Bobble Head, DC Universe Mini Wacky Wobbler Bobblehead 4 Pack Superman, Batman, Joker, Green Lantern, Funko The Muppets: Fozzie Bear Wacky Wobbler, Funko Big Bang Theory: Sheldon Talking Wacky Wobbler, and even a Funko Anchorman: Talking Ron Burgundy Wacky Wobbler. Highly impressive array of product.

I wasn't expecting much when I ordered this as I was expecting a basic speaker with Bluetooth capability. I was getting it more for convenience so as long as it provided decent sound I would have been happy. However the Turtle Shell 2.0 exceeded all expectations tremendously. It really is hard to express how impressed I am with this device.Once charged (approximately 12 hours) it connects easily to any Bluetooth capable device. Once connected I started playing different types of music, from rock to jazz to classical, etc. I was blown away with the sound quality. It's one thing for a speaker to be able to play loud music without distortion but the Turtle Shell also excels on soft orchestral pieces as well. While not Bose-like quality it still has great clarity of sound. The range is promoted at 32 feet which may be pushing it just a bit. It comes close as long as there is a clear signal path. If you have a wall or two between the speakers and your Bluetooth device it drops to about 10 feet at best.Overall I would highly recommend this as a transportable speaker with wonderful sound. Great for the beach or just about anywhere you want to listen to your music library. Highly impressive.

For the first time in my life I chose jewelry off the internet. The picture truly shows the beauty of the piece and honestly the Sterling Silver Black and White Diamond Halo Pendant Necklace is gorgeous in person as well. At the current price it is also a nice value.However I do have one issue with it. It is small, very very small. I obviously knew that from the dimensions listed on the Amazon page (height 0.57 inches, width 0.31 inches) but I felt the pendent could carry that size off well. It really doesn't. Up close it is a beautiful piece. From a distance of just a foot or two you really lose how intricate the pattern is. Now mind you I'm not a jewelry expert. But in my opinion a small pendent should be able to be appreciated by someone you're having a conversation with. That is really not the case here.Overall for the price it's a nice piece of jewelry, one that will coordinate with a lot. I can see it being a nice gift for a casual friend. But it is so understated that to call it understated would be an understatement.

Being a repeat traveler on international I decided the "carry on" that I had wasn't the best selection so going to various stores and trying many spinners/rollers I decided on this model.  The pluses that made this model the model of choice were several - among these1. this carry- on rolled much smoother than other models tested and sailed through cornering and even backing up - it is a no effort roller and in this regard earns a full 5 stars with the next nearest competitor earning only 3.5 stars for not doing well on corners2. the telescoping handle is a bit longer than most of the other models/makers tested - being tall this was the only carry-on of this size that didn't leave me feeling as though I was having to walk leaning over while using the suitcase3. the design is compact but at the same time provides sufficient room for an experienced traveler that is only going to be packing what is truly needed in a carryon suitcase4. price - the price of this model was about mid-point of the suitcases inspected with eye to purchase - least expensive was 69.99 while top price was 129.99 -- this model at the 80.00- 90.00 price point performed better in the various tests used in the store to determine which model to purchase.Each of the models tested were tested for rolling ease both forward as well as backwards also tested doing corners and ease of picking up the unit as if going onto a bus or train.

This reviewer has used other generic cartridges previously without any problems at all - these generic remanufactured cartridges had several problems.1) printer at first did not want to recognize the ink was in - this can be by-passed by pressing the print button on the actual printer and after that first print the printer would print from the computer.2) as can be seen by image the color cartridge is actually 3 separate cartridges - with the previously used generic cartridges the colors blended correctly so what was red on the screen was red on the paper.  These cartridges do not seem to be able to blend the colors in the printing process -- instead of getting accurate colors the print job comes out with yellows and blues whereas the original image was neither yellow nor blue.In this reviewer's opinion if you are looking for color refills this product is a pass - the black seem to work better but are a bit lighter black than previous cartridges used

This travel guide has one advantage over many of the other travel guides on the market and that being that with the right mobile device maps and websites can be accessed directly from the guide.This reviewer has made several trips to London and found the guide while having some useful information also tended to be geared more for the first time traveler - providing information on such things as the various airports and transportation options for getting from the airport to London.  Again for the first time traveler there is somewhat useful information on the various modes of transportation offered while in London itself.  Covered in this section are oyster cards for the tube systems, as well as other options such as bus and taxi serviceThe first half of the book covers various hotels and the various airports that serve London unfortunately the reader is into the second half of the book before actually getting to information about London -- this was a negative for this reviewer especially with the extensive "here are the best hotels" section.  Better and more up to date information can be found on travel sites.A first time visitor I would give the book a 4 out of 5 stars with only real reservation being the somewhat awkward layout of the book.  A returning visitor to London I would give this book a 2 out of 5 - if you have the right mobile device it can be handy with the various maps and links to websites to check opening times and such.

This book is an improvement on the two volumes which immediately proceeded this release but, there are several weaknesses that keep this book from being the brilliant storytelling of the early Mrs. Murphy and Tucker escapades.  In the earlier works Rita Mae Brown gave the reader the experience of "being there" in the story.  Mrs. Murphy, Tucker, and all the other animals seemed so lifelike as to almost expect a bark or meow.
