She’s got her head screwed on straight, from my perspective: “When I think of immorality,” she writes, “I think of the payday loans and hidden bank fees, the failure to pay a living wage, the preference for crappy schools in poor neighborhoods. I don’t think about sex.”

Hugh Howey debuted with a big splash as a science fiction writer with the publication of Wool. This three-part dystopian novel (really, a novella plus two full-length books) tells the tale of the Silo, an underground city of several thousand future Americans that descends through 144 stories into the earth. Shift — the three books that together constitute the prequel to Wool — carries readers from the mid-21st century for several hundred years until its central character is about to cross paths with the principal actor in the future world portrayed in Wool. Along the way readers learn the grim explanation for the origin of the Silo.The tale begins in 2049. Donald Keene is a freshman Congressman elected from Georgia with the help of “the great Senator Thurman.” As a freshman, he finds himself at loose ends as he casts about for meaningful work when the Senator recruits him for a top-secret job that engages his background as an architect. We soon learn that Keene, now happily married, was once engaged to the Senator’s daughter. Predictably, this inconvenient fact will complicate the story and loom large down the line. But the complications emerge slowly, building suspense all the while.Shift is dystopian fiction with a twist — several twists, really. Its strength lies in Howey’s cleverly imagined underground world. The writing style is unexciting, the characters not fully fleshed out. But the world of the Silo, and the backstory in this prequel, are bound to fascinate any fan of science fiction. After nearly a century and a half of SF, it’s tough to come up with something new. The world of the Silo is new.

A few very clever people can turn a simple truth into a career. Sam Horn is one of them. Walking the well-worn path trod by Dale Carnegie (How to Win Friends and Influence People), Horn — who is a she, by the way — has crafted a useful little handbook for anyone in the business of communication. Got Your Attention? is a user-friendly, latter-day updating of Carnegie’s 1936 classic. It’s more in tune with today’s impatient strivers. And the world would be a whole lot better place if everyone read this book and heeded Horn’s call to listen more and talk less.In the field of fundraising — my specialty for three decades — it’s often said, “If you want advice, ask for money. If you want money, ask for advice.” Although she never touches on this particular point, Horn makes this lesson clear enough in her clever little handbook.Sam Horn loves mnemonic devices. The word “intrigue” in the subtitle is an acronym that sums up the contents of the book:I: “Craft an INTRO that has people at hello.”N: “Create the next NEW thing.”T: “Win trust by being TIME-EFFICIENT.”R: “If they can’t REPEAT it, they didn’t get it.”I: “Don’t just inform, INTERACT.”G: “GIVE attention first.”U: “If it isn’t actionable, it isn’t USEFUL.”E: “Don’t tell stories, share real-life EXAMPLES.”There’s a great deal of wisdom in all this advice, and it’s all presented in snappy, conversational style. Several other acronyms appear in the book — perhaps a few too many. However, as the author states at the outset, “there are ways to overcome people’s impatience, alienation, and chronic distraction, and this book teaches them.” Amen.Sam Horn, who bills herself as “the Intrigue Expert,” has written nine other books on the art of effective communication (although I don’t recall coming across that word in this book!). Got Your Attention? is a worthy addition to the narrow shelf of personal development books that are actually worth the paper they’re printed on.

Literary awards can be a poor guide to enjoyable reading. Britain’s Man Booker Award-winners, for example, strike me as a mixed bag at best. Generally, though, a book that wins a Pulitzer and is a finalist for a National Book Award deserves more than a casual look. That’s certainly the case with All the Light We Cannot See, an historical novel long at or near the top of the national best-seller lists, winner of the 2015 Pulitzer Prize for Fiction.Here is a wildly original boy-meets-girl story. Two teenagers are caught up in the frenzy and the mortal dangers of World War II: a German boy who is extraordinarily clever with all things electronic, and a blind French girl who reads Jules Verne. Author Anthony Doerr explores the trajectory of their lives in parallel, moving them inexorably toward a fateful intersection in the book’s surprising climax. Like millions of other Europeans, Marie-Laure LeBlanc and Werner Pfennig are victims of the war, but their stories are fresh: these are uniquely drawn individuals, each masterfully portrayed by a writer at the top of his form.The action in All the Light We Cannot See takes place late in the war, two months after D-Day (June 6, 1944), with the Allies poised to turn back the German lines on all fronts. Marie-Laure is hiding out with her father and great-uncle in Saint-Malo, a coastal town near the Normandy beachhead. Werner has been pressed into service in the German army and (inevitably) is transferred to the town as the Nazis rush to reinforce their defenses in northern France.However, it is the backstory Doerr tells of each of these remarkable young people that forms the backbone of the novel: how Marie-Laure lost her sight early in life and came to live with her doting father in Paris and later in Saint-Malo; how Werner demonstrated genius with electronics as a child and was later maneuvered into making a major contribution to the German war effort. These are full-bodied stories, rich with complexity, detail, and suspense.All the Light We Cannot See is Doerr’s second novel. He has also written two volumes of short stories and a memoir.

Alternate history is a curious branch of science fiction — or, perhaps more properly, of speculative fiction. Because the factor that limits the author’s imagination aren’t the boundaries of science but those of history itself: reality. To work, alternate history must be believable in the context of what we know of our past. In Ha’penny, the second volume of her Farthing Trilogy, accomplished British science fiction and fantasy writer Jo Walton has achieved that, and more. She has written a gripping, suspenseful novel that illuminates the past with her artful imagination.In Farthing (reviewed here) the first book of the trilogy, Nazi Germany and England had signed a peace treaty in 1941, leaving Hitler dominant on the Continent — before the seminal events that drew the US and the USSR into the war. The “Farthing Set,” the group of right-wing aristocrats credited with ending the war, is poised on the brink of power eight years later. Farthing — combining alternate fiction with a murder mystery — tells the story of the violence that facilitated their ascent to power.How could this have happened in the seat of democracy? It’s not so far-fetched. “England is like a country of sleepwalkers, walking over the edge of a cliff,” Walton writes, “and has been these last eight years. You’re prosperous, you’re content, and you don’t care what’s going on the other side of the Channel as long as you can keep on having boat races and horse shows and coming up to London to see a show . . .” Is this description so far from today’s reality, when the Conservative Party, which has stubbornly kept Britain in recession for five years, has just been returned to office with its biggest victory in thirty years?Ha’penny picks up the story shortly after the Farthing Set has settled into 10 Downing Street. The scene shifts from the country home in the village of Farthing where the first book was set to London’s theater district. There, Viola Lark, one of the six notorious Larkin sisters, has achieved stardom on the stage and is set to begin production of a production of Hamlet, with herself in the title role in the theatrical fashion of the age. Viola cares only about the theater. She’s less than indifferent to politics. But the novel tells the fascinating tale of her gradual immersion in a plot to put an end to the fascist Farthing regime that has recently risen to power.At the center of the story are the aristocratic Larkin sisters. They’re closely modeled on the real-life Mitford sisters, whose divergent paths through life in the 1930s, 40s, and beyond kept the English people variously entertained and enraged. The noted journalist and author Ben McIntyre describes them as “Diana the Fascist, Jessica the Communist, Unity the Hitler-lover; Nancy the Novelist; Deborah the Duchess and Pamela the unobtrusive poultry connoisseur.” In truth, two of the sisters (Diana and Unity) were close to Hitler; Diana married Sir Oswald Mosley, the head of the British fascist party. Nancy and Jessica, both accomplished writers (Jessica wrote the widely acclaimed The American Way of Death pillorying the funeral industry), were also both left-leaning. Jessica, who moved to the US early in life, was a member of the American Communist Party until 1958. [I’m proud to say that I knew Jessica Mitford — she was better known as Decca — for a few years in the 1970s. She had long since settled in Berkeley with her second husband, a leftist attorney. Decca was a brilliant social critic with a wicked, non-stop sense of humor.] With such stranger-than-fiction models for her characters, Jo Walton could hardly be faulted for a too-vivid imagination in writing Ha-penny.Jo Walton has written a total of eleven novels, one of which, a fantasy titled Among Others, won the Hugo and Nebula awards for best novel in 2011 and 2012. Farthing, Ha’penny, and Half a Crown form the Farthing Trilogy. They were published in 2006-2008.

It's unlikely that a general reader would pick up a book on economic history, and this one -- with a bland main title and not one but two off-putting subtitles -- would appear to be a work that only an economist could love. It's not. The dramatic interplay of personalities that Ed Conway brings to light in The Summit is entertaining enough to please any devotee of serious historical fiction.At its core, The Summit relates the stormy relationship between two towering personalities, John Maynard Keynes and Harry Dexter White. Representing the UK, Keynes was the world's most famous economist and a certified celebrity to boot. He is still widely regarded as the most important economist of the 20th Century. White, little known to the public before Bretton Woods and not much more so afterwards, was his counterpart heading up the US delegation on behalf of the Treasury. Together, these two men managed against all odds to put in place the world's first global economic system in the waning days of World War II -- a system whose surviving remnants include the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. The mechanisms negotiated at the Bretton Woods Conference in New Hampshire in 1944 never truly worked as Keynes and White intended, but they did help accomplish the overarching goal of the conference: to maintain world economic stability up until Richard Nixon upended the system in 1973 by taking the US off the gold standard.The details of these events, and of the tense negotiations that led up to them, are to be found in abundance in The Summit. Far more engaging, though -- and no doubt more memorable -- are the portraits Conway paints of Keynes and White. If you think people are necessarily boring if they study economics, you should read this book. It would be difficult to dream up two more fascinating people.John Maynard Keynes was, by all accounts (including his own), a genius. Fresh out of the Versailles Peace Conference that ended World War I, his bestselling book The Economic Consequences of the Peace foresaw with rare prescience the economic turbulence of the 1920s and 30s and the likelihood of a second war. His General Theory of Employment, Interest, and Money, published in 1936, is often compared to Adam Smith's The Wealth of Nations as one of the most consequential books of modern times.But these accomplishments, and many more, were only part of Keynes' story. Friends and foes alike considered him crude, rude, arrogant, overbearing, and disdainful of practically everyone else except his long-suffering celebrity wife, the former prima ballerina of Ballets Russes. For example, on several occasions, when he was dispatched by the British government to negotiate with the US, he so thoroughly alienated his counterparts that, had he not been accompanied by more temperate members of his delegation, he might have torpedoed the US-UK alliance.Harry Dexter White, unknown by comparison, was brilliant, too. He was also almost equally capable of alienating those he worked with. He, and to be fair his progressive policies, made sworn enemies within the State Department, which frequently complicated and sometimes undermined international negotiations. He was also a Soviet spy. Though not a Communist, he shared the prevailing view within the American Left from the 1930s through the end of World War II that the USSR was advancing the interests of humanity. However, unlike most other progressives, White found his way into the arms of the NKVD (predecessor to the KGB and today's FSB). Over the years, he handed over reams of sensitive documents to his handler in the Soviet Embassy -- though, reportedly, nothing top secret. Following World War II, White was caught up in the Red Scare sweeping the country and driven from his government job.It was inevitable that these two personalities would clash -- the hard-driving son of poor Jewish immigrants and the Cambridge-educated son of an esteemed economics professor and a social reformer.Ed Conway, a journalist, is the Economics Editor of Sky News, the 24-hour TV news service in the UK controlled by Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation. The Summit is Conway's second book.

The brooding landscape pictured on the cover of this off-beat detective novel sets the stage for the complex tale within, suggesting the depth of the multidimensional characters whose lives today intersect around a tragic event half a century ago.Fin McLeod has returned again to the Isle of Lewis, the northernmost of the Outer Hebrides Islands off the northwestern coast of Scotland. In The Blackhouse, the first novel in the Lewis Trilogy, McLeod had returned from Edinburgh to the site of his childhood to assist the local police in investigating the murder of a man he had known as a schoolchild. Now, he has just left his marriage and his job as a detective in the capital to return to Lewis, perhaps to stay. McLeod is a troubled soul, tortured by the recent loss of his eight-year-old son to a hit-and-run driver and the failure of his marriage.No sooner has McLeod arrived on the island than a body turns up in the peat, obviously murdered some decades in the past. True to his nature, McLeod soon finds himself assisting, and then leading, the long, convoluted trail to the truth of the victim’s identity and the circumstances of his death. As the investigation moves forward, it becomes clear that those closest to him — his former lover, the son he fathered with her, his best friend from schooldays — are somehow involved in the tale.Although The Lewis Man is a detective novel, a murder mystery, and a good one, it’s equally a portrait of a “wind-ravaged corner of the earth where warring factions of an unforgiving Protestant religion dominated life. Where men and women struggled all their lives to make a living from the island, or the sea, turning in times of unemployment to the industries that came, and went again when subsidies ran out, leaving the rusting detritus of failure in their wake.”

Welcome to “Night Soldiers,” the brilliant series by one of our most accomplished writers of espionage novels.Meet Nicholas Morath, 44, is an aristocratic Hungarian living in Paris, where he is a partner in an advertising firm. His uncle, Count Janos Polanyi, is a senior diplomat in the Hungarian mission to France who is engaged in organizing the resistance to Hitler in Eastern Europe. World War II hasn’t yet started in earnest — Germany’s Anschluss with Austria is still weeks away, and the occupation of the Czech Sudetenland on the distant horizon — but Polanyi sees the future with clarity. He presses his nephew into taking on a dangerous mission in Budapest . . . and the trouble begins.Morath, known as Nicky to Cara, his young Argentine lover, is one of those world-weary Europeans who surely abounded on the Continent during the fateful years of the 1930s. “He was doomed to live with a certain heaviness of soul, not despair, but the tiresome weight of pushing back against it. It had cost him a wife, long ago, an engagement that never quite led to marriage, and had ended more than one affair since then.” As war approaches, Morath’s already complicated life becomes ever more challenging. His work for his uncle exposes him to grave danger. The stakes grow as the months go by. And the suspense increases apace.Kingdom of Shadows is the sixth of the thirteen novels in Alan Furst’s “Night Soldiers” series. Each of these finely crafted stories features its own protagonist, typically a man in early middle age engaged in (or about to become engaged in) a love affair who is reluctantly drawn into a role in espionage. The setting shifts from the Balkans to Iberia and Paris to Warsaw, but the cast of characters often overlaps. In this manner, Furst has created a finely textured portrait of Europe before and during World War II.For reviews of some of Furst’s other historical espionage novels, go to Spies of the Balkans, Red Gold, Midnight in Europe, and Mission to Paris.

Imagine that you live in a town of about 115,000 people. Berkeley, California, say. With only rumors and rumblings in the news media to warn you, an edict comes down from the Federal government that all the Muslims in town must be “relocated” to camps monitored by the US Army. Why? Because, supposedly, the threat of terrorism is so great, and the behavior of many Muslims so troubling, that they must be removed from their homes and placed in detention for the duration of the War on Terror.Couldn’t happen here? Well, it did.On April 21, 1942, the front-page story in the Oakland Tribune was headlined, “‘Japs Given Evacuation Orders Here.’ The article reported, ‘Moving swiftly, without any advance notice, The Western Defense Command today ordered Berkeley’s estimated 1,319 Japanese, aliens and citizens alike, to be evacuated to the Tanforan Assembly Center by noon, May 1.” These Berkeley residents were among a total of about 120,000 Japanese Americans who were interned, two-thirds of them United States citizens — including the adopted Japanese children of Caucasian parents.No doubt you’re aware that, not long after Pearl Harbor, President Franklin D. Roosevelt ordered the removal of all American Japanese from a broad swath of California, Oregon, and Washington bordering the Pacific and moved them into what even many at the time called “concentration camps.” However, chances are you don’t know the half of it. I certainly didn’t.In Infamy, Richard Reeves brings the full story to light for the first time, working from one-on-one interviews, unclassified files, records of legislative hearings, and published sources to put a human face on this shameful episode in American history. His accounts of the families who lost everything, the children who grew up bitter, and the courageous soldiers of the all-Nisei 442nd Regimental Combat Team are profoundly moving.Today, many are aware that “the 442″ was the most decorated unit in the history of the US Army and famously rescued the so-called Lost Battalion trapped behind German lines, losing as many as nine out of ten of its own men in some units to bring the surviving Texas National Guard members to safety. However, “[f]or most of the American reporters, the rescued not the rescuers, white men not Nisei, were the focus of the story.” The New York Times ran the headline “‘Doughboys Break German Ring to Free 270 Trapped Eight Days.’ The article did not mention that the ‘doughboys’ were Japanese Americans.”FDR didn’t act alone in setting all this in motion. Far from it. Reeves unmasks the powerful people who lobbied and spoke out for the evacuation. My jaw dropped as I tallied the list: Earl Warren, then Attorney General, later Governor of California and Chief Justice of the US Supreme Court. Edward R. Murrow and other prominent broadcasters. Secretary of War Henry Stimson. Artist and writer Theodor Seuss Geisel (Dr. Seuss). Walter Lippmann and other, less influential but then-famous newspaper columnists. Assistant Secretary of War John J. McCloy (“‘The Constitution is just a scrap of paper to me'”), later president of the World Bank, chairman of the Council on Foreign Relations, and member of the Warren Commission. Plus every member of the Congressional delegations from California, Oregon, and Washington.Warren, McCloy, and Lippman appear to have been the most influential in channeling into terms that could persuade the President the upwelling of vicious racism triggered by the attack on Pearl Harbor and early Japanese victories in the Pacific. (However, FDR himself was by no means immune to racism, as indicated by his decisions that adversely affected African-Americans and Jews.) Most of the nation’s newspapers — even the allegedly liberal New York Times — editorialized in favor of the evacuation. Within the Army, which managed the evacuation, the driving force was an ignorant and deeply prejudiced general named DeWitt and his top aide, a pathological liar named Bendetsen.Why did they do this?  Those who championed the evacuation argued that “[t]he Pacific Coast is in imminent danger of a combined attack from within and without.” But economic motives figured in as well: the evacuees were forced to sell their homes, their farms, and their businesses for a pittance to their neighbors or other profiteers, who benefited hugely from the opportunity their government had given them.There was dissent, but not much of it at first. The Navy objected because they knew perfectly well that the threat of invasion was an absurd fantasy; there was a single Japanese submarine off the Coast of California. Eleanor Roosevelt spoke out in her newspaper column. J. Edgar Hoover didn’t like the idea because he had already arrested everyone the FBI had tagged as potential spies and saboteurs starting the day after Pearl Harbor, and he wanted the credit; of course, Hoover’s idea of a “Suspect Enemy Alien” was wildly distorted. In the upper reaches of the Administration, only the Attorney General, Francis Biddle, spoke out forcefully and repeatedly in opposition — at Cabinet meetings and in letters to the President.In 1943, a year after the evacuation, some of its erstwhile backers realized they had made a huge mistake. Despite continued opposition from the Army, regulations were steadily relaxed at most of the camps, with 4,300 young Japanese-Americans released to attend those colleges that were willing to take them and 4,000 more were recruited into the Army to form the 442. (Those 4,000 men “had to be replaced nearly 2.5 times. In total, about 14,000 men served, earning 9,486 Purple Hearts.”) Meanwhile, Lt. General DeWitt and Colonel Bendetsen were quietly relieved of their duties and promoted. The general even received a fourth star.Roosevelt charged McCloy and Stimson with drawing up the evacuation order with great care to avoid giving the impression that the action was racist. Naturally, that’s exactly what it was. There were no concentration camps for German and Italian immigrants on the East Coast.Reeves documents in abundant detail the hysterical wave of racism that swept through the West — in newspaper editorials, speeches by public officials, confrontations between whites and Japanese-Americans, and in the occasional violence directed at individual families.Infamy fills a void in documenting a vital example of the racism that has scarred American history from the time the Pilgrims landed until the present day. The evacuation of American Japanese in World War II paled against slavery or the genocidal war against Native Americans. However, if the shameful treatment of immigrants over throughout our history — Irish, Germans, Italians, Jews, Chinese, and others — were to be ranked in order of severity, the incarceration of more than one hundred thousand Japanese-Americans would top the list. And after the war, thousands of the internees were deported to Japan!

Dystopian fiction seeks to illuminate the consequences of the bad choices we make today. Goodhouse follows in this tradition by extrapolating into the late 21st Century the intersection of two of America’s most troublesome present-day realities: our counterproductive criminal justice system, which does a great job training young people for lives of crime, and the hubris of a scientific community that seeks to predict human behavior by reading our DNA. As author Peyton Marshall reveals in the Acknowledgments, the “Goodhouse” where most of the action takes place in her novel is modeled on the notorious Preston Youth Correctional Facility, a juvenile rehabilitation center closed by the State of California only in 2011.In Peyton Marshall’s dark-hued future America, the country is engaged in an endless war overseas while on the brink of civil war at home. On one side are the officials who maintain the nationwide network of Goodhouses, where young men tagged as having criminal tendencies are raised from an early age in draconian conditions sure to bring out the worst in them. (“There was no Goodhouse equivalent for girls. The same markers in women were not predictive of criminal behavior . . .”) On the other side are the revolutionary Zeros, who stage massive attacks to annihilate the Goodhouses and all those who live within them because “[t]hey wanted to purify, to cleanse. They didn’t believe in reforming us.”The novel tells the story of “James Goodhouse” — his birth name and origins have been suppressed, like those of all his thousands of fellows — and the trajectory he follows from the equivalent of a low-security youth facility where he was a model citizen to what can only be described as a prison. The Goodhouse shelters a totalitarian mini-society where James is physically and psychologically abused by the former inmates now in positions of power over him.When James is given a rare opportunity to leave the Goodhouse for a day, he meets Bethany, a gravely ill young woman who lives with her mother outside the walls in a home that represents an idyllic world for him. Their awkward relationship unfolds as James is increasingly dehumanized by the Goodhouse staff, and the violent clash between the system and the Zeros gathers force.Goodhouse works — as a cautionary tale, a novel of suspense, and a compelling read.

Here is a potentially terrific novel, a police procedural with consummately clever plotting and believable characters, where the reading experience was spoiled for me by the most trivial of writer’s errors: the failure to employ a proofreader!Admittedly, the story is intriguing and suspenseful. Detectives in two different Brooklyn police precincts are simultaneously pursuing three different cases, each very different from the others. As their investigations move forward, the connections among these seemingly unconnected events begin to emerge. Of course, that’s not surprising. Any seasoned reader of detective fiction knows to expect that. What’s surprising is how these disparate storylines are shown to merge into a fascinating whole.Now back to the spoiler.When I was a kid, my mother, a former English teacher, constantly complained about the spelling of “this new generation.” The culprit, as she saw it, was the phonetic approach to reading then in vogue. NOBODY under the age of 25 could spell, she insisted.Well, here we are again. I have no way of knowing whether D. James Eldon learned to spell because he was taught reading by the phonetic method, or whether he suffers from some sort of spelling disability, but I can say this: I have never, ever before understood clearly the value of proofreading.All the Way Gone is riddled with boneheaded misspellings. Throughout the book, Eldon uses “you’re” when he means “your” and “it’s” instead of “its.” He substitutes “loosing” for “losing,” “boarder” for “border,” “coarse” for “course,” “quite” for “quiet” — and those are only the errors I caught on the run. Undoubtedly, I missed a number of others. Where was the proofreader when we needed her?FYI, Mr. Eldon, spellcheck doesn’t cut it in cases like this. (For the record, they’re called “homonyms” — words that sound alike but have different meanings.) Please get a proofreader if you write another book!

Cast iron skillet pans are my preferred browning, oven bake & sauté pans.  I have also purchased & reviewed the skillet pan (Utopia Kitchen Pre-Seasoned Cast-Iron Skillet, 10.25 inch but the dutch oven is a specialty pan that definitely gets use around here.Dutch ovens are great for :*  any dish that you want to start on the stove & then move to the oven.  The cast iron gives you even heat distribution for browning, and is completely oven proof for finishing.*  Perfect to braise some onions & vegetables, then brown your chicken & cover & cook on stove - YUMMM!*  Oven casseroles - covered or uncovered - save the cost of the foil!Why is cast iron so great?*  Even Heat: Cast iron is heavy & because of that, the heat is retained and distributed throughout the pan, including the sides of the pan*  Stove to oven - you can start a dish on the stove, then finish it in the oven*  Exercise & cook at the same time: Remember that part about weight? Yep - they are heavierWhy I like this pan:*  Grip handles on both sides - the weight of the pan makes them harder to handle one-handed*  Pre-seasoned - I was able to cook on it the day I got it*  Lid- Also fits the skillet I bought from them. ((Utopia Kitchen Pre-Seasoned Cast-Iron Skillet, 10.25 inch)*  Fit & finish - good weight to the pan - nice finish. It has that slightly sand-cast feel common to cast ironCare of your pan:Wash with hot water & a rag. If you must, use baking soda but not soap. Dry & wipe the pan with oil (use a paper towel or pastry brush). Put on the warm stove. I do this right after cooking & the residual heat from the stove slightly warms the pan. Sounds complicated but it takes seconds. The reward is a pan that is nonstick & will brown like no other.I purchased this pan at a reduced price in exchange for writing about my actual experiences with this pan. It is the equal of my other cast iron, with a few extra features (2 handles, lid). It is a great value - and makes it easy to do those braised dishes & crusty potato casseroles.

2:11 Mins We like to drink different wines on different days, and often open more than one bottle depending on the preferences of the wine drinkers that day.  This preserver lets you open those bottles guilt free, because you can keep them fresh until used up.  The idea is simple - air is not the friend of your wine, because air will oxidize your wine & change the flavor.  This pump pumps the air out of the bottle, drawing a vacuum over the wine.  This slows oxidation.The process is simple, as I show in my video.* Wet the special plug* Insert into wine bottle* Place pump on top of plug (they mate together) and pump.  Pump until it becomes hard to pump.  You will feel it.  8 pumps pulled the vacuum on a fairly empty bottle.* To drink the wine, press the button on the top of the plug to release the pressure.  Remove the plug & enjoy.They include 2 plugs & the pump - great to keep a red and white going at all times.  This is a great gift idea - or really great to buy for yourself.  I purchased this wine pump at a discounted price in exchange for writing up my actual experiences with this product.  We are using and enjoying it every night. LOVE things that are fun and functional too! Hope this helps you with your buying decision.

I love to buy  coffee from local and small batch roasters.  When I travel, you will always find coffee in my luggage from the local roaster I have visited.  But what to do when I haven’t seen some new roaster for a while?  Enter Coffee Crazy.  I could not resist the opportunity to purchase  this French Roast at a discount in exchange for writing up my actual experiences with it.  After all – we are coffee crazy in this house – so coffeecrazy coffee should suit us just right.When we opened the bag – the first whiff was heavenly.  It is dark roasted, but did not have that burnt overtone that some dark roasts have.  This coffee smells sooo good you almost want to have the beans sitting right next to you all day – but then I would drink too much coffee.  This is a dark and bold roast – a perfect complement for milk  (my choice), but my husband goes for it straight.I really like being able to support Fair Trade practices – I like drinking my coffee knowing that someone is making a sustainable living delivering it to me.  Organic is also important, since it reduces chemical exposure to me and to the framers that produce the coffee.  I’ve been to the rainforest – I know that there are ways to farm without destroying the eco-system, and I like to be part of that – while sipping some amazing coffee.  ♥♥♥♥♥ Definite recommend!!!

Great for that extra stretch for Yoga.  These are nice thick bands - good weight & good resistance.  I have been having fun using these to get that extra stretch in my Yoga workout & for runner stretches.  I loop it around my foot and use it to deepen my stretches.  For those not familiar with these types of bands, it is one long loop (not shown in the picture).  I purchased this item at a discount and was asked  to test it and write an honest  review based on my experiences with the product.

Very sleek and modern looking when seen in person.  The stainless steel  is a beautiful brushed finish.  This is a battery operated mill – something not mentioned in the listing.  You press the button on the top to grind.  There is a light that comes on the bottom (mine did not always come on).  The pepper that comes out is a mix of grinds – fine to coarse – which is fine for table side, but for cooking I prefer more control over the grind.  Adjusting the screw did not seem to change the grind very much – you cannot get real control of the grind with this grinder.  Also, it comes out slower than my manual grinder – which can be fine for tableside grind, but not ideal for cooking when I want to generate a teaspoon or tablespoon of pepper at a certain grind.So why 2 stars?  They need to look at their packaging.  The grinder came in a box that just barely surrounded the grinder.  The box was shipped in a plastic envelope with no padding from China – so the box was crushed badly.  Not sure if it affected the functioning of the grinder.  When I messaged the seller they blamed the carrier – not okay when their packaging was sub-standard.  I don't really care why it was crushed - I paid for a new functioning item. They wanted me to pay to ship it back to China – which would cost more than the grinder was worth.  They did finally agree to refund, so I give them points for that.  I did purchase this at a discount, and as always I am giving you my honest review based on my experiences.  For me, this grinder did not work out.

2:48 Mins Power plugs aren't always where you want them, and Apple only makes a 3 foot & 10 foot cord.  The 10 foot cord is $39.  What if you want something in between for a reasonable price?  This is where this 6 foot Akiko cord comes in.What I look for in a cable:► MIFI certified: MFi means Made for IPhone, Made for IPad, Made for IPod etc. This means "that the electronic accessory has been designed to connect specifically to IPhone, IPad, respectively, and has certified by the developer to meet Apple performance standards." Lightening cables are much more complicated than the previous Apple cables. They must have the proper chip, and be constructed to insert in either direction. MIFI certified means they adhere to Apple standards. I tried those cheap Ebay cables when lightening cables first came out, and they just don't work. Either they don't work from day one, or they stop working at the next software update because their chip is wrong.► Charge & Sync: I used this cable with both my IPad Air 2 and IPhone. The IPad Air is the trickier of the two devices to charge/sync (some third party cables work with my phone & not my IPad Air 2). Absolutely no issues. First I tried charging with the cable, and the cables were immediately recognized. The devices charged with no issues. Next I connected them to the computer. The devices were recognized in Itunes, and data was properly synced.► Durability: The materials at the plug ends are heavy duty, and the connection at each plug end are well fitted & tight. The connectors are nicely made.► Fit: The lightning connector goes into the phone snugly and is recognized. However, the plug that plugs into the Apple device is slightly wider and thicker than the standard lightning cable. It does not work for a Lifepoof case.► Warranty: LIFETIME warranty means they believe in their product. I like that.  I also liked that some people have tried them out on their warranty and they have delivered.► Conclusion:Great charge and sync cable in a useful length at an attractive price. I purchased this cord at a discounted price and was asked for my review based on my actual experiences with this product. This is one of the few third party cables that passed all my tests.  I will always update with further information as I continue to use the cable.  I would definitely recommend this cable, as long as the user's case could accommodate a slightly larger lightning connector.

4:04 Mins I LOVE selfie sticks - add them to a party and it definitely ramps up the fun.  This is my smallest selfie stick yet► Why I use a selfie stick* To be able to capture the scenery behind myself in a selfie* To not have to ask sketchy characters to take my picture* For photos or video* So I don't see that "fat arm" in the selfie"* To be able to be in the group shot instead of behind the camera► What's included that's extra? (Other selfie sticks I own did not include these features)* Bluetooth functionality: This allows you to use your selfie stick as a wireless remote for your phone - even if the phone is not in the selfie stick, as long as it is within Bluetooth range.* USB to Micro USB charging cable: Nice short one - easy to use.  Yes I have a bunch, but nice to include* Wrist strap - to carry the stick & keep your phone secure.  This one has an adjustment that allows you to snug it onto your wrist.► Materials: The handle is a nice rubber feel - smooth to the hand.  This is not one of those handles that swivels in your hand. The selfie stick telescoped and collapsed easily. Fully telescoped, this selfie stick easily supported my IPhone 5 or 6 without flexing or collapsing. (Do be careful with any of the selfie sticks of this type to not over-extend, or  it will break.)  The phone cradle has silicone padding top & bottom where it would touch the phone. I was able to secure my phone so that I felt safe extending it. (I have tried some selfie sticks that are so flimsy that they flex from the weight of the phone.) I would not turn my phone sideways in this selfie stick, since there is only top & bottom support. The knob that adjusts the camera angle tightens enough to hold the camera in place.► How do I make it work? NOTE: These are IPhone instructions & may differ for Android.1. Charging: It came partially charged, so you can play with it immediately. If it needs charging, use the supplied cord to plug into the bottom of the handle, and then plug it into one of your USB phone chargers.2. No Assembly required! Woohoo! Just pull it out & play!3. Attach Phone: Loosen the thumbscrew so you can tilt the phone bracket to the position you want. The phone holder is nicely padded on the top & bottom where it grips your phone. It is a spring loaded grip - It was easy for me to load & unload my phone & it felt secure.4. Pair the phone: Turn the Bluetooth to "On" by pushing the shutter release until the shutter release pulses with a blue light. Go to the Bluetooth settings on your phone and select the stick (It appeared as D-09 on my phone). When it say "connected" you are good to go.5. Snap away: Open your camera App. Touch the camera icon on the upper right to change the camera to selfie mode. Extend the stick & snap away by pressing the round button (with a W on it) on the handle of the selfie stick6. To turn it off, turn off the Bluetooth on your phone, then turn off the stick by pressing the shutter release for 3 seconds. This will save batteries.► Conclusion:I LOVE the fold down feature - it means I can keep this in my purse. I like the Bluetooth functionality, power cord, wrist strap, and secure grip for my IPhone.  The extension is very good for such a compact stick.  This selfie stick is perfect to keep in purse, backpack or glove box for those shots you just can't get any other way. This product was purchased at a discounted price in exchange of an honest and unbiased review based on my actual experiences with the product. My reviews - positive or negative - reflect my actual experiences with the product. I hope it helps you with your shopping decision.

2:14 Mins I need tools that function, but like to make ecologically sensitive choices whenever I can.  Bamboo is a wonderful alternative to plastic or wood cutting boards.  It grows faster - so it is more easily renewable, it does not use up our petroleum resources, and is decomposable at the end of its lifespan - which should be many years.What I like:* SIZE:  Small boards don't work as well for me - it is big enough for all my meal prep chores. (Yes it is slightly smaller than the listing says - 15.5x11 not 16x12, but plenty big enough.) I can cut away without worries of food spilling off the board.* Drain Channel:  This is a feature I like on all my boards.  It lets meat / fruit juices drain off into the channel - instead of onto your floor or counter.  When the channel is full - carry the board to the sink and empty - LOVE it!* Removable Non-Slip Feet:  I like that the keep the board secure, and that they also make it so the board does not scratch the surface it is on.  On my board, the silicone feet stuck up above the board on one side, and were flush on the other.  They remove for cleaning - essential!* Bamboo:  Bamboo is fast growing & easily renewable.  Also, it is easy on my knives.  It is a stacked construction (meaning the edges are facing up) - the only type of bamboo chopping block you should get.  Hand wash like any wood/ bamboo board.* Multi-use: can use as cutting board or as cheese board (I will used one side for each purpose.)►Conclusion:  I am very happy I purchased this cutting board.  This product was purchased at a discounted price in exchange for an honest and unbiased review based on my actual experiences with the product.  I recommend this for anyone who wants a highly functional kitchen tool that is eco-friendly at the same time.

These cables work perfectly to charge my iPhones, friends android phones, Bluetooth gadgets, power banks etc - all with one cord.  Having the adapter built in, with a connector so it doesn't get lost is brilliant.I have purchased this cable in three colors, so this video review shows all three types:[ Apple MFi Certified ] PeleusTech®[ 2 Pack ] 3ft 2-in-1 Lightning & Micro USB Cable, Sync Data & Cable Charging Cord for iPhone 6(4.7) Plus(5.5) 5C 5S 5, iPad Air,mini, mini 2, 4th Generation, iPod Touch 5th Generation, Galaxy S6 S5 S4 S3, HTC, Huawei,...[ Apple MFi Certified ] PeleusTech®[ 2 Pack ] 3ft 2-in-1 Lightning & Micro USB Cable, Sync Data & Cable Charging Cord for iPhone 6(4.7) Plus(5.5) 5C 5S 5, iPad Air,mini, mini 2, 4th Generation, iPod Touch 5th Generation, Galaxy S6 S5 S4 S3, HTC, Huawei,...[ Apple MFi Certified ] PeleusTech®[ 2 Pack ] 3ft 2-in-1 Lightning & Micro USB Cable, Sync Data & Cable Charging Cord for iPhone 6(4.7) Plus(5.5) 5C 5S 5, iPad Air,mini, mini 2, 4th Generation, iPod Touch 5th Generation, Galaxy S6 S5 S4 S3, HTC, Huawei,...The cables function  identically, but the white cable is constructed differently.  The blue & green cables are wider flat ribbon cables/.  The white cable is a round apple style cable.  The white one has a stress relief collar, and markings to show which way to insert the micro USB connector into the lightning adapter.When I look for any charge sync  cable I look for:► MIFI certified: MFi means Made for IPhone, Made for IPad, Made for IPod etc. This means "that the electronic accessory has been designed to connect specifically to IPhone, IPad, respectively, and has certified by the developer to meet Apple performance standards." Lightening cables are much more complicated than the previous Apple cables. They must have the proper chip, and be constructed to insert in either direction. MIFI certified means they adhere to Apple standards. I tried those cheap Ebay cables when lightening cables first came out, and they just don't work. Either they don't work from day one, or they stop working at the next software update because their chip is wrong.► Charge & Sync: I used this cable with both my IPad Air 2 and IPhone. The IPad Air is the trickier of the two devices to charge/sync (some third party cables work with my phone & not my IPad Air 2).  Absolutely no issues.  First I tried charging with the cable, and the cables were immediately recognized. The devices charged with no issues. Next I connected them to the computer. The devices were recognized in Itunes, and data was properly synced.► Durability:  The materials at the plug ends are heavy duty, and the connection at each plug end are well fitted & tight. The connectors are nicely made.  The lightning adapter snaps in nicely,  but be sure you orient it correctly.  Only the white version has arrows to help you orient it.  To orient the colored cables, use the attachments for the spring connector - put them on the same side & you will have the connector correctly oriented to the lightning adapter.► Fit: The lightning connector goes into the phone snugly and is recognized. However, the plug that plugs into the Apple device is slightly wider and thicker than the standard lightning cable. There is a "step" before it gets very wide, but it does not work for a Lifepoof case.► Warranty: 12 month warranty means they believe in their product.  I like that.► Conclusion:Great multipurpose charge and sync cable that can charge a large variety of mobile gadgets.  Fun colors add a dash of style & fun.  I purchased this cord at a discounted price and was asked for my review based on my actual experiences with this product. I would definitely recommend this cable, as long as the user's case could accommodate a slightly larger lightning connector.

3:21 Mins In my review video I tried to address some of the concerns people had about the cap opening on this water bottle infuser.  I am able to use the bottle with no problems once I understood the mechanics.  I like the handle, the leak proof design, and the generous fruit container.  It is easy to assemble and easy to clean.Infused water is a great way to drink wonderfully flavored drinks without all the calories and sugar of per-bottled drinks.  I love that you can customize your drink, and save lots of $$$ from not buying all the fancy, pricey flavored waters in the market.  Be creative & mix the flavors.  I use it with berries, lemon, lime, mint.  Other ideas - cucumber, cilantro.  For the liquid I use plain water, sparkling water, or iced tea.  Experiment with different teas - very different results.  Try the green tea and lime flavor popular at that famous coffee shop - and spend MUCH less.  Always use room temperature or cold liquids - not hot.  I like to infuse for several hours or overnight to get the best flavor.I do like this bottle, with the small concern that the tight keeper (see video) may impact the durability of the lid.  Still, compared to the cost of market drinks, this bottle should save you lots of money while providing you with many yummy drinks.  Also, I like he functional aspects of this bottle better than most.  I purchased this item at a discount and was asked for an unbiased review based on my actual experiences with the product. I try to give all the details of my actual experience with the product & appreciate your feedback.  I will update if I have further information as I use it longer.

I love to walk barefoot – but then I develop calluses, and if let go too long, my heels crack and become sore & ugly.  So – the need for a callus remover.  The one that came with my pedicure kit was cheap & flimsy, so I counted on the salon doing them when I went.  So – when offered a discounted price if I would do a honest review of the product – I went for it.This callus remover reminds me of the ones they use in the salon.  Nice size – easy to grab hold of – no flimsy feel if you try to put some pressure.  Having two sides with different grit is very nice – I followed their instructions.  I soak my feet first, then dry them, File with Coarse side on dry foot, then rinsed, then smoother side of callus remover to smooth out the skin, then lotion.  Go gently – you can always do more another day.I have got to mention - I love that they put a hand written note in the packages – saying thank you.  Small businesses that care are the backbone of our economy, and this is one who cares that we buy from them. Recommended!

Essential oils are great bang for your buck, because they are so concentrated.  Most products you buy on the store shelves have just a small amount of these powerhouse oils (if any).  You will definitely want to dilute this with carrier oils (such as jojoba or almond), or use it in a diffuser.  It is very strongBOTTLE:  It’s clear that Art Naturals is experienced with what it takes to package & ship essential oils.  The dark heavy weight bottle protects the essential oil from light.  I still store mine in the fridge with the screw cap, to prolong shelf lifeDROPPER: The dropper is a very nice plus when using with a diffuser for aromatherapy, or when adding just a small amount.VALUE:  This 4 oz. bottle will last for a very long timeI intend to use it in my soap making – tea tree oil is considered beneficial for many skin conditions & has a bracing & invigorating scent.  I purchased this item at a discount and was asked to write an honest  review based on my experiences with the product.  I am very happy with this purchase.

My husband & I took ballroom / social dance lessons for a while, but then the teachers moved out of town. After attending a family wedding recently, I realized I really wanted to brush up on what we knew, and add a few more steps.  I purchased theWedding Dance Mastery System, 5 DVD Set: A Complete Instructional Step By Step Guide to Dancing at Your Wedding and this set as well.  This set is a subset of the other set, so if you want to learn more dances, and more steps, I suggest the other set.  If you just want to survive the wedding dance & look good, this set should do it.The description for this item is limited, so:'What's Included - also known as - all the fabulous steps you can learn!* Disk 1 -  Foxtrot/ Waltz:** FOXTROT: The Basic Step, Left Rock Turn, The Sway Step, The Promenade, Promenade with Underarm Turn, The Dip** WALTZ: The box step, the Turning Box, Box with Walk around turn, Progressive Basic, Open Break with Underarm Turn, The Twinkle, The Promenade, The Dip, Wedding Dance Tips* Disk 2 -  Swing/ Rumba:** SWING: Basic Step, Release Break, Right Underarm Turn, Left Underarm turn, Right & Left Turn, The Cuddle, The Dip** RUMBA: The Box Step, Turning Box, Box with walk around turn, Rumba Rocks, Cross Body Lead, The Dip, Credit / Outtakes'Conclusion: This is a simplified version of  Wedding Dance Mastery System, 5 DVD Set: A Complete Instructional Step By Step Guide to Dancing at Your Wedding , which I also reviewed.  They teach you  less steps for each dance(check my review for the steps included in the more complete system), but still teaches you the basics of the dances.  The dance sequences are left out, as is the tips section that appears on some of the other disks on the mastery system.  I prefer the more complete system, but this is cheaper and will get you through the dance.  The Mastery system will keep you dancing after the wedding is long over. I purchased this product at a discounted price and was asked for my honest review based on my actual use of this product. After using it, I will tell you, IT WORKS, and this is a bargain compared to the dance lessons we took. It's less than signing one of us up for the community classes. It would be a great gift for a bride to be (or groom to be), but it's great for anyone who wants to learn to dance.  Please let me know if this review was helpful. I will always update if I get additional insights after further using the product, and I try to answer any questions left in comments.

Essential oils are an important ingredient in my bath body products – especially my soap making.  No artificial scent really can substitute for the wonderful scent of true essential oils.  Don’t be fooled by the cheaper imitation scents.  They never smell as good in your finished product, and the difference is really obvious in aromatherapy and massage uses. Majestic Pure has impressed me repeatedly with the various scents I have tried.  They are pure & undiluted.  The scents are true & concentrated – not musty or off.  Peppermint has a stimulating quality – use sparingly, because it is strong.  Good thing about that – this bottle will go very far.  Highly Recommended!  I purchased this item at a discount and was asked for an unbiased review.  I try to thoroughly test the products & always give my honest review.

2:57 Mins Travel means accommodating the different voltages & plug types in various parts of the world.  Accommodating foreign visitors has some of the same challenges.  As you see on my video, this handles the plug incompatibilities - but not the voltage issues.  However, the problem is partly dealt with because it does have 2 USB ports that will charge your mobile devices, and many mobile wall power blocks can handle a range of currents.►What I like:* Wide range of plug types* Two 2.1 Amp USB ports PLUS a plug - so I can  charge 2 mobile devices (including smart phones & tablets) without bringing the charger blocks, and still plug in something else.* Case - so it doesn't snag something else and breakThis adapter is a nice combination of utility and portability - great to keep in your foreign travel kit. I purchased this travel adapter at a discounted price and was asked for my honest & unbiased review.  It is now installed in my travel kit.  I will always update if I have new information  as I have further adventures with this product.  I always appreciate your feedback or comments.

For years I have been growing lavender. Over the years I have probably grown 50 varieties of lavender. Of all the varieties, the Angustifolias are the sweetest scent. They have true sweet Lavender smell, with none of the camphor smell of some of the other types. When I realized this was made from 100% Angustifolia variety, I was delighted! So many products that claim to be lavender don’t have the true scent – but this one really does. Perfect product to use for my soap making and other bath & body products.For me, lavender is a calming, soothing yet refreshing floral scent. I use it in many ways to make bath / body products.• Add to almond, jojoba, grape seed or fractionated coconut oil for a massage. Choose oil based on your preference – lavender will be the scent you smell.• Add to coconut oil as a moisturizer.• Freshen up potpourri – freshen up lavender sachets• Use a few drops to freshen a bathroom• Use with aroma therapy diffuser• Use it in soap making – I like to use it alone or combine with rose or rosemary scents as well. I make lye soap, but you could add it to a glycerin melt & pour soap for a lovely gift.• Scent an eye pillow – very restful scent• Mix with Epsom salt to make a bath salt.The dark bottle is great for keeping the oil fresh, and the dropper is a nice plus that is often not included. Store in a cool dark place ( I use the refrigerator). Remember - it is a concentrated oil - use sparingly until you get used to how much you need. You will be surprised how far this bottle will go. Lovely smell, good value, it’s the real deal. I purchased at a discount in exchange for writing an unbiased review.  Delighted with this purchase!

I love multi-use items – as long as they work well. Up to now, I have had to have a heating pad and an ice pack to accomplish hot/cold therapy.  It’s very nice to have one pack that can do both.  It can even double as a thin ice pack in a small ice chest.The plastic outside is a thick material, and I like that that they made a point of not putting ink on the outside – so no staining skin or clothing with ink transfer.In my freezer the pack freezes rather firm – but in a short time it started to become more flexible.  It puts out a lot of cold, so I wrap it in a towel so it does not contact skin directly.Being non-toxic is great, because I will also use this in my small ice chest .From room temperature – about an hour to freeze, about 30 seconds to heat.It has moved into my freezer so it is ready to use when needed. I purchased this item at a discount and was asked for an unbiased review. If you found this review helpful, please let me know.  I try to give all the details of my actual experience with the product & appreciate your feedback.

I have dry skin, so I am always looking for the magic moisturizers & cleansers that will not over-dry my skin. People say my skin looks younger than my age - and I hope to keep it that way! Argan oil has now taken a place in my skin care regime. I have used it for cleansing - to loosen the dirt / sunscreen /makeup from my face. I rinse my face, then moisturize with the Argan oil - it only takes a tiny amount. The result is my skin doesn't get that tight dry feeling.The smell is light & earthy - no fragrance added. I like the fact that it is 100% cold pressed Argania Spinosa Kernel Oil - aka Argan oil, so there is no surprise reactions to other ingredients.I have tried and loved several other Majestic Pure products - this was no exception.  I like that they have a commitment to freshness and purity - something that isn't even mentioned in some other brand listings.  The bottle is pretty enough to sit on the bathroom counter for easy use. I purchased this product at a discounted price and was asked for my honest review. So happy I did!

I  know strong passwords are important, and maybe Enigmaze could help me get there.  I was very intrigued when I was able to purchase this at a discount  in exchange for my honest review.  What arrived were two cards, but absolutely no instructions.  I looked on the web – checked the Facebook page.  I am  still intrigued but did not find enough information to really help me use this effectively.  Some of the places I looked referred to a whole system – notebook, pen etc.  Do I need that?  How would it be different than what I have?  I honestly I have no idea how to use this to change all my passwords to safer ones that I can regenerate when needed.I think this idea has such promise.  Hopefully more information is coming out that will make it possible for me to use the item.  It would be nice if the seller sent an email to each buyer with information on how to use it.  Maybe the seller could include a  card with the product directing people to a website where they can get more information.  Maybe they could sponsor users creating and sharing new ways to use it.  I would love to be able to generate strong, unique passwords I can remember.  Then it would be ♥LOVE♥ instead of like.

1:15 Mins This is a well made, but different, phone clamp.  It uses a very effective jaw clamp to grasp your phone. Silicone pads cushion the phone from the clamp and keep the phone from slipping.  The jaw clamp can be easily positioned to not interfere with buttons or ports.  The clamp does not interfere with my view of the screen.  You can charge the phone while in this mount.  Phone is very secure in clamp.* 360° viewing angles - allows you to swivel left or right - BUT no vertical adjustment is possible* Suction Cup: The suction cup is covered by a special 3M Gel Pad that increases the ability of the mount to adhere to windshield or dashboard.  So far it lives up to their claim of leaving no residue.  (I will report back if that changes)* Install / Removal: One touch lever makes it really easy to apply & remove the mount.* Could be uses as a table top phone stand.* Could be used in a rental car* Money Back Guarantee - always like these - means a company believes in their product*► Possible concerns:* No up / down adjustments - limits viewing angles - so be sure it will work in your car If you position your phone in landscape mode* Only landscape orientation possible* Tricky to remove & install phone (clamp is strong).  I think this would get better with practice► Conclusion:  Nice phone mount - good build quality - lots of attention to detail. 6:56 Mins I use vacuum seal bags for freezing food and for Sous Vide cooking, so I was thrilled to  find the quality I need for less money.  They can't just be cheaper - they have to perform as well. As I show in my video they works just as well, and the price is much better.► Why I like these bags:* Thick - It is crucial that bones or sharp edges of food do not puncture the bag.  Nothing cheap or flimsy will do when you cook in them.  These bags are a quality weight that will handle all my tasks.  (See video - they were able to handle the sharp edges of my metal powerbank)* BPA free - crucial if storing / freezing or Sous Vide cooking* Air channel design - As you can see from the video, all the air was evacuated - indicated good air channel design. They claim it evacuates the air faster.  Not sure if that is true, but it did pull all the air out - which some cheaper bags I have tried have note* Cut your own size rolls - eliminates waste of pre-cut bags* White panel on bag - for easy labeling with permanent marker* Price - Compare the prices:  The FoodSaver  brand FoodSaver 11" Roll, 3pkis $27.99 for 3 x 16' (48 feet total) of 11" roll.  The Fresh brand is $18.79 for 2 x 25" (50 feet) of 11" roll.  So Fresh Brand gives you 2' more for much less $$.► Conclusion:  Most importantly for me - it works as well or better than the FoodSaver brand.  It is also cheaper than FoodSaver brand.  When I was offered the chance to purchase this at a discounted price in exchange for sharing my experiences with the product in an unbiased review, I jumped at the chance, because I use a LOT of these every year.  These passed the test, and will be my new replacement brand for vacuum seal bags.  HIGHLY recommend!

4:02 Mins This case is for the user who wants more protection than all those slim cases offer.  It has three layers that combine to offer many protective features:► What are the layers and what do they do?* Layer 1: Clear screen protector attached to hard bumper - the screen protector protects your phone from accidental scratches & nicks.  Go ahead - Drop it in your purse. Only the camera and the touch pad are exposed - so finger print ID still works, and selfies are crystal clear.  The touch screen is very sensitive - and so far no scratches.  The screen protector is beveled below the edge, so it does not touch the table surface when placed face down.* Layer 2: TPU back & sides - Provides shock resistance and wraps the sides completely to the front and seals with a gasket fit around the bumper and against the clear screen protector* Layer 3: Polycarbonate Back plate & kickstand.  Provides additional impact resistance.  Snaps on.  Kickstand is part of this layer, and will detach if this layer is removed.'► What about the Kickstand?This is my least favorite part of the case, and the reason I will deduct 1 star.  The kickstand is hinged by two tiny plastic pins that look fragile & easy to break.  They are held in only if the back plate is on the case - (see video).  The kickstand snaps into place, but is hard to snap out of its slot.  When you pull out the kickstand, it feels very fragile.  It does not lock into an open position.► Ports:  This case made some good choices for offering moderate to high protection against the hazards of life.  The ports most susceptible to accidental water damage (earphone jack & power jack) are sealed by plug.  However this is not a waterproof case.  The mute button has a very comfortable cutout.  The microphone, home button, camera & apple logo are all exposed by cutouts, giving you much enhanced function over the true waterproof case.  All buttons functioned well, and the touch screen worked very well through the screen protector.► Conclusion:  If you are looking for a classy protective everyday case, this may be your case.  It should serve you well. The phone did take a fall from a table while in this case - phone & case were unharmed. If you are planning to use the kickstand daily - I would suggest you look elsewhere.  Recommend if kickstand is not your main reason for wanting this case. I purchased this item at a discount and was asked for an unbiased review. If you found this review helpful, please let me know.  I try to give all the details of my actual experience with the product & appreciate your feedback.

2:23 MinsRunning belts are preferable to fanny packs because they allow you to distribute the weight close to your body. No more bumping of your phone against your body with every step. Although I do use armbands at times, I prefer a running belt when it gets warmer. It keeps sweaty neoprene off my bare arm.  Also, you can put other items in a running belt besides your phone - like car keys & remote, which those key slots on armbands never hold.This is a flip style belt - meaning you place items through the slits in the center seam (see vioideo).  Then you can (if you wish, flip the slits toward your body for extra security.As you can see from this video, this belt is well made.►What I like* Good weight stretchy spandex*  Reflective stripe running the length of the belt on top & bottom* Key clip on elastic cord - so key doesn't slip out & get lost* Customer service is 5 star ★★★★★.  When they realized I had a sizing issue, they contacted me right away and made it right.►So what about the sizing?It's important to get it right.  On the video I show you an XL belt - that measures 32 inches un-stretched. (They say it fits waists 31"-35")  I can get about 5-6 more inches more when I stretch it - And that is REALLY stretching it. Smaller sizes will have less inches of stretch.  So, you need to consider where you want it to fit (hips or waist) and then whether you can get it on over your head or over your hips when stretched.  So - be sure to measure the widest part of your body  you need to get it over  before ordering.  Ladies - this is going to be more of an issue for you because we have wider hips - going over the head may work better for some people.  It would be nice to know the un-stretched & stretched sizes for SM, Med, L, XL.  In general, my advice is order larger than you think.If you choose carefully with sizing, this is a quality product. I purchased this product at a discounted price and was asked for my honest review based on my actual use of this product.

One of my Yoga teachers introduced me to use of the Yoga block.  In Yoga, it is very important that you first master the correct form, then AFTER that deepen the pose while maintaining alignment.  The Yoga block helps you do  that.  You can start with it in a vertical position, then as your ability to master the pose increases, you can turn it to horizontal position►Ways I use a Yoga Block:• Meditation – Sit on the block cross-legged  at the start or end of practice to relax the back & get a different experience of cross leg pose.  Try forward bends in this position• In triangle pose – I use it for my lower hand, instead of grasping my leg, especially early in the a session• Bridge Pose – I put it under my hips – and then relax – AHHHH• Spread leg or any forward fold – I rest my head on the block – started vertical – in some poses I now use horizontal.Well – the list could go on and on – but this gives you some ideas.  I place it by my mat at the start of practice & use it as needed.►Why this Yoga block:• Size – I have taken a picture of it next to my current block – this one is wider – which makes the difference between horizontal & vertical positioning a more natural step.  Also, it is more table when in the vertical position.  Still, of course, portable in a yoga bag.• Color – When I bring my other plain blue Yoga block – that looks just like all the other ones in the studio – people are always trying to take it and put it away at the end of class.  (People in yoga classes are very helpful!)  This one is distinctive looking  – and in my favorite colors.• Beveled edges – something I always look for – makes gripping it more natural• Non-slip surface has some give, but very supportive.  – surface can be cleaned• Recycled materials – Important to me – Gentle on the earth is a good thing.:It’s so much nicer (and more hygienic) to bring your own block to class (and some studios don’t have them).  My old block will stay at home – this one is going to class with me. ♥Love♥ the bigger size & purple / blue vibe.  Definitely recommend!!  I was delighted to purchase this at a promotional price in exchange for doing a review based on my experiences.

I use this type of grate a LOT – so much that I finally broke the handle of my previous one (another brand) after many years.  My kitchen gadgets work for a living, and I was wanting another one (because that handle glue job was not doing it – LOL).  SO – I was delighted to try this when I was offered the chance to purchase it at a discount and review it.  Some of the ways I use this grater / zester:• Lemon Zest (or any citrus zest) – This is what they advertised this for.  A lemon zester should take off the yellow part only, not the bitter white part.  This zester performed admirably.  See my picture.• Parmesan cheese – or any hard grating cheese.  I tried it and it worked as expected.  Fluffy billows of fine shredded Parmesan – you will never buy it pre-grated again.  It is so easy to grate it over a finished dish.  Be warned that if the cheese is too hard (and you push too hard) you can compress the shredder blades.  For instance, don’t run the cheese near the rind of the Parmesan across the grater (Just saying – learn from my previous bad experience).• Ginger – lovely ginger taste in your dish without the time of mincing• Chocolate – perfect for garnish.This zester is SUPER SHARP so watch those knuckles.  That is why it works so well.  The rubber handle is comfortable, and it does have a hanging hole at the end of the handle.  I have mine in a utensil crock on the counter.When cleaning, be sure to run any cleaning cloth from handle to blade, and gently, or you will shred it.  Usually I just run it under water with soap or put it in the dishwasher.Conclusion:  There are similar zesters out there, but the lifetime warranty is huge for me – because this zester is going to get some serious use.  Currently it is $14.97 (prices move around on this type of zester).  I wouldn't pay the full price they are showing - $29.97 - but $15  is a good value for this type of zester.  It is now one of two zesters in residence in my kitchen.  I used it last night to top the pasta with fresh grated Parmesan.  It’s a wonderful addition to your cooking gadgets.

I love my kitchen gadgets, but they can’t just be a pretty face in my kitchen.  They need to work for a living.  I use this type of grater / zester so much that I finally wore mine out after many years of use.  (It was another brand and the handle came off).  SO – I was delighted to try this when I was offered the chance to purchase it at a discount and review it.  I use this type of grate a LOT (so much that I usually have two of these in the kitchen).  Some of the uses:• Lemon Zest (or any citrus zest) – This is what they advertised this for.  A lemon zester should take off the yellow part only, not the bitter white part.  This zester performed admirably.  See my picture.• Parmesan cheese – or any hard grating cheese.  I tried it and it worked as expected.  Fluffy billows of fine shredded parmesan – you will never buy it pre-grated again.  It is so easy to grate it over a finished dish.  Be warned that if the cheese is too hard (and you push too hard) you can compress the shredder blades.  For instance, don’t run the cheese near the rind of the parmesan across the grater (Just saying – learn from my previous bad experience).• Ginger – lovely ginger taste in your dish without the time of mincing• Chocolate – perfect for granish.This zester is SUPER SHARP so watch those knuckles.  That is why it works so well.  The rubber handle is comfortable, and it does have a hanging hole at the end of the handle.  I have mine in a utensil crock on the counter.When cleaning, be sure to run any cleaning cloth from handle to blade, and gently, or you will shred it.  Usually I just run it under water with soap or put it in the dishwasher.This grater / zester is a good value compared to similar zesters.  The handle is a comfortable grip & the cover is a big plus – those blades are sharp!  The lemon yellow color makes it easy to find in a drawer.  I already used it to make a lemon goat cheese pasta recipe.  You will wonder how you every got by without a zester like this.  Definite  thumbs up!

Love being able to keep chilled coffee, soda, sparkling water, flavored water & wine without watering it down.  Once I make a drink, I want it to stay chilled to the proper temperature, and not get watered down.This is especially good for drinking a cold drink over a longer  time. At my desk I use an insulated travel mug to sip iced tea at my desk.  Adding these keeps it chilled for hours without diluting it.  When work distracts me I have often gone back to watery tea or iced coffee before I tried these.It takes about 4 hours to chill them – but with 8 cubes (4 of each) that is not a big problem.  I find myself using the stainless mostly – they seem colder.  Maybe the soapstone is better for desired whiskey temperature?They had me when they said you don’t have to choose between soapstone & stainless – because why choose when you can have it all!  The tongs are nice bonus – perfect for placing cubes in when company is over – me I just use my fingers usually.  The case keeps them from getting lost in the freezer.Altogether a nice set – perfect gift for the whiskey connoisseur - or someone like me who enjoys chilled drinks on a daily basis.  I purchased this product at a discounted price and was asked for my honest review.  I was delighted to try this set – Recommenced - it’s coooool!

I have dry skin, so I am always looking for the magic moisturizers & cleansers that will not over-dry my skin. People say my skin looks younger than my age - and I hope to keep it that way!  Argan oil has now taken a place in my skin care regime.  I have used it for cleansing – to loosen the dirt / sunscreen /makeup from my face.  I rinse my face, then moisturize with the Argan oil  - it only takes a tiny amount.  The result is my skin doesn’t get that tight dry feeling.I like the fact that it is 100% Argan oil, so there is no surprise reactions to other ingredients.  The bottle is pretty enough to sit on the bathroom counter for easy use.  I purchased this product at a discounted price and was asked for my honest review.  It has been a delight to try it!

I am always looking for a new twist on my exercise routine, and when I was offered this jump rope in exchange for a honest review, well ----- I JUMPED on it!  I liked the carry bag it came in – easy to take to the gym without it tangling in other stuff in there.  The adjustment for height was easy – I haven’t cut it, but you could if you wanted it only for you.  In my case, I want other family members to be able to adjust it for their use.►What I Like:• Lightweight – took some getting used to – the cable is so lightweight.• Ball Bearing action – the handle is attached to a ball bearing that allows the cable to effortlessly turn without tangling or getting twisted.• Adjustment – Adjustment is easy – just turn the screw (no tools needed) and then tighten where you want it.  (Not too tight or you might puncture the plastic sheathing).  I adjusted evenly on each side, and thought I am short (and quite a bit of cable was protruding), it surprisingly was not bothersome for me. I wish they had instructions on proper length or exercises,  but I easily found the info on google.  What I did was tep on the rope with one foot, then adjust so the cable end was at my chest height.This is a well made jump rope  - lightweight & portable - so much nicer than the ones I remember from school.  Major realization -  it is not as easy as it was years ago to jump rope.  I am not sure how well the plastic coating will hold up. I will always update if I get additional insights after further using the product

My husband & I took ballroom / social dance lessons for a while, but then the teachers moved out of town.  After attending a family wedding recently, I realized I really wanted to brush up on what we knew, and add a few more steps.  This set of videos is just what I needed.  The description for this item is limited, so:►What’s Included – also known as - all the fabulous steps you can learn!• Disk 1 – Wedding Introduction & FOXTROT: The Basic Step, Left Rock Turn, The Sway Step, The Promenade, Promenade with Underarm Turn, Dance Sequence #1/Tips, The Zig Zag, The Back Basic, The Dip, Dance Sequence #2/Tips• Disk 2 – WALTZ:  The box step, the Turning Box, Box with Walkaround tunr, Progressive Basic, Open Break with Underarm Turn, The Twinkle, The Promenade, The Dip, Tips• Disk 3 – SWING: Basic Step (City), Basic Step (East Coast), Release Break, Right Underarm Turn, Left Underarm turn, Right & Left Turn, The Cuddle, The Hammerlock,  Men’s Turns, Women’s Tuck & Spin, The Arm Slide, He Goes, She Goes, The Dip, Tips• Disk 4 – RUMBA: The Box Step, The Turning Box, Box with walkaround turn, Rumba Rocks, Cross Body Lead, Outside Partner Breaks, Fifth Position Breaks, Crossover Breaks, Open Break with Spot Turn, The Dip, Styling• Disk 5: WEDDING TIPS Bonus CD:  The Right Dance for You, Choosing Your Music, Band or DJ, Tips for the Dip, Stage Fright, Footwear, Alcohol, MistakesThe format of the teaching is very similar to what was done when we took classes.  In order for each step:• Introduction of step – why/when you would use it• Men’s Breakdown of the step• Woman’s Breakdown of the step• couple dancing together – no music, talking you through it• couple dancing together – with music, talking you through it►My Tips:• At the end of some of the discs, they sometimes have a tips video segment.
