I would suggest watching it before you get to the end of the disc (and maybe again after you have tried it a bit)  There are some excellent tips.• The music for the menu for each disk is in the style of that dance.  It’s in a repeating loop – so use it to practice!►Conclusion: You can use this to learn to social dance for a wedding or other party – you don’t have to be the bride or groom.  Compared to the cost of lessons, this is a bargain, and you can do a few minutes a day to learn it.  It is great bonding time with your partner.  I purchased this product at a discounted price and was asked for my honest review based on my actual use of this product. After using it, I will tell you, IT WORKS, and this is a bargain compared to the dance lessons we took.  It’s less than signing one of us up for the community classes.  It would be a great gift for a bride to be (or groom to be), but it’s great for anyone who wants to learn to dance.  We will be using these CDs until we learn all these steps before going back to lessons.  Please let me know if this review was helpful.  I will always update if I get additional insights after further using the product, and I try to answer any questions left in comments.

The first words out of my daughter’s mouth when she saw this case “Wow, that is COOL!  Here did you get that?”  Loved that reaction! For me, this looks like a gadget that Darth Vadar’s Star Wars storm troopers would have had.  This case is rugged, and yet not so bulky that you can’t put it easily in a pocket.  I’ve had it on my phone for a few days, and I am enjoying it more the more I use it.Why do I like it?► Materials:  This is a dual layer case. ★PLUS!!!! ★ You can remove the black outer bumper if you would like an all white case (of course, you would sacrifice some protection).  See my pictures.  The black layer is a silky matte finish – I found myself wanting to hold onto the phone where the black wraps toward the middle of the screen.  The back of the black layer looks like tire tread (but it feels smooth & silky).  It’s a stylish industrial look.  The white layer is shiny & flexible & grippy – thick enough to have good shock absorbance.► Kickstand:  Great for watching movies on the plane, or setting on your desk with clock/weather app.  Turns you phone into a bedside alarm clock.  (I’m having fun inventing new uses for it.)  The Kickstand snaps flat securely, and they use a steel pins for the hinges (a quality touch), which should make it last longer.  Still, I am going to treat the kickstand with care – since it’s a feature I like &  I don’t want it to break.  I think they made it as sturdy as they could with the size / weight of the case, but I would not press on the top of the phone while the kickstand is out, for instance.► Ports & Fit: The case has a nice lip on the front that protects the glass screen when the case is laid face down (or if it falls face down). Its big enough to hold the glass off a table, but set back to the edge.  The only interference with function I found is that is it a bit more difficult to slide up the Control Center when in landscape mode.  In portrait mode there is no interference with sliding the control center up from the bottom.  I had no problem sliding down the Notification Center in either orientation. The covered buttons (power & volume) work well. Mute button cutout is large enough to make muting very easy (this is often not done well on sturdier cases – see my picture).  Speaker & earphone are cut out well. The case is thick enough that the camera does not stick out beyond the case. The lightning port was big enough to accommodate my Apple lightning cable as well as all of my third party cables.  I like the extra strength & protection of cutouts if they are functional.► Style: The grips on the side & back provide shock absorption, grip & style.  I like being able to remove the black part to give a more streamlined look – gives me the option of different style during the day, while still feeling my phone is protected.  I like the logo cutout – an extra they did not have to include but really adds to the look.► Conclusion: This is a sturdy, stylish kickstand case that will help keep your phone safe from the hazards of life.  I purchased this product at a discounted price and was asked for my honest review based on my actual use of this product. After using this phone for a few days, I am really appreciating its combination of form & function.  The kickstand feature is something I am having fun trying out in all sorts of ways.  Definitely recommend!  Please let me know if this review was helpful.  I will always update if I get additional insights after further using the product, and I try to answer any questions left in comments.

I own a whole collection of various seasonal decorative cutters, because I love to bake, and I like my baked goods to be beautiful as well as tasty.  What I look for is a cutter that cuts AND embosses a design on top of the cutout, like these do.  Smooth plunger action & good materials (use of metal in the plunger instead of all plastic) are also things I look for and found in these cutters.  I've purchased quite a few at those overpriced kitchen stores (that I can't resist :) ).  These are a unique design & a good value.So what do I use them for?  Let me give you a few ideas.Christmas means pies & cookies.  I like to sprinkle pie cutouts on my pecan & pumpkin pies, and layer them onto the edge of the crust.  I always get OOOHS and AHHS when I bring out a pie like that.  It is  simple to do - use your pie crust scraps.  For scatter decorations (that you put on after the pie is baked) cut them & emboss them, then cook them separately on a cookie sheet.  Use the various sizes for interest & depth in your design,  To decorate the crust, layer cutouts onto the crust edge or the lattice or top crust (for double crust pies like apple).  Protect with foil if needed and bake as usual.You can even decorate streusel or crumbles with these seasonal cutouts.  Gives a very gourmet look to your cooking.  I was delighted to try these at a promotional price in exchange for my honest review.  My reviews – positive or negative – reflect my actual experiences with the product.  I will always update if I get additional insights after further using the product.

Running belts are preferable to fanny packs because they allow you to distribute the weight close to your body.  No more bumping of your phone against your body with every step.  Although I do use armbands at times, I prefer a running belt when it gets warmer.  It keeps sweaty neoprene off my bare arm.What I liked / noticed about this belt:• MATERIALS:  The outer material (that touches your skin or clothes is a  smooth The material is a smooth silky feeling Lycra / spandex.  The 2-1/2”x1-1/2” buckle & 1-1/2” strap are sturdy & good sized so they distribute pressure.  The pockets are lined with a WATER RESISTANT covering – so no rain or sweat worries for your valuables.  Great for bad weather (or bubble / color fun runs! ')  No more soggy ID!• ZIPPERS: Some running belts just have slits where the zippers are on this belt, and you flip the slits toward your body to secure your goods.  I never feel as secure with those belts.  The zippers on this belt secure the goods.  They are are  nice nylon zippers with a strip of reflective material on each side – giving a nice sliver/green/ silver effect on the one I got.• TWO GENEROUS POCKETS (9.75” & 5.25”):  I have posted photos showing my Iphone 6 laying on the pockets.  The pockets are gusseted (folded) on the back, to allow larger items to easily fit, but give a more minimal look when not full.  My Iphone 6 fit with room to spare.  When not full and folded into gussets, it is about 2” wide.  When expanded, it is about 3-1/4”, without any stretching.  I did not try stretching it.  I like to having 2 pockets so I can separate my phone from my keys.• SIZE:  When adjusted to the smallest setting, it measures 28”, and at largest setting, it measures 36”.  The belt is stretchy, but I’m not sure I would want to stretch it to 45”What matters is how it works – and the answer is GREAT!  I go out daily on a 3 mile loop, and this belt was barely noticeable on my route.  I was delighted to try this at a promotional price in exchange for my honest review.  Running gear is something that gets really used and tested at my house.  My reviews – positive or negative – reflect my actual experiences with the product.  I will always update if I get additional insights after further using the product.

Great idea for keeping afloat whatever you need to protect from sinking.  I tested it in the tub to make sure it floats. PASS!!!! I like that there are two, so you can float heavier items by using them together, or float two smaller items.  Great for my waterproof camera, but it also can be used for anything you don’t want to sink to the bottom of the pool/pond/ocean.  Kids toys, hats, and all those loose items in boats.  Be sure to test that the weight of the item can be floated by these before you are on/in the water.  You can use multiple floats for heavier items.  (Bathtub is a good way to test - I was surprised at how much weight these could float!)I have a picture showing it on my wrist – it should fit a good sized wrist.  This product was purchased at a discounted price in exchange of an honest and unbiased review based on actual experiences with the product. My reviews – positive or negative – reflect my actual experiences with the product.

Like many other reviewers, I have a love/hate relationship with the Assassin's Creed series. I marveled at the first one, but have been disillusioned ever since. There's so much I want to like about it and, when I compare it to the last couple releases, I want to give it 5 stars for effort. But just like in school, we're not graded on our performance against ourselves, but where we should be among our peers. And Assassin's Creed Syndicate is just pulling a C average when I look at it across the landscape of other Xbox One games.For starters, UBI Soft really needs to fix the controls. They're so tedious, they completely impede game play. Like its predecessors, I find myself giving up after I've nearly finished a scenario because my character did not respond to my inputs in the way I intended. There are many other games out there that are models of complexity where you never once feel like your character has a mind of its own and fights against your every wish. I offer up Elder Scrolls Online and Fallout 4: Two of Assassin's Creed Syndicate's competitors that are doing it well.Aside from the controls, there are other blunders: Why do I have to play both Frye twins? I want to use the stealthy Evie exclusively, but then I'm forced to play some scenarios with her melee-specialized brother. This is silly. Let me stick with my play style.The game is beautiful and the story telling is rich, but it's hard to immerse yourself in the world when the game pulls you out of the moment by fighting against your actions.

I've been using B+W filters for my Nikon gear exclusively for over a decade. They're well made and have the finely crafted feel you associate with high-end electronics like Leica. This is important with Circular Polarizers because they need to be tactile and agile, but also hold small adjustments. This filter handles all of that well. But what's most impressive is B+W's new line of filters doesn't sacrifice the f-stops that previous generations did. I love this! Especially since I will sometime leave the filter on all day when hiking or otherwise unable to remove it safely.But I'll stop writing, because a picture truly demonstrates the value of this filter. I took two comparison sets of the same shot. You can see the striking difference in clarity and color depth.

The 2015 Snowflake a well-made ornament that will look fantastic on both modern and traditional trees. It comes it a gift-worthy box with a plastic enclosure that is lined with a velvety texture for storage. A nice addition to your ornament arsenal.

I've been wearing the UP2 for three weeks now. I own multiple FitBit products and an Apple Watch. I find that I use the UP2 for my everyday, always-on tracking, but my Apple Watch for specific, exercise related tracking (I use a rowing machine, and the UP2 doesn't support it).Here are my impressions of the UP2:// PROSSTYLE: Love the simplicity of the grey  band. It's not bulky and is barely noticeable throughout your day. I wear mine with the clasp on the outside and it looks stylish.WATER RESISTANT: Since I received my UP2 for review, I decided I wouldn't go easy on it. I've saturated the fitness band with three weeks of long, hot showers and it's doing just fine.KEEP IT ON 24/7: Because I can wear it in the shower, I'm able to leave the band on 24/7. A great feature because it garners a more accurate representation of the steps I take. (Whereas my Apple Watch is frequently off my wrist when I'm home.)BATTERY LIFE: So far I'm getting about 7 days per charge. Pretty good, but significantly less than the 10 days it advertises. Even still, I love that I can leave this on my wrist all week and take it off for about an hour each weekend to charge it up.SLEEP MONITOR: Again with the 24/7 wearability! I can't leave my Apple Watch on at night because it needs to charge. So UP2 grabs all of my sleep activity (or inactivity, I should say). It's light and small so I don't notice I'm wearing it.// CONSSLOW DATA EXCHANGE WITH PHONE: For some reason it takes forever for my UP2 to exchange data with my iPhone 6. It's one of the most annoying aspects of the product. Sometimes I just want to do a quick check on where I am with my activity and it's more of a process than I'd like.LOSING IT'S SHAPE AFTER TWO WEEKS: My band is definitely stretching out and morphing a bit, so it looks less elegant. Fortunately it's easy to resize, but the rubber is a bit misshapen after three weeks. (I'll update here if it gets much worse.)Overall, this is a great band. For the price, I'd like to see it connect with my phone a little faster so I can check my progress more quickly and easily since there isn't a light-weight progress indicator on the band itself.

Peace of mind found. I've had "Buy earthquake food" on my to-do list ever since The New Yorker made all of us Seattleites crazy with its 2015 article about the Sub-Cascadian rupture that's expected to devastate the Pacific Northwest. Problem is, when you live in a city you don't have a lot of space for emergency supplies, so storing a bunch of canned food was stressing me out.Enter Mountain House Just-In Case. The box is light weight and about the size of two large shoe boxes. It's easy to store up high where it can be out of sight, out of mind. I tucked mine away on a top shelf in my pantry with a case of bottled water. And guess what? Mountain House Just-In Case Emergency Food Supply will last for 12 years. That's right, 12 years! Yes, the price is high, but think about all money you'll save over time versus storing a bunch of cans that need to be replaced every year. (Just don't forget to do what I did and store some bottled water with your box, since each of these meals requires that you add water. You might also want to store a camping stove and some gas, because hey, who knows what will work come "the big one".)All in all, I love that this box just solved my emergency food supply dilemma and I won't have to buy another for 12 years.

I initially had a false start with this game. My friends and I sat down to play it and we just could not understand it with the supplied instructions, so we punted and played something else. A few weeks later, determined to play the game, I sat down with a different group of friends. This time, we watched some helpful YouTube videos and we're off and running. (Seriously folks, the directions in the box are horrible. Check out some online videos and the game will make sense in no time.)My litmus test for a great board game is this: Do I want to play it again immediately after finishing? The answer for Homeland is an emphatic yes! Once you get the hang of it, it's actually quite easy to play and there's a lot of strategy. The fact that you're working as a team with a possible mole thwarting your every move adds some fantastic drama.The gameplay is multi-layered and reminiscent of Pandemic. In addition, the gaming "engine" provides a great balance between strategy and randomization making for dramatic twists and turns. All in all my friends and I loved it and I'm incredibly anxious to play again.

My cat's a picky eater and she loves this food. Coupled with the fact that my trusted vet has recommended the Solid Gold brand in the past, I'm completely satisfied. I feed my cat wet food in the morning and dry food in the evening, with a focus on holistic, grain-free products. Given those constrains, as long as her eliminations are consistent and her coat is in good shape, I'm happy if she'll eat it. No need to over think it.

This is a sweet little game that's easy to pick up. It's perfect for families with older children or adult friends that are looking for something that's easy to teach new players. The negotiation aspect of the game will reveal the personality traits of the people you're playing with--some strive for fairness, others greed, and still others just latch on to a favorite treasure color. The game takes about 30 minutes to play thanks to the egg timer, which keeps negotiation time to a minimum.Overall the game art and pieces are well designed and fun to play with. However, we have a very hard time distinguishing between the gold and silver treasure, which sometimes hinders negotiation speeds.

I've been using this product for two weeks now and I've noticed a dramatic change. As a former athlete, I have terrible arthritis in my knees and hips. It's bad enough that I have to take pain killers anytime I'm going to be sitting for any length of time.I'd taken Glucosamine and Chondroitin supplements before, to no avail, so I was skeptical going in. After a few days of taking this Joint Soother, I started noticing a difference. Now, two weeks later, the pain is gone. It's as if it never existed. I'm elated!

These headphones are vastly superior to the headset Microsoft provides with Xbox One. That said, there's room for improvement. I've used the headphones for a week now with Elder Scrolls Online and Destiny on the Xbox, as well as a couple of phone calls on my iPhone. Here's my experience:// PROSCOMFORT: My biggest complete about the headset that comes with your console is that it's incredibly uncomfortable. The Recon 50X will be an immediate improvement in that department. The phones fit over your ears and provide a cushioned experience that's common to more expensive sets.COST: At this price, the headset is worth the investment for the comfort upgrade alone.SOUND QUALITY: Voices are clear on both ends of these phones, vastly improve communication when compared with the included headset.// CONSSOUND VOLUME: I've used these headphones as the sole source of sound and with the TV on providing surround sound in addition to the headset. They don't provide noise cancelling, so they work best worn in quiet room. That said, even in a quiet room they seem a touch underpowered.MICROPHONE: The microphone is large. It can be a bit distracting. You "self bend" it into a position that's right for you, but it does seem more obtrusive than it needs to be.Overall, the headphones are a great deal and an inexpensive upgrade if you find yourself playing multiplayer games. I wouldn't invest in them for anything but gaming, as they're too underpowered to act as headphones for music and video.

What a fantastic addition to my kitchen. I love this multi cooker. Here's why:EVEN COOKING: The wide, low profile cooking "pan" maximizes the cooking surface, whereby ensuring that everything is heated and heated thoroughly.GREAT LOOKS:  I keep the cooker on the corner of my counter between my stovetop and my sink. It fits in perfectly with my stainless appliances and has a minimalist/industrial look.EASY CLEANING: The non-stick surface of the cooking pan is easy to clean. I cooked some chili yesterday and even though it was cooking all day, clean up only took a few minutes. In addition, the pan is so light weight compared to ceramic models--much easier to hand wash in the sink and you don't have to worry about chipping it.OVEN REPLACEMENT ON A HOT SUMMER DAY: Such a perfect way to cook food on a hot summer day. With this multi cooker, you can roast a chicken or some brussels sprouts without heating your kitchen up the way running your oven would.All in all I love my new Multi Cooker and will be recommending it to friends.

I absolutely love AHAVA products. Their line of moisturizers is one of the best. AHAVA has found a way to provide just the right amount of moisture without leaving my skin feeling oily. I only wish AHAVA would tone down the scent--it's not my favorite, but it's bothering me less and less with each use.Also try the hand lotion. It will moisturize even the driest situations without feeling tacky. Love it.

I feed my cat Weruva wet food in the morning for her main meal and then give her a handful of kibble in the evening so she won't wake me up for a midnight feeding. I used to be pretty laissez-faire about what I fed her in the evening, after all it was just a snack and as long as she was willing to eat it that was good enough for me. However, she started to develop a pretty severe dandruff problem, so I've been more careful to keep her off of grains and fillers that seem to exacerbate the problem. Unfortunately, the most recent food I tried brought back the dander with a vengeance. Wellness CORE Natural Grain Free to the rescue. Since I started feeding her Wellness CORE food and treats (the treats are great, check them out), her dandruff is on the mend. This will be my new go-to food for my fussy little girl!

I played the PC version for a while and took advantage of Bethesda's offer to transfer my account over to my Xbox One console. Quite frankly, I tired of ESO Online pretty shortly after I started playing it nearly a year and a half ago. I was disappointed and found the game to pale in comparison to the other games in the Elder Scrolls series. I was still disappointed (too many connection issues) when I first tried it on Xbox and let my copy languish on my machine for a while. It was initially buggy and reminded me of everything that made my initial experience with ESO less than stellar.A month later I picked it up again and now I'm loving it and totally hooked. This is a fantastic port! Bethesda has ironed out the connection issues that plagued the game when it was first released. In addition, the console port fixes a lot of the tedium that was bogging down the PC version. ESO for Xbox One is a blast! It reminds me of all the joy I had with my favorite Elder Scrolls game, Morrowind. It's gorgeous, responsive, and using the game controller makes it much more fun than trying to slog away on the keyboard.If you haven't tried it yet and you're a fan of the series, you won't go wrong with this version. Give it a chance. I'm hooked!

My girl is a picky little effer when it comes to food and treats. I gave her a few of these and she's been begging for them ever since. First time that's happened in ages. These will definitely be my go-to snacks for her. Thanks Wellness!

I read China Mieville's "The City and The City" shortly before I read this collection. If you appreciated the complexity of "The City and The City", you'll enjoy Three Moments of an Explosion.As I learned with "The City and The City", Mieville doesn't believe in spelling everything out for the reader. This is particularly true of many of the stories in this collection. They are often difficult narratives that require an attentive reader. You're often left to fill in the blanks (or even the endings) with your own imagination. But when you do, you're rewarded with some fantastic imagery that perhaps, like me, you'll carry with you.Overall I am impressed with the quality and quantity of this book. It reminds me of a collection of fiction the likes of which you find in The New Yorker.

Really loving the Ageless La Cure Natural product line and this exfoliator is not exception. Here's why:SCENT: The product has a wonderful, herbal scent with strong notes of peppermint that evoke a relaxing spa.IT ONLY TAKES A LITTLE: Yes it's expensive; however, I use a portion about the size of a dime twice per week, so I expect this tube will last the better part of six months.LEAVES SKIN RADIANT: My skin has a glow to it now that all the old skin has been sloughed off.NATURAL: Everything about this product just FEELS organic and all natural. I love the way it goes on (and how easy it comes off).

Great product that I'm definitely adding to my regular skin-care arsenal. Here's why:CLEANS WITHOUT DRYING: I've found you often have to sacrifice one or the other--sparkling clean versus moisturized. Not with Ageless La Cure Natural. My skin has that deep-cleaned feeling coupled with hydration.HYDRATION: After 3.5 weeks of use, my skin is soft and significantly more hydrated.SCENT: A wonderful, herbal scent. I use the Ageless La Cure nightly and it's like a touch of aroma therapy before I go to sleep.FOAM: I'm typically not a lover of foam-based cleansers, but this one is fantastic. It goes on smoothly and gently.

I have a tiny, urban yard in Seattle. I have patches where I weeded. I filled the patches with new soil, spread this seed, gently raked it under with a hand rake, and watered. A week later, I'm still waiting for the Turf Builder to germinate. I'll update my review in a few weeks after it (hopefully) has started to grow, but at this point it looks pretty bleak. The weather has been mild, plenty of rain and watering, and still nothing.

I would absolutely love this hand cream and buy it regularly if it didn't smell like I just pawed around in my grandmother's purse!The product name and packaging lead me to believe that this would have and earthy, more natural smell. Something akin to Aveda or Malin & Goetz products. Instead, the scent reminds me of the strong, floral perfumes that were popular in the 1980s. AHAVA: Please get rid of the scent. It's not unisex, nor is it contemporary.Ok, now that I got that off my chest, I just want to say that the moisturizing aspect of this hand cream is fantastic! I put it on 7 hours ago and my hands are still moisturized. Unheard of considering I typically apply Lubriderm every hour.Five stars for moisturizing, minus two stars for scent.

My cat's primary meal of the day is Weruva canned food. She gets half a can each morning. The food is dense and whole and made in a human-grade food processing factory. Each evening, when I come home from work, I feed here half a cup of dry food. It keeps her from waking me up at the crack of dawn to ask for her wet food. She'll eat almost all dry foods, only occasionally does she dislike one. When I fed her the Purina Pro Plan, she loved it.Purina's come a long way over the years. They've, obviously, completely rebranded and are trying to strike a cord with high-end cat food buyers. As other reviewers have noted, this isn't the most "whole" food on the market, so I wouldn't feel comfortable with this as my cat's only source of food, but it's likely one of the better options if you're on a budget or otherwise limited to grocery-store variety cat food.

I use this for two things: (1)  Travel and (2) to hold my iPad in front of my ergometer while I work out.I recently took the RND Compact Power Station to Mexico for a week. It was ideal. I had USB ports to charge my devices bedside and could still plug in the light fixture in my room. The size of the Station fits easily in a bag. (Note it does require a grounded outlet, so if you're traveling somewhere that may not have them, bring an adapter.)As an iPad shelf, this thing is fantastic. I workout with a product called "BitGym" that allows me to "tour" scenic places while I work out. BitGym measure how quickly I'm rowing on my ergometer using the iPad's camera, so I needed something to hold it in front of the machines. This RND Compace Power Station works perfectly. Plus it charges my iPad at the same time. Love it.Overall these are a great solution for any room. If you're an Android and/or Kindle user, the charger is built in. For those of us with iOS devices, it's not as simple, but still very effective with the USB ports. Either way, the charger will support your phones, readers, and tablets while charging them and without sacrificing a traditional outlet.

As a Vine reviewer, I am required to post a review after 30 days. Because this is well under the manufacturer's suggested time with the product, this review only covers my first experience with the NuFace itself, not its effectiveness.PROSBUILD QUALITY: Other reviewers have complained about the build quality of the NuFACE, but I think it's quite nice and, as a designer, I have a pretty high bar. Granted, it looks a bit like a frog, but overall it's quite nice.ERGONOMICS: The NuFACE feels good in the hand.CONSCHARGING LIGHT: Why oh why do products intended for bedrooms and bathrooms insist on bright, blue lights? Studies show that blue light triggers the brain to wake up. The light the NuFACE emits while charging is bright enough to illuminate my entire (rather large) master bathroom. I really don't need a "Facial Trainer" to be the most prominent thing in my bathroom. Nor do I need it to trigger me to wake up every time I make a midnight pitstop. Silly and unnecessary.UNCOMFORTABLE: This isn't the most comfortable treatment. You'll feel a mild sting throughout the process. And if you have a problem with acne, forget about it. I've noticed that even the slightest facial blemish, scratch, or sunburn is irritated, rather profoundly, but the electrical current given off by the NuFace.As for effectiveness, I'll update my review after I've had more time with the product.

I've owned a small Jawbone Jambox and a Jabra Soulmate. The Braven LUX borrows from the best of the two.AESTHETICS: The LUX is classy piece of industrial design. It looks sculptural and comes in finishes that are very on trend.CONNECTIVITY: This is a mixed bag. I had no problems connecting to iOS; however, getting the LUX to connect to an Android was a huge ordeal. While iOS took about 2 minutes, Android took over 20 minutes.SOUND: The LUX doesn't have the bass you get with the Soulmate. It more resembles the sound from the small Jambox. I find that if you properly position it near a wall on a resonant surface, you can make it sound pretty good.VIBRATION: I had issues with my Jambox vibrating off of surfaces. The Soulmate designers over compensate for Jambox's flaw by creating a show-like, rubber "soul". This worked, but was ugly. The Braven LUX solved this problem elegantly. The rubber foot is more of a perch that's barely noticeable.SIZE: It's the size of a small Jambox. I like that I can connect the LUX to my iPhone and carry them around together as I'm moving through the house listening to a podcast. In addition, it's a great size for travel. The LUX will easily slip into a carry on.Overall, I love it! It's my favorite Bluetooth Speaker, hands down.

After a week of tracking what I eat for my nutritionist, she told me I need to get a lot more protein at breakfast. Coincidentally, she recommended a protein powder and Amazon Vine  already had the Vega One All-in-One en route. My nutritionist read the label and gave it a hearty two thumbs up. Here's my experience:VEGAN AND GLUTEN FREE: I'm allergic to dairy and gluten and my nutritionist told me to stay off the soy. Very limiting when it comes to all-in-one solutions. Not so with the Vega One. It doesn't have any of these items and it's fully vegan.DECENT TASTE: I'm using the Natural. It's not too sweet or too chalky--two things that usually turn me off of mixes like these. In fact, I like it straight up with water, but you can mix it into a traditional smoothie or some almond milk if you're not a fan of the taste.LOTS OF PROTEIN AND FIBER: One serving has 20g of protein and 6g of fiber. Exactly what my nutritionist was looking to add to my typical breakfast of steel-cut oatmeal.EASY TO MAKE AND STORE: It takes 5 seconds to pull this off your pantry shelf, throw a scoop in a glass, and add some water. If you're looking to supplement your diet, this is an incredibly easy way to go.REASONABLY PRICED: The 15.2 oz, small tub comes with 39 portions. At the list price, that a dollar per shake. Not bad when you compare it to similar, pre-made retail products. At Amazon's price it's significantly less.Overall, I'm excited to find a shake my nutritionist approves of that is allergen-free, easy to make, and tastes good. Thanks Vega!

The BLU Vivo Air is a smart choice for any Apple fanboy or girl to venture into the world of Android. It has the look and feel of an iPhone right down to the unboxing. After a week with Vivo Air, I'm happy to say I like it. A lot. However it has a few significant flaws that have me reaching for my iPhone after a week with it. Please note that I'm not going to make any comments here about Google's Android OS (because this is a review of the hardware and apps endemic to BLU):// PROSLOOK AND FEEL: This is a gorgeous phone. It's incredibly light-weight and just stunning. I love how it slips into my pocket and barely makes a bump. It has the outward craftsmanship  you expect from Apple.SCREEN: Gorgeous. Photos and text are crisp. A side-by-side comparison with my iPhone 6 Plus and they rendered identically. Not bad at all for the price...which brings me to:COST: $200 unlocked is a flat-out bargain for a smartphone of this caliber. Nice job BLU.CONNECTIVITY: Fantastic! I had fewer issues with WiFi and cellular than I've had with all of my previous phones. BLU definitely got this right.INCLUDED EXTRAS: It comes with a case and a screen protector in addition to the charger and headphones. Really nice perk. I only used the case and it's quite nice. Certainly good in a pinch until you find something that makes better sense for you.BATTERY: The battery life is decent considering I run my phone with every possible signal at full blast and hunting for connections. Why not? This era is about the connected self and I want to take advantage of it: Bluetooth to my Fitbit, Waze on GPS while I'm driving, and so on.// CONSSPEAKER: This is the first thing that irritated me. The speaker is terrible. Calls on speakerphone are very hard to hear. If you use your phone for GPS in your car, forget about it. This is clearly a place where BLU had to make some cuts to keep the phone thin.CAMERA: The photos out of this phone left me wanting. They're not horrible, but also not on par with what I expect in 2015. I tried a few camera apps from the Play Store and it's definitely the hardware. That said, I could totally live with this when traveling because I always have a camera with me.USER INTERFACE: BLU's on-board apps are terrible. I still cringe ever single time I get a call. In fact, when I first received a call I had absolutely no idea how to answer it. This strange card bounces up and down and you have to drag it. Not at all intuitive. (Absolutely no way to one-hand a phone call.) In fact, most of the time I just call people right back because I don't get the interface. There's something a little off about all of BLU's apps. Yes,  you can replace them from the Play Store, but you always have to deal with them in some way, at some point, since you can't delete them.SIM TRAY: Be careful here. The SIM tray has a tendency to get stuck. As someone that plans to use this phone for travel, I will be swapping a card pretty regularly. I found the only way I can get the card out is to use the SIM remover to pop the tray out as far as it will go, which for me is about the depth of a dime, and then press downward on that ledge with a micro screwdriver I uses for my glasses. It took me hours to figure this out.// SUMMARYThis is a fantastic phone for the price. Four stars because there is room for improvement with the speaker, the camera, the UI and the SIM tray. However, I wouldn't hesitate to recommend this phone to any Android user (or iPhone user for that matter). It's a great deal and perfect if you want to stay off contract or replace an on-contract phone before your contract is up. I'm going to be using this as my travel phone. It's so thin and light it's perfect for on-the-go.

I've had the Pro-ject Debut Carbon for about four months. I set the TEAC TN-300 up adjacent to the Pro-Ject. I listened to a dozen albums on both decks hooked up to an Arcam A85 amp and Blumenstein speakers. Here's my assessment:SOUND: Both decks have great sound at this price point. I used the on-board preamp on the TEAC and a Behringer Microphono PP400 with the Pro-ject. The output was essentially equal. I'd say the TEAC sounds slightly warmer. The Ortofon 2M cartridge that comes with the Pro-ject is supposed to be better than the  Audio-Technica AT95E, but I'm not hearing it. Winner: TieUSABILITY: This is where the TEAC blows away the Pro-ject. It's significantly easier to use the TEAC. The on/off switch is on top of the deck; whereas the Pro-ject's is underneath. The TEAC's cue lever has a richer feel to it and the tone arm has more presence. If you want to listen to 45 rpm records on the Pro-ject it's an ordeal. You have to take the platter off and move the belt (this doesn't sound like as much of a nuisance as it becomes, trust me). On the TEAC, the rpm switch is adjacent to the on/off switch. I tested a long-playing 45 rpm on both decks and it was so wonderful to just flip the switch on the TEAC. Winner: Hand's down the TEAC.APPEARANCE: What drew me to the Pro-ject Debut Carbon was its simple aesthetic. It really is a gorgeous piece of artwork for the minimalist at heart. The TEAC is a beautiful machine in its own right (it has a 70's feel, which I love), but there's something sculptural about the Pro-ject that I find more compelling. Winner: Pro-jectVIBRATION: The Pro-ject deck is more substantial. However, its sturdiness makes it prone to vibration. The TEAC's lighter and is coupled with shock absorbent feet that really do work. Winner: TEACSETUP: The counterbalance and anti-skating were significantly easier to setup on the TEAC. In my time with the Pro-ject I've had trouble with the anti-skate weight coming loose--it's held in place by a piece of fishing line. Winner: TEACEXTRAS: Both decks come with dust covers. The Pro-ject's includes an unsightly logo on top. The TEAC's comes with some useful, rubber feet. The TEAC also includes a rubber mat that is substantially nicer than the flimsy piece of felt that comes with the Pro-ject (you'll have to replace it because it will cling to your records). The TEAC also comes with an electrical cord with swappable US and European plugs. Both units include cables, but the Pro-ject's has built-in grounding wires. The TEAC includes a USB cable. (For the record, I think TEAC could have left out the USB functionality as I suspect its superfluous quality will turn off purists.) Winner: TEACSUMMARY: Overall I'm actually quite surprised I'm giving this one to TEAC. I'm torn because I truly love the simple look of my white, Pro-ject deck, but I've fallen for the usability and slightly warmer sound of the TEAC.

I used to use a traditional pay-per-month system from a big-name security company. However, the system was prone to false alarms, sending the police out and regularly netting me a ticket. The cost of the tickets coupled with the monthly charge and general hassle became to much. Enter SABRE wireless alarms. I've been using a SABRE system for a couple of years now and it's great.PROS1. GREAT FOR PETS: If you have pets, motion-sensitive systems are a no-go. With a SABRE system, you can alarm all of your windows and doors without the need for a motion detector (the go-to choice of monitored systems) or invasive wiring.2. SIMPLE: Put the alarms where you need them, using a very light-weight, unobtrusive setup. Door alarm is simple and the minimal keypad is all that's needed.3. SET AND FORGET: Until the batteries need refreshing, you can pretty much set these alarms on your first floor windows and forget about them. No other maintenance is required.4. EXPANDABLE: Need more units? Add more units. You can also mix and match from different similar companies based on your needs.5. LOUD: When activated, these are loud. Great for deterring theft, but don't forget to tell visitors, house keepers, and family members that you've installed these. Otherwise you might subject someone to heart failure.CONS1. DOOR UNIT HEFT: The door unit is clunky and a bit unsightly.I've recommended SABRE systems to several of my friends and everyone's been happy with the product.

As a Seattleite and avid Sleater-Kinney fan in the 90s, I was a bit skeptical about the stalwart riotgrrls return. Could they revive their classic sound a decade later? Should they?This album is a definite departure from the Sleater-Kinney we once knew. While they didn't completely divorce from Corin's signature caterwauling or the staccato of Carrie's guitar riffs, they substantially massaged these hallmark sounds to produce their most refined and mature album to date.No Cities To Love is filled with a new-found musicality that will please old fans and welcome many new ones. I'm loving it and I'm loving this new direction. Thanks SK!

My adult acne results from a combination of stress and hormones. So far, I'm having good results with this system. It's been almost 30 days, and took about 25 to really start working. I actually like it when a product takes a while to work because the effects usually last longer. Some highlights from my experience:1. PERFECT SCENT PROFILE: Finally a product that doesn't smell like cheap perfume. The Benzac system has a pleasant, herbal scent that smells great going on your body but quickly fades. Fantastic. I'm so tired of products trying to compete to be THE smell on my body. Hey companies: I choose cologne for that. I don't want to smell like my acne product. Ok?2. BALANCED AMOUNT OF PRODUCT: This system comes with three steps. I've tried many multi-step systems and I dislike it when one or two bottles run out way before the other(s). It ends up being wasteful--particularly with products that are only sold in kits. The Benzac system is well balanced--the bottles are each about 2/3rds empty after a month of daily use.3. SKIN ISN'T OVERLY DRY: We all know that acne systems dry out your skin and can create a vicious cycle of clearing your skin only to have the requisite moisturizing create further acne troubles. This system isn't drying my skin out like others do. I love that the lotion aspect goes on lightly and leaves my skin feeling soft.I think this is a system I will continue using. It's reasonably priced and has good results.

I hated the flavor and waste of microwave popcorn, so I used to make it in a pot on my stove top. What a time-consuming pain! Not anymore. I buy delicious organic corn in bulk at my local natural foods store, add 1/2 a cup to two TBs of olive oil, 2.5 minutes in the microwave and voila! Toss it with a little truffle salt and I instantly have a gourmet snack that tastes the way I want it to.Clean up is easy, too. I put the two clear pieces in the dishwasher and set the cardboard concentrator and black base aside.These are going to be my gifts of choice moving forward.

Not what I expected at all! The scent of this product anything but subtle. I couldn't detect a hint of lavender or chamomile. The smell is more akin to the extreme air fresheners found in bathrooms at airports and stadiums.I can't imagine anything about this ZzzQuil product is good for you--the box even tells you not to touch the pads and to wash your skin if it comes in contact with the pads. Really? How are you supposed to get them in there? In addition, we know it's certainly not real lavender and chamomile that could warrant such a warning. What's actually in this thing? Can't be good because after half a night with this plugged in, my nose was stuffed up and my eyes were burning.I'd recommend getting a simple, lavender sheet spray. This chemical blaster is not the way to go.

I just finished using the Tacwise to reupholster four dining room chairs. Here's my experience:PROS• Inexpensive.• It's lightweight and reasonably comfortable.• Easy to use.CONS• Feels cheap and not very durable.•Lacks power. I had to use a hammer to make about 80% of the staples flush with the base of the chair seat. The gun just wasn't powerful enough to drive the included staples completely into the wood. (Note: I was using a woven, Knoll fabric and not vinyl or leather, so I expected better penetration.)Overall, I'd recommend the Tacwise Z1-140 for light duty, home use.

Love.This.Scale! I replaced the cheap scale I bought from Ikea with this Taylor scale. I had no idea what a difference a nice scale could make. They always seemed like a boring, but necessary, tool. Not only does the Taylor scale look gorgeous in my bathroom—like a floating piece of silver glass—but the digital output is fast and accurate. The surface area is large making it easy to stumble onto in the morning and the digits are large enough to read without my glasses. Excellent.Only negative: The surface is SLICK. I almost slid off the thing when I hopped on in socks. Best to use with bare feet!

These measuring spoons are exactly what you'd expect from OXO: Durable and easy to handle. They're perfectly suitable for any practical kitchen.The only negative I've found is the "unique snapping feature". I don't need my measuring spoons to snap so I can "fan the spoons out". Seriously? What product manager thought this was a good idea? It makes it difficult to store the spoons anyway other than snapped together. Unnecessary gimmick. (Plus I found them somewhat difficult to unsnap and resnap--interesting considering the OXO line was historically intended for people with arthritis.)

I applied this to the locking side of my front door, which had shifted and was a drafty. The weatherstripping was incredibly easy to use. It's a solid strip of pliable rubber that feels like a marshmallow and conforms to seal uneven nooks and crannies.I was worried it wouldn't adhere because the door frame was so cold, but it wasn't a problem. The draft issue was solved!A week after I applied it, I had to remove it for a locksmith to do some work. The Rubber Weather came off as easily as it went on.All in all a simple, effective, and reasonably priced product that is worth a look if you have drafty windows or doors.

As a professional user experience designer, I've been evaluating prototyping tools for my team to use. Since my company subscribes to Adobe Creative Cloud, I decided to give Muse a try.What Asch offers us is a step-by-step tutorial for how to build a pre-packaged, 2004-era website. I'm not sure how the title can be called "Creative Web Design" when it's basically a paint-by-numbers book to build exactly one website--the one supplied by the author.  In addition, the workflow it proposes doesn't work with the actual process of conceptualizing a site and building it from scratch. It only works with this kit-of-parts approach to build the tutorial site. Frankly, I wouldn't even recommend this book to someone looking to get into web design because the tutorial workflow would only establish bad habits.I found myself frustrated from the moment I opened the book. I was expecting to use the book to help me translate my already vast of creative web design into Muse. But the book offered no help there, because it's organized in a way that only fosters building the sample site. I found myself wondering why Asch didn't take a more task-based approach that explained things like how to use Muse to setup your information architecture. What to do to translate existing web pages or content into the Muse environment. And how the software's new design environment might fit into an existing workflow.Overall, this book is a poor choice for the professional or anyone with web experience that's interested in adding Adobe Muse to his or her toolkit. If the title were more up front about what the book is, I could give this more stars.

I reconfigured my den to install this projector and centered my system around Apple's Airplay. My goals were to (1) keep the system simple with as few wires as possible, (2) focus on setup for movies, assuming that live tv, games, and sports would remain in the living room, and (3) compliment the projector with equipment I already have. Here's what I came up with:WALL MOUNTFirst things first, I needed to mount it. I used the Cheetah Mounts AS1S Single Shelf TV Component Wall Mount Shelving Bracket with 18x16" Shelf, 15' Twisted Veins HDMI Cable and Cable Management for Cable or Satellite Box, DVD Player, Game Station, Receiver, etc., and Compatible with all LCD LED Plasma F... and it fits perfectly. I'm projecting directly onto a wall with light, taupe paint that's about the same hue as a silver screen. The image is crisp and clear and Epson provides a variety of ways to fine tune your image to your configuration and lighting situation.The PowerLite 3000 comes with two HDMI inputs. I dedicated one to an Apple TV MD199LL/A (Current Version) and attached the 15-foot HDMI cable that came with my Cheetah Mounts shelf to the other (to give me the option to attach my Macbook Air). The tiny Apple TV sits neatly behind my projector on the shelf.AUDIOThe PowerLite 3000 doesn't come with audio out, so you either need to incorporate an A/V receiver between your sources and the projector or use a system built around a wireless technology like Airplay. I chose the latter since I already have an A/V receiver setup in my living room and I didn't want to either invest in or give space over to another one.As a result, I decided to build my sound system around a Tivoli Audio Model Two AM / FM Radio, Black/Silver Finish and Tivoli Audio Model Subwoofer (Walnut/Beige) connected to an Apple AirPort Express Base Station (MC414LL/A) for 2.1 audio. The Tivoli over Airplay provides a beautiful, warm sound reminiscent of a movie theater. (In addition, it's a great little music system for iTunes via the same setup.)APPLE TV (AND HOW I GET AMAZON PRIME)Apple TV gives me my primary sources of movie content (i.e., Netflix, HBO Go, and Showtime Anytime); however, it lacks Amazon Prime Video. Amazon's iOS apps allow you to use Airplay via Apple TV to play Prime content. However, I had significant trouble with audio sync (Airplay from iOS to Apple TV to Airport Express broke down). In order to access Amazon Prime, I've been using my Macbook Air connected to an HDMI cable with one of these: AmazonBasics Mini DisplayPort (Thunderbolt) to HDMI Adapter. For audio, I unplug the 3.5mm cable from my Airport and plug it into the Air. It's not pretty, but it keeps the audio in sync and the picture is quite good.ROKUBecause I already have a Roku 3500R Streaming Stick (HDMI), I plugged it in and was able to get excellent video quality out of the Epson, unfortunately, the Roku won't broadcast audio to the Airport, so requires an A/V receiver.CONCLUSIONOverall I'm thrilled with this projector. It's perfect for any movie enthusiast that wants a projector that is focused on throwing up a fantastic picture. It is not intended to be the hub of your system and will require an A/V receiver to output wired sound. However, pairing it with an Airplay system is a great way to avoid the bulk and cost of an A/V receiver.

I'm disappointed as I had high hopes for this little guy. Perhaps my copy wasn't properly balanced, but it was nearly impossible to fly. In fact, the Kodo such a lilt that it blew into a neighboring construction site and is gone forever. Either it's too difficult for an adult (who works as a user-interface designer for one of the largest high-tech companies) to fly or it suffers from poor quality control. Either way, you can find something far more reliable and/or entertaining for you money.

Worth the money. Cork is a wonderful surface for your vinyl. It helps reduce static and vibration. In addition, it looks great. I replaced the thin felt mat that came with my Pro-ject Debut Carbon 2M-R turntable with this 1/8" mat and it's a drastic improvement. Not only is it a functional addition to your deck, but it looks retro-modern.

I love this spill-proof travel mug and haven't had any of the upper-lip-burn problems that other reviewers mentioned.PROS1. SPILL PROOF--In locked position, I carried this thing around upside down to see if it would spill. Nope! Leak free. I would actually carry this mug INSIDE my bag. I'm that confident it won't spill.2. CLEAN DESIGN--Very simple and attractive design.3. CLEVER SEAL--It took a bit of getting used to, but opening the mug by popping the SnapSeal is a great way to keep the area of the mug that touches your mouth clean. In addition, I loathe that the seals on other mugs flip down and hit my upper lip or nose as I'm drinking. Really great design.4. MAINTAINS TEMPERATURE--I filled the mug with coffee and it was still hot after four hours of opening and closing the seal.5. EASY TO CLEAN--The mouth piece of this mug is very easy to keep clean.CONS1. SNAPSEAL A LITTLE TIGHT--Sometimes the SnapSeal can be a little difficult to pop when you're driving. It's tight. But that also means it prevents spills.Priced about 30% below the travel mug I used to use, I'd definitely recommend trying this mug to see if it's right for you.

I've been using Cascade Complete pods (one down from this Platinum) since my local big-box membership club started carrying them. For this review I was able to compare Cascade Complete to Cascade Platinum by doing back-to-back loads of dishes in a Fisher & Paykel dishwasher. I typically include two sections in my reviews: Pros and Cons. However, I don't have a single negative to report with Cascade Platinum pods.CONVENIENT: I am sold on all things "pod". I use pods for my dishwasher and washing machine. They prevent mess and eliminate the need to measure products. I'll never go back to traditional powdered or liquid products.CLEAN: Both Cascade Complete and Platinum clean your dishes exceptionally well.* I am not particularly good at pre-rinsing my dishes and Cascade is able to handle crusted on items. Since I started using Cascade pods, my glassware looks fantastic.DISHWASHER CLEAN: Cascade Platinum advertises (see photo in photos section) that it cleans your dishwasher in addition to cleaning your dishes. I have noticed that my dishwasher is cleaner since I switched to the Platinum pods.Overall,  I'm completely sold on Cascade pods for my dishwasher.If you're curious about the difference between Complete and Platinum, I posted a side-by-side picture coupled with a feature comparison chart in the photos section to accompany this review.* According to the comparison chart (see photo in photos section), Platinum adds "Sparkling Clean Silverware" and "Helps Keep Dishwasher Sparkling". I compared my silverware from two similar loads, one using Complete and one using Platinum. I didn't notice either batch having more "sparkle", but overall the Platinum seemed a little cleaner.

I'm usually disappointed with the texture of heavy-duty lotions. I often feel like my skin can't breathe after applying them. This Curel lotion feels light and breathable. Such a welcome relief. I've been using this lotion for about a month now on my elbows and legs where my skin tends to get rough and flakey. It's noticeably smoother and silkier than when I started.

I used to use Feline Pine, but my little adopted cat was declawed and the Feline Pine pellets hurt her feet. So I moved to a litter that is gentler on her feet. I was hoping this Paper Cat Litter would be a nice compromise: Soft on the cats feet with the feel-good benefits of a natural litter, like Feline Pine. There's a lot to like about this litter, but I'm not completely sold. Here's why:THE GOOD1. LIGHT-WEIGHT BOX: Litters are typically so heavy. To get a reasonable supply, I often risk throwing out my back. okocat Natural Paper Cat Litter feels feather-like in comparison.2. ENVIRONMENTALLY FRIENDLY: You can feel good using this product because it's recycled.THE BAD1. PELLETS EVERYWHERE. The pellets are all over the house. For some reason, the paper sticks to my cat.2. DIFFICULT TO SCOOP. The litter doesn't break down well, so scooping ends up removing more of the good pellets than the bad.3. SMELLY. Doesn't mask the smell as well as litters like Feline Pine.

I'm giving these treats 3 start--the average of two reviews from two separate cats.THE ONE STAR REVIEWLet's start with my cat. I saved these for the most stressful of all days: The Fourth of July. I couldn't imagine a more perfect test case. Unfortunately, when I called her to the treating zone in my house and presented two of the Calming treats, she sniffed them, made the most disgusted face I'd ever seen her make, backed up, and ran away. Well, that was a surprise coming from a cat that will try anything.THE FIVE STAR REVIEWAfter my cat's disgusted response, I brought the treats over to my friends' house. Their cat loves them and responded well to them and remained social during a rather large BBQ (an event that would typically result in hiding).Hopefully your cat will have the positive experience that my friends' cat had!

Not a single negative to report. I recently tired of lugging my DSLR around and picked up a Sony DSC-RX100M II. With my DSLR, I didn't mind carrying a little box filled with SD cards because I typically carried a camera bag as well. With the tiny Sony, I only carry the camera, so having one, huge, Class 10 SD card that could hold a week's worth of vacation photos is exactly what I needed.I've taken photos at two weddings and a few other outings with the 64GB Pro SDXC and I'm thrilled. I've been able to snap quick photos with no write delay, take some videos, and generally just use my camera exactly as I want to. But where this card has really shined in my workflow is when I get home. I can pop the card out of my camera, pop it into my Mac, and Aperture pulls the images of the card with speeds I haven't seen before. In the past, I've typically plugged the card in my computer and left to do other things because it would take ages to transfer the images. Now I can wait and watch as the image pour off the card quickly. Awesome!So pleased to add this little guy to my new mini-kit!

UPDATE: Changing from 3 stars to 1 star. Soap is seeping into the bottom of other compartments because of poor workmanship. Throwing it in the trash! What a waste.___Does a nice job of gathering together a few of the things that typically clutter up a kitchen or bathroom counter. Coincidentally, my bathroom soap dispenser broke just before this caddy arrived. So I had a need for it. I probably wouldn't have chosen this one because the price is a little high for a plastic soap dispenser. Here are my thoughts:PROS* Nice to have two containers to corral things like tooth brushes, combs, hair brushes, and cotton swabs.* Great space saver for a small spot by the bathroom sink.CONS* Should cost half the price. The unit is made of light-weight plastic.* The worst problem I've found is that the pump doesn't screw into place. It just sits on top of the soap dispenser. Anytime you want to move something from another compartment, you risk dislodging the pump. Obviously this can be a messy situation as the tube that dangles from the pump can fling soap everywhere.Overall, it's a pretty clever design, but it needs a few refinements in build quality to make it worth this price point.

First the good: The smell and texture of this product is outstanding. I've been using similar, much more expensive products by Kiehl's and Vivite and this has the best texture. It's cooling, feels great on the skin, is organic, and not tested on animals. At this price point I was looking forward to replacing those other products.Now the bad: You can imagine my disappointment when after several days of using it, my face and neck broke out severely.Even though my experience was poor, I'm giving it three stars because I think the product is good and my experience isn't the norm--just try it on a small patch of skin for a few days before you slather it on like I did!

I've had a few iHomes and this is the first one that feels substantial and not like another piece of landfill plastic.PROS• PLUG AND PLAY: Snapped my iPhone into place and the clock immediately synced. I was able to enjoy music from my iPhone seconds later.• BUILD QUALITY: The unit feels solid and the buttons are tactile and have the right amount of play.• APPEARANCE: Looks great. The unit has a nice, small footprint that is suitable for a nightstand or desk (where I have mine).• SOUND: The sound is very similar to a Jambox; ergo, it's quite good for the small size. In fact, I'm surprised by how much base this iHome puts out (particularly when situated close to a wall).• WORKS WITH CASE: I had to slightly modify my iPhone's case by trimming the plastic a bit around the lightning jack, but otherwise it works just fine with the case on.CONS• CONFUSING BUTTONS: The "-" and "+" buttons are used to change FM stations and to skip tracks on your iPhone/iPod. However, those icons and their placement are confusing. I keep hitting them to adjust the volume and end up skipping tracks or changing channels.• NO AUX JACK: It would be nice to have an AUX jack for easy use with non-Lightning music players (i.e., this is pretty standard fare and found on Jamboxes to Tivoli radios).Overall, a great little unit. Mine's in my office and I'm enjoying the new Lana Del Rey as I write this!

I'm a big fan of Manhattan Portage. I've owned several of their bags. I've only ever replaced an MP bag because it no longer suited my needs, never because it showed signs of wear.This time around I wanted a simple, stylish backpack in black.PROS1. TIMELESS: The look of the bag is timeless.2. VERSATILE: The simplicity of the bag makes it ideal for many purposes--travel, book bag, gym bag, electronics, and so on.3. LARGE BUCKET COMPARTMENT: The main compartment is nice and large. The drawstring coupled with the secure top flap make anything in the main pocket safe from rain and prying hands. I can fit a sweatshirt in there, a laptop in a case, camera equipment. You name it.4. BACK AND STRAP PADDING: The back of the bag is well padded and feels great. Even with larger loads. The stap padding is ample. These are not the most ergonomic straps when carrying heavy loads, but they have ample padding and a slip-free material that keeps them from moving around.5. SPACIOUS FRONT POCKETS: I can fit everything I need quick access to in the front pockets. They're great for sunglasses (in the case), wallets, work badges, even my Kindle Paperwhite fits in the front, snap pocket.6. TOP HANDLE: This is one of the things I count as a must have on my bags.CONS1. EXPENSIVE: This bag is pricey for how simple it is.2. NO BOTTOM PADDING: I would like this bag more if it had just a hint of padding on the bottom of the main bucket. Whenever I set my bag on the floor there's a "clunk" as the contents make direct contact with the surface.Overall, the cons are negligible and I'd certainly recommend this good looking bag to anyone.

Love it! I've owned many portable chargers. All of them languish in a drawer. Usually because they can't hold a charge and are useless when I actually need them. I've been testing this Power Pack for a month and it's great. For about the size of a compact camera, you can be sure you'll have power when you really need. Super useful for festivals, days at the beach, camping, etc. This is the charger I'm keeping with me now.PROS• Dual amp power ports allow you to charge larger devices, like tablets and camera.• The Power Pack has been able to fully charge my iPhone 5, Sony RX100 ii camera, and Dell Venue 8 Pro tablet.• When the Power Pack is full, it can provide multiple charges. Fantastic!• It's reasonably light considering the substantial power it has.• I actually like that Belkin didn't include a wall outlet. I have so many of them from other devices.CONS• None

I wouldn't recommend this trimmer to a friend. It's a LOT of trimmer for a very LITTLE benefit. The lack of line feeding alone is enough to drive you mad.PROS1. INEXPENSIVE.2. POWERFUL. I have a small yard that I typically mow with an old-fashioned, manual push mower. Oftentimes I will go over the yard with a trimmer before I use the push mower  to handle thick and weedy patches. This trimmer does a great job in that respect.CONS1. LINE WON'T FEED. I have to take the line housing apart at least 3 times every single time I trim. And my yard is not large! This is infinitely frustrating and renders this trimmer almost unusable for anything but the smallest of projects.2. EDGING IS HORRIBLE. First off, trying to edge just chews the line to pieces...resulting in repeated problems with CON #1. In addition, I can never seem to get a nice, straight edge despite following the instructions in the manual. Just can't do it.3. HEAVY. This thing weighs a LOT for an electric trimmer. Wow. The weight makes it somewhat difficult to control. (I've also used a trimmer that was too light, and equally difficult to control. So there's obviously a sweet spot. And it's not being met here.)

The Karcher Pressure Washer did a great job cleaning my deck and walkway; however, I spent a ridiculous amount of time putting it together and other than the main body of the unit, I don't predict the kind of longevity I'd expect for the price. Rating: Average (3 stars).PROS1. WORKS. The unit cleans well. My deck and walkway look great.CONS1. SLIPSHOD WORKMANSHIP HINDERS ASSEMBLY. It took forever to put together. The pieces don't align well. When attempting to attach the top piece to the main body of the unit, the screw housing piece broke off. This seemed like an absurd amount of assembly.2. QUESTIONABLE LONGEVITY. The unit is rickety. The wheels are practically useless, but very necessary for how heavy it is.3. ENORMOUS PLUB. The outlet plug is large than my outdoor socket housing and didn't seat well.4. REQUIRES STRICT PERPENDICULAR APPLICATION. To get the unit to clean my deck and walkway, I had to a aim the water perpendicular to the surface I was washing. I couldn't angle it like hosing off a sidewalk. This made cleaning horizontal surfaces very time consuming as it limited the surface area I could attack and made for an awkward cleaning stance.

I'm a user experience designer. This book interested me because my target market is often the demographic that Dana Boyd researches. This books sheds significant light on how teenagers are actually using tools like Facebook and Twitter. And it may not be how you think they are. It's Complicated is peppered useful information that is presented in a legible way that omits the heavy-handed approach often found in short-form writing on the topic. For example, Dana Boyd unpacks the teenage population's reliance on social media with regard to their shrinking access to time to congregate and the places to do so. Social media for teens IS their public space, they way shopping malls and parks were to generations before them. They quickly access and connect with their friends in a meaningful way when all of their free time is spent garnering activities and achievements that will help them get into college.This book isn't just for the parents of teenagers or those who work with that population. It's for anyone thinking about what space and place mean in a culture where these things are increasingly restricted or privatized in the physical world. It challenges us to think about place-making online as a necessary component of human connection.

The book showcases a selection of photographs from 11 National Geographic photographers. Each woman's work is preceded by her photograph, a thoughtful quote showcasing her vision, and a brief biography. The photos are expertly curated and peppered with additional quotes from the photographer about what she's trying to achieve on the assignment; concurrently telling the story of the photographer and the assignment.As an amateur photographer, I found the coupling of the photographs with the quotes and biographies compelling. I'm often impressed by an excellent composition or technically difficult shot, but this collection demonstrates the magic that happens when the photographer goes deeper into the spiritual place that all of these women find in their work. Even when that place is incredibly demanding. Truly inspiring!Women of Vision is an exciting collection that deserves a spot on any discerning coffee table.

I've been using the Friedrich 5-Stage Air Purifier for three weeks. I'm allergic to dust, mold, and pollen. My cat is constantly stirring up dust, I live in the Pacific Northwest where mold is rampant, and it's now Spring and everything is blooming. Ergo, it's a perfect time to test an air purifier.Despite all of my allergies, I've never tried air purification. After three weeks of sleeping better and displaying significantly less night-time congestion (the unit is in my bedroom), I'm sold on air purification, but I think Friedrich could improve a few things with the unit.PROS* CLEAN AIR:  Definitely clearing the air of dust, pollen, and pet dander  in my bedroom. Sleep is restful and significantly reduced congestion. The air in my bedroom just feels cleaner than the rest of the house.* INDUSTRIAL DESIGN: Overall the unit looks modern and is well-designed except for the dashboard display (see below).* INEXPENSIVE TO OPERATE: I ran the unit 24/7 and I just received my electric bill and there was a barely noticeable increase over the same period last year. Coupled with the annual cost of Friedrich AP260HFRK Annual HEPA Filter Replacement Kit for AP260  I'm guessing the Friedrich costs about $10/month--definitely worth a few bucks a week to sleep well!CONS* LARGE: The Friedrich is about the size of a roll-aboard piece of luggage. So it is definitely noticeable in your room.* DASHBOARD DISPLAY: Why does it need to have all of these bright, obnoxious lights on the front of the unit? I want this thing to go unnoticed, not to scream "look at me, look at me!" I'd much rather have the control panel on the back, leaving the front unblemished by something that looks like a children's toy from the movie Tron. Whoever made the decision to "showcase" the dashboard on this thing should be fired.* NOISY: The Plasma Filter sounds like a squeaking fan. I only turn this on when I won't be in the room. It's obnoxious and at first I thought the unit needed lubrication.

I've used this conditioner for almost a week and my hair is responding to it well. It's been a really dry winter and my previous brand seemed to be leaching any moisture out of my hair. I'm using both the Toni & Guy Shampoo and Conditioner for Damage Hair and I've noted a marked increase in moisture. My one complain is the smell. These products smell like cheap perfume. I far prefer the more modern, herbal scents of products like Aveda. Fortunately, the smell doesn't seem to last.

I've used this shampoo for almost a week and my hair is responding to it well. It's been a really dry winter and my previous shampoo seemed to be leaching any moisture out of my hair. I'm using both the Toni & Guy Shampoo and Conditioner for Damage Hair and I've noted a marked increase in moisture. My one complain is the smell. These products smell like cheap perfume. I far prefer the more modern, herbal scents of products like Aveda. Fortunately, the smell doesn't seem to last.

Like other reviewers, I find this texturising spray to work very well. I have a lot of very fine, short hair. I use texturizing sprays too help manage my mane, which can get a little unruly depending on the conditions (e.g., moisture in the air, wind, etc.). I've been using this spray for a few, blustery days and it's working well. The hold isn't too stiff and lasts all day. I can do without the perfume smell; however, I have noticed that it doesn't seem to be as pronounced once it's applied and doesn't bother me throughout the day like some other products have. Overall I think this product is excellent considering it's about half the price of similar sprays.

This is exactly what I wanted for my new MBA! It protects the Air without the extra weight  and bulk of materials like neoprene and leather and does without the damaging friction of zippers. The Acme case fits snuggly and lets my MBA slip into incredibly small bags. In addition, when I'm using my Air I set it on top of the case, which acts as a placemat on tables and a cushion on my lap. Wonderful!

I've been PC gaming for about two and a half years now.  I've long wanted to try a mechanical keyboard, having heard they are essential to gamers.  As such, I jumped at the opportunity to use the Lenovo Y Gaming Mechanical Keyboards.  I'm new to mechanical keyboards, so I can't speak authoritatively on the technical specifications, so I'll focus more on gaming use, feel, etc.First off, this is one sharp looking keyboard.  I live the red glow.  Very sharp.  Having not used mechanical keyboards before, I can't compare this one to others, but the build feels pretty solid.  I was a bit surprised that it's entirely plastic (or at least I think it is).  It's neither here nor there, but just an observation.The keyboard's profile feels a bit taller than regular keyboards, so the removable wrist plate is probably better left in place.  I think it'll make a huge difference in typing and gaming, otherwise your wrists might get a bit tired.One thing I've noticed is that I've had to adjust my typing a little bit.  With most keyboards, I'm able to rest my fingers on the keys without any issues.  The Lenovo is so sensitive that you sometimes inadvertently hit keys even you don't actually depress them.  If you press the keys even gently to the side without the key actually clicking, it will register.  Consequently I find myself backspacing and correcting much more than I used to.  I'm sure it's only a matter of getting used to it, but it is an adjustment.I've used this keyboard to play Dead Island, Assassin's Creed Revelations, Black Ops, and a few others and I found that it responds quite well.  I didn't experience any issues whatsoever.All in all, I find this to be a great keyboard, especially once one adjusts to it.  I've added a photograph.  Hope it helps!

We love trains in our house and have a lot of wooden train tracks. This type of train track is new for us, but my boy (almost 3) was just tickled to see a choo choo train and new tracks! Really, is there anything that little boys love more than trains?  I don't think so.Set up is easy and quick.  It took no time at all.  We love that there is no batteries to deal with (a big plus) and that my boy can scoot around to make this train go. It doesn't stay on track very well, but that doesn't stop my boy from trying over and over again to get the wheels lined up!We look forward to putting it under the Christmas tree for a simple decoration. I do wish there were more tracks but my children are easy to please!

We are big fans of Fisher Price old school cash register, in fact, we have two!  Out of the box, both my children were interested in this Melissa and Dough wooden  cash register, their ages being 2 and 4. I like the simple design basic functions, however, 3 coins is not enough. This toy holds their attention for 10 minutes, then they're off to other toys, but will come back to visit it. My older toddler plays "store" quite often, so my son enjoys playing along on this machine with her.  The only drawback, as many others have noted, is the drawer catching and not always opening, but easy to look over.

I've tried two Travel Money Belts in the last couple weeks and each has their own merits, which I'll get into at the end, but let's go over the basics and some thoughts about the Hopsooken.The Hopsooker is comparable in size to other travel money belts out there.  I did notice that's a bit lighter, probably because of the lack of an interior carabiner hook.  It has the standard two pockets - main and exterior - and the interior pocket has two mesh pockets sewn into the lining for keys, change, or other small items.  As far as I can tell, it's quite durable and should last a lifetime if well maintained and cleaned.The real only difference between the two is 1) the Hopsooken doesn't have the interior carabiner clip.  It may not be a big deal for some, but something to consider.  2) The upside is that this is $10 cheaper than the other brand, so there's significant savings to be had.My only idea for improvements would be to add another 4 inches the elastic band.  I'm an average-sized guy at 5'11'', 185 lbs.  Even at my size this belt was tighter than I'd like.  It's definitely made for slender/slim people.  It's neither here nor there, just an observation.**Disclaimer - the manufacturer sent me a free review sample in exchange for my honest review**

This is the kind of product I could never have come up with myself, but after using it I have to say that it's kind of brilliant.  I'll make this short and sweet, so let's get to it.1)  This sucker is BRIGHT.  That's a good thing for people who may have trouble seeing in darker environments.  The light, however, is extremely focused, so it's not going to light up a room or disturb your bed mate.2)  It's very flexible.  I don't know what it's made of, but this thing is very flexible and holds its position very well.  It's not going to move or bend unless you do it or bump it into something.3)  Cheap!  $5.99?  Are you kidding me?  Great deal.  Pull the trigger.The only improvement I would recommend is that they make it a bit longer, or make a longer version of it.  It's 6.5 inches long, which is perfectly fine, but if it were a bit longer,  it might be a bit more useful to some folks.*Disclaimer - the seller provided me a free review sample in exchange for my unbiased review.*

The 100 Vintage Bottle Caps collection is, for the most part, pretty good.  I don't think "Vintage" is the appropriate description, however.  They may be "vintage-inspired," but definitely not vintage.  I had modern-looking caps for Sprite, for example. Some of the caps designs that read "China Cola" and "Pour hard for bubbles" and other kind of nonsensical things.  The colors, however, are quite nice and I was very impressed with the over designs.But perhaps most discouragingly, a full 12% (12 out of 100) were of a wolf (see photo).  Since when are wolves vintage?  It seems to me like it was filler and honestly, it was pretty disappointing since I have absolutely no use for a wolf bottle cap.I probably wouldn't buy these again, but if you don't mind non-vintage caps or questionable designs, then they're probably suitable for your project.

I had no idea that fanny packs had undergone a redesign for the new century.  It makes sense if you think about, though, because we unfortunately live in a world full of cheaters and deceivers and taking precaution with your data and information is extremely important.The Zero Grid Money Belt is a great accessory for protecting your stuff.  At 11.5 inches long and 6 inches tall, there's plenty of room to store plenty of important things.
