There are two main pockets, with the larger pocket containing to pockets sewn into the  outer lining for things like change, etc. There's also a carabiner clip for keys.  Nice touch.  I have another RFID money belt without the carabiner clip, so it's a nice bonus, but it also makes a few ounces heavier (though still extremely light and manageable).The Zero Grid is awesome for people who bike, walk, or push their children along in a stroller.  You'll have everything at your reach, yet it's completely concealed if you pull your shirt over the top of it.  It's a great product and recommend it with all confidence.*Disclosure:  the seller provided a review sample free of charge in exchange for my honest opinion*

I have to admit:  this is the first time I've slept on a silk pillowcase.  I can also say I absolutely love it.  The presentation of this silk pillow is quite nice.  It comes packaged neatly in a black box with the logo stamped in wax.  Very fancy.The pillow case itself is very nice.  It's silky-smooth and for me people like me, the coolness of the silk is terrific.  I run very hot and I'm always hot, so a nice cool pillowcase is paramount for a good night's sleep.  For this reason alone it's well worth the $20 price point.The case also runs a bit larger than the average pillow, which is great because assuming that there's some natural variation in pillow sizes.  This pillowcase should fit just about any bed pillow.  The hidden zipper is a nice touch, too.  I love it.*Disclaimer:  the seller provided a free sample for review in exchange for my unbiased opinion*
1:31 Mins Please see our video review!

I have to say that I was pleasantly surprised by the Jelly Comb 2-port USB car charger.  I recently had the opportunity review a USB charger by Haweel, which is great, and I can easily state that the Jelly Comb is just a great as the Haweel.As far as the design, the Jelly Comb is sleek and smart looking.  It's got a slightly futuristic look to it.  I imagine that is the crew of the USS Enterprise used USB chargers, they'd use these.Of course function over form is paramount with these devices and the Jelly Comb excels on all levels.  First of all, it's very convenient.  It's slim design makes it easy to transport in a backpack, purse, or even your pocket.  The dual USB ports means you won't have to fight with anyone else over its use, which is nice.What I didn't expect is that it's also an auxiliary power source.  Before I even plugged it in the first time, I hit the power button on the top, plugged in my phone, and it started charging up.  Didn't see that coming, but it's a very, very nice feature.  I appreciated that aspect of it.It appears its currently unavailable for purchase via amazon, but if and when it becomes available again, I wholeheartedly recommend this dual USB charger.  And by way of disclosure, I received a free review sample from the manufacturer in exchange for my review.

Chances are there will come a time when you find yourself in a tight spot.  And when you find yourself in that tight spot, you need to be prepared.  After using the Pocket Chainsaw, I can state that this little gadget should be a part of your emergency kit, bug out bag, etc.As many others have noted, this is not in any way, shape for form, a replacement for an electric chainsaw nor is appropriate for mature trees.  This is for branches, 2x4's, etc.  In the event there's an earthquake or other natural disasterAlso, it's a GREAT shoulder work out.  Feel the deltoids burn with this bad boy.  If you want to build shoulders, take this pocket chainsaw out in the woods and fell a few small trees.  You'll probably turn into the Hulk after a couple of weeks.I love that it comes in this small pouch and that the pouch has a belt loop.  It makes it easy to attach to the outside of your bug out bag or straight on your person.  Very convenient.  The fact that it's so compact makes it really easy to transport.I wholeheartedly recommend the Pocket Chainsaw.*Disclaimer - the manufacturer provided a free review sample in exchange for my honest review.*

I've had the good fortune to review several Haweel products of late and I come away each time more and more impressed with this company.Luckily for me, I received this product the day before I was leaving for a long weekend trip in another state.  I took my phone and my kindle with me, but I knew I would be on the road a lot, so opportunities for charging my devices would be few.  Needless to say, it was a lifesaver.First of all, I really like the appearance and build.  It feels solid and digital display gives a bit of a hi-tech feel.  It almost feels like a robotic arm coming out of your dashboard or cigarette lighter. The swivel is a nice touch and gives you a bit more flexibility while using it.Secondly, it works like a charm.  I was able to charge both my phone and kindle with ease.  So long as your charging cord has a usb on the end, you'll be able to use the charger.  And like they say, it is a rapid charger.  I noticed a difference is speed when charging with this device as compared to when the devices were plugged into the wall.  The Rapid Charger is noticeably faster.Lastly, you can charge two devices at one, which is great.  I'm a big fan of that.If you need a new charger, I gladly recommend this unit.  It works, looks good and comes at a reasonable price.  Highly recommended.

The Burberry Weekend for Women is an intoxicating scent.  As I man, this is the kind of scent that drives me wild.  It's soft, yet sophisticated;  elegant, yet sexy; and oh-so glamorous.  In fact, I'd say it's pretty much liquid heroin.  It holds magic power in it's beautiful, little bottle.  (In all seriousness, It's a beautiful bottle and package.)Others have mentioned that the scent isn't long-lasting or that it's possibly a knock-off.  I can't attest to either issue.  All I know is that it seems amazing.  I would love to spend a night out with a woman wearing this scent.  In fact, I would rank this one up there with my all-time favorite, Amarige de Givenchy.TL;DR - smells great.  Buy it.
After one stick I am fueled up and ready to go!  These are pretty tasty snacks and perfect backpacks, school lunches, hiking, etc.  Get fueled up!

This is a fun monster truck hot wheels set!  One of the best parts about this set is that it comes with three trucks to play with with or without the track.  In other words, no kids fighting or quarreling over trucks.  If you have four kids, that's another story, but if you have a couple of kids, there's enough to go around.  The track is lots of fun as well for my 5 year old and 10 year old.  Once you assemble the dragon head the trick is to use the lever to flip the truck off the jump at the right speed so that the dragon can't get it. If you're too slow or fast the dragon bites down and catches the truck in it's mouth. If you succeed the truck hits a panel that pops a trophy out for you and causes the dragons head to fly off. Either way it's a lot of fun. As far as car tracks go this one doesn't take up too much space.  5/5 stars.

If you don't need a fancy set of computer speakers, this is the set for you.  That's by no means a slight on the HP S7000 2.1 Speaker System.  They're perfectly acceptable as a quick and relatively inexpensive set of speakers.  They'll work just fine with your desktop computer, iPad, laptop or any other gadget with a 3.5 mm jack.  If you're getting these for your TV, you'll need an adapter.  The sound quality is perfectly acceptable for the price point and the subwoofer gives it some added dimension and depth.  Set up was a breeze, too!

This is the perfect toy for a baby/toddler. My 2 year old loves dolls, plushy animals and balls. This plushy ball is perfect for a curious infant with many different tactile and crinkly noise elements. But it is also soft and cuddly as well so she can snuggle it. And being a ball it can roll around and bounce (fairly well) for ball fun. This toy is particularly good for younger children with all the different flaps and things like little activity centers on the ball. It adds a variety of entertaining elements in one toy.

*Disclaimer - I was offered a free set of cutting boards in exchange for my unbiased review*In a perfect world a butcher's block would be reasonably priced and every home chef or wannabe chef would have easy access to one.  Unfortunately, for most of us, that's not a reality.  Yet cutting boards are an essential item for any kitchen and it's good to have one, or two or three.As many others have pointed out, take notice of the size.  These are smaller cutting boards and may not be suited for everyone.  However, here's what I really like about them:  when you get to cooking in the kitchen you often find yourself cutting something, then rinsing or wiping off the board and then cutting something else.  This is especially true if you're cutting meats.  You don't want raw chicken juice in your salad, etc.  With these boards you can cut an onion on one board and a chicken breast on the other.  Two of the these boards take up about the same space as one large cutting board.  So, for me, it's a nice convenience.Storage is also a plus.  Since they're smaller, you can store them in a kitchen drawer instead of the pantry.  Again, it's a convenience.  It may not be a big deal for some people, but I appreciate it.

Little did I know that when I purchased the double album at my local Best Buy back in 1998 that for the next 18 years it would remain one of the most played albums in my entire collection (which, I say humbly, is not small - about 250,000 songs in total).  I was fairly new to the world of "Classical Music" at the time and was listening to a lot of composers, both well and lesser known, trying to find music that spoke to me.  I certainly had an appreciate of Mozart and Beethoven and the other heavyweights, but it didn't necessarily speak to me (I could say the same thing about the Sex Pistols and the Clash, too).Then a friend sent me a cassette tape in the mail (those were the days!) , from Spain no less, that included Vaughan Williams "Five Variants of Dives and Lazarus."  I recognized the melody from a church hymn ("If You Could Hie to Kolob"), which I had always loved, but didn't know that it was borrowed from Vaughan Williams' original.  Needless to say I was instantly smitten and searched out more, which led me to this CD.  At the time, "Dives and Lazarus" was the only composition I knew, but I also immediately recognized "Fantasia on Greensleeves" and "Fantasia on a Theme by Thomas Tallis," both equally evocative and beautiful.But nothing compared me for the grandeur that was "The Lark Ascending."  18 years after I first heard it, it remains the most played song in my library.  There have been times I've was sitting at my desk alone working on some project, listening to it in the background and tears just well up for no reason whatsoever.  It has that affect on me.  For me it's the most sublime piece of music ever composed.  I heard it a thousand times and I never, ever tire of it.  It's just of colorful, emotive, evocative, and breathtaking as the first time I heard it.  I've heard other recordings, but for me, this is the best of best.  It captures the mood so wonderfully.  I can only assume the recording itself somehow had God's seal of approval and Divine Influence.In addition to this collection, I highly recommend symphonies 3 and 5 (particularly the 3rd movement of the 5th symphony, "Romanza") and a someone obscure composition called "A Dark Pastoral."Here's hoping Ralph Vaughan Williams reaches a larger audience, especially stateside.

**Disclaimer - The seller offered me this Bluetooth Headset at a deeply discounted price in exchange for a review**Previous the seller contacting me, I'd never heard of the YUMMQUA brand, so I was curious to try it out.First of all, let's talk about the device itself.  It's comparable in size to other bluetooth devices.  The construction feels solid and durable.  I imagine it could withstand many, many drops and still function as designed.  The ear hook (I don't know the technical term) is mostly ineffective.  It the photo it's black, but the one I was received was a clear, hard plastic.  It didn't help secure the device in my ear any better than without it.In order to pair the device (I paired it to my Kindle since I don't own a smart phone), you simply have to push down on the top of the device instead of a tiny button on the side.  I really like that.  Pairing was a breeze and my Kindle recognized the device very quickly.  I honestly don't know if the audio is HD, but it was certainly fine and clear and I had no problem hearing what I was listening to.I would gladly recommend it this device to anyone in the market.  It's small, compact, works as advertised, sounds great and the price is more than fair and reasonable.

I was fairly late to the Sleeping Dogs party.  But as they say, better late than never.  Sleeping Dogs, I believe, is one of the great open world games of the last 5-7 years.  I enjoyed much more than ever enjoyed Grand Theft Auto 4.  (Incidentally, I think GTA V is superior to Sleeping Dogs).  I played the standard version of the game on PS3 and PC before plopping down for the Definitive Edition (DE) because I loved it just that much.Well, it's still an amazing game with a lot to do, a fun story, awesome martial artists, good gunfights, Asian Dating, and collectibles galore.  The only difference is that this time around there's even more to do as all the bits of DLC are now part of the game.  Also, the graphics got a nice upgrade.  In the standard edition, the colors looked pretty much out of the tube.  The color palette in this version is much more realistic and nuanced.  The sky is a bit smokier (which you'd expect in Hong Kong), the trees look better, the cars gleam in the sunlight a bit more, etc.  It's a fantastic-looking game.If you've never played the game, definitely splurge on the DE version.  If you have a PC, it regularly goes on sale for $7.50 on Steam and Humble Bundle.  In addition to the original game and loads of cosmetic DLCs, money opportunities, etc, you get the two additional story DLCs which are a lot of fun as some old friends make appearances.I think I can safely say this game makes my all-time Top 10 favorite games list.  It's a blast.

*Disclaimer - The seller provided a complimentary unit for review purposes*On its own merits, the Wisdompro Arm Band is a perfectly acceptable product.  The problem we encountered, however, is that it's not compatible with other after market cases that you would use to protect your iPhone, like Otterbox, Lifeproof, etc. In order to use the armband, those cases would have to be removed in order to slide your bare bones iPhone into the armband case.  If you don't mind doing that, or you plan to be wearing it all day, then it's probably not that big of a deal.  If you're only going to be out for a quick run or walk, it might a bit more inconvenient.Most iPhones I see out in the public eye are all cased up to protect them from the elements they encounter. Unless you had a very streamline protective case, this arm band case will not work.

From my sister who reviewed these blankets:I am a new mom and have heard such great things about muslin swaddle blankets. These SwaddleMe swaddles were so darling, I just had to add them to my collection. I love simple and contemporary designs which is a major reason I was drawn to these swaddles (not everyone wants colorful animals plastered on their blankets!). Since aden + anais swaddles are the "gold standard" I decided to compare the two. This comparison is between the classic aden + anais swaddle blanket (not the lower quality "aden by aden and anais").The first difference in SM and a+a is the size. The SM blankets are 40"x40" while the a+a blankets are 47x47". There isn't a huge size difference, but enough worth noting. The smaller SwaddleMe blankets are best swaddling a small baby, while the more generous sized a+a blankets are good for larger tasks like draping over a carseat.The a+a blankets are a little more "plush" that the SM blankets. This could be because they are a little more crinkled straight out of the package, while the SM brand are pretty smooth and flat. When I folded both, A&A was noticeably taller (a difference I don't think is completely attributed to the extra 7" of size). I am including photos ofboth blankets side by side before and after they were washed.After 2 washes the a+a blanket was slightly softer and "crinkled" more than the SM blanket. The SM blanket has a slightly tighter weave in the fabric than the a+a blanket. Both blankets are similiar thickness, lightweight, breathable and should get softer with each wash.Whether or not it is worth noting, the white in the a+a cloud design blanket I own is definitely a warm white, while the white in the SM blanket is a cool white. The a+a looks slightly dingy in comparison, but on their own you would never notice.Overall I am impressed with both swaddles and think I will be happy using both. Both are sold in multi-packs. At the time of this review, the SM blankets average $10/ea and a+a blankets average $12.50-$15/ea. A&A has a slight advantage for being bigger and being barely more "plush", but the SM blankets are a solid runner up and for the price can't be beat. I will enjoy using the SwaddleMe blankets and would not hesitate to select them again.​

I love hot bubble baths, especially in winter! I like the size of these bubble bath bottles; they're easy to handle. The scent it subtle and enjoyable, without smelling too artificial. Like most bubbles, they quickly fade unless you dump copious amounts under a running faucet. My favorite is the Milk and Honey scent. So nice and so sweet! I think these would make a great gift for a new mom, a new bride or anyone that loves baths!

We have a VERY active 4.5 year old daughter is never stops moving.  She's as high energy as they come, so we rarely get the chance play "board games" because her high energy doesn't allow her to sit still for very long. So you can imagine how excited we were to play this game with her!  Moving and energy are a big part of the game! It challenged her to use her body and she loved it! She just giggled and wanted her little brother to join along too! I know we will be back at it soon, which is saying a lot.  And as she is beginning to read The Cat in the Hat books, this is especially exciting for her!

My daughter loved these necklaces. These are pretty basic and simple necklaces but look ornate enough to make a 6-10 year old girl excited. They are perfect for young kids/tweens who are into jewelry. The clasp only allows the necklace to be one length, which isn't that big of a deal. Also the chains are pretty thin and wound up in knots but a little effort resolved that issue.

My daughter loved these necklaces. These are pretty basic and simple necklaces but look ornate enough to make a 6-10 year old girl excited. They are perfect for young kids/tweens who are into jewelry. The clasp only allows the necklace to be one length, which isn't that big of a deal. Also the chains are pretty thin and wound up in knots but a little effort resolved that issue.

The History of flight airplanes set comes with four different planes to assemble. Although this set is for 8 years and above it is probably more of a serious hobbyist's set. My 10 year old found it difficult to assemble by himself. The sticker labels make the planes look very realistic however were a little difficult to get on right and unforgiving when you laid it on incorrectly.My kids loved soaring the airplanes around. The rubber tip noses make them able to take some impact. Some of these planes broke pretty easily however.

**Disclaimer - the manufacturer provided me a free set of labels for review**I had never heard of erasable labels when I had the chance to review them.  What where they? How did the work?  I was completely intrigued.  Was it some sort of juju or black magic?  I was anxious to find out.Well, these labels are pretty neat.  They work exactly as advertised.  The liquid chalk marker is cool.  It a lot more liquidy than I thought it would be, though.  You need to be a little bit careful when using it because it's very wet and takes several minutes to dry.  But the cool thing is that once it's dry, you just need a damp rag to wipe it clean and do it again.  It's very cool.This package comes with 48 labels, which is more than you'll probably ever use or need.  So, find someone you can share with and split the cost.  I honestly think 48 labels is probably too many.  I think 24 labels for $7 is a much better deal.I wholeheartedly recommend these cool chalk labels!

*Disclaimer:  The seller provided me this free product for review*I have to say, I really like like the Haweel Universal Gooseneck Cell Phone Holder.  So let's get to the good stuff.  The construction is top notch.  It feels and is very solid.  The tension on the clasp is outstanding.  There's little to no change that its going to lose its grip wherever you attach it.  I was impressed by this.  Secondly, the goose neck portion is about 25 inches long (see the photo I've uploaded), giving you plenty of maneuverability if you need it.  The clasp you use to attach your phone has the perfect amount of tension, too.  It's very easy to put your phone in and take it out with little to no effort.  Very nice.At $16.99, I think the price is about right, especially if you have children who watch on their phones while in the car.  Whether or not you actually *need* one is entirely up to you.  Some people are more than happy to hold their phones, but if you're making dinner while watching a youtube tu tutorial, this is super duper handy.  Highly recommended.

The Baby Alive Super Snacks Snackin' Sara is an awesome addition to your baby doll collection.  Apart from the slightly creepy appearance, overall she's a very cute and fun doll.The level of immersion is pretty impressive.  Snackin' Sara can do quite a bit: she talks, responds, eats, and even poops.  Although I have to admit that the eating/food stuff you can probably do just as well without.  In my opinion it doesn't necessarily add a whole lot, it's a bit of pain, and a bit of a hassle.  Give it a try, but I don't think it's something that will have lasting appeal.The outfit, however, are great.  It's fun for the little kids to change the diapers, too.  The kids really liked the dress up and baby care aspects (without the poops, of course!).  Sara is the perfect size for 3-8 year olds.  I imagine she's pretty close to life size, which is good/fun practice.The only qualm I have is the price - Sara seems spectacularly expensive for what you get.  Yes, she's cute, but I think she's at least $20 overpriced, so buyer beware.

Of all the toys we've had the opportunity to review over the years, this is one of the few that hadn't really resonated with the littles.  While the set piece is fine, it's fairly small and doesn't really foster or encourage imagination or creativity.  What our two year old loved were the figures.  He does carry them around everywhere and plays with them a lot.  However, that doesn't justify the overall cost.It's a perfectly acceptable toy, but your money might be better spent elsewhere.

Green toys are always welcome in our home and the speed boat is no exception.  Our two year old absolutely loves it.  He plays with it in the tub and out.  In fact he carries it with him everywhere he goes.  It's the right size for little hands, durable, and responsibly made.  Recommended for all the little ones.

Before I was contacted by the seller who offered me a heavily discounted purchase price, I had never heard of a neck pouch.  I had no idea what it was.  I had to do a little research and discovered it's basically a wallet on a lanyard that you hang around your neck, especially used for traveling.Well, the day it arrived my sister was over visiting and she was about to head out on a walk.  I said, 'Hey, do you want to try this neck pouch?'  She said, 'sure.'  One hour later she walked in the front door and said, "Matt, this thing is awesome.  I love it.  There are a ton of pockets.  I can fit so much in it.  I could take the dogs for a walk and bring all my things with me without having to take along a purse or wallet."I have to agree with her.  The Hopsooken Neck Pouch is perfect for traveling, exercising, dog walking, etc.  It's convenient, has a ton of pockets, is lightweight, and as far as I can tell, is solidly constructed.  I would gladly recommend this pouch to anyone in the market for one.  I only wish I had heard of them sooner.***By way of disclosure, I was offered this product at a highly discounted price and encouraged to write an honest review, which I have done.  The purchase price has nothing to do with my positive review.

The Miles from Tomorrowland Superstellar hoverboard is, in theory, a fun and great toy.  After all, who hasn't wanted a hoverboard at some point in his/her life?  I think we pretty much all hive.For the most part, it's a pretty fun toy.  It does encourage balance and coordination and the games/challenges can be fun.  However, as our ten year old said, "It's too loud and needs an 'off' button."I think, too, it probably has a relatively short shelf life, so for the price point I don't know that it's the best investment.  Your child may enjoy it, but it seems like it will lose its novelty pretty quickly.  Still, it's fun while it lasts, so caveat emptor.

If your child loves Minecraft, there's a pretty good chance he or she will love the Terraria line of toys.  In the event you don't already know, Terraria is a PC, scroller video game (as opposed to Minecraft, which is 3D).  They may share a few similarities, but really, Terraria is very much its own game, and a great game at that - some would even argue it's vastly superior to Minecraft, but that's another topic for another day.Still, it's not hard to see some similarities in the toys.  The Multi-level Biome set is a great jumping off point for anyone new to the world of Terraria.  It's a pretty large set.  Our ten-year old absolutely loved it.  He was able to assemble it himself in no time flat and was off and running (it also got him interested in the game, which is pretty great!).  I love how the backdrop is faithful to Terraria's aesthetic - above ground, under ground, and mines.  The track is pretty fun and the character figure about the right size for 5-10 year olds.  It really is a lot of fun!The only drawback is the price, which is fairly steep, in my opinion.  It's probably a $25-$30 set, but I see it going for 5x that here on amazon.  I think it may be partly due to it's apparent rarity, but still.

We had the opportunity to try the Radio Flyer Red Rider Trike and boy are we glad we did.  What's interesting is that our little guy has a couple of developmental challenges and his therapist recommended a tricycle to help with his legs.  So, it was a godsend in a way.What we love about the RF is the vintage look.  It's the classic red of old radio flyer wagons of yesterday.  You can't miss it.  It's beautiful to look at.  We also loved the adjustable seat, meaning your child can grow and still enjoy the Red Flyer for many years.  This is a great innovation, in my opinion. I don't know if it's a new innovation, but I think it's a genius move by the manufacturer.The construction, as far as I can tell, is solid and build to last.  I suppose our little guy will get many, many years of exercise and enjoyment out of this trike and at $50, that seems like a bargain.

This is a great puzzle!  It was perfect for our 4-year old.  She loves the big, bright colors as well as the big pieces, which are perfect.  She was able to work on the puzzle and get most of it completed on her own, which is great.  She's pretty independent to begin with, but it's nice that she can just go about working on it without any supervision.  Of course it helps that dinosaurs are awesome and these dinosaurs are particularly awesome since they glow in the dark.I'd gladly recommend this puzzle to anyone in the market for a fun, bright, engaging puzzle.

The TOMY Constructable Dinos are absolutely the perfect size for toddlers and little kids.  They were ideal for our two and four year-olds.They're pretty basic in their presentation.  Their mother commented that they looked like something out of the 90s, which is all well and good (and probably "vintage" by now), but they definitely lack the Bang! Zoom! of too many of today's toys (not a bad thing, just an observation). They colors are bright and engaging, too.  When motorized the dinos were able to traverse the wood table and concrete driveway with ease.The only thing to consider is the noise they make when they're motorized.  Its a low growl that might drive parents a bit crazy after a couple of minutes.  But they're equally as fun even when they're not motorized.

The STK worked like a charm for me.  I borrowed my sister's camera which had been dormant for a couple of years.  Unfortunately, somewhere along the line she lost the battery charger.  A little research brought me the STK and when I compared it to the much higher priced "Official" charger, I figured I give it a shot.  Well, it worked like a charm.  The batter charged up and I was able to start taking photos after a couple of hours.  Piece of cake.It works, it's reasonably priced and I would gladly recommend it to anyone who needs a replacement charger.

Ay caramba, since their worldwide smash hit with "La Bamba" many people think of Los Lobos as a tacky Mexican novelty act. In fact they are from East Los Angeles and started out as a blues band before listening to Richard Thompson and Fairport Convention mixing rock with British folk gave them the idea that they could do a similar thing with their Mexican heritage. It's been five years since their last studio album 'Tin Can Trust' which I thought was very good - although not as good as their previous record 'The Town and the City' - a clever concept album dealing with the place of Latinos in American society - which mixed American roots music and rock with Central American cumbia - much as they've done throughout their 42-year career.We begin with "Made to Break Your Heart" a laid-back bluesy shuffle featuring David Hidaglo's heart-rending vocals and his fabulous emotive blues lead guitar, this is followed by “When We Were Free” which has a similar sound but much looser and jazzy, underpinned by Conrad Lozano’s rumbling bass lines and Steve Berlin's occasional piano and sax, until the blues lead guitar once again cuts in, followed by some jazzy riffing. Then there's a nice change of pace for Cesar Rosas' “Mis-Treater Boogie Blues” an uptempo basic boogie blues. “There I Go” is another moody, bluesy shuffle which features Louie Perez's agile drumming and ends unexpectedly... Elsewhere there is variety with the beautiful folky, acoustic title track, the pretty cumbia of “La Tumba Sera el Final” and the semi-acoustic Chicago blues of “I Believed You So”, another track featuring Cesar Rosas. The band also do a different song that is also called “When We Were Free” a bit confusing but it is another great David Hidaglo blues shuffle and to finish there is a nice, atmospheric live track "Prenda del Alma".Many of Los Lobos' gigs feature extended instrumental workouts, in the spirit of the Grateful Dead, but the tracks here are all fairly concise, although the whole album seems a bit 'ramshackle' after "Tin Can Trust" (and at just over 40 minutes a tad short). I did love most of it - particularly the production which they did themselves and which reminded me of 'Kiko' in places - but after a five year break I would thought that they could have produced something a bit more structured. Some of the tracks reminded me of the British group Traffic and (like Steve Winwood) David Hidaglo is always worth hearing - and the rest of the group also play their part in another very good album - four and a half stars.

Shemekia’s new album is again produced by Oliver Wood, as was her last wonderful record ’33 and a third’.  The basic band is Oliver on guitar, Lex Price on bass and Jano Rix on drums, percussion and keyboards, with big name guests including Billy Gibbons playing guitar on ZZ Top’s “Jesus Just Left Chicago”, Alvin Youngblood Hart and steel guitarist Robert Randolph.  Shemekia’s old guitarist Arthur Neilson also plays as do guitarists Will Kimbrough and Guthrie Trapp, Pete Finney on pedal steel, Eric Fritsch on organ and Matt Glassmeyer on horns.Like ’33 and a third’ this is very much rock blues – from the driving rock of the opening title track to the fabulous Stones-style rocker “The Battle is Over (But the War Goes On) -  although “Cardboard Box” featuring Alvin Youngblood Hart playing guitar and sharing the vocals with Shemekia is a great downhome acoustic blues.  And as she says on “Drivin' Out Of Nashville”, complete with its pedal steel guitar, “country music ain’t nothing but the blues with a twang”.  “I Feel a Sin Coming On” is a heartfelt soul ballad complete with nice horns and “Isn't that So” is nice N’Orleans rock and roll.For all that I said that this was mainly rock blues, Shemekia’s voice itself is just pure gutbucket blues - listen to her make “Jesus Just Left Chicago” completely her own, ditto Creedence Clearwater Revival’s “Long as I Can See the Light”, done as a soul-meets-power ballad.  Shemekia’s old guitarist Arthur Neilson adds his blues lead guitar to Albert King’s funky “Wrapped Up In Love Again” and the final track “Lord, Help the Poor and Needy” is a moody atmospheric closer.I picked ’33 and a third’ as my blues album of the year in 2012 I thought that it was the best album that she’s made and to be honest I didn’t think that she’d be able to top it.  She has – this album is even better, it’s the best record I’ve heard for years, a combination of great playing from all involved and excellent production from Oliver Wood BUT most of all Shemekia’s voice - which is just so full blues feeling that like an alchemist she can transform any material into pure blues gold. 50 stars…

Like Gary’s first album ‘Blak and Blu’ this record is a mixture of his influences - blues, rock, hip-hop, soul and folk – indeed the opener “The Healing” starts off as an olden-days work song before turning hip-hop, with the addition of some stinging blues lead guitar.  The whole record is less guitar-heavy than his recent live album but his guitar does feature, even the funky “Hold On” suddenly has a hard-hitting blues guitar solo.  The album was recorded in Austin, Texas, Gary’s hometown, and he produced the record himself, played most of the instruments and even enlisted his sisters as background singers.I like the fact that Gary isn’t afraid to experiment by mixing styles and isn’t prepared just to be the next Texas blues guitar slinger.  Consequently there is more variety here, from the heartfelt soul ballad “Our Love” to the heavy rock of “Stay”, from the echoey downhome rock and roll of “Shake” to the acoustic folky-gospel of “Church”, which reminded me of Ben Harper.  We also get smooth soul in the shape of the short (one minute) “BYOB” and the long (nearly eight minutes) Marvin Gaye-ish “Down to Ride”.Personally I would have preferred more straight blues but I applaud his adventure and versatility, and he's also done a great job with the production, my only worry is that by including all these different styles Gary will end up pleasing no one.

In 2013 John signed to Eric Corne's Forty Below Records, who produced the recent wonderful record from 1967 featuring Peter Green, as well as last year's 'A Special Life'. 'Find A Way To Care' was recorded at the House of Blues Studios in Encino, California with John's current live band of Rocky Athas on guitar, Greg Rzab on bass and Jay Davenport on drums. It's a mixture of John's own songs and blues classics like Junior Parker's “Mother In Law Blues”, Percy Mayfield’s “River’s Invitation”, Muddy Waters’ “Long Distance Call”, Charles Brown's "Drifting Blues" and Little Milton's "Feel so Bad". There is more focus here on John playing keyboards (both organ and piano) as well as three songs with horns (Ron Dzublia on saxophone, Richard Rosenberg on trumpet and Mark Pender on trumpet), a couple of tracks with John playing harp and he also plays guitar Muddy's on "Long Distance Call ".I don't know if it's Corne's production or the sympathetic band or John being newly inspired but I think that this record sounds really good and is one of the best he has recorded in years. We get off to a great start with “Mother In Law Blues” which sounds like one of John's tracks from the 60s - great guitar from Rocky Athas over John's rolling boogie piano. I love Percy Mayfield’s “River’s Invitation” and John's version speeds it up and he plays some nice funky Hammond organ - great version - it's followed by his own “Ain’t No Guarantees” which again is classic Mayall with great Hammond and John's strong vocals. The title song is one of the album's best tracks and "I Want All My Money Back" is great rocking blues with John playing Hammond and piano and "War We Wage" is a moody blues co-written with British blues guitarist Matt Schofield. On the restrained version of Charles Brown's "Drifting Blues" John plays some nice late-night piano and his vocals sound vulnerable, another thoughtful take on a classic blues song.I originally gave the album four stars having been a bit put off by the lyrics of the final track "Crazy Lady" but these are similar to many of John's lyrics from his songs in the 60s and the track is redeemed by his great rolling blues piano. Overall this is an excellent piece of work featuring good versions of traditional blues, John's own songs that can stand alongside these classics and some great playing from the band and from John himself who for once gets to showcase his keyboard skills, often overlooked by people focussing on his various guitarists.

Listening to this record it's almost impossible to believe that Jon was born and brought up in the county of Kent in the UK and not in the Crescent City - everything in his singing and piano playing just screams New Orleans. Or rather doesn't scream - Jon is just so effortlessly laid back and funky, and it doesn't hurt that he is accompanied by some of New Orleans’ top session men, including guitarist Shane Theriot, keyboard player Nigel Hall and the Dirty Dozen Brass Band, as well as members of his own band - the Absolute Monster Gentlemen. We get off to a great start with "Pump it Up" which perfectly demonstrates the link between New Orleans and reggae/ska, then the funky "Boneyard" probably my favourite track and "Bringing Back the Home" is a tribute to the "Jazz, funk, rhythm and blues, and soul" that America has given to the world. While Jon's composition the Little Feat-sounding “Love On One Condition” featured on Bonnie Raitt's album 'Souls Alike'. An accomplished album from a very accomplished musician.

This year is the centenary of bluesman/bandleader Muddy Waters’ birth and we have already had one tribute CD from his son Mud Morganfield together with Kim Wilson. That CD was very traditional, whereas this tribute puts a slightly more modern spin on Muddy’s songs and involves a larger cast of guest artists including Shemekia Copeland, James Cotton, Gary Clark Jr., Johnny Winter, Keb Mo', Billy Branch and Derek Trucks. The band is led by two ex-Muddy Waters’ sidemen, guitarists John Primer and Bob Margolin, with Primer also handling some of the vocals, as on the opener Muddy’s theme song “Got my Mojo Workin’” where he shares the singing with Shemekia.I always loved the Waters band’s ensemble playing and these guys certainly do a great job in playing Muddy’s songs without actually trying to replicate that 50/60s sound. When Muddy released “Can’t Get no Grinding” in the 70s it featured electric piano which at the time I thought wasn’t traditional but it shows Muddy was keeping up with the times and I’m sure he would have approved of these updates to his sound. There is variety here as well - "Rosalie" goes back to the country blues of the Son Sims Four with Steve Gibbons on fiddle and Billy Flynn on mandolin and "Why Don't You Live So God can Use You" is a rare example of a Muddy Waters gospel song from the same era and features Leanne Faine on vocals.Elsewhere its great Chicago blues with soaring harmonica from Cotton, Branch and Vincent Bucher, I particularly liked Billy Branch’s rocked up versions of “Trouble no More” and “Can’t Get no Grinding” and also “She Moves Me” with its blistering harp from Matthew Skoller and great Muddy-style slide guitar. More great slide on “Still a Fool” from Derek Trucks and on “I’m Ready” instead of the original chromatic harp we get the late Johnny Winter’s distinctive slide guitar. I also really liked Keb Mo’s “Last Time I Fool Around With You” which had more nice slide and also great piano from Johnny Iguana. I really enjoyed this tribute which I thought honoured the legend of Muddy Waters, featured some great playing and although it put a slightly modern spin on some of the songs didn’t stray too far from Muddy’s original template.

Their last album 'Snapshot' sounded like a return to the British R&B groups of the early 60s - the Stones and the Yardbirds (my favourites) - with its snarled vocals, raw guitar and howling harmonica. However, those groups 'progressed' away from the raw sound of the blues to more commercial sounds later in the 60s. The Strypes have made that transition after one record and this second album sees them sounding much less raw, more polished - with better arrangements and more accomplished vocals from Ross Farrelly.  In short a lot more professional, although crucially they have managed to keep that same sense of excitement - even if the overall sound is more like the Arctic Monkeys than the Pretty Things. There are also nods to 70s British New Wave acts like the Jam and early Boomtown Rats, as well as the the originators of 'Maximum R&B' - The Who.The harmonica is mainly on the back burner here, although when they do use it, it just makes them sound so different to all the other guitar bands around, like on the opener "Get into it" and on "Rejection" and also on "Status Update" (which with Peter O'Hanlon's pounding bass is pure Yardbirds) although the harmonica sound isn't grown-up Little Walter it's definitely youthful Brian Jones. Josh McClorey's guitar ain't half bad either, nice tight rhythms and odd bits of stinging lead work, as on probably my favourite track the very catchy "Scumbag City, and Evan Walsh on drums powers everything along and is very tight and crisp. The four extra tracks on the deluxe version are all of the same standard as the rest of the songs and not just assorted odds and sods added as an afterthought, as on some other records. This is a really good record which manages to balance its youthful enthusiasm with a growing maturity.

I really like Vintage Trouble’s modern twist on old-style blues-based rock – for me they were one the real highlights of this year’s Glastonbury Festival in the UK - and this new record sees them carrying on from where ‘The Bomb Shelter Sessions’ left off.  We get off to a great rocking start with “Run Like the River” with its nice slide guitar and “Strike Your Light” (featuring vocals from Kamilah Marshall) and “Another Baby” are other raucous rockers in the same vain.  However, it’s not all flat-out balls-to-the-wall rockers - my other favourite tracks are the lovely soul ballad “Another Man's Words” – this album’s “Not Alright By Me” – and the restrained, thoughtful “From My Arms”.Singer Ty Taylor is in superb form again – this man could sing the phone book and make it sound funkyy – and guitarist Nalle Colt doubles up as both rhythm and lead guitarist, in front of the rock solid rhythm section of drummer Richard Danielson and bass player Rick Barrio Dill.  “Before the Teardrops Start” features some nice bluesy guitar from Colt (ditto “Shows What You Know”) and “Soul Serenity” sees the band in laid-back almost acoustic mode.  I think that this record is certainly on a par with ‘The Bomb Shelter Sessions’ with a similar mix of catchy, well-performed songs and while I liked it, I don’t think that the band have really developed from their first album.

Buddy was the youngest of the classic Chicago bluesmen and often angered critics by including popular soul songs in his sets - in many ways he was the first modern blues man. Many of his recent albums have been too rocky for me but when I saw him headlining the Maryport Blues Festival in the UK in 2004 he was absolutely wonderful - subtle but also able to really turn up the excitement levels with searing blues. This latest record is another produced by Tom Hambridge and sees Buddy playing in a number of different styles, it sounds 'modern' but also has echoes of his illustrious past and while the band is very good Buddy is clearly the star of every track. .We get off to a great start with the title song, a slow, subtle rolling blues where Buddy's voice sounds really emotional and slightly vulnerable singing "I was born to play the guitar and I've got the blues running through my veins" - I found it very moving. There are two great tracks with ace harmonica player Kim Wilson "Too Late" and "Kiss me Quick" which evoke Buddy's partnership with Junior Wells and "Wear you out" sees Buddy trading guitar licks and vocals with ZZ Top's Billy Gibbons (suddenly all the power is back in Buddy's voice!)  One of my favourite tracks is "Crying out of One Eye" real West Side Blues which really reminded me of a mixture of Magic Sam and Otis Rush with its echoey production and nice horns. "Flesh and Bone" is a another very moving song, a tribute to Buddy's friend and mentor B.B. King, including vocals from Van Morrison, while the final track is a nice poignant acoustic tribute to another blues great - Muddy Waters.  From the moving to the amusing as Buddy and Joss Stone recreate Brook Benton and Dinah Washington's duet on the 1960 soul classic "Baby (You've Got What It Takes)" - you can clearly hear that they are both really enjoying themselves and having a ball.  On "Turn Me Wild" Buddy sings "You can't pick how people remember you, you just hope that they do..." - people will certainly remember Buddy Guy and when they do they'll say this was one of his best albums - and I'm not even going to mention that he's 79.. doh!

There have been a couple of tribute albums to Nina Simone, a unique artist who over the years inspired many artists to cover her songs. This tribute produced by Jayson Jackson, Suzette Williams, Peter Edge, Robert Glasper and Lauryn Hill (who appears on 6 tracks) is to accompany Liz Garbus's documentary film "What Happened, Miss Simone?". Rather than the 'cod' jazz of previous tributes this is mainly in the contemporary R&B style and as such it has a pleasing unity and I think that Nina would have approved. Lauryn Hill is all grown up here and even has that world-weariness in her voice that I associate with Nina, most of her tracks are successful but I wasn't convinced by the synthesiser/hip-hop stylings of "Black is the Colour" which for me just sounded wrong. Whereas Jazmine Sullivan's upbeat, reggae version of Randy Newman's "Baltimore" really hits the spot, as does the eery, unnervinging version of "I Put A Spell On You" by Alice Smith, an artist I hadn't heard before.I'm afraid that I found many of the other performances by Grace, Usher, Mary J. Blige, Lisa Simone and even Gregory Porter just a bit bland and predictable (despite being well-produced and very professional), without that edge and sense of danger that I always associate with Nina. I also think that it was a mistake to finish off with one of Nina's own performances because for me it just emphasised the point that no one can compare with her versions of her songs.

I enjoyed Damon's first two CDs which showed great promise for such a young singer/guitarist/songwriter and he builds on that promise with this record which is assured and accomplished and if he isn't quite yet the finished article then at this rate he soon will be. It helps that this record is produced by the experienced Tab Benoit who brings the sounds of the Louisiana swamps with him and adds a bit of dirt and drama to Damon's sound. The first song 'Thought I Had It All' is a moody mid-tempo blues-based workout featuring Damon's slide guitar and this sets the tone for the rest of the record, which is very subtle and laid back but still packs an emotional punch. 'Old Fools, Bar Stools' and 'Do It for The Love' (with Tab's nice steel guitar) add a country twang to the mix and Damon brings a bluesy twist to Elvis Costello's wonderful song 'Allison' - complete with a heart-wrenching guitar solo. My favourite song was probably 'Where I Belong' with its understated slide guitar that really reminded me of John Moody.

It's very hard to classify Paul Cebar Tomorrow Sound's music, it's definitely based in roots music with elements of soul, blues, rock and roll and jazz but it's also full of melody and has the hooks of the best pop music, as well as a sly understated sense of humour.  There is lots of variety from the almost frantic new wave beat (think Elvis Costello and Attractions) of the title track to the smooth soul sounds of "You owe it to you", to the funky "Might be smiling" and the almost reggae-like grooves of the final "Like loving people do".  My favourite track is probably "Not necessarily true" a lovely mid-tempo melodic soul ballad. Paul leads the band with his upfront vocals and subtle guitar and is ably assisted by Bob Jennings on keyboards and sax (a bit like the band's Garth Hudson).  The fine rhythm section of drummer Reggie Bordeaux, Mike Fredrickson on bass and percussionist Mac Perkins power everything along to give music that is great for dancing as well as listening to. This is a really nice record that is a great calling card for Paul and the boy's wonderful live shows.

This is a really nice record featuring live performances by a number of American roots artists, some like the Wood Brothers, Seth Walker and Chris Thomas King I'd heard of but the majority I hadn't come across before. There isn't a bad track here and there are lots of excellent ones such as Kellin Watson and her great band, the McGary Sisters with their soulful version of Dylan's 'Blowing in the wind' and best of the bunch Seth Walker and 'Lay down (River of faith)' from his album 'Leap of Faith'. However, all the other tracks aren't far behind - this is a very consistent album with all the acts truly turning in SOULFUL performances - if this was a live concert I would have loved to have been there...

I came across this album by accident on the other side of the pond and I was very impressed by Kellin Watson's voice, by the backing band and by the quality of the songs, which are all very good.  The music and Kellin's voice is very influenced by jazz and blues but still sounds modern rather than harking back to the past and is also original without trying to copy anyone. I particularly liked her version of the old blues standard "Sittin' on top of the world", which featured Sarah and Christian Dugas as well as Oliver Wood, and had a wonderful imaginative arrangement on a par with anything done by Cassandra Wilson.  I'll look forward to hearing more from Kellin in the future.

This is the third in the series of 'How Britain got the blues' and represents the records that influenced the London R&B bands, including the Stones, the Yardbirds, the Pretty Things, Downliners Sect etc during the first Blues Boom of the early 60s. Included are gems from the Chess label by Muddy Waters, Howlin' Wolf, Chuck Berry and Bo Diddley including the signature song of the era Muddy's "Got My Mojo Working" which every spotty herbert with a mouth organ (including myself) was singing . Also included are very influential electric blues songs by Jimmy Reed, John Lee Hooker, Sonny Boy Williamson, Slim Harpo etc plus a couple of slightly more obscure cult classics like "You Don't Love Me" by Willie Cobbs (later covered by John Mayall) and Billy Boy Arnold's "I Wish You Would" (covered by the Yardbirds). So far so good but then the compilation goes slightly off-piste by including a few straight rock and roll songs, some country blues and two early Bob Dylan covers of traditional blues. I accept that these probably would have influenced some bands but so would the Shadows, Lonnie Donegan and Acker Bilk - I just feel that you've got to stop somewhere and I'm afraid that for me these songs didn't fit in with the rest of the excellent songs on this compilation, so it looses one star.

I became a fan of Nina Simone as a teenager in the 60s after seeing her in concert on TV, much to the puzzlement of my friends who considered her 'uncool'. However, I've remained a fan although I never saw her live - I did have the chance to see her at the Bishopstock Festival in Devon UK in 2001 but by that time her voice had gone and I chose not to attend that night and to remember her through her records. There are several biographies of Nina, including an autobiography, which all seem to have their supporters and also their critics, this is the latest and so can draw on these previous memoirs together with fresh interviews to give a comprehensive overview of this unique artist. She wasn't really a jazz singer, a blues singer, a folk singer, a soul singer, a protest singer, a pop singer, a cabaret singer, a show singer or a classical pianist - although her work contained elements of all these genres, combined into Nina's own unclassifiable style.When first skimming through the book I was a bit surprised that her performing career only began from pages 60-odd onwards but these early pages dealing with the lives of her parents and family and her own young life give an excellent context to her later life and also to the place of black people in America at that time. Nina emerges as a determined and very focussed child, who was opinionated and knew her place in the world from an early age (a foretaste of the diva she was to become in later years). Even in her earliest performances she didn't put up with what she considered disrespect but there are also instances of unreasonable behaviour even in her 20s which must have been early indications of the bipolar disorder that she was diagnosed with in later life.The book charts her career progressing from small club dates to international concert appearances, a constantly changing procession of backing musicians, her recording sessions and her fight to get royalties from these records. It also notes Nina's gradual involvement with the civil rights movement and her increasing militancy and sympathy with black power. In line with all these the book also catalogues increasing bad behaviour both on stage and off and although some have criticised other books for focussing on this behaviour unfortunately it was unquestionably a feature of many Nina Simone performances in her later years. However, the book also details how many musicians, promoters and friends remained loyal despite the bad treatment they sometimes received from her and also how audiences still greeted her ecstatically despite late appearances, erratic on stage behaviour and failing vocal and musical powers.I found Nadine Cohodas' book a good, very objective study of the life of a truly unique artist. I've previously read Nadine's 'Spinning Blues Into Gold' - the story of Chess Records - which I also found very interesting but like this book strangely 'cold' - it was so objective that you couldn't tell if she was fan of Miss Simone or hated her. There are some excellent photographs of Nina throughout the book but these are printed on the same pages as the text rather than separate glossy pages, which no doubt keeps costs down but does reduce the quality of the images. The book ends with a comprehensive index, a bibliography, a (very) short list of CD/DVD credits, acknowledgements and 40 pages of notes. The notes contain several very interesting snippets together with the page numbers that they relate to but at the back of the book they are completely isolated from the text - I felt it would have been better to include the notes at the foot of the relevant pages or to annotate the text with reference numbers to link with the notes.

The first volume of 'How Britain Got The Blues' that I listened to was volume 2 - How Merseyside Got The Blues - which was excellent, a really good compilation of well-chosen songs that accurately reflect the original R&B, rock and roll and early soul that influenced Merseybeat. However, this collection is much less-focussed (as the title 'Skiffle, Folk, RocknRoll & The British Blues Boom' perfectly demonstrates) with a collection of pre-war folk blues, R&B, electric Chicago blues, country and rock and roll. Although I fully accept that this was exactly how people at the time in Britain listened to music, hearing anything that was available and that the jazz, folk and blues scenes were all interlocking - I think that now in retrospect many of these tracks don't sit well together. I feel it would have been better to have kept this as a mainly acoustic collection of tracks that influenced skiffle and blues, leaving the electric tracks for the forthcoming Volume 3 - How London Got The Blues. However, needless to say there are some classic performancess here from the hugely influential Leadbelly and Robert Johnson sides to the later, just as influential, Muddy Waters and Howlin' Wolf tracks.

What a fabulous compilation, every record is particularly well-chosen and as someone originally from Merseyside this collection really resonates with me. When I first got into music these were exactly the songs that I was listening to - but as covered by British groups. This is a collection of the original American blues, R&B, rock and roll and pop that when mixed together equaled Merseybeat. I don't think that there was any 'overall design' in this, these were just the records that happened to be available in the UK, either as imports or as British releases. There was never a particularly big blues scene on Merseyside and this collection shows the bias towards more tuneful R&B, soul and R&R that fed into what the Beatles went on to write for themselves.Unlike many collections which are bulked out with a few duds this really is "All Killer, No Filler". However, I will just highlight what I consider to be particularly key, heavily covered records - the Clovers' 'Love portion no. 9', 'Slow down' by Larry Williams, 'Fortune teller' by Benny Spellman, 'A shot of rhythm and blues' by Arthur Alexander and Bobby Parker's 'Watch your step', together with all the Chuck Berry, Little Richards and Elvis of course.

This is a really good record with Chas and Dave not doing anything new but giving us their unique blend of rock n' roll, R&B and skiffle together with old-fashioned English pub-style singalong. Joe Henry (Hugh Laurie, Bettye LaVette, Loudon Wainwright etc) produces and keeps everything very simple and direct, letting the music speak for itself. Everything is very relaxed with Chas often bringing in the soloists with comments of "Go on Martin" etc but this certainly isn't a chaotic rambling jam - everything here is very crisp and really well-played. There are some top-name guests including guitarists Albert Lee and Martin Taylor, Jools Holland, Hugh Laurie and the Crickets' drummer Jerry Allison but I also really enjoyed the fiddle of Lucy Wilkins and Greg Cohen's double bass.There are some good old blues songs like Jesse Fuller's 'San Francisco Bay Blues', Big Bill Broonzy's 'All by myself' and Leadbelly's 'Midnight Special', together with golden oldies like 'The glory of love', 'Pretty baby' and 'I can't give you anything but love' and rock and roll rarities like 'Look at me' - which are all transformed into the classic Cockney Chas and Dave-style. However, my favourite song was probably the very clever new song 'Lonnie D' - a homage to Britain's King of Skiffle Lonnie Donegan, closely followed by another new song, the single 'When two world's collide'. Great stuff from two British rock and roll veterans who have paid their dues and know their roots music but who have also created their own completely unique sound.

Harmonica Shah is from Detroit and has released half-dozen studio and live discs since 2000, he isn't the world's greatest harp player or singer but this record is nice, unpretentious, authentic urban blues that really swings. Shah is backed by the excellent guitarist Jack de Keyzer, Canadian pianist Julian Fauth and drummer Bucky Berger. Alec Fraser produces with a straight-forward, no-nonsense approach which lets the music speak for itself and he gets a good sound on Shah's harp and on Keyzer's guitar. Apart from "Worried life blues" (where Shah shares the vocals with Fauth) the songs are all `originals', albeit with a familiar ring to many of them - for example the title track is a "Rock me baby" retread. Nevertheless this is an enjoyable album of raw 50s-style blues with really nice guitar and piano that seem to inspire Harmonica Shah onto greater heights.

For what it is, this router does the job. It's an Ethernet-only 4-port router with an easy-to-use interface. The problem is the lack of a wireless option. This seems unforgivable these days for the typical home user, with a myriad of other choices that offer wireless and are much less expensive.

I've always found photo editing software of any kind to be a bit daunting to use; the choices can easily be overwhelming. This software makes the whole process a bit easier. Once I went through the tutorials on this software, I was pretty much able to get a hang of it, and found it fairly easy to use. It's simpler than other editing software I've used, and offers a good array of choices. I did, however, find registering the software to be a little frustrating. The software usage can be a little clunky at times, too. Overall, the software isn't bad, but I think I'll stick with what I'm used to: Photoshop.

I love the geometric, modern design of this faucet! We're remodeling our master bathroom, and when I saw this, I just knew I had to get it. Not only does it have a pleasing, Asian-inspired design, but it is also quite sturdy and functional. The handles turn smoothly and seem to work perfectly. It is rather small, which isn't too surprising, given its stylized build. The pull-out feature is handy, as well. It's a gorgeous addition to our home.

Before I got this, I would always forget to charge my phone; it'd always be dead at the end of the day. Now, I just listen to my iTunes library all day, while my phone charges -- though to be fair, I guess that'd be true for any docking station like this. What makes this particular product good, in my opinion, is the quality of the speaker system. Another good feature is how small the device is; I can easily fit it onto my cramped office desk. It even comes in a sleek, pleasing design. The only thing I don't like about this is the clock itself. It's so dim that I can barely read it in certain conditions. Still, I am quite pleased with it and plan to use it every day.

This headset is light, compact, and easy to use. The ear loop is quite handy for those of you who wear glasses, as it doesn't really get in the way. It's also small and unobtrusive; I just slip it into my shirt pocket whenever I'm not using it, and almost forget it's there. I also find it pretty comfortable once you get it fitted properly. When using it, I found the volume to be crisp and clear, and it responded to voice commands rather smoothly. This seems to be a good buy overall.

This is a wonderfully quiet hard drive that works well with my iMac. It's very easy to use and doesn't complain when I have my computer on all day. I also like that the design is nice and simple -- some of the other hard drives I've had have ugly, cloddy designs that irritate me. This one makes my office look that much more clean and professional. Another handy feature is that you don't need to switch it on every time you turn on your computer; it turns on automatically. Overall, I'd recommend this for anyone looking for a good hard drive.

I got this to replace my clunky old vacuum cleaner, and it's been a lifesaver for cleaning up the house. It has a powerful, satisfying suction that seems to get every speck of dirt out of my carpets -- though that does mean that I have to clean out the dust cup fairly often. It also has a handy carpet setting that ups the suction power. It's pretty quiet compared to what I'm used to, which makes cleaning the house a bit less headachy. It's fairly compact and lightweight, but still a little awkward to lug up the stairs. The retractable cord is a nice feature, but I keep accidentally stepping on it, causing it to retract at the worst moments. Overall, I'm satisfied with it, but they could still improve the design if they worked at it.

I have to get to work pretty early, so I need something to get me started. I'm not crazy about coffee, so I've been trying to find an energy drink that agrees with me. This brand is the first I've found that both wakes me up and doesn't have that off-putting chemical aftertaste. It doesn't give me as much energy as some of the other brands I've tried, but it tastes better. It's a nice compromise between flavor and kick. However, if you're looking for a more powerful boost, look at some other brands -- but they'll probably taste worse than this.

Aimed at non-professional filmmakers, this book covers the day-to-day nitty gritty details about producing a movie. It does NOT talk about the creative aspects of filmmaking, but rather the scheduling, budgeting, accounting end of things.It goes into great detail about the mundane business of producing movies, especially the planning aspect.Any amateur contemplating producing a film would benefit from this book. Highly recommended for them; not for the creative end.

This sturdy grip allows iPhone 4s owners to turn their phone into what feels like a "real" camera, with the proper "real" camera buttons. Since the iPhone has such an excellent camera built into it, this accessory can make sense, especially if you would like to mount the phone to a tripod.One drawback: this product only works with the Belkin App, so that limits what you can do with this accessory.

It's a peppy pink, which is distinctive and makes my phone stand apart. This basic case has protection for the back of the iPhone, and provides bumpers for the sides. It allows for good access to its ports and controls. The ribbed, textured feel is pleasant in my hands, and offers a good grip. My only complaint is its fit; the sides are slightly too loose. The price is right, however, for a backup case.

This smooth antiperspirant did its job, even in the Florida heat. Its fragrance was fresh and clean, and overall provided good protection.However, I had tremendous trouble getting the cap off. No matter what I tried, I couldn't get it off. Only after taking the scissors to it did the plastic cap come off.

Discover Thailand is perfect for anyone wanting to not only read about this destination, but also to see it. Nearly every page has one or more full-color photos.The content features must-see destinations and experiences, and itineraries based on region and theme, and different lengths of time for the visit. For example, on the page titled "Discover Bangkok," there are one-day, three-day and one-week itineraries.Each geographical area has a Things You Need to Know segment:1) At a Glance2) Accommodation3) Advance Planning4) Be Forewarned5) Costs6) Emergency Numbers7) Getting Around8) Getting There and Away9) Tech Stuff10) Travel SeasonsVisually compelling color-coded chapters make it easy to navigate.

For anyone who has used Neosporin for pain relief over the years, here's a convenient spray version you can use with one hand. The hard-plastic packaging prevents crushing, which means you can easily take Neo To Go with you (hence the name). It'll slip into a purse or in a glove box with ease. It's especially good for parents with kids that often get scraped knees or stubbed toes. Neo To Go also works for burns or cuts.

Bursting with vivid color, this Lonely Planet guidebook doesn't disappoint. Not only is it compelling to look at, it also has great insight and in-depth information.The book covers all the topics travelers look for: activities, food, geography, history, lodging, points of interest and detailed maps. It begins with a summary called This Is Spain, followed by Spain's Top 25 Experiences and Spain's Top Itineraries. After a Planning Your Trip chapter, the bulk of the book is broken down by geography into Spain's cities and regions: Madrid, Barcelona, Central Spain, Catalonia & Aragon, Spain's North Coast, Spain's East Coast & Islands and Andalucia. A "Spain in Focus" chapter covers fascinating topics such as flamenco, master painters, architecture, wine and the Spanish kitchen.This is an outstanding resource both for planning and as a take-along on a trip to Spain.

Perfect for those watching their weight, this tiny cookbook specializes in cocktails and party foods. It's the most recent in a series of best-selling Hungry Girl cookbooks focusing on healthy, low-cal recipes written and presented with a humorous flair. There's no seriousness behind the recipes for Pumpkin Pie-tini, My Oh Mai Ti or Buff Chick Hot Wing Dip.Each of the 75 recipes includes the calorie count; amounts of sodium, fat, carbs, fiber, protein and sugars;  number of servings; ingredients and clear directions. Alas, only a few photos show the finished creations.Before the recipes begin, the introduction includes a list of things to have on hand (such as a blender, shaker and corkscrew), a list of things to know (such as what types of alcohol to use in the cocktails, and how to make the recipes with no alcohol) and a list of recommended products to have on hand (such as diet cranberry juice drink and fat-free vanilla ice cream).I've enjoyed every one of these cookbooks, and every dish I've tried has been light and tasty. I look forward to many more in this fun series.Other Hungry Girl books:Hungry Girl: Recipes and Survival Strategies for Guilt-Free Eating in the Real World,Hungry Girl 1-2-3: The Easiest, Most Delicious, Guilt-Free Recipes on the Planet,Hungry Girl: 200 Under 200: 200 Recipes Under 200 Calories.Here's the chapter list:Introduction1. Martinis and Mixed Sips2. Margaritamania3. Fun with Blenders4. Cool Classics5. Crazy-Good Crowd-Pleasers6. Party Foods!

Did you know that a Red Lobster "Traditional Lobsterita" has the same calories as two Wendy's quarter-pound hamburgers? Trying to figure out what a lobsterita is? This book is for you.Perfect for anyone watching their waistline or wanting to be healthier, Drink This Not That is a must-have. Before picking this up, I didn't know that 21 percent of an American's daily calorie intake came from drinks. What a shocker! Simply returning to the calories that Americans drank 30 years ago would cut 23 pounds in a year.Drink This Not That follows the familiar pattern of the Eat This Not That series: Gorgeous graphics and full-color photos, food report cards, head-to-head comparisons, restaurant reviews, nutritional education. It also has recipes like the Cook This Not That book, for everything from chai tea to The Blue Monster smoothie.A particularly compelling section called America's Drinking Problem has pages of "worst-of" lists based on their healthiness: Worst water (Snapple's Agave Melon Antioxidant Water), worst bottled tea (Honest Tea Green Dragon Tea), worst energy drink (Monster Lo-Carb), worst bottled coffee (Starbucks Vanilla Frappuccino) and on and on. The worst beverage in America? Cold Stone PB&C in the Gotta Have It size, which is the sugar equivalent of 30 Chewy Chips Ahoy Cookies.Other books in this addictive series include:Eat This Not That! 2010: The No-Diet Weight Loss Solution,Eat This Not That! Supermarket Survival Guide,Cook This, Not That!: Kitchen Survival Guide,Eat This Not That! Restaurant Survival Guide,Eat This Not That! The Best (& Worst!) Foods in America!,Eat This Not That! for Kids!: Be the Leanest, Fittest Family on the Block!.Here's the chapter list:Introduction1. Drink Up, Slim Down2. At Your Favorite Restaurants3. Soft Drinks4. Functional Beverages5. Juice & Smoothies6. Dairy7. Coffee & Tea8. Wine9. Beer & Cocktails

Perfect for families looking for creative and amazing projects, Geek Dad had me bookmarking favorites to try right away. Many involve science in a fun, lightweight way. I can't imagine a child who wouldn't be excited by the prospect of some of these activities: the ultimate outdoor obstacle course, the light-up nighttime kite, the finger-painting with windup toys. The directions make each step simple and understandable.Each project has a table that describes the concept, lists the tools and materials needed, and gives ratings for cost, difficulty, duration and reusability. Costs are from $0 up to over $100. Difficulty levels begin with primary-school kids up to high school age. Duration is from 0 to 15 minutes up to 3 hours or longer. Reusability ranges from one-time-only use to "good forever."Throughout the book are drawings, maps, diagrams and tables. Everything's in black and white.Here's the chapter list:Introduction: About Being a Geek and a DadMake Your Own Geeky Games and Crafts1. Make Your Own Cartoons2. The Coolest Homemade Coloring Books3. Create the Ultimate Board Game4. Electronic Origami5. Cyborg Jack-o'-Lanterns and Other Holiday Decorations6. Windup Toy Finger Painting7. Create a Superhero ABC Book8. Model Building with Cake9. Pirate Cartography10. Parenting and Role-Playing Games11. A Never-Ending Demolition DerbyGeeky Activities for the Great Outdoors12. See the World from the Sky13. Best Slip `n Slide Ever14. Fireflies for Every Season15. Video Games That Come to Life16. Fly a Kite at Night17. Build an Outdoor Movie Theater18. The "Magic" SwingAwesome Accessories19. Smart Cuff Links20. Light-up Duct Tape Wallet21. Crocheted Dice Bag of HoldingGeeky Kids Go Green22. The Science of Composting23. Home HydroponicsBuild / Learn / Geek24. Build a Binary Calendar25. Portable Electronic Flash Cards26. Wi-Fi Signal Booster27. Cool LEGO Lighting from Repurposed PartsGeeky PotpourriIce Cubes Fit for a GeekExploding Drink Practical JokeAfterword: Pneumatic Wiffle Ball Cannon -- Failure as a ProjectAppendix A: Resources and References by ChapterAppendix B: RPG Character SheetAppendix C: Projects Listed by Rank

Ideal for adults wanting to improve the look and feel of their skin, Olay's Regenerist Skin Care Kit is the real deal. It advertises results after three weeks or so, but I saw a difference in about a week.Having tried a half-dozen or so of these skin care kits, I was skeptical that Olay had anything different. For one thing, the larger tube had much more of an exfoliant than I was used to, but it felt exhilarating. The creams in the smaller containers felt good when I applied them, leaving my face moist and supple, especially around my eyes.The real difference became apparent in the morning after I slept with the product applied. I could actually tell a difference: My skin looked more glowing and younger. Especially after a week, this Olay skin care kit made a believer of me!

This bar has a good flavor which seems too fresh to be a wrapped product. Unfortunately it is heavy and dense, and sits in your stomach like lead after you've eaten it. It's certainly healthy -- organic; sweetened with agave; no preservatives, trans fats or cholesterol; full of heart-healthy Omega-3 fats. I just prefer a lighter snack.

This simple book features charming illustrations of a diverse group of children engaging in a series of seven yoga poses.Each features a two-page set up that lends itself to guessing:"Stand with feet flat. Bend and touch ground. Bottom up! You are a... (next page) DOG. Stretch in the sun. Bark at your friend, ready for fun."It should be noted that the children in the book look very young, making the book better suited for toddlers and preschoolers but a little too "babyish" for older kids.  I wish that I could find a similar title with illustrations geared towards 6 - 9 year olds!

Sure, it's shockingly synthetic, but it's a flashback to childhood to have chocolate-y Magic Shell on a bowl of ice cream once in awhile.Chocolate pretzel flavor sounded like a good salty-sweet treat but this stuff is awful!For some unexplained reason it smells like dry dog kibble and tatstes like one might imagine that dog kibble might taste.It also separates very easily and requires LOTS of shaking to reach the proper consistency.My advice: Skip this one, and just sprinkle some crushed pretzels on top of the regular chocolate flavor!

We adopted a medium-sized dog who was collar-reactive.  A review of the rescue's records showed that she had experienced neck trauma, arriving in a too-tight collar that had cut into her neck to the point that it had to be removed by a vet.  Her anxiety level with any collar pressure was extreme, so we opted for a harness to help her learn to walk on a leash.We started out with the Freedom No-Pull harness and were very pleased with the dog's natural responsiveness to it, but would like a padded harness for longer walks.We were on the fence between this Chai's Choice harness and the Ruffwear harness. The Ruffwear had our preference of colors and had great customer reviews, but this harness specifically claimed to be "no pull".  I assumed that it would give some feedback to a pulling dog, like the Freedom harness does.It turns out that this harness is almost identical to the Ruffwear harness..  Other than a ring attached to the front of the harness, there is nothing to discourage pulling.Thankfully our dog is at the phase in her training where pulling has decreased and she's getting the idea of loose lead walking, as long as no squirrels cross our path!  If there is a close-range squirrel encounter, however, it becomes a matter of sheer strength to wrestle with her as she comfortably strains against this harness (and leash and leader) with all her might!It's not a bad harness, but if I had it to do over again I'd just go with the Ruffwear and/or keep looking for a true "No Pull" harness for high risk walks.

It seems like almost every review for this product so far is from someone who received a free product in exchange for a review.I did not.  I bought these at the store because they seemed like an easy option for an extended road trip.They are exceptionally easy to use and they get the clothes pretty clean.They can melt when stored at high temperatures, so don't plan to stock up and keep the extras in the summer garage! (Or travel with them packed in a hot car!)The label warns to protect them from heat, so no stars were deducted for the melting.However, the scent of these is really odd and off-putting.  It smells like flowers mixed with over-ripe apples, and it is very strong.  I'm not a fan, and would expect an apple scent to be labeled "Harvest", or "Orchard" or some other tell-tale clue.  Who wants to smell like cider all day?  I'd love to see these in Febreze's Linen & Sky or Meadow & Rain, instead of this cloying, not-so-fresh scent!

Good close shave and great battery life. Unfortunately, the foil is very thin when compared to higher end shavers and damages very easily.
