Sarah is an interesting character and since Meg doesn't seem to have any girlfriends, perhaps she should be carried over, especially since she and Meg get along so well.  I will say that if the decorating of rooms does not appeal to you, skip this book.  But I found it highly satisfying to see all the colors and designs come together.I'd also like to give a shout out to the fanciful, fun and flip titles Andrews comes up with for her books.  I'd like to see a story where Meg is sidelined in bed and her family has to do her bidding, and all the thousand and one little detective tasks that pop up.  She could be like the Spider and they are carrying out her web of discovery.  In the end, the killer will show up while she is incapacitated and alone -- and she triumphs ON HER OWN, with no need to be rescued.  It could be called, "Along Came a Spy-der."I would also love to see another Turing book published.  She's only written four and each one is a true original and a delight.

This near-brilliant book so beautifully and thoughtfully written is a joy to read.  Science and its definition is in the process of a profound change.  Eben Alexander is on the cutting edge in terms of the general populace about speaking to this.  Business as usual  will not do any more in the scientific community and these exciting new changes Dr. Alexander talks about are exhilarating.  Basically, they show a firm and enduring connection between the spiritual and the material worlds.The book may appeal to the scientific mind, but only one that has a degree of openness.  Otherwise, the book is primarily aimed at the general, educated or curious reader.  For me, for the first time Plato and Aristotle fell into place in a way I could apprehend them, as did several famous scientists and their theories and experiences, including Einstein, Planck and Schrödinger.  And I'm an English major!Dotted throughout the book and in between Dr. Alexander's clear, sparkling prose (with many nods to Ptolemy Thompkins), are personal stories that have been sent to him, each of which impacts what has just been discussed, or prepares one for explanations and insights to come.  For a "philosophy" book, it is, thankfully, not dry, but easily understood.  The book is well-organized and each chapter flows into the next.  We in this world have been under the thumb of a rigid scientific method for far too long.  It is time to evolve -- and Dr. Alexander's "Map of Heaven" is a sounding note that heralds a deeper and broader and more truth-oriented way of dealing with life and this world's functioning.This book is an eye-opener and I highly recommend it to anyone with average or above intelligence and a curious mind.  For those who do not fit this description, or who insist upon clinging to the rotted pillars of ancient Christian structures, or who are too mentally lazy to think of a title for their review, don't bother your little selves with this book.  You won't understand it, you will dislike it and then feel emotionally obligated to inflict your ridiculous or hateful reviews on honest folk.

Being a bit skeptical about a book like this, yet also intrigued, I began to read Susan Lander's "Conversations With History" with mixed feelings.  They didn't stay mixed for long.  For one thing, her humble, thoughtful, respectful tone spoke volumes right there about her character.  The other thing that won me over was that each of her spirit subjects came across as distinct from one another; they did not all sound like Susan Lander.  No one better typified this than Louis Armstrong.  When asked about scatting, he replied, "I took a little of this, a little of that.  And then just hit it where I was."  And as you might expect, Gandhi's wisdom had considerably more depth than John Belushi's.  Even their farewells showed the difference. Gandhi said, "May many blessings be bestowed upon all of you, and may you see clearly the blessings that you already have." John shouted out, "Sayonara!"This is a book of wisdom far more than of history.  Know that while most of the questions are interesting, they are not hard hitting, and in some instances when they come close to it, the subject refuses to answer.  I do wish Susan had asked more of them what they are now doing.  Much of the spiritual advice was similar but it was good to have the diversity of expressions.  Walt Disney sums it up:  "Never -- and I mean never -- underestimate your potential."  I don't think we poor humans can be told enough how powerful we truly are.I didn't entirely understand some of the coyness.  For example, Frederick Douglas declined to say what he died from.  Can it really matter anymore?  However, he redeemed himself when he talked about slavery in a deeper way.  Says Douglas about modern society, "There has been a societal decision that says:  it is okay to overwork individuals.  It is okay to pay them less than they are worth.  It is okay to cut their wages, or increase their hours, or cut their benefits that they cherish and count on for seeing them through old age.  It is okay that people do not have access to health care if they should become ill or infirm.  It is NOT OKAY, and I ask you:  How is this any different than slavery?  Though their employers may not beat people physically, they certainly do financially and emotionally."  (I was reminded here that Denmark's minimum wage is $20. an hour and their corporations do not suffer, nor are prices sky high.)  Perhaps Andy Warhol supplied the answer to Douglas's question when he said, "Humans are prone to perfectionism, so anytime we are sick or injured or disabled or what have you, we can be very judgmental and harsh with ourselves."  Gandhi takes this subject even deeper, commenting, "Any kind of violence goes against all we are as souls."  And what is more violent than slavery?  I love what Gandhi says about his assassination:  "I forgive you, I love you.  I do not choose to be victimized twice by carrying negativity, hate, and unresolved feelings toward this man."  Thus does he continue to teach us.There were some interesting commonalities among these departed spirits.  Many echoed what Henry Ford said, that "Earth is a very tough place."  It is also interesting in this context that most NDE'ers (those who have died and returned) have not wanted to come back to their earthly lives, but quite a few of  Susan's subjects expressed the wish to have had longer lives and they say they miss many things on Earth.  Patrick Swayze couldn't say enough times how badly he missed his "soulmate, Lisa."  Another thing in common is that an unusually large percentage of those interviewed died from pancreatic cancer.  According to Louise Hay this indicates a sense that life has lost its sweetness.  Makes you wonder.  I also wonder if Susan has heard from any of the friends or family of those she interviewed regarding the messages.I enjoyed every page of this book, especially for its unexpected wisdom, so I highly recommend it.  I think Susan Lander did an excellent job here and I'd like to read her second book on this subject.  Maybe next time she might consider Eleanor Roosevelt or Carlos Castaneda, or Hitler or Queen Elizabeth the I or Robin Williams?

I honestly don't know what people want. To give this perfect gem of a book less than five stars is insane.  But since so many readers mentioned how short the book was I can only think they were so disappointed at having to take less of Sharyn McCrumb's beautiful mastery, that they decided to vent their spleen and give the book less than five stars.  If so, how ungenerous, how short-sighted, how pitiful and how low."Nora Bonesteel's Christmas Past" is a blend of two separate stories, each written so precisely that not one word is out of place.  In some circles, the prose could pass for poetry.  Each droll expression, each accurate image, every emotional resonance, each character and all of their traits are laid out like the rolling patterns on the sublime quilt mentioned in the book.  In the end everything comes together in perfect harmony.  The reader has been taken on a journey that is gentle and yet, in its way, fierce, is hauntingly familiar and yet shows a style of life few live anymore, that is fast disappearing even as we turn the page.  And it is a journey well worth taking.  I simply cannot believe (although I've been assured it is true) that these characters are made up.  Surely, Nora and Spencer, Tom Honeycutt and J.D. Shull are McCrumb's ancestors whose histories and stories have been handed down in her family, whose present members even now are humbly putting the book on a shelf, too modest to let the neighbors know it is about them.If you want clash and dash and busyness and boring length padded with nonessentials, this will not be your book.  If you want a most lovely and satisfying experience to savor, with a book written with grace, subtle humor, humanity and clarity, you will fall in love with this book and remember it longer than most.  So what it is short.  Joy usually is.

I get immediately suspicious when I see "Scratch Baking Mix" on a box. It tells me that the manufacturers are willing to exaggerate or even lie to pull in customers. By definition, "made from scratch," excludes a packaged, boxed mix. True, you have to add two eggs and an entire stick of butter to this mix, but, still, that is not "from scratch."  God, I get so tired of all this hype, l don't you? Everything that is sold these days seems to be dishonest in one way or another, from 'natural' products, to houses, from cars to politicians, which tells us just what the money-makers think of us. But can you blame them? We so often let them get away with it.At any rate, in the service of honesty, I must tell you that I hate brownies. In the past 30 years I've eaten exactly one brownie that I absolutely loved. The rest were moderately to extremely inferior to that one special one made by a now departed friend. Her brownies were homemade (even this word has lost its original meaning since some manufacturers are calling their boxed mixes "homemade " because you end up putting some ingredients in at your home!), and aside from a deep chocolaty taste, were crisp on top and moist beneath. So now you know what my definition is of an excellent brownie.Immaculate Brownies came out with a good, satisfying chocolate taste, but they were too dry all the way through.  And speaking of honesty, I had to laugh when they put the calories per piece at 200. They claim that there are 16 pieces in the box, but let me tell you, in a baking pan 8 x 8, I got nine medium-sized ones!  You do the math.I followed instructions to the letter and felt that it was unlikely my fault or the fault of my normal-type oven that the brownies came out too dry. I offered them to some friends down the hall who stopped over when they smelled that divine warm chocolate scent and by that time the brownie crumbs had hardened to little pebbles.  Still, my friends agreed with me that, overall, compared to other mixes this one was more chocolaty and even the "little pebbles" tasted good.

There is no question that Mario Dirks has taken some smashing photos. The guy has genuine, sometimes exquisite, talent. But what he didn't have, perhaps, is a good editor. Starting with the cover photo, which looks like a clever commercial for a new car, the book is so crammed with pictures that only a few really stand out. The book itself is hard to handle, wants to close up on you, so worshipful appreciation of some of the pictures is well nigh impossible. I wanted to say, "Slow down, slow down, please." Some pages hold up to 4-5 pictures which does none of them justice.Also, I thought the layout lacking in finesse and structure. Of course, the thrust of the book is geographical, but it seems to me that categories of people, places, things, landscapes might have worked better. But that might entail more than one book! In fact, the layout could have been more presentable, understandable and beautiful had the one book turned into four. This book almost fell into the category of "family vacation photos."Finally, a word about the words. Unfortunately, the prose is pedestrian and often does not give you the details that you want to hear. Sure, Dirks is a photographer and is oriented spatially rather than verbally. He is more familiar with form than sound -- and it shows.  For example, he writes, "The first (sightseeing tour) is my first-ever ride on an elephant." So far, so good. He now has the opportunity of using his memory and imagination to rhapsodize about this experience. But all we get is, "Being carried through countryside some ten feet off the ground is an incredible experience." Incredible? At least, thank god, he didn't use that ubiquitous word, "amazing." But the thing is, because there is so little emotion in the writing, there is also very little depth.In short, the book does not do Mario Dirks' photos justice, but I'm glad we have them anyway.

I've never been impressed with authors who physically beat up their heroines. They usually do it for one of two reasons. Either they want to "prove" that their "girl" is "tough." or at least as tough as any man, or they are looking for the sympathy vote as they make their heroine a victim. For an author who strives to give her heroine as much smarts, strength and opportunities as any male, Donna Andrews has fallen far short of her goals in this book. As for the victim thing, she is outrageously out of date and out of style for the times. Meg Langslow spends the entire book hurt and getting further hurt and the last 30 pages were ruined for me as she does one stupid, inept, duh thing after another.In "The Good, the Bad, and the Emus" Andrews proves once again that she doesn't handle action scenes very smoothly. It's as if she simply cannot imagine the action she is writing about. She takes a competent, strong, smart, imaginative woman and turns her into a total dunce in the last 30 pages.I've read all of Andrews books. They are deliciously unique with memorable characters, lots of fun and plenty of excitement. But when it comes to action they each hold too many characters who fall apart or stand by idly. Michael is one of the most underwritten characters of all -- a temptingly sexy, viral, interesting man who spends all his time standing about or taking care of the kids.  Meg talks more to aging P.I. Stanley than she does to her own husband. What is the point of Rose Noire? A rather fascinating character, she is used only to mention a fact or two, or to spell Meg from mother duties. Dad is a little boy who is always running to and from a scene of trauma. Rob seems to have no sense and so does senseless things or nothing at all. The only truly active character in the book is Spike the Dog, and he can be quite irritating. This book even has a do-nothing chief of police for the most part.So, the last 30 pages. Would any sensible 90-year old woman head butt a Valkyrie? Not on your life? Read it and weep in this book. Would a 90-year old woman jump vigorously up and down on a metal cellar door? Nope. Andrews talks about "brittle bones," but apparently in a failure of imagination, she cannot visualize what that means. But Meg is so passive that even a 90-year old shows her up. She comes to on the floor, the killer leaves and what does she do? Try to get up? No. Crawl away? No. She chats with the woman beside her unraveling some of the mystery. Not the time! But wait, it gets even more laughable. There they are, Meg and the old woman, outside in the still night air with perhaps a hundred people close by who could help them. As they both get away temporarily from the killer they both worry about how to raise the alarm. Hello? Have neither of you vocal cords? A sudden scream would raise all hell at that time of night and be heard for miles, let alone just a 100 feet away! And don't tell me the emus knocked down the emu-proof fence, yet again! But of course they did, for we need to have yet another way to batter Meg. The dogs attack the killer who never thinks of shooting them? No, because for the sake of a laugh, if not common sense, we must be given a picture of a large dog sitting on the killer -- something it has done before in another book. Proving once again that Andrews can visualize doing nothing much better than doing something.Andrews also is timid about emotions. Meg suffers through a whole host of them -- and rightly so -- but alas, no release for her or for us as she keeps them hidden inside. We do not see a crucial reunion -- the two go inside the house and shut the door. Again, no emotional release or full-circle moment. Mother shows up, an incidental character who is the high-hand who shuts off the two who are reconciling in private in a very clumsy way. But the biggest reunion falls flat.  Grandfather, always a man of many words and damn the consequences comes face to face with a hugely important person from his past and all he can do is dither and squeak, "Morning," "Er . . . likewise," "Um, yes," his entire catalogue of emotional outpouring.And, finally, not to be mean, I love kids, but I do not love Meg's kids. Andrews writes the boys as just another pained trial for Meg, who dips in and out of their lives just as they are either entering or leaving some horrible mischief. They have no manners and act like barbarians. They are always disagreeable and always seem to be competitive with each other in a 'boys will be boys' stereotype as odious as the 'female as victim' stereotype. Josh, upon seeing his mother (did Andrews forget what Meg looks like at this point in the plot?) filthy, bruised and bandaged, has his first words be that Daddy has brought you a doggie bag, can I have your bacon. Really? Can we make these boys a little more human?Even though for me the last 30 pages were a bust, and the emus were explained and detailed far too much, still the book had a very good plot and I would lend it to someone to read, if asked, and smile while doing it.

I've read quite a number of books on animal spirituality, but LInda Bender's "Animal Wisdom" is the most intelligent book of them all. She starts off by asking a good question regarding newscasts using cute animal stories:  "Why is it that we dwell on the parts of a newscast that make us anxious and depressed while dismissing our favorite part as mere fluff?"  She thinks it's odd that a source of our happiness "at once so reliable and so universal isn't regarded as more significant."  Well, the dread answer to that, of course, is, that is how our "survival-at-any-cost" society faces life. The joke's on us, though, for, as Bender points out numerous times with facts and stories, animals are the measure of how we humans are surviving, either well or not very. At this moment in time, I'd have to say we are struggling toward "not very."  Then she lays it out for us with shivering truth:  "The fewer plants and animals we are able to recognize as individuals -- recognize well enough to name them -- the more alienated we have come to feel from ourselves, the Earth and God, the Source." Our cultural blinders prevent us from also reporting how many plants, flowers, trees, fields, forests, sides of mountains, parts of rivers and oceans, animals, birds, butterflies, bees and other nonhuman creatures have been decimated in Syria, Gaza, Afghanistan, Iraq, Ukraine, etc. etc. etc.You may ask, so what? These are just soulless creatures, not as important as humans. You'd be wrong. Animals very much have souls and within them is the same altruistic impulses found in the human soul -- and this according to the latest scientific studies. Bender says, "It is this altruistic impulse in the animal's soul that we violate when, out of a sense of entitlement, we seize and exploit rather than permitting the animal to give." You may say, "Well, fields and oceans and mountains and forests don't have souls!" I would ask you, "Where would you think to find the soul of the Earth if not in all areas kissed by the Sun?" Scientists now know with great certainty that the Earth is indeed, one total and complete entity lifeform, a whole system unto itself. If a dog has a soul, which no aware person would doubt, surely the Earth does too!And lest ye forget, we humans are very much "animals." Bender clarifies, "The hierarchical view that holds humans inferior to angels and animals inferior to humans is based on a faulty premise. All of God's creations are perfect, and it is impossible for one perfect thing to be inferior to another perfect thing."  Thus are we truly all created equal!  Which explains how it is we can all be "One."  Some of you more enlightened ones have observed that animals appear to have a "connection" to Spirit that humans have to work hard to achieve. Bender teaches us that "What all creation myths have in common is the idea that whatever catastrophic event put an end to Paradise applied only to humans. Wild animals . . . were fundamentally happy and continue to be fundamentally happy to this day."  She adds, "We cannot find our way back to Paradise without them."This book, though slender in volume, is wide-ranging. One of my favorite sections has to do with St. Francis of Assisi. Lots of interesting comments here as she delves into St. Francis's mystical abilities. She observes, "Francis's great discovery was that you have to act trustingly before you can feel trust." A scary proposition, but one that is nonetheless crucial. However, Bender helps us to find our way into trust:  "You are practicing trust when you give up your attachments to the way you want things to be going at any given moment and surrender to the unwelcome splendor of whatever it is that's happening instead." I love the phrase "unwelcome splendor."Okay, so we hapless humans lost ourselves Paradise. Now what? Well, Bender offers us this definition that we can all understand and relate to:  "Paradise is a spiritual ecosystem in which every species has some essential role to play." I get that, don't you? We may not all be able to be saints, but all of us can surely try to live inside this definition.My most favorite chapter deals with William Blake and Job. She lets these men help her understand God.  We are treated to brief, pithy explications of God's words to Job and the famous Blake poem whose first lines can still raise the hairs on the back of my neck, "Tiger, tiger, burning bright/In the forests of the night." Bender explains, in part, our disconnect from our understanding of God:  "To look at an animal's culture from that animal's own point of view is to glimpse some aspect of divine mind that is foreign to the human mind, yet not entirely incomprehensible to it."The tone of the book, aside from its intelligence, kindness and clarity, is more good-natured than humorous. For example, in her chapter on death, telling neat stories, quoting Rupert Sheldrake, Mark Twain and Dr. Eben Alexander, she says, "At this point, you are probably expecting me to ask you to join in a rousing chorus of 'The Circle of Life.'  Relax, she doesn't.  But she does remind us that even when we're "in the trenches" facing death that "prayer isn't about asking for things to be different. It's about asking to be shown the blessing that is within the pain."  Definitely a hard request, but it's necessary to find the courage to do so.At the end of the book Bender gives us some really fine and very doable instructions for communicating with animals, the major action being this:  "By quieting the mind, focusing on the present, and opening the heart, we create the sacred space in which our souls can encounter the souls of animals."  I found this out for myself when two red squirrels were fighting and chittering away loudly on my porch railing where I'd set out some birdseed.  I did as Bender instructed, then walked out the door -- which put me only about four feet from them. Ordinarily, they'd freak and leap off the porch. This time, though, both stopped their squabbling and turned to me. I greeted them quietly, pleasantly, saying I hoped they enjoyed the seeds and not to fight over them and requested them  to leave some for the birds. They "spoke" to me.  I learned that one was an old male squirrel and the other an almost-full-grown baby squirrel from another family. One needed to keep his energy up to live; the other needed to live to grow up. I asked them to be willing to share and promised I'd continue to put seeds out for them. The fighting stopped. Each ate so much and then left the rest for the birds. I've since seen them together on the railing, eating peaceably after a brief initial exchange of territorial declarations that were quite unselfish.One of the best things about this book is Bender's ability to give us an idea, and then show us how to apply it concretely and specifically. That's a rare gift.  The book is quite accessible to all regardless of education or background. This is the kind of life-saving, world-changing, mind-opening book that we humans need so badly today. Our children's hopes and dreams  may be dying for lack of the information contained in "Animal Wisdom." When you can't believe in nor trust anything organic in this world, what do you do? You turn to technology, to metal and plastic, to screens and robots. You think these will provide you with a measure of safety, but that's not how life works. You will still get your heart broken, still become ill, still fail and experience grave loss and then you will find that much of technology was a dead-end road.  I am not anti-technology, and neither is Bender, but the exclusive or near-exclusive dependency upon it, is like sitting on a raft on the ground while expecting the buoyancy of waves to take you where your soul wants to go. You will wait a long, long time. Unless there's a flood which will definitely complicate things.

Joan Rivers constantly surprises -- and that says it all about a woman whose experience of life is considerable, as is her courage. "Bouncing Back" is the best book I've ever read about dealing with adversity and defeat and overcoming it. Sure, it's funny on every page, but it is also wise and practical on every page. In fact, if Norman Cousins had had Joan's book, he wouldn't have needed "Candid Camera" reruns and he would have cut his healing time in half.The book intends to reassure in every category. For example, you don't hear much about the second wave of grief in most books on the subject. Joan's insights on the matter are instructive. In fact, her insights are at once both humble and wise and will allow you a different perspective, one that will lead you to healing.Let me say something about her humor. If you're hurting, I'm sure you are not in the market for a "funny" book that will poke fun at what you're going through. Don't worry, this book does nothing like that. It is full of warmth, love, support and encouragement. The humor involved tends to be an enlightening sort of humor, or a joke that aims to make you smile, but never does it aim to make you flinch or laugh mockingly at yourself. Some people can't take a joke, even in marriage. (Okay, I had to.) Because some people are unable to laugh at themselves in a healthy way, anyone else joking about others' lives and habits is seen by them as disrespectful and mean. If you have seen Joan in this role, be aware that you won't see that Joan in "Bouncing Back." You can, in other words, trust her when it comes to this particular topic.This is also not a braggy book. She writes about herself in a straight-forward way, in the way that people do when they have matured and evolved from their youth. She is the topic she knows most intimately and she gamely uses herself in order to teach you lessons. How awful it would be (as we have sometimes seen) if at 80 we were still as shallow as we were at 20. You won't find that situation here. Frankly, I think if Joan were a man she would be known (as Don Rickles is) as "An American treasure" and celebrated at the Kennedy Center Honors. The thing about comedians is that if they don't tell the truth, they don't last long. You may not approve of Joan's making a joke of a Hollywood starlet's unfortunate choice of evening wear, but you must admit that her remark hits home. I saw Joan back in the 60's in NY doing her comedy act when she still had brown hair. The audience was split. Half of it (mostly women) thought she was sharp, edgy and totally hilarious. The other half (mostly men) thought she was uppity. Well, sirs, it was a whole slew of "uppity women" who changed the face of American culture, so let's hear it for uppity women in general and Joan Rivers in particular.Here's an indication of how she writes:  "The other mental tape I like to play is the one that says, as I keep meeting new people, 'I like these people. I'm going to have a good time today.' I'm not saying that you should play that tape at a tax audit or gum surgery, but the prophecy often does become a self-fulfilling one."I say, tell yourself, "I like this book. I'm going to have a good time reading it." Then buy the book! You won't be sorry.

Beethoven is my favorite classical composer, bar none.  I've read other biographies about him over the years.  The problem with Jan Swafford's "Beethoven," however, is that as much as I love Beethoven, I do not love Beethoven himself as much as Jan Swafford does.  Therefore, I could have done without so much (unnecessary) minutiae, such as what the priest intoned in Latin at little Ludwig's baptism.  And we come upon it AGAIN 800 pages in!  Another example:  it takes six lines of type to let us know that Beethoven's birthday is lost to history.If you want history, culture and the wide view of people and the doings of that era, in addition to learning about Beethoven, this is the book for you. For example, Clemons August, Swafford tells us, "may have" admired another LVB and summoned him to Bonn.  Ten pages are then devoted to explicating Clemons August.The information is colorful and fulsome, but unfortunately it is organized in such a way that causes confusions and repetitions.  Swafford tells us in Beethoven's own words, which are found plentifully throughout, that Beethoven claimed his models were Socrates and Jesus. But we really never learn why.  Swafford muses a great deal.  He begins Chapter 25, "Only to youth can love seem easy.  With the years come losses that taint the yearning and the passion." While this may or may not be true, I looked to find it in Beethoven's life and could not discover that particular conclusion. He seems to have always found love difficult.I will say Swafford does not give Beethoven's music short shrift, but writes knowledgeably about it. Concerning the Missa solemnis, he says, "There were two streams in Beethoven's music, the secular-humanist and the sacred, and the later had never gotten its due." He illustrates some of his points with the music in printed form on the page.If you have all the world and time and wish to begin or continue a love affair with Ludwig von Beethoven, this is your book.  It is also your book if you are doing research. While at times Swafford can be tedious, giving way too much information to the reader, overall, perhaps we can say his passion excuses him.

Let me start with the "big negative" first. For me (but possibly not for you) one-third of the book is unusable. That's because I have no interest in following a meal plan, couldn't do it if you paid me! I would have preferred more recipes in that space. A few minor disagreements: too many recipes with salsa, jalapenos, red pepper flakes, black pepper, cayenne in them; too many recipes with too many ingredients in them; too many recipes with arcane (to me) ingredients I've either never heard of or cannot get where I live, such as Malaysian red palm fruit oil, grape tomatoes and coconut aminos, to name just a few. However, she did turn me on to Cumin, for which I'm grateful! There are also a number of exotic recipes that I really didn't understand, such as "Pork Souvlaki Kabobs with Tzatziki" and "Pounded Chicken Paillards." I wouldn't mind someone else cooking these dishes for me, though. BTW, what is "smoked paprika"?Many of you will have no problem whatsoever with my "negatives," and if that's so, you will love the entire book. The first part is a goldmine of tips, advice and suggestions for healthy eating, including  "swapping" one type of food for another. The recipes, by and large, are appealing and doable. Loved the "Toasted Macadamia Nut Dressing," "Swiss Chard With Olives," and "Chickpeas With Spinach, Lemon, and Tomatoes" -- although beware there are 11 ingredients, including black pepper, monk fruit extract, onion and curry powder.JJ Virgin has a pleasing writer's voice and her recipe directions are clear and easy to follow. There's quite a few charts and lists that are invaluable. "The Virgin Diet Cookbook" taught me a lot. You will profit from it even if you don't need to lose weight!

I've always had a high opinion of Iyanla Vanzant. She's been through the hardest of times and always picked herself up from them, bringing with her the wisdom she accrued and then disseminating it out to her fellow human beings. For that we are so grateful!This book is a gift box, wrapped up with tape and ribbons. A lovely piece of work. However, that's just the problem. There are so many "do this's" and "do that's" that it can be overwhelming and feel like a closed system. It seems clear that Vanzant is the type of person who likes to hand herself large chunks of life whenever possible. Some of us can't handle that. The book feels driven, as if you MUST follow each chapter as demanded of you, no matter what. The thing is, I've been through the "forgiveness mill" -- and believe me -- if you do not already know -- that "mill" can grind your heart to pieces. It can take days, weeks, years to come to the end of one's blame and reach forgiveness. And all the "tapping" in the world won't get you there sooner! No allowance is made for this in the book. Instead, there is the idealistic expectation of "21 days and out!" Plus, there are deep spiritual reasons why forgiveness is necessary in order to evolve, but most of these reasons are not mentioned. For example, if we agree on another level to everything that happens to us, then, basically, when someone treats us abusively, we have agreed to it. To then not forgive that person is to act the hypocrite. Of course this is a "mind" statement and does not deal with the emotional -- another kettle of fish altogether!The wisdom in Vanzant's book is solid and helpful. The stories and anecdotes, while often skimpy on details, nevertheless open your awareness and are certainly interesting. Just know that this is a WORKBOOK and you use it everyday in detail. It is harder to get through than the year-long Course in Miracles because there's so much to do, to feel, to learn, but if you can modify the instructions and take it down a notch, you will be far ahead in the game of life, that much more empowered, free and loving. This book has a lot to teach you -- just be patient with it.

And that's a good thing!  Some drawing books are too wordy but Chris Hart knows what to say and how to say it with a minimum of verbiage.While the emphasis in "Fashion Design Studio" is on, well, fashion, the lessons are so clearly and simply laid out that anyone could profit by it even if they were not interested in fashion.  The drawings and instructions are easy to follow.  You get little important details like how to make creases in someone's clothing, and are shown the difference between squinting eyes and hopeful eyes.The drawings are appealing, as are the "models," but while this may seem to some a picky point, in this day and age I noticed very quickly that all of them are of white women, as I am.  I would have liked to have seen Asians and Blacks represented.  They draw, too.But overall, a delightful book, probably more of a beginner's book, but it holds lessons for anyone wanting to improve their ability with proportions, have more realism in their pictures, and apply useful tips that are inspiring.

I didn't expect much from this book, which was a good thing.  I took a "wait and see" attitude with a positive upturn.  I read it willing to be enlightened and uplifted, but that didn't happen. The reason is because TS writes in a jumpy, abstract, convoluted manner, saying a few mysterious and curious things about a subject, then moving on without elucidating. You keep hoping he will come back to the topic, but that never happens. The book is basically in a question and answer format, and there are many, many questions that TS never answers. Instead he will pull off to the side, or change the subject. The book should have been edited more stringently.I gave it two stars because he does say some important and good things about surrender.  However, I've been around a long while and frankly there are things I know that clash with what TS teaches, little mistakes he drops into his conversation in the book that indicate he is clueless about a few vital things a spiritual teacher needs to know.  I'll just give one small example because he is a work in progress like all of us and one supposes he will grow and learn like all of us and I do not wish to make a big deal out of it.  He refers to the body as a "machine."  It is nowhere near to being a machine.  That is a deep insult on a sacred entity without which we wouldn't be able to be here on Earth.  Also, he mentions love very little -- too little for the level he claims to be on. In life, LOVE is both the message you are carrying and the road on which you travel.  To lose sight of that is to lose sight of the truth, and then you have lost yourself. The best trackers know who they are.I would not recommend the book, although there are a few (too few) exercises in it, some of which are written badly so there are questions about what to actually do.  Other exercises are fine but can be found in other places. Overall, I feel this book is more an offering of ego than of love, yet I do applaud TS's intentions, whose end result, I'm sure, has been helpful to some people..
The brush is beautiful, sturdy, easy to hold with bristles that are kind to my hair.  I find no fault with it and assume it will last a long time.

Just want to add my two cents in upholding the veracity of George Jacobs memoir of Frank Sinatra. The book is kind but truthful and draws an unusually complete portrait of one complicated man.One of the things biographies do is show us how little we know about anyone. I think about all the "secrets" that were shared in this book about famous people and realize how easy it is to idealize someone, especially when you are mostly ignorant about who they are. I expect that we are just as nave today about our "stars" be they political or movie or sports stars. This book has soul. And therefore it has the capacity to teach us something about the world and ourselves, to help us grow up a bit. Because of the respect and courtesy Jacobs displays in his stories, we are moved to humility as we realize that people are just people -- like us in so many ways -- no matter what they've achieved or how much money they've made. Life is the school we are all in and despite the "glory" and "fame" that accrues to someone, they still have to go through the same paces as the rest of us. In that sense, we are all truly equal. But, oh! don't we just love to put people on pedestals!The only confusion I found in the book was that Jacobs claims that Frank believed he was the man who put JFK in the White House, with help from Sam Giancana, yet the "proof" was not very forthcoming. There seemed to be no clear cut evidence of this and everything seemed to be merely implied. But my main wish is to know more about George Jacobs. It was clear that FS was the love of his life (nothing sexual intended) and when you receive a betrayal from that person it can easily end your life or defeat your life from then on. We've all seen it. But George had something deep and strong within him. Though his heart mended somewhat I'm sure it always had a bit of a crack in it. Despite that, he managed to grow post-Frank, and give himself a decent, loving life, shaping his formerly sterling character into spiritual gold.

If you are post-60 and have a fairly decent life with few physical problems, this book will bring you down faster than turning a page. Billy Crystal (who I love in all other respects) declares in every paragraph his intense focus on the negative, on every rotten thing that can happen to a person as they age. Many of these things DO NOT happen and many of them are fixable. Attitude is everything in life and unfortunately, our Billy has a bad one. He doesn't seem to have any spiritual beliefs or practices (not talking religion here), so therefore he tends to feel he is all on his own in the no-man's land of the elderly. He doesn't seem to connect up his attitude with his experiences!To give him his due, I admit that to be a comedian one must be clever and insightful at seeing "what's wrong," and that's fine, but to project "what's wrong" out into your future years is a really dumb thing to do. I believe that for every "what's wrong," in life, there are at least two "what's right," and I find this belief becomes my experience. There is so much "what's wrong" in this book that I think it could make some people sick, especially if you have an open nature.It's possible that Billy's long-time insomnia has soured his faith that he can handle his life and make it better no matter how old he is. There comes a time as you age when you begin to realize you control very little in this world, including your own life. The thing is to make your peace with it and then try to understand over time why this is so. I would also say that if you don't find your life getting better, happier, and you becoming wiser as you age, you've taken a wrong turn somewhere and had better back up and look around. Insomnia, in psychological and spiritual terms, indicates you are not trusting the process of life. It is also a control issue. You can't "let go" and lose consciousness every night because you have too many fears of what could "go wrong" if you weren't mind-meddling in your own and others' lives.If you want to go down the "poor me" route as you get older, then by all means, get this book and allow Billy to commiserate with you and make you laugh in the process. But if you prefer being positive, upbeat, optimistic, looking for the joy in each moment, knowing the best is here or close by and wishing to be loving rather than worried and fearful, this book will slam you quickly into a very helpless place where you will find yourself the victim of the world and your body. Empowerment? Forget it! This book is a compendium of all the negative possibilities you could possibly face in old age, so just shoot me now!

There was something pure, humble, seeking and appealing in the young woman who first rowed across the Atlantic. You felt she had integrity, a solid spiritual core that was evolving with each pull of the oars. That young woman is no more.The woman who wrote Start Rowing preaches, denounces, takes sides, argues, is negative and focuses on all that is wrong. Even her book title is an exhortation. I submit that drifting is necessary to spiritual growth. Instead of listening to the wind, the waves, the sea life, she fills her mind with books on tape so she is not even present to her own experience. The first woman seemed to know how to listen -- not only inside but to her environment. She appeared to be divinely guided even at her most confused. She wrote a book full of fun, wisdom and wonderful word pictures. She gave you hope and you just knew that Life had singled her out for something special. It feels as if that is no longer the case. In this book she is just another crusader. If you insist on being ordinary, then ordinary is what you will live with.This present woman has little or no wisdom to impart. She has advice instead, suggestions for saving things, overwrought emotional reactions, and, unfortunately, a sort of bored prose. Wisdom and spiritual knowledge most often come in the silence. If you fill your every waking moment with thoughts and opinions, you don't hear what is given to you.Her first mistake was changing the sacred name of her boat:  Sedna. Did she think it meant nothing? That goddess herself would guide and protect her. A pact was made.  She broke it. She changed the name because of commercial concerns, i.e., money, since her main supporter wanted their name on her ship. Thus she began her journey losing a part of herself and insulting her true patron. No wonder she misjudged to the point where she had to abort her trip and return to land.The book is shallow and confusing. It was not terribly clear that she was making actually two trips and would hit land and rest up and recuperate for awhile before starting the second half. It didn't seem on the up and up that she did this. To me, rowing the Pacific doesn't mean stopping in the middle for a vacation. If I don't understand the ramifications of this choice, it goes to the lack of clarity in Savage's writing.In short, the book feels like something she promised to do but then made very little preparations on her trip to fulfill this obligation which she turned into a grinding chore. I can't help wondering if she had been present more often during her row, what amazing insights and revelations might have come to her -- for she does have the ability to receive them. We saw this in her first book. This book is more about research for what is happening in the marine world, than it is about her own experiences and thoughts. Magic touched Roz Savage, but she shrugged it off in favor of the mundane.

People who do not like to think deeply, or use their imaginations, or stray from the 'norm,' or think outside the box will probably not appreciate Shirley's new book, "What If . . . "  But if you're the type of person who loves to explore new ideas, put intellectual puzzle pieces side by side and compare them, try to figure out the larger picture, speculate on meanings and causes, then you will have a good time with "What If . . ."MacLaine's new book is almost a compendium of what many free thinking advanced souls are ruminating about within themselves and with their friends. She runs the gamut from politics to alien DNA, carries on regarding the Founding Fathers and Downton Abbey, references an overview of past lives and life being "show business,", dwells on the spirituality of animals and the purpose of UFO's. In fact, this book could be the newest entry in adult party games for the intellectually brave and curious. You'd all gather around and then choose a page at random and read the "What if . . ." that's on it. Discussion ensues! Fun! Also involving -- and everyone would learn something and feel exhilarated. Laughter would abound except for those who would take it all so seriously. But isn't that always the way with life and party games?One of my favorite parts was where she gave 140 definitions of "love." Some were hilarious; others profound. A few made you cry. But a brilliant chapter. Her comments on "hope" are illuminating -- and poignant in their way. And who knew the Dalai Lama had a dirty mouth? She drums up some good possibilities as to why we all seem to be losing our memories, but ignores what, to me, is the most likely culprit:  the world is now so polluted that it has to be affecting the one organ that uses most of the nutrients we take in:  the brain. I don't think her advocating for cynicism would hold up, spiritually. I get her point, but if we create our own reality cynicism would not be our friend. Likewise, I wish she would question her need to destroy us all with some planetary cataclysm, or make us 'victims' of an extraterrestrial race. As Seth says, "You get what you concentrate on. There is no other main rule."I found it discouraging to read some reviews that complained because Shirley didn't "dish" as they wanted her to, or tell stories, anecdotes (there are a few of these, actually) or get real personal (which she also did a time or two). These people obviously had rock hard expectations that were not going to be met by this book. So they turned away, called it "boring" or "just thoughts" (what else is there??). In the process they lost a good deal of wonderful mind-stuff to play with and learn from. But maybe they couldn't have handled it in the first place. Here's YOUR test:  If you've read two or more reviews of this book, you can definitely handle it! You've got the mind and curiosity to follow each page down to the ground and up to the heights.

Andrea Syrtash and Jeff Wilser won me over quickly when I read, ""Don't trust the rules, trust yourself." They explain, "Rules in dating keep you inside your head and out of an experience; they make you question your own instincts. And your instincts are better than what anybody else can instruct you to do (or not do)." (And don't feel too played by the controversial title. They freely admit the title is just for getting attention.)The two writers interact with one another putting their own slants on the topics. This works fairly well most of the time even as they contradict one another occasionally. It gives the reader some perspective. But what doesn't work are the waste-of-space comments in gray from ordinary people. Most of these comments are lacking. They are inane, stupid, incomplete, confusing and sometimes gross. I think they bring the tone of the book decidedly down. Why would these two clever, witty, informed and insightful people want to put words from people who are not those things on a par with their own?Syrtash and Wilser are a strange pair. Jeff can come off as a dud, even a skunk. He's very funny, quite smart -- yet still has a lot to learn -- probably because he's been in so many shallow relationships and so few really deep, long-lasting ones. These last are necessary for achieving genuine depth since the only thing that really gets you to 'profound' is trust and short relationships do not build enough trust.I also wanted to kick his sexist butt for flapping his mouth here and there about being for equality between the sexes, then putting in a horribly out-dated and cliched sentiment about counseling his daughter to wait to have sex or perhaps join a nunnery. Really, Jeff? Is your daughter going to be so much better than, so superior to all of the women you lied to and fooled? No one who writes this about a "figment daughter" is able to give objective, nonsexist advice with any integrity. As for paying on the first date, Jeff, let me just say that when women receive equal pay for equal work, I'll be happy to pay. Or maybe when the glass ceiling is shattered and half of Congress is female. How's that!Some of Jeff's shallowness can be seen in his frequent reference to "chemistry":  "You either have chemistry or you don't." Oh? Chemistry can change, it can grow, it can diminish, it can disappear and then reappear. He doesn't seem to realize this, or that there are different kinds of chemistry. Some of that chemistry is generated by one's own need for sex -- regardless of with whom. So you can tick off 50% of the chemistry you feel for someone right there! Next, hard as it is to admit, some people are only good for 1, 2, or 3 encounters and then the chem is all used up. You are more likely to realize this over time without sex. It'll just happen. Besides,chemistry isn't necessarily meant to last in promising relationships. It's meant to transform into love at some point -- and down the road a piece, that's where all the excitement awaits.I know I'm picking on Jeff, but he deserves it, ha. Although he does shell out many an apology, as if he were using the book to "make amends" to old girfriends. He says he's changed. Perhaps Andrea's influence? One hopes! I must say he keeps the book zinging with his humor, making it worth the read just to have a laugh, such as, "All relationships end poorly:  either in a breakup or in death."Andrea does some solid writing in this book, making things clear, giving good examples and being warm and thoughtful. The problem with the book overall is that it assumes everyone is normal and healthy and all they have to do is read this book, see the options and then choose correctly or intuit the right feeling. The advicegiven is really a mere outline. Let's face it, life is just much too complicated and most people are damaged. You can't enter a relationship from your left brain -- which governs rules, logic, reason. Without imagination, intuition and emotion, there is nothing -- unless you want to cozy up to a robot. There's a reason you are attracted to the punks and skanks! Using rules and logic will not make your attempts to connect to someone better. However, reading this book will give you some tips that might help steer you in a healthier direction.Glad the book has an index. I'd recommend getting the book, especially if you are under 30. If you need this book post-30, you are in a lot of trouble and may need a therapist.
As a veteran I am proud and want my service known to anyone who sees it. Great product, and is on my car today.
Not worth the money. Loses charge after around 100 hours.
Cute Bromancing movie. Brings out what friends will actually do for each other. I saw this in the theater when it came out, and needed to watch again.

Really great story line, and it will keep you on your toes throughout the majority of the movie. I could honestly see the events unfold in real life too with some of the crazies out there in today's society.
a Decent sequel to the original.
I Loved the first movie, but this one isn't as good in my opinion. still funny though and worth a watch to fill your entertainment need.
Not worth the time to download. crashes often with my Samsung Avant, and my Nexus one. Needs more support options.

4:36 Mins After getting this product was wondering if it would be worth it. I am going to say yes, it is. My daughter likes to sleep with music on and my wife and I find it difficult at times to get music for her for her age. with this device we can run music to her room from ours via Bluetooth. This thing works well and can reach up to 15 feet on the Bluetooth range (Our room to hers).It doesn't come with any instructions unfortunately but its rather easy to figure out once you get going with it.You can get music through it via the following:BluetoothLine inmicro SD card (forgot to mention in video)FM RadioWorth the money in my book and the lights will keep children entertained for a while at night helping with sleep. Don't know if it will effect seizures or not but I don't see warnings on the box. and the voice on it seems like it may be a french accent or possible Chinese.

3:36 Mins I got this item through a promotional offer online. This device allows you to charge up to seven items simultaneously while allowing a full charge dispersed equally between them. I have used all seven ports together overnight and am pretty impressed that it not only charged everything, but it didn't overheat or short out at all like another similar device I have used.This is definitely worth the money for people who may need multiple charging points from USB cables. It would be nice to see a car charger for this eventually which would make this more friendly for cabbies, buses and carpooling.Either way as stated in my video, I am giving it a 5 of 5 stars. Excellent product.

0:38 MinsThis book is riveting to say the least. though it is 6 chapters, its well written and thought out as you take your adventure to a new level from different worlds to a united front. You learn that with the main character not only in knowing ones self, but what type of perseverance you would take to become who you are meant to be no matter the struggle.It has a lesson to be learned as well that will teach you what it takes to struggle through lifes issues to include how special you are even if others may not see it. The importance of a families bond is also brought out in a new light here.Well worth the read and definitely more then what you pay for.

This is indeed an excellent introduction to Barth. The first part is an amazing short background to Barth's background -- succinct placement -- and the second part covers everything from then on.  It is clear! It is a really what it says it is -- an Introduction.  Others are more convoluted. This is a good place to start.

This is the classic study of the main theological dimensions of Western Mysticism as found in Augustine, Gregory, and Bernard.  There have been lots of other studies since (McGinn's work, for example, covers this terrain), but this study is perhaps even better for the actual practitioner looking for very specific detail of certain stages in the mystical process. Cogent, clear, definitive in its way.  Of course there are other strands of mystic understanding in this tradition -- the desert fathers, Cassian, Bonaventure, Eckhardt, etc. -- but these are crucial figures in understanding the long history.The book is somewhat strangely organized -- Dom Butler added afterthoughts and moved things around in this second edition. The essentials are here: basically a series of excerpts surrounded by exegesis. It is perhaps worth adding that excerpts from other mystics are also discussed, ranging from Dionysius to St. John of the Cross, and more modern figures.

This is a terrific book, with everything you might want to know about this period in Kipling's life, well-written and with some good maps (!!!!!).  Allen's take on Kipling's outsiderness and complicated imperialism is excellent. The final chapter on Kim is perhaps the best of all (as is Kim itself).
This is only Volume 1 (up to 1759).Old, but still serviceable. Some of this was cannibalized for his later classic "Whig Supremacy".
Note that, in spite of the picture on this page, the edition you get is not Pluhar's (Hackett) translation, but an old one without any apparatus, etc.

This seems to be just about the only edition currently available online, with only Newman's notes -- the old Ker edition and the old Image edition are out of print. The Grammar is widely considered to be one of the earliest texts in what could be called "the phenomenology of thinking" and it is an amazing tour-de-force in detailed differentiation among such concepts as assertion, inference, and assent.  It is, among other things, a defence of certain of the powers of common sense and ordinary life -- in the tradition of Bishop Butler -- with very amusing side glances (into the controversy over Falstaff's line "a'babbled of green fields" for one).  It has been widely influential in theology and law, particularly on "burdens of proof", etc. There is also a small current flurry of philosophical interest in its anticipation of Wittgenstein's work in "On Certainty" (and there is one tiny piece of evidence suggesting Wittgenstein had read some Newman). The new reader should be warned that the first few pages are forbidding, but after that Newman's beautiful style takes over. The only real problem with the book is in the last fifty pages or so, when Newman does a desultory job of putting forward the "evidence" for Christianity -- mostly by attacking Jewish post-Temple history as a punishment for its (supposed) failure to acknowledge the Messiah, and producing the testimony of the early martyrs as a kind of counter evidence to Gibbon (!). This is, to put it mildly, not exactly good advertising for his overall position, which is very interesting and powerful in many ways -- students of philosophy would benefit a great deal from working through it.  If you can find the Ker edition I would recommend it over this one.

There are a bunch of strange, half-hearted reviews here for one of the great works in modern biography. This volume is even better than the first, which is saying a lot. The whole book is fraught with the tension between Coleridge's endless bouts with failure, and his spectacular mind at work on the whole panorama of life in the early 19th century.  The reader (well, this reader) is constantly on the verge of giving up on Coleridge completely, and then he does something beautiful, and then he wrecks it, and so on ad infinitum (the history with the Morgans is one such).  It remains astonishing that so many people put up with him for so long, they all seem like saints after a while.The only slight issue I have with the book is that the philosophy is not really dealt with in any depth -- but there are lots of other books on that (The recent Oxford Handbook is a great example). The best thing in the book is the whole sequence in Malta -- just dripping with sunlight and big echoey palaces and the Napoleonic war, and an (alas) temporary triumph in Coleridge's life.I knew almost nothing about Coleridge's children until I read this -- Sara Coleridge is very interesting.  There is a discussion of a painting of her which hung over Coleridge's desk (by William Collins), but it is nowhere to be found on the Internet.....The whole book (volumes one and two) are both beautifully considered, and each one is a masterpiece.

This is a very good book on the subject (about which I knew nothing beforehand). I was looking for a general intro, and this provided it. Well written, and with some authorial reflections that were apposite. The first half is an excellent biography of Wesley and his contemporaries -- his parents deserve a bio of their own -- with a lot of general background. The second half is Wesley's theology, which I frankly found fairly ordinary and derivative from the mainstream theology of his day -- except of course for his emphases on salvation and new birth --  what makes Wesley interesting (to an outsider) is his life and practices.  But it would be useful for the intended audience, which is beginning theology students in Methodism. I liked it.

Extraordinary.This book has many, many virtues:(1) It is a clear exposition of the elements of the Davos debate between Cassirer and Heidegger. From this, you can get a real sense of what it is like for two masters of philosophy to expound and argue.  Philosophy students would learn a lot about how to argue.(2) The event throws a powerful light on the tensions in Weimar Culture, and the text covers them in exemplary fashion.(3) The erudition of both philosophers shines through: the whole debate centers around the interpretation of Kant's Critique of Pure Reason, which both men have at their fingertips.(4) Gordon makes very clear what is at stake between the two interpretations and the world views of Cassirer and Heidegger.  He is very, very judicious between the two. It is not a hatchet job on either man: rather the reader comes away deeply impressed by both figures and their committments.(5) Gordon is an excellent writer. I am in awe of his capacity to navigate through both the narrative and the philosophical arguments.

I had great hopes for this book to get an overview of Cassirer and Langer, but it is a difficult book to review -- Cassirer has had a minor revival recently (conferences, a biography, and a couple of books about the Heidegger/Cassirer debate in Davos), but is now mostly unknown, at least in North America; and Langer, who had a major vogue awhile ago, has practically disappeared from most people's view -- so anything about them is worthy. Also this book is full of detail about their theories. But having said that, it is very poorly written and a struggle to get through. I can only assume that English is not the author's first language: punctuation is spotty, many sentences are hardly English, and it is difficult to make literal sense of some of the arguments.  I find it hard to believe that Routledge allowed this book to go through without some serious editorial scrutiny beforehand.I would suggest that the interested reader head for Cassirer and Langer themselves: both of them wrote well and straightforwardly.

Deserves a constellation of stars. I have read this book many times, and just recently read it again, and it is even better than I remembered.  There is now an entire literature on the relationship between a gift economy and a market economy, spawned in part by work of Jacques Derrida and others in the higher reaches of theology (e.g. the grace of God as a gift).  But this book was in there first, is still better to my mind, full of sudden insight, easy to read, beautifully written, life changing.  The amusing thing is that the author is under the impression that it is about artists: that is a tiny fraction of its insight -- it is really an attack on the entire world view in which we operate, and opens up whole ranges of spiritual understanding. A well run society would send a free gift copy to everyone.

Bowie's book is an extended meditation on Adorno's work -- not for the novice, and not an introduction.  Bowie has written a number of books on early German philosophy (Schelling in particular pops up in this volume from time to time), which I enjoyed, so I picked this one up.  The main theme, using Adorno, is the way in which modern analytic philosophy forecloses on wider or better truths through its narrowness of method and goals.  Aesthetic truths (especially music, naturally) get discussed in a late chapter. This is all linked to the classic theme in Adorno of how science, capitalism, commodification, and reification have "objectified" the world as assumed by modern societies in general, and a certain cadre of philosophers in particular.  Bowie fairly elegantly deals with the Kantian and Hegelian influences on Adorno -- especially the critical theme of how much of the framework we contribute to the creation of understanding of the world around us is constant (Kant), and how much is transiently dependent on the influences of temporality, e.g. historical and social change (Hegel).From time to time Bowie brings in contemporary examples, such as the recent economic crash as an example of capitalist rationality out of control (at least Bowie thinks that is what it was.....).I enjoyed the book, but, as mentioned, you need a pretty substantial background in Adorno-ish writings to get much out of it.

This is a clearly written exposition of Jonas' thought from the perspective of someone with primarily an environmental concern. Jonas' ontological ethic is one of the few really strong ethical frameworks in environmental philosophy -- much of the rest is a hodgepodge of other forms of ethics bolted on to various environmental issues. Jonas has been much more influential in Europe than in North America. It would serve fairly well as a complementary text for an undergraduate philosophy class on Jonas' ethics. My only problem with the book is that it isn't very critical, more of a generalist overview.

This is a worthy entry in this really fine series (I have four of them already), and one of the clearest and most straightforward. I enjoyed it a lot, as someone who has worked on the Gita for years. There is an excellent set of references and bibliography. It is, however, not an exposition or critique of the text in any detail: it is really about the history of the vagaries of the text and its influence. It is interesting in particular how much of the Gita was overshadowed early on by the stories/histories of Krishna as a child, cowherd,etc. as the "bhakti" movement gathered force in the medieval period. A chunk of the book is about the use of the Gita as a political force beginning in the late 1880s, in part as a Hindu "bible" to counter the prestige of Western "bibles". Towards the end of the text there is a discussion of a few recent translations into English (from Van Buitenen to Stephen Mitchell), and a glimpse of various settings where there are oral readings.My study of the Gita was influenced strongly by Zaehner's old Oxford translation and Winthrop Sargeant's valuable word by word translation and exegesis (neither of which are mentioned here) and I have a fondness for Barbara Stoler Miller's elegant translation (which does get a mention).

This is quite a fine book, well written.  It isn't Tacitus, but then what is?  I found that the wrestling over which Seneca is the real one to be judicious and even-handed, though the relationship between the man and writer  remains a puzzle. I would have liked a bit more on the Senecan style, his writings, and so on; a bit of an Epilogue on the later influence would have been good. And there is a certain amount of repetition that a good editor would have removed.  But I enjoyed it throughout.

This is an astonishing book: lucid, deep, and very careful in its readings.  Of the books on Maimonides I have read, this is easily the  most penetrating, particularly in the chapters on the earlier works of Maimonides (Mishneh Torah, etc.).  It grapples in detail with many of the scholarly and theological arguments, and in clear, astute language. Other books deal in more detail with the life and the background -- this gives some of that, but it is more devoted to the arguments It is not just that Maimonides is profound; Halbertal makes many profound comments on his own as he works through the arguments and ideas.

This is a great novel, one of the few that really enters into the life of the native villagers of Sri Lanka in the early 20th century (and before).  It is very oppressive and dark, and captures a kind of inexorableness of both the surrounding jungle and the internal hates and loves of tightly bound village life.  It perhaps assimilates too starkly the natives with the ambient natural world (they are likened to the animal realm from time to time), but then Woolf was a white colonial administrator (and the colonial administration doesn't come off all that well either).  The darkness and oppression of the story are offset by the fabulous writing which gives the whole thing a kind of glow.It is interesting that this novel has never achieved classic status, probably because there are no western heroes, and nothing really redemptive. But parts of it are in the same league as A Passage to India.

This is a gorgeous book, beautifully and judiciously written (like a lot of Ondaatje's other books) and a mixture of an exploration of Leonard Woolf's time in Ceylon, and Ondaatje's own return and exploration of the area. Of particular note is Ondaatje's travel into the North during the Tamil crisis.  He is perhaps too kind to some very stupid writers on the Woolfs.There is a paperback edition that is much cheaper than advertised here, from the Sri Lankan publishers.

Brandon was a tough minded, compassionate man who toiled in the underbrush of social work and related fields for many years, eventually becoming a Zen monk and a professor.  In the obits after his death it was clear that he was difficult to get along with: had a sharp tongue and mind and didn't suffer fools (including himself) gladly. He wrote many articles and newspaper pieces, and several books on specific topics. His other book in this area is the Tao of Survival (which is, alas, not nearly as good as this one).This is a masterful book, full of insight and hard truths. Beautifully written, I decided to re-read it a few days ago, and it is still amazingly insightful. His examples and ideas come from social work, but they are applicable to any of the so-called "helping professions".

This is a wonderful book, full of zoological detail, and Aristotelian history around the island of (then) Lesbos.  It follows very closely (but with much more detail) the author's earlier version of this that was a BBC TV show in 2009, and which is now available on Youtube (search for "Aristotle's lagoon") -- an indispensable complement: for instance, the author cuts open a cuttlefish in the show, which is described in the book, but of course is much more powerful seen visually.  And some of the characters and locations in the book make their appearance in the film: plus, of course, there is the bonus that you get to see a Greek island and vicariously sit and drink ouzo at a cafe by the sea!I would personally have liked to have more background about the other aspects of zoological work Aristotle undertook (Martha Nussbaum's well-known edition of the Motion of Animals is a good example). There is a brilliant outline, background, and discussion of Aristotle's biology on the Stanford University Philosophy site (by James Lennox who has written extensively on the topic) that further complements this book; and another good one at the Internet Encyclopaedia by Michael Boylan, also a well-known specialist.  It is always worth remembering that something like a third of Aristotle's work was on aspects of biology.

This is a solid biography, based primarily on the letters (it hardly deals with the literature or ideas at all). The last part is a bit tedious -- we get a lot of unnecessary detail about practically everything.  There are very interesting things I learned from this biography that I had missed in others, e.g. how very, very wealthy Voltaire became.  This made him somewhat more invulnerable as his life went on than in his younger days. The biography makes clear that while Voltaire was a great man, he was a very tiresome human being.  It is also well noted in the biography that he was prone to making dramatic gestures and then obsequiously backing away from them.  Still, Voltaire remains surprising: it is not everyone who in their 70s in the 18th century starts up a surprising and profitable watchmaking industry from scratch!

We are in the midst of a Diderot boom, and this a good place to start. This is a great biography and should be back in print. Furbank writes beautifully and masterfully, and his choice of quotations and his summaries of Diderot's works are exemplary. Diderot's novels became fashionable again in the postmodern era, and his own political stance has also become the subject of renewed interest in discussions of the pre-French Revolutionary "pivot towards the republic".  His writing on the Salons is everywhere in contemporary art criticism. Everything Diderot writes has this fascinating mix of deep committment and pervasive irony -- he is really one of the first modern people, for better or worse. And how much better Diderot comes off than virtually all of his contemporaries as a human being!  It can only have been a pleasure to be in his company.

This is an authoritative, reliable, big biography of Machiavelli, rich in detail and learning, covering practically everything Machiavelli wrote in great detail (including letters, poems, etc, as well as the more famous works). Black is steeped in the manuscripts and Italian history of the period -- this is not one of the pop bios that Machiavelli seems to attract these days.  However, it is not easy reading at all and is certainly not for anyone coming to him for the first time.  You will need already to have a working knowledge of Italian history of the period and a pretty good sense of Machiavelli's life and work so as to make the most of this book. The critical discussions of the books most people are interested in (The Prince and the Discourses) are pretty good.I still think Hale's old Pelican "Machiavelli and Renaissance Italy" is about the best intro for setting the English speaking reader into the period; and Skinner's Oxford short book is best for the ideas and their background.

A fair-minded, clear exposition of Jameson's thought from a one-time student of his.  It is not very critical, but certainly useful as an introduction, since it covers Jameson's long academic history, including the main texts and the summary punctuations provided by his books of shorter essays.

This is by now the standard biography in English, and well deserved.  It is balanced, full of astute comments, and contains short summaries of each of Flaubert's books. I was particularly taken with the chapters on the trip Flaubert took with Maxime du Camp to the Near East (available in more detail in a Penguin collection).  Brown has also got a sly wit that he sneaks in on occasion.

I have just reread this, and wanted to echo the other 5 star reviewers.  When I originally read it, it spun me off into reading all the other books he mentioned, and helped me travel to some of the places he travelled as well (alas, I haven't been to the Cevennes, yet).  The idea behind the book -- tracking the author's personal life alongside the subjects he began to study along the way -- could have been a narcissistic disaster, but in fact it is a total delight.  His other books are also great -- The Age of Wonder is, well, a Wonder.  I confess having not gotten completely through the Shelley bio (there are other Shelley bios that are comparable, and that I slogged through back in school); but the Coleridge and Johnson/Savage bios are works of art.  But this is still the best of them all -- it has a youthful sense of exuberant discovery that is sweet and fine.

Leakey was for many years the doyen of English speaking critics of Baudelaire (his Collected Essays and book on Baudelaire and Nature are essential reading for scholars). This is not an introduction for readers just coming to Baudelaire. Rather, it is in some ways an abridged version of some of his other work, and the reader should have already had a reading of Les Fleurs du Mal under her or his belt.  The first section is not where I would start, as it gives an exhaustive review of how the published text was put together in its various versions, which is important for a structural recognition of how different poems lead into and away from each other, but for the reader who is captivated by the power of individual poems (most people, let's face it), this editorial work isn't immediately enticing. The chapter on Baudelaire's craft is exemplary; but the prize of the book is a close reading of Le Cygne which is a classic (and adapted from his famous essay on the same topic).

Le Grand Meaulnes is one of the great books, creating an atmosphere and a world that is only matched by some of Watteau's paintings.  It is a standard text for French schoolchildren, in the same league as To Kill a Mockingbird or Catcher in the Rye, for American schoolchildren: its power (for them) is that it begins in a rural schoolyard, and then turns into something deep and sad and nostalgic -- evoking a lost France and a lost world of ephemeral magic dreaming.  I've read it many, many times, and it is still intensely powerful and moving.Of course the title is untranslateable (though we do have 'The Great Gatsby', influenced by this novel, and no one seems to object to that title; but 'The Lost Estate' is clunky (it is a pun on a lost place as well as the 'estate of youth', but it is still crummy, and 'The Wanderer' is misleading)).

Like many another reader, I was disappointed in this book.  It is dragged down by various kinds of self-indulgence that don't do the author any favours.  Given the possible audience (people who already know something about Thoreau), it is bizarre that the author felt the need to juice up his prose with ridiculous contemporary "with-it-nesses" -- does he think we will suddenly "get" Thoreau by likening nature to a hard drive and making reference to Thoreau's MO? There are some irritating typos ("council" for "counsel" in one spot). The final chapter, recounting the author's walk to Walden Pond today, was done better by E.B. White a long time ago.  Having said that, there was some information I didn't have-- the author has read extensively on the subject -- and for that I am grateful.
