This would have essentially made their product a DO ALL product considering you can tell you phone everything you want it to do. They dropped the ball on that. My work around is to have Hey Siri enabled and plug the power cord in.The multi-function button works nice when music was the last thing you were playing, and you want to press it to start up some music when you first get in your car. If it was YouTube for instance, then the multi button won’t do anything when you press it. You’ll have to use the phone to open the music app / iTunes and press play from there. After that the multi-function will resume functioning as a PLAY / PAUSE button again. Annoying...but more so a iOS flaw I’m assuming.Now for some weird /  major problems with the SoundBot. The sound is terrible when directly wired to my AUX. This was the same with the BlueTrip, except the SoundBot was 10x worse. You can hear the power hum coming through excessively. Could be more of a wiring / Mazda issue, but at the same time, there is nothing built in to the SoundBot to reduce this. I had to buy a Kensington Noise Reducing Car Audio AUX Cable, and now the SoundBot is virtually silent. Not a peep coming through as far as power hum is concerned.Another thing to mention is the audio from my phone still seems to play a few seconds after my car is turned off. Possibly there is a battery in the SoundBot ? Capacitor that shuts off after a few seconds..?? Once the connection is lost between the SoundBot and my phone, the music stops playing on my phone, and the volume annoying jumps down. Not sure what that is about, but this never happened with my BlueTrip. Did they design it to do this in the SoundBot? Why? Annoying.And…the weirdest of all that I cant seem to replicate….sometimes when I get out of the car after it is turned off while music was playing (say to run in a store real fast), Ill come back out and turn the car on and BAM. The music automatically starts playing again. Then sometimes, it will not do this and no music will play when the car is turned back on, even if I reenact the same motions. There no rhyme or reason to it. I actually would prefer it to NOT automatically play. But wouldn’t be the end of the world if it did. Just so long as it consistently does one or the other.I was about to send this back and go with the HimBox because of the Siri integration, but I read to many mixed reviews with the Siri and the HimBox. So I decided to just use the Hey Siri instead.Besides, I got this on sale for 15 bucks and it is worlds better than the BlueTrip for my situation. And it also comes with a very nice 2 port USB charger which I needed as well.I recommend this for its price and if you don’t care too much about Caller functions. If you do, just enable Hey Siri for you iPhone users.Hope this helps.

The quality is great. Probably the best boxer briefs Ive tried. However, they only had small left. And while I normally wear mediums, boxer briefs are sometimes forgiving with size. Not these. Small was way too small. These are very true to size. I did wind up getting mediums and they fit perfect.They dont stay tight to your legs as others claimed after a full day of wearing, but they stay form fitted better than other brands.I like that they come down the leg further than others as well. The short boxer briefs that are seemingly more popular are annoying because they ride up. This does not happen with these.I highly recommend Tommy Hilfiger when it comes to boxer briefs. But check around, and most place overcharge for them.

I typically only used the Scotch Heavy Duty tape in the past. That tape is amazing.I was soping this would be somewhat the same, however, it is kinda flimsy in comparison (very thin).Still gets the job done and you can always double up if you feel uncertain.

I like the idea of this but unfortunately the execution is not very good. The bottle is cheap and flimsy-seeming. The lack of a pocket clip or armband means it is not very useful for on-the-go. Skip this one.

The NutriNinja is a compact, relatively inexpensive all-in-one kitchen appliance that could replace a separate juicer, blender, and food processor. In terms of affordability, ease of cleanup, and counter space "footprint", it is a winner. If I had limited funds and space, the NutriNinja would be the clear winner over the 3 separate machines. I'm actually considering getting rid of my blender entirely since the NutriNinja works better and I could use the pantry storage space the blender is currently occupying.NutriNinja vs. Kuvings NS850 Masticating Juicer-The NutriNinja is WAAAAAAY easier to clean than the Kuvings juicer. The juicer frequently clogs partway through and I have to stop the juicing and take the whole thing apart to unclog it. After I'm finished juicing, I have to spend quite a bit of time cleaning the machine and all its various parts. The NutriNinja only has 2 pieces and takes less than a minute to clean.-The NutriNinja requires a higher level of prep of the ingredients than the juicer. Crispier fruits and veggies have to be chopped into small pieces and the stems have to be removed from kale & other greens. The juicer is much less picky and the added prep time of the ingredients for the NutriNinja negates a lot of the time savings of the easier cleanup.-The NutriNinja leaves the pulp with all the fiber in the resulting smoothie rather than separating it out like the juicer does. From a nutritional standpoint, this is obviously much better. But from a purely taste standpoint, some of the smoothies coming from the NutriNinja were on the chunky side and my kids complained.-The NutriNinja has smaller capacity so I wind up having to make multiple batches instead of just 1 for the juicer. Most of the time I'm juicing for my whole family and with the NutriNinja I have to listen to complaints about who gets his/her smoothie first.-The NutriNinja requires water or another liquid to be added to the smoothie, whereas the juicer will just extract the juice from dry produce. Several times I had to stop the NutriNinja to add more liquid.Bottom line: both machines have pros & cons and I don't think there is a clear winner if price is not an issue. I foresee myself using the NutriNinja more often because of the ease in cleanup, and saving the juicer for when I want to incorporate stringier/tougher produce that the NutriNinja doesn't handle as well.NutriNinja vs. Breville BFP800 XL Food Processor-If you do a lot of food processing, you probably want to stick with a heavy-duty machine like the Breville. The NutriNinja doesn't have the selection of blades and plates that a traditional food processor does. It also is harder to "pulse" the NutriNinja.Bottom line: if you don't have the budget or need for a traditional food processor, the NutriNinja can do perform some of the same tasks, but not as well. It isn't a real replacement for a traditional food processor.

"A Thousand Pieces of You" is an intelligent, suspenseful, and romantic sci-fi thriller. It is the planned first book in a trilogy but unlike many YA trilogy openers, the novel stands on its own reasonably well. Yes, I want to see what happens next to Marguerite, Paul, Theo, and Marguerite's parents Sophia and Henry. But I felt like the ending gave the appropriate amount of resolution rather than ending abruptly like so many first books these days do.Parents should be aware that "A Thousand Pieces of You" contains a non-graphic sex scene as well as references to adultery, drug use, drinking alcohol, and smoking cigarettes. I would say that it's best for older teens and up as a result.

I really have very mixed feelings about this kit.Pros: my little one LOVES it and has spent hours happily coloring it and playing "astronaut" in it.Cons: overpriced for what it is, flimsy, a bit tricky to put together.

My youngest child is daytime trained and only wears Pull-Ups to bed. This type of Pull-Up leaked whereas the Huggies Pull-Ups Night Time Training Pants for Girls, 3T-4T, 42 Count (Pack of 2) generally do not. I would recommend skipping these and going straight for the night-time ones.

I think we have a new favorite travel neck pillow in our household. The plush cover is super-soft and will go a long way to ease the discomfort of long-distance travel. We tend to take red eye flights when traveling to visit family on the East Coast so having a goof neck pillow is important. This pillow is definitely a step above the ones we currently have.

I wasn't expecting these placemats/chargers to be as shiny as they turned out to be from the description as "perfect for everyday use". For me personally, they will be perfect for adding a festive touch to holiday celebrations. The photo really does not show just how shiny they are. Think like a tube of red glitter glue shiny. Fun at a Christmas party but too much for everyday use, even during the holiday season.

My daughter, like most girls her age, is a huge fan of "Frozen". She is also working on phonics so this game is a perfect way for her to practice determining what letter words begin with. She can match the letters on her own but needs prompting to match the letter sounds to the letters. So this game is definitely one where she needs adult facilitation.

A big problem I have with energy drinks is that they often leave me jittery. I don't get that kind of reaction to coffee or caffeinated soda so I'm not sure what exactly I'm reacting to in Red Bull, Monster, etc. I was very pleased to discover that E-ON left me energized without making me jittery. I would say that the energy boost was about equivalent to a 12 oz. cup of coffee.The taste was pleasant, kind of reminiscent of raspberry ginger ale but not quite that flavor.

I love dystopian YA novels and also Homer's Odyssey, so when I heard the premise of "Love in a Time of Global Warming", I was excited to read it. Thank goodness it was short because I didn't like it at all. I did read to the end because I wanted to see how the author handled Pen's homecoming. The ending was a disappointment just like the entire book was a disappointment. I didn't like any of the characters and felt that the whole pro-homosexuality message was totally inappropriate for a book aimed at a YA audience. Beyond that, I felt like the author couldn't decide whether her book was fantasy or dystopian because it was a weird mishmash of the two.

It's a beautiful design and this new Symmetry series is not as bulky as some of the other Otterbox's I've seen. And it's very stylish. It fits well and honestly is such great protection, even at the cost, that it's worth it. You can't go wrong with a Otterbox case. Just splurge and get it.

It's a beautiful design and this new Symmetry series is not as bulky as some of the other Otterbox's I've seen. It fits well and honestly is such great protection, even at the cost, that it's worth it. You can't go wrong with a Otterbox case. Just splurge and get it.

This is a story tale from the 1960's that has been translated to English.  It's a tale about doing the right thing even if it costs you what you wanted.  I remember a story on God Vine recently about a runner who was within feet of the finish line when her opponent started to wobble and fall down.  Instead of finishing the race she went back to carry her injured opponent across the finish line costing herself the trophy.  This is a similar tale in that a young man in line to become a knight is asked desperately to go help someone else.  He does knowing it will cost him his knighthood.  This tale is an eternal story of self vs. others. It's a good book and easy read.

These are NOT DII kitchen towels.  They are cheap, cheap, cheap.  Mine came with such a horrible chemical smell I thought something was on fire. They already don't lay flat and I haven't even washed them yet.  But the reviews I see of the bleeding issue I'm not sure I will even get that far.  They're thin, not particularly absorbent and they just feel cheap.  PASS.

These bags depend on what you're freezing in them.  They are not airtight and did leak liquid.  So if liquid can come out that means air can go in.  I would only use for short term freezer storage and even then it concerns me. They are very thin and the zipper mechanism is flimsy.  And they're expensive.  Mine all came mashed from Amazon, in fact one of the boxes was so bad I had to take all the freezer bags and put inside another freezer bag and I just threw the box away. I've been getting alot of stuff from amazon mashed lately.

The rug does not have non-skid backing on it so it could slip for some when they get out of the shower.  It was thick enough and I have vinyl floors so for me it didn't slip.  However I could see if you have ceramic floors this rug could go for a ride. It's thick so consequently it does take some time to dry.  I really liked the look of it, and plan on using it. I'll update once I wash it and see how that goes.

Suzy's friend dies and she goes through the grief process and this story concentrates on the blame cycle.  She is finding anyone to blame to include a jelly fish. It's a tragic story line and would be a good book for a psychologist that deals with children who have lost a loved one. Suzy is immature and consequently deals with her friends' death in a weird way.  But that's what makes the book so compelling and true to life.  Enjoy.

This back cover fits the Surface 3 but not the Pro model. It is designed to protect the back, all corners and edges from scratches.  You would need to purchase a screen protector and/or entire case if you want the entire tablet protected.  I think this is designed more to help your tablet stand up by working with the Kickstand for reading etc. It does allow for a full-range of viewing options. It is thin and keeps a low profile. And it still allows for access to all the ports, etc. Overall it does what it says it does.

This flat iron can straighten or create volume and waves; it's big enough to do both. It heats up to 410F and because it is ceramic the handle gets a little hot as well.  It heats up in 30-second so minimal wait time and has several different heat settings. It says it works on all hair types so your mileage may vary on that.  Mine is thick hair but not super wavy. I do like the auto off feature however because it gets so hot I'd hate to rely on that.  It's got a three year warranty but the cost of sending it back getting a replacement etc is just too much so you're basically buying a disposable flat iron.  I would recommend for the price.

This is a great product for gymnasts who need to keep their feet together.  While you're doing your bar routine you can instantly hear when your feet come apart.  It does encourage keeping your feet together.  If you have a high arch I'm not sure they'd stay secure around the balls of your feet without sliding up.  My arches are not that big and they stayed in place OK. If you use this for children during cheerleading or gymnastics they would be OK as well. The hook and look tape is strong enough to stay together but when coming apart you can definitely hear it.

It's a beautiful color and not as bulky as some of the other cases I've seen. It fits well and honestly is such great protection, even at the cost, that it's worth it.  And it has the space to keep your credit card, nice!  Just splurge and get it.

It's a beautiful color and not as bulky as some of the other Otterbox's I've seen. It fits well and honestly is such great protection, even at the cost, that it's worth it.  You can't go wrong with a Otterbox case.  Just splurge and get it.

I'm not sure it's really geared for the middle school aged student.  I also think the subject is too sad for most 7th graders to relate. It's about a boy who is a teen himself and wants to see his daughter.  I cried it was just heartbreaking.  It's a good read and a well written book but again I just think the target audience may not relate nor actually be the target audience.  Just loved it.

Good read for a middle school boy struggling to figure out where he fits in.  It reminds me of  The Gospel According to Larry by Tashjian,Janet. [2003] Paperback. I would recommend because it's intended for the smart kid who finds the everyday things boring or unimportant. So Anthony decides he needs a new life.  Very similar to Larry in that he finds the most things trivial and wants to understand the true meaning of life. Good read and well worth the investment

The Iron Trial (Magisterium, Book 1) was the first book in this Magisterium series. Black and Clare again return to the Magisterium, a school in this second of a series. The end of the last book we learned that who we thought was the hero, Callum, was in fact the Enemy of Death and terrifies everyone in his magical world. This second book carries on and Black and Clare now need to figure out who their enemy is and who's their friend.  Quite a fascinating read for a middle schooler, enjoy!

I go this Bible for my teenage son and he was afraid it would be kid like.  It does have simple language but it's appropriate for teenagers. There are articles from other teens, young adults, etc He really liked it and has been using it so far. It's a nice paperback that he can carry in his backpack and it's help up well so far. The pages are thin so you'll have to worry about highlighting as it would bleed through.  Overall a worthy Bible for teenagers.

It does run on Windows 10, they offer 24/7 customer support at 877-495-3178. The program does do payroll and state taxes but you need to purchase a subscription (not basic) and buy tax tables. You must also renew every year to keep the payroll module open. If you purchase the Basic they'll help you transition to the other version and help you get the tax tables. This is a PC version only and not available for MAC yet. The license is perpetual but the updates will cost each year. I find it easier than Peachtree but it is a little pricey with having to purchase each year. But it's still much cheaper than going through a payroll service. I would recommend just know you will have additional costs every year.

This privacy screen really does work, unless you're looking at your screen head on you can't see it.  It was easy to apply and came off when I had to reapply it.  I have no bubbles and I haven't noticed a decrease in sensitivity.  I would recommend.

What a nice series this is going to be.  It starts out with a young fox journey into the wilderness.  Her house has been burnt down, she's lost her family and now is wandering the streets a lone.  Her fairy god mother comes to take care of her and it's magic after that.  It's a good read, the kids loved it, it's not too long to lose their attention.  I can't wait for #2!

I use these wipes for everything, not just for diaper changes.  I use them to clean, wipe the dogs' paws, door handles, etc.  They have a nice fresh scent, they're not overly wet but wet enough.  So far they've come out of the package as intended not 5 at a time that I get with the Wal mart brand wipes.  I would recommend although the price seems a little high for only 72 wipes in a package.

This is a great resource for preparing for the GMAT.  It's all the about the questions and there truly are 1600+ of them.  This is actually a Kaplan book with the name of Grockit.  Not sure why. This book will definitely help you prepare, it's all about the reading.  These questions are from actual tests that have been administered so you know they'll probably come up again.

This book is a great resource to prepare for the GRE.  It has lots of questions 1600+ from actual tests.  It's actually a kaplan brand book even though the name is Grockit. I would recommend especially for the $15 price.  You just have to sit down and read...and read. But it helps.

It comes with the ship, figurine, and projectile.  I didn't think there were particularly small parts but it is intended for 6-9 year old kids who love star wars and action figures. The ship modifies so it can stand or fly; that's the X wing part.  My son loved it and flies around with it making his own noises.  There are other figurines available but they're sold separately. It's a great toy and any kid who loves star wars will get a kick out of this. The dog did chew the projectile missile within a few days so he's without that.

Great blue booth for a ride along.  This is intended for outdoors use, especially those with a golf cart or similar ATV that you want to listen to the game while you're down at the pond or music while out on the back 9.  It had exceptional sound and I was very impressed.  I would definitely recommend and it even came with a paper that listed tech support people you could call if you ever had any trouble.  Very nice.

The DoldrumsThis book is intended for ages 8 - 12 years.  It's a fascinating book and reminded me quite a bit of the Scooby Doo stories where something would get stolen and those meddling kids would have to track down the culprit. LOL. I like this book and also another good one would be.  This is a good book for curious kids and maybe even kids who don't fit in because they are orphans and one is a knife thrower.  All in good fun and a good read.

I use for household chores like cutting meat, making meatloaf, cleaning toilets, pulling weeds, etc.  I like the fit of these, they are thinner than other brands I have used but still hold up well.  The only problem was in pulling weeds they tended to get pierced easily and break.  Which would be expected with stiffer types of jobs.  My husband used for an oil change and he had no problems with them.  He didn't think they'd be used for heavier duty jobs. Overall for the price they are fine for light garage and household duties.  They are powder free so no worries.

This is only for the S6 Edge plus not for the regular galaxy phone.  It fit perfectlly and was easy to get on .  However, after a couple weeks of use it looks awful. It's scratched up and dirty.  It's like dust is magetically attracted to it.  The back of the case is not scratch resistant at all.  I don't abuse my phone, it's either in my purse or on a desk.  I'm not bee bopping around the mall or on it all the time. I've not dropped it yet so I can't verify the cushioning but I do know it fit well and looks OK.

This does have the swiffer rag all the way around for the 360 cleaning however the handle is very short.  Unless something is eye level you're not going to be albe to reach it and if it's eye level then you don't need to pay extra for the 360 brush.  I couldn't even reach my ceiling fan in the dining room but if it had the extender this would be a very useful product.  It came with two of the rag refills and is very effective at picking up lint, dog hair and spider webs.

The warning label says do not use more than seven days in a row because allergies may result.  I kept mine in the fridge for an added chilling benefit; however my baby also got the same pain relief with a cold wash cloth and a teething ring.  I mostly used this at night if it seemed my baby was waking up because of tooth pain.  Then using a cold wash cloth isn't effective. And it did help my baby fall back to sleep.  I liked it and it's cheaper than orajel.  My only complaint was it came in a paper envelope and was completely smashed when it arrived.  This would not be a good thing if you're buying it for a baby shower gift.

This was pretty easy to assemble and install in a doorway.  The doorway just needs to have a frame around it for the bar to sit on while you do your pull-ups.  It didn't do any damage to the door frame and held on securely.  Unfortunately it is big and hard to store if you have a small space.  My son uses it in his dorm room and it's cumbersome to find a place to keep it. You can't leave it on the door frame because your door won't shut. However it works and it's easy to use and effective.

Definitely good for the back seat of a car.  Sometimes the fast moving scenery is too much stimulation for a baby and either gets them motion sick or agitated.  These simple designs are bright enough to keep your young baby's interest as well as able to be changed out once the baby gets older. I liked it because it would be a great gift for a military deployed family to put pictures of mommy or daddy in the pockets so the baby gets to see their deployed parent whenever in the car.  While they consciously may not remember them the visual image will keep the memory printed in their brain.  This is a great product.

They're not marked right or left so if you're a true music freak you know this is bothersome.  They also don't stay in my sons' ears.  The plastic insert is soft but there are no additional sizes so they just fall out of his ears.  Because there's no clip they wind up falling to the floor when he's walking. For the price they just weren't that great and the sound quality didn't seem to be all that.  I just can't imagine where they'd be comfortable unless you're truly doing nothing but sitting still because as soon as you move they fall out of your ears.

It didn't smell very good to me and it proved true as my grand baby only gagged down one bite and that was that.  It did get hard very quick which I saw on the other reviews but then so many others didn't mention it.  There are some seeds that never did soften up and it concerned me that so many hard bites were in a baby food. Unfortunately I won't be getting this again as my gbaby just won't eat it.  I'll stick with the rice cereal for now.

Wow the taste is awful and my DIL drank a gallon of water.  I'm wondering if it wouldn't be better to just make a cup of thistle or fenugreek tea rather than choke down this stuff?  It made her gag every time.  However she did seem to have increased milk production but she also was very hydrated; it took about 5 days to notice.  This product already has a lot of sugar so adding more sugar or sweetener for the taste seems dangerous.  I think this product your mileage may vary as they say.

The description says 70% rayon but they are 70% bamboo.  Bamboo is suppose to be softer but not at first.  It will take multiple washings and then these blankets are the softest you've ever felt.  It's just that initial swaddling and you don't think these are as soft as they should be.  Bamboo is also very breathable so your baby won't over heat.  They have a very pretty design and are the perfect size for swaddling.  Enjoy but only after 10 washings.

These goodnites can be used many many times over.  The package says 30 washings but they can be re-used more than that with no problem.  The initial starter set comes with the underpants and 5 pads and then you purchase the pad refills.  The refills are a little expensive but if your child has a wetting problem at an overnight sleepover they are worth every penny. These are similar to the pull-ups but for bigger sizes.  They are very absorbent and I would definitely recommend.

These goodnites can be used many many times over.  The package says 30 washings but they can be re-used more than that with no problem.  The initial starter set comes with the underpants and 5 pads and then you purchase the pad refills.  The refills are a little expensive but if your child has a wetting problem at an overnight sleepover they are worth every penny. These are similar to the pull-ups but for bigger sizes.  They are very absorbent and I would definitely recommend.

This is a very pretty purple and durable case together; wow.  Most otterbox cases are bulky but they do protect your phone.  I dropped it in the drive way and no problem, nothing shattered, phone works perfect.  It is hard to fit in a pocket with this case but the case is pretty enough that you don't mind carrying it around.  Buy with confidence.  It's durable and pretty.

This cube doesn't snap together it just folds up together. So it's hard to travel with because of that, it falls apart in the bag.  It doesn't roll otherwise it could have been a nice rolling cube.  It twists but it takes so much effort that a baby can't twist it.  The little telephone dial turns but it takes so much effort that a baby can't turn it. One of the stars is stuck so now the stars and balls don't fall around. It is bright colors and it is very sturdy but it's really expensive and not that great. Pass

This calendar is made out of glossy paper so you have to be careful about the ink pen you're using to write on because it will smear.  You can't erase anything you write down. Now the good part is it's resistant to small spills, coffee rings, etc.  They will wipe up pretty quickly if you get to them where a paper calendar the ring is going all the way to March. It is a big calendar so it's what you'll be using this for.  YMMV.

This steamer does seemingly everything, and it does these tasks well. As a steam mop, I like its simplicity. All it requires is filling the tank and pressing the "On" button. I was surprised at how quickly it reached temperature and started releasing steam. It was well under a minute.At its default mid-setting, it produces a good amount of steam that is sufficient for cleaning both wood and tile floors. After testing the unit, I left it for the cleaning people thinking I would show them how to use it. I was pleasantly surprised that they figured out how to use it and went ahead and cleaned the floors with it. I did not have a chance to talk to them but I would imagine they preferred it to the regular mop and water.I decided to try cleaning out our grill. It was just as easy to configure it and very effective. I was able to steam clean the grill in less than ten minutes. And part of that was playing around with the steam settings and blasting an annoying fly. Once again, I was pleasantly surprised at how fast and effective this tool is. The one part that was a little inconvenient is the long power cord. I looped the cord multiple times and carried the cord with one hand and the steam cleaner with the other hand. The long cord is useful when mopping a large area but can get in the way when doing local steam cleaning. I would be especially interested in a cordless version of this steam cleaner.

As an animal repellent, this seemed to discourage some visits by stray cats. At least it initially seemed to repel some cats that have been visiting out back yard. After a few weeks, however, we observed these same cats, so it does not appear to last more than 2-3 weeks for us. We also have rat visitors but this is not effective for mice or rats. For birds, it seems that there are fewer after spraying. Overall, I would guess some animals are less affected than others are.As far as a fertilizer, we have recently converted to artificial grass in the front (and curiously received a gift deposit from a canine visitor which prompted me to spray the "lawn"), so that is not relevant. In the backyard, it definitely did not make anything worse but also did not noticeably improve anything either. Overall, I would say this works OK as an animal repellent and the fertilizer is a nice bonus.

People who like to personalize their crayons are likely to enjoy this crayon carver. It does work and my children customized a number of crayons with just a little of my help, mostly removing stuck tiles.The crayons have to be the correct length, which is new or almost new. They have a Crayola Crayon Maker but, unfortunately, it produces crayons that are too short to be used in this carver. It would be better if this could carve different length crayons.From my limited usage, I would give it four stars. My daughter rated it three and a half stars.Her review:This is really fun. It doesn’t require you to handle any sharp objects to cut shapes into the crayon and the result is nice. However, some of the designs are unclear and certain tiles got stuck in the slots; I could not pull them out. The wrapper ripper works okay, but it causes an unsightly line to be carved into the crayon’s side.

The concept is good and the YouTube videos are fun, but this book misses its mark (at least the excerpt for Romeo and Juliet). To be fair, I may not have read the entire summary but what I did read was not suited for children (many four letter words and slang). Cliff's Notes provides better information without the language issues. This could be entertaining to listen to in order to get a different perspective, but I don't see using only these notes to seriously understand a complex book.

For a Kamado type cooker, this works reasonably well. It holds the grate and allows removal and replacement as long as it is used near the center of the grate. I would prefer if it had some bends lengthwise instead of across the tip. This would make it more robust. It seems to be sturdy enough to lift medium or large steel grates but extra large or heavy iron grates may require assistance. I have not seen any rust develop so it is decently plated at least.When tried with other grill grates, it did not work as well. It did not work at all with a Weber propane grill (specifically Genesis Gold C). These grates are wider than most and have tighter spacing. This gripper also did not do as well with a Traeger grate.  These grates run parallel to the short end and removing would require reaching in sideways to grab near the center.

This is my older daughter's review. She reads a lot and knows what she likes. I thought she might like this book but did not know she has already read books by two of the authors and enjoyed them.--------This might possibly be my new favorite book. The story is about Nory Horace, a girl who lives in a world where magic powers are very common. Powers are divided into 5 Fs: Flickers—who can turn themselves and other things and people invisible, Flares—who can control heat/fire, Fuzzies—who can do general animal magic, Flyers—who can fly and hover, and Fluxers—who can change into animal forms.Nory is a Fluxer, but her magic sometimes gets out of control and changes her into two animals at once. So when she applies to Sage Academy, a magic school, she fails and is sent to a special class for kids who have strange magic like her. By the end of the story, Nory realizes that it's not so bad to be different.

My younger daughter likes graphic novels. She usually picks up a few from the library and enjoys reading them more than regular books. So I selected this for her. She started off strong and then lost interest. I picked it up and read it at the gym.It is a quick read with excellent graphics. I can easily see how the author has won awards for his art and writing. The story is quite good and I am not sure why it did not catch my daughter's attention. It could be the subject matter (whale waste) is slightly off-putting. Otherwise, I thought it was well done and will get her to continue reading it.

My younger daughter generally enjoys Captain Underpants books and that type of humor. But for some reason, she did not click with this book and has not finished reading it. So I picked it up and read it at the gym.This is the first Captain Underpants book I have read. I appreciated the older audience references and the introductory cartoon so that I did not feel completely clueless. The Flip-O-Rama™ pages did not really do much for me, but I can appreciate the temporary diversion and think younger readers may enjoy it. The story was decent and held my attention during the workout. This is a good book and I will get my daughter to finish reading it.

A couple of years ago, I bought a pair of Oral-B electric toothbrushes for my children. I had been using the same set for over ten years and have been pleased with the results. Unfortunately, they did not take to using the Oral-B toothbrushes and have mostly been manually brushing their teeth.I was offered this Sonicare electric toothbrush and decided to let my younger daughter use it. She has crazy teeth (even worse than her sister who is now wearing braces) but many are still primary so the orthodontist is waiting for more permanent teeth to come in.The standard size fits her mouth OK although we may try the compact size in the future. The Sonicare brush head design is superior to the Oral-B for keeping the brush clean. Both children have had some build-up around the brush area. I am in the habit of removing the brush head and rinsing it thoroughly, but they cannot remove the Oral-B brush too easily. The Oral-B brushes are less expensive.My old set started having charging issues (understandable after 15 years) so I bought a new unit with Bluetooth capability. I tried the BT app a couple of times but did not really see the benefit and just use the toothbrush one a day, alternating with a regular toothbrush.We have not tried the iOS app yet, but I do not really see the need. She knows how long to brush and since she is messy, it is better to avoid taking other electronics into the bathroom.

In an effort to cut down on my middle school daughter's notebook requirements, I chose this for her. My impressions are that it is well constructed and can reduce the size and weight of notebooks. The only downside is the price.Daughter's review:This notebook is very strong. I dropped it a few times on the floor to see if it would bend and scratch up, but it didn't. Covering the notebook's spiral was a good idea, because I often get scratched or cut by my notebooks' loose coils when I reach into my locker.

In terms of writing, this is a good read. It is well written and full of details that really make the story come alive. I especially appreciated the partially written song lyrics and well fleshed out story line. The author definitely has a way with words and can weave interesting story lines together.I felt the Harry Harrington skier character did not really tie in well with the other Harringtons. The ending, while captivating, just did not seem to fit. It seemed to end a bit abruptly, but it did provide closure.

Children should learn about human rights early on. Parents can help children learn and experience other cultures and freedoms early on. This will lead to a better informed new generation.This book is surprising. I did not know such a book existed that is geared towards children and expresses the basic tenets of human rights. It is a wonderful book that belongs in every home.Daughter's review: Bright, vivid illustrations and short, moving words come together nicely in this book. It was an easy read and enjoyable as well as attractive. I especially liked how the last few pages of the book explain the illustrators and the people who spoke/wrote the words that were quoted in the book.I found the message by Chief Stranding Bear of the Ponca Tribe to be very inspiring.

OK, I admit it. I selected this watch for my 8-year-old daughter. I asked both my wife and my 11-year-old daughter if they were interested in it, and both declined. However, my younger daughter saw it and really wanted it. I figured, why not?It actually looks more impressive in real life than in the pictures. Both my wife and older daughter thought it looked good. Even I was surprised and I have over twenty watches.The band is a nice mix of three colors, and the main face shows minutes clearly. The three subdials are a little busy but functional and readable. I thought the 24 hour subdial could be used for a second time zone but can not set it separately than the hour hand. The instructions are generic and do not really explain this particular watch. It is a larger watch but can be sized for smaller wrists. It weighs more than plastic watches and leather strap watches, but it should be manageable for most females. I do have some monster Invicta watches so my perspective may be skewed.Since this watch was for my younger daughter, I sized it for her and she happily wore it to school as well as to a music performance. To her, it is like jewelry that tells time. I hope I don't regret this later. Maybe that is why the label says it is not intended for children 12 and under.

These are a nice set of earphones. The sound is good although maybe a tad less efficient than my Ultimate Ears 600vi. It also seems to have less dynamic range than the UEs, but their response may open up after more hours of listening. The Phiaton MS100BA, however, has a superior cord that I have never had to work at untangling. The MS100BA also has a solid metal construction. It has a nicer feel and look but also weighs a little more. The Ultimate Ears produce less cord noise, which might be important to some listeners.The controls work well. They are smaller and presumably lighter than those on the 600vi. The integrated mic is useful and Google Now did not have any problems understanding my commands, similar to the 600vi. The left and right earphones are clearly marked with R and L. The Ultimate Ears has color-coded sides. The MS100BA comes with a drawstring pouch while the 600vi comes with a hard case.

This cover was made for the 18.5" Weber Smokey Mountain (WSM) or similar cookers. It is well constructed, has the classic black color, and has vents for preventing moisture buildup. It is a heavier fabric, maybe 600D.While I have not had this cover too long, I have owned another Classic Accessories cover (the Veranda Square Smoker Cover) for almost three years and it is still performing well covering a Bradley smoker. It is under a covered area and does not get direct sun.

Although the book includes the phrase "and other smokers" in the headings, there is little to no technical information for other cookers. It is, however, an excellent guide for the Weber Smokey Mountain (WSM) cooker. While it does not cover assembly and installation, it does provide workflows for basic operation as well as the different cooking methods: low and slow, hot and fast, combination low and high heat, and grilling.Organizationally, it is different from many other cookbooks that arrange dishes by ingredients. This book arranges recipes by cooking methods. The recipes themselves are also unique. There are quite a few recipes that I have not seen in other books. Some examples are Grilled Romaine Lettuce, Pizza-Wrapped Burger, and Buttery Smoked Cabbage.It has many mouth-watering full color pictures. The binding is nice. It allows the book to lay flat and remain open.

This book is an excellent introduction to poetry for kids. I figured my younger daughter (3rd grade) would be interested in it since she likes Shel Silverstein, butt jokes, and all sorts of bodily functions, but it turns out my older daughter (6th grade) also enjoyed it. Her school had a flyer about a poetry competition with the book as a prize, so she was pleased to have already read the book.Younger daughter's review: The book is actually very funny, but it's also disgusting. It's disgusting because there's a page with a poem about booger or burps and farts but I still like it. I like burps, farts, and boogers the best. I think this book is perfect for a person who is focused on private parts and disgusting body functions.Older daughter's review: This collection of fun poems is sure to catch the attention of kids of all ages. Discussing everything from stinky feet to cyberbullying, it's almost like Captain Underpants got into one of Shel Silverstein's poem books. Although it seems to be more directed toward boys, I enjoyed it very much. However, if you aren't interested in looking at a couple images and poems of boogers and other bodily functions, this may not be a good match for you.

This tea has a nice light jasmine scent. I normally drink tea at work. Mostly I drink green tea although sometimes I will have oolong or jasmine (from black) tea. For convenience, I mostly use tea bags. At home, my wife and I will occasionally brew higher quality loose leaf teas. For reference, some of the jasmine (green) teas have been $30-40 per 1/4 pound, which is approximately upper middle grade.This tea is quite good. It is not comparable to the $150/lb loose leaf teas, but does compare well with many bagged teas. I do admit to preferring Mighty Leaf Tea, Organic Spring Jasmine. Tea bags allow variable steeping time and temperature which can bring out additional flavors so that is better. It is also much less expensive. The downsides are it is not as convenient or fast as K-cups.I tend to brew teas twice per K-cup. The second brewed cup for this flavor is noticeably weaker than the first cup. Combining the two yields a still acceptable strength.

My wife and I met after she had already finished her residency program, so I, thankfully, did not experience the duress of intern/residency life. She has not talked much about it, mostly just dropping hints of a time best forgotten.Matt McCarthy does the opposite. He extensively documents his intern year and all its trials and tribulations. Judging by what he has written, it was mostly trials. If his is a typical intern year, it is amazing so many doctors survive this period.He focuses on a few key people and events and appears to keep other influences (his personal relationships and clinical practice areas) relegated to secondary importance. Maybe they were not as influential, but he did marry his girlfriend and eventually chose infectious medicine as his specialty.It turns out my wife started one residency and then switched to another after a year. She actually completed two years as an intern. My take on all this is if she can survive two years as an intern, my peccadilloes must not be even a blip on her radar.

There are many treasures in this book. It is well written and provides some of the reasoning and decision-making that Alibaba's management took. At times, it is a bit excessive on praise for Jack Ma, Alibaba's founder, and reads like a press release. This is understandable considering the author's former role with the company.Prior to reading this book, I had no idea of the size of Alibaba and its sister companies. It is amazing that an e-commerce company could be larger than Amazon and eBay combined.I enjoyed reading the forty take away points/lessons in the final chapter. It points to focus and drive more than rule bending and under-the-table negotiations that some businesses. Quite illuminating. Of course, the ultimate test is whether Alibaba thrives and survives 102 years.Close sesame.

Although I have only had this hose for a few weeks, it is just about everything I could ask for in a 50' garden hose. It is remarkably light and compact, rolls up well, is drinking water safe, handles 400PSI, comes with a lifetime warranty, and is American made.It works very well as a secondary garden hose. We have a couple of 75/100 feet 5/8" hoses for primary use and I was thinking of getting an expandable hose to put on the other side of the house as a backup. This hose is perfect for that. It might not be as suitable as a main hose for larger yards since it is ", but for smaller yards or as a backup hose it excels.

Last year, I bought an air compressor combo kit that included brad and finish nailers. Of course, I had to get a pneumatic staple gun, too. Thus began my journey to find an assortment of staples.While searching, I discovered several finish/plating options: no (non), galvanized, stainless, and Monel. I searched for galvanized and stainless steel assortments but could not find any and eventually settled for Stanley TRA700BN Heavy-Duty Staple & Brad Assortment, 2500-Pack.This assortment contains only staples and is galvanized finished. I tried them with several staplers. The first is my old standby POP Brand 3000 stapler. I loaded several sizes and had no problems driving them into some wood boards. I also tried the Tacwise Z3-140. Loading was even easier, but the staples did not always fully embed. Sometimes they ended up a millimeter or two off the wood. This stapler has a "linear power curve" so it may be a matter of getting used to its operation.The final staple gun I tried these staples with is the Surebonder 9600A. This kit is a perfect match with the Surebonder. I fired off too many staples in several sizes and pockmarked the poor board with no misfires and excellent penetration. I need to find some project to do so that I can play with it more.I hope Tacwise comes out with reasonably priced stainless steel assortments.

Daniel Lubetzky has certainly lived an interesting life and he has barely reached middle age. He describes it well in the pages of this book. It is worth a read to learn how an entrepreneur can lead a purpose-filled life and business by sticking to ten tenets, detailed in each of the book's ten chapters.For me, reading this book had its vicissitudes. Learning about his philosophy and ideas was worthwhile, but reading all the people and events left me reeling at times. I can only imagine how it read before he edited scores of them out. In addition, there are at least a couple of anecdotes that were repeated.My family and I have enjoyed eating KIND bars in the past and learning more about the company and its philosophy makes me even more inclined to reach for one.

Many people may not pay attention to water quality, but it is vital to vitality. I first heard about oxidation-reduction potential (ORP) while maintaining marine aquaria and koi ponds. I know it is a good measure of overall water quality and went so far as to buy a Hanna HI 98121 meter, but did not actively start using the meter until more recently.We have a whole house water conditioner as well as a reverse osmosis filter in the kitchen for drinking and cooking. The water conditioner supplies conditioned water for the lawn and outside plants and I have been using RO water for our Aerogarden, as recommended.I was curious about this product and decided to test it with the 98121 as well as a TDS meter. I can reasonably state that this water conditioner does what CleanGrow claims. For our tap water, I measured 330PPM (TDS), 273 mV (ORP), and 7.72 pH. After adding a drop of conditioner to a cup (granted not accurately measured), I measured 346 PPM, 350 mV, and 7.77 pH. Using RO water, I measured 23 PPM (recently changed filters), 301 mV. The pH reading was not stable but < 7. After adding conditioner, I measured 98 PPM and 400 mV and pH < 7. For both tap and RO water, the TDS increased slightly, the pH was virtually unchanged, and the ORP increased significantly (almost 100 mV).

Pulled pork is one of my family's favorite foods. The taste and texture of smoke, seasonings, and juicy meat is unbeatable.I started shredding the old-fashioned way, with large forks. I considered getting some bear paws/claws but found Steven Raichlen's insulated meat gloves convenient and controllable. I have been preparing pulled pork using these gloves for several years. Overall, they work well but it is possible to overcook the meat and then using these gloves can sometimes create a more mashed texture than the desired fibers that soak up the sauce.These meat claws work well. They are heavy gauge and will not bend or deform. I would imagine the plastic bear claws work similarly but prefer metal for food handling and preparation.

Unlike other hair color kits, this has little ammonia smell and is an easy to use cream. It does require two steps so it is not as quick as some kits, but it seems that the second step creates a more uniform look (blend).My wife was pleased with the application and results and also used it on my hair. I noticed the smell was much less objectionable and the application did not bother me as much as some of the other color kits she has used. The included conditioner is a nice addition to the kit. This is a premium hair coloring kit worth the small additional time and cost.

This pillow provides excellent support. It molds well to support the head and neck and I quickly adjusted to it. I use a CPAP machine and did not have any problem finding a comfortable sleeping position. The height works well for me as a side sleeper.It is noticeably denser (and heavier) than my previous fiber filled pillow. As a person who tends to sweat at night, I wondered if it would regulate temperature like my old pillow, but this pillow does seem to keep my noggin cooler. The included cover is also nice and worthwhile.The only issue I have is the initial smell. It is quite strong. Since my CPAP sucks in air several feet away, I did not directly inhale the fumes while it was initially outgassing.

These appear to be the typical Dickey's good quality. I have had a few Dickey's pants and always thought they were comfortable and durable. I thought my daughter might like these pants.She wears leggings whenever possible. Compared to leggings, these are not as comfortable and she complained about the waist area being itchy. Kids these days...

This was a hit during a birthday party. The kids had fun and improved their flying disc throws although they still have a ways to go before playing the game as intended. They were giddy when they hit the pole but did not master catching the disc. I was able to ping the pole several times despite it being quite a while since I have thrown around a flying disc.The included disc is good for adults and teens but a little too big and heavy for children. They also thought it was too hard and did not want to catch it. I dug out an old flying disc that was softer and lighter and they enjoyed playing with that disc more. The bases, poles, and bottles are solidly built and appear as if they will last.This game could also be used to improve throwing accuracy: maybe set the poles several feet apart and throw between the poles. If the disc knocks the bottle off, you lose a point. Or maybe set the poles so you get one point for knocking one bottle off and five points for knocking both off with one throw. I think this set could also be useful for practicing Frisbee golf with different disc weights.

This is a large bath towel, similar in size to some beach towels we have acquired over the years. While it does dry well, I did not find it to be particularly plush. We have some other towels that feel thicker, softer, and more absorbent, so this did not seem like a luxury product. I do like the color and the weight but this is a personal preference.On the sample I received, there was a hanging thread pair. I was not sure if I should risk cutting it and the end unravel or leaving it. I left it alone. More disappointingly, a loop caught on a hook and pulled a section tight. This also left me questioning whether to leave or cut the loop. I tried stretching the section to reabsorb the loop but it did not work. I left it alone and put the bath sheet to be washed. After washing it appears the loop was reabsorbed but one end of the hanging thread broke free. Overall, it seems like a decent product but priced a little too high for me.

These are very good dividers. They are 30% post consumer recycled and are reinforced at the end. The paper is somewhat thin, maybe 24-pound weight, and relatively bright white, around 90 brightness.The labels are excellent. Avery's website is easy to use and very configurable. I like that you can select how many rows (1—10) as well as which rows to print. It even differentiates between back and front sides and accepts images. The labels apply easily and align well using Avery's peel away strip.

In general, Romik running boards/side steps seem to get little love here on Amazon. I have no idea why. They are well built, American made, and at least for my 2014 Cadillac SRX, a great fit. The assembly pictures are decent and helpful. I do recommend using the extenders (Romik 999609 Black Step Extender) for SRX installation; otherwise, the steps do not extend far enough to be really useful. After I added the extenders, my children mostly use the steps for getting in and out of the vehicle.

According to my wife, these are similar to the pad she used for years. They are thicker than what she's using now, but are more absorbent and also do not leak. She likes the pink wrapper. I told her she wouldn't have to worry about these for nine months if she got pregnant, but, and this is paraphrased, she told me to impregnate myself. Now I know to tread lightly when I see pink wrappers.

An easy way to tell if a story is worth reading is to give it to my ten year old daughter. If she quickly reads through it, it is a good book. If I have to remind her a few times, it is OK but some how it did not catch her imagination. She read this book completely within a day or two. It's going on my To Read list. This is her review:Nightbird is captivating and full of bits that will keep you reading for answers. It has a great ending and didn't bore me at any point. As a side note, I finished this the same day I started reading it.

Pure Fix Oscar. Several years ago, I received a copy of Fixed: Global Fixed-Gear Bike Culture and drooled over fixed gear bikes. A co-worker sometimes commuted on a fixie and I started leaving my bike in a single gear all the way home at times, thinking about converting to fixed gear. I never took the plunge.In recent times, I have biked or Trikked to the gym whenever possible. It is straight and flat. I seldom shift on my bike and can't shift on the Trikke. When the LBS declared my beater bike kaput, I thought about converting it to fixed gear. But after looking at conversion kits, I decided it would be cheaper and easier to just buy a new bike. I happened into a Pure Fix Oscar.This solid bike looks as good as some of the bikes in the book. The frame is heavier than my old aluminum bike, but it is well built and rides well. It reminds me of my first commuter bike, a converted mountain bike that I had for decades and put thousands of miles on.One of the tubes on the PF had or developed a pinhole out of the box and I had to replace it. Unfortunately, the replacement tube was also defective and burst while I was adjusting the kickstand. The third tube has held up OK, so I am glad it is not a wheel defect causing the leaks.The components are of surprisingly good quality. I thought I would replace more parts but have ended up keeping a lot. I did put on a trekking bar, kickstand, rear rack, and my old saddle. This bike is made to be customized. It is not a beater bike, but more like a bling bike that can take some beating.
And there was light.Low in power.Instant on light.Easy connect.Flicker free light.Cost effective.Non-buzzing light.Twenty ballasts.More than enough.And it was good.

Years (uff, decades?) ago X-10 offered an interface that allowed interested parties to directly read and control their devices through the AC power line. My brother was heavily into home automation and asked me if I could read and control this interface. I programmed a microcontroller and was able to read and display information from the interface on some 7 segment LEDs. After that exercise, life got busy and we did not develop further. It seems the home automation industry also tapered off a bit.More recently, I acquired a WeMo switch. It, along with the app for Apple, Android, and Windows Phone, has very conveniently controlled our hot water pump and has been saving water and electricity over the past year. Then I discovered the WeMo Maker. I have the Popular Science issue where it is listed as one of the Top 100 Innovations of the Year and that started churning the gears.A real application for this device would be a battery powered standalone project. Any line connected device could just as easily be controlled with one of the WeMo switches. What would be a good battery powered project? I might need to sleep on that. Wait! How about a motor control to automatically swing my hammock?!?The first thing to test is whether this bad boy can be powered by a battery. Sure enough, I hooked it up to an external power bank and even programmed it all without using AC power. Using the same network as the WeMo switch causes both devices to appear in the app.The hammock motor took a little more effort. I bought a cheap baby swing (Craigslist, $5) and ripped it apart, removed the motor, and mounted it on a wood base. A hook screwed into the end of the oscillating part attaches to a cord hooked up to the hammock. I tapped the USB line for 5V power to the motor. It works. I just need to tweak the speed and boost the torque to handle my size. I could also hook up the lights and soothing music, but that's probably going too far.The world is once again my oyster and I will get to it after a quick nap.

Before marriage, I had a set of nice Wusthof Grand Prix knives. I kept them honed and sharpened and took excellent care of them. After getting married, my wife and I still used them but she did not take care of them and I thought about getting a cheap knife set. Eventually, we bought a cheap Wolfgang Puck set that she and the nanny regularly abuse.Lest you think I am joking, my wife broke the tip of the paring knife. Evidently, jabbing a knife tip into a frozen chunk of meat and then flexing the blade side-to-side is an acceptable way to divide a large piece of meat. And one or the other seems to have used the chef's knife as a mallet or something. The handle has a small crack, which I just noticed. These people cannot be trusted with fine quality cutlery.Honestly, I have never heard of Mercer Culinary before this. I thought it is a new consumer grade products company. It turns out they have been supplying cutlery to culinary schools and working chefs for decades. The local restaurant supply store sells them. They are truly professional quality.The knives are individually packed and have their own slot in the block. My block is well constructed and everything is properly finished. I would prefer additional spaces for a steel and knives but can accept that it would detract from the simple visual appeal.The blade steel is excellent quality and the knives are quite sharp straight from the box. Mine could probably use some honing to align the edges. I do not know how long they hold their edge but suspect they should perform similarly to the Wusthof. Regardless of brand, I highly recommend watching Craftsy's free Knife Skills class taught by Brendan McDermott.This is my dilemma: do I let known abusers use this knife set or keep this for my own use? Students and professionals are the most demanding users, and if Mercer Culinary can supply those audiences, they should be able to withstand a couple of home (ab)users. I'll keep the Wusthof knives tucked away.

My ten year old daughter found the first part of the book slow and uninteresting, but she stuck with it and provided the following review:This book is an interesting mix of sad, moving, boring, creepy, weird, and amazing. I had to sort of force myself to read it, but it was worth it. The book is centered around the question "Why do only certain people get miracles?" Once you are past the beginning, The Question of Miracles is an amazing book.

Many reviewers rave about how this product restored their old cars to like new appearance. I say, "Pfft! Amateurs! Let me try this stuff on my three month old Cadillac SRX." It still has wisps of new car smell. This, people, is a real reviewer.As far as this product goes, it applies easily using a microfiber cloth. I wasn't sure how much to apply since it is thick like hair conditioner, so I started with a small amount and increased it proportionally as my comfort level increased. Then I got lazy and glopped it on. I will say that it led to some noticeably uneven areas, so I recommend taking your time and doing it right.As far as smell, it does not have a strong scent but I did detect a faint ammonia or some other chemical smell. My family has not said anything about it, so it is not a strong smell. And since my children do not like the "new car smell," it might even be considered more neutral than not. Overall, I think it is a good product and will continue using it.

This story was for my younger daughter. My older daughter is easily frightened and would not be a good match for it. My younger daughter, however, has an active imagination and is not as easily scared. Her tastes tend toward action and adventure books. She enjoys the BeastQuest series as well as Captain Underpants and other similar books.I let her read it and asked what she thought about it. She said it starts a little slow but finishes well and it kept her attention to the end. She enjoyed it overall and would read the next book in the series.I decided to read it and also thought it was worthwhile. I could see how the first part might not interest a younger reader but the action in the later sections is non-stop. The end seemed a bit abrupt and unfinished to me, but it does keep the reader looking forward to the next book in the series.

My wife had a small George Foreman grill before we met. She appreciated its quick and simple operation and ease of cleaning, so we requested a large version on our wedding registry. This larger version has performed well over the years and it has been a reliable appliance.We first tried this out with waffles. The waffle plates were a little misaligned and it took some effort to get them installed. I do like the convertible feature of this grill, but this could also be a weakness if the plate handles are banged around. I think careful storage and attachment/detachment will be important to protecting the plates. The company should make a storage rack or cover available.Anyways, the first waffles had an unpleasant odor, as expected, so I discarded them. The next waffles turned out OK. They were evenly cooked but did not have a nice crunchy shell that we get from our waffle maker. I wonder if searing the waffles the last minute might help. As a waffle maker, this is better than a previous one we had but worse than our current one. I think we will keep using our other waffle maker. This one does make larger sized waffles.Later for lunch, we tried it with veggie burgers. Here is where the grill shines. I like the new ceramic surface, and the temperature adjustment is very handy. This is a great improvement and allows all types of cooking. After grilling the burgers, I popped a cheese sandwich in there for my other daughter. Using smoked Monterey jack cheese with a little ranch, she said it was the best grilled cheese sandwich she ever had and ate it all including the crust.The adjustable slope is also useful and better than our old one's fixed angle. It is necessary to keep waffles even while allowing other foods to drain liquids. The plate size is a little smaller than our old George Foreman but still quite large and capable of cooking a family sized meal.Overall, I would say it is an excellent update to our old indoor grill. If only the waffle plates worked a little better, it could replace our waffle maker. As it is, we may buy some other plates and reduce some of our appliances.

After using VideoStudio for many years, I started looking for another video editing program that is faster and could output 3D Blu-ray. Several months ago, I bought and used PowerDirector 12 and was impressed by how fast it authored and burned 3D Blu-rays.This version is even faster. I have burned several 3D discs and am amazed at its speed. A short compilation video of a trio of scenes took less than three minutes. A six-minute puppet show took less than eight minutes. I am used to starting the process and then coming back hours later, hoping that everything worked. With this software, I can try multiple options and not be as concerned with time. I generally use BD-RE discs so wasting discs ("creating coasters") is not an issue.Editing video is similar to other programs but there is still a slight learning curve. As I learn more about this program (and I had only used PD12 for a few months so not a lot of experience overall), it appears that it will expand to meet my needs. I have downloaded some menus and templates from the Cyberlink website and appreciate the other users' contributions. I tried the EZ video option where the program will attempt to analyze the input files and select the project options. It took quite a while to process the video and the result was similar to what I would choose. Maybe I did not enable some feature but overall I did not find it worthwhile.For 3D video, I am using a JVC Everio GS-TD1 and it works quite well. I have also tried a Fujifilm W-3 but have not been able to find the proper combination to output a usable disc. It records in 24FPS and there might be some setting I am not choosing correctly. The JVC works pretty much with defaults. 2D video is completely straightforward and I have used multiple sources successfully. All that is required is to choose the proper output path.As far as resources, I am running this on an i7 PC under 64-bit Windows 7. I did get the BSOD once while editing video with Adobe Lightroom and Internet Explorer running in the background. Reducing resource load while editing is definitely recommended. I have burned usable discs while surfing the net multiple times so that should be OK.

My wife and I first became aware of Grohe on our honeymoon cruise. The cabin had Grohe fixtures and we were well impressed with the quality and durability. We figured if a fixture could take daily cleanings and abuse by different sea-faring passengers every week, it must be well above your standard home improvement store selection. When we remodeled our home, we selected Grohe fixtures. We were not disappointed. Our master bath had thermostatically controlled body sprays and a nice showerhead. With softened water, we frequently looked forward to returning home even while on vacations.We bought a new house and moved several years back, and the plumbing supply recommended another brand (Danze) as comparable quality at a lower price. Sad to say it has not performed nearly as well. We miss our Grohe fixtures and may move back to our old house when the kids have grown.When this appeared, it took me all of a few seconds to choose it. Even then it was just trying to decide where to install it. I decided to try installing this myself in our guest bathroom. It is a little more involved than expected and took me about two hours, but I am not a plumber and made a few mistakes. At this price point, most people will probably have it professionally installed.First off, this requires a ½" nipple and Teflon tape and/or pipe thread sealant. Tools required are 2.5mm hex wrench for set screws, a T10 Torx screwdriver for the upper anchors, a #2 Phillips screwdriver for the lower anchors, a set of wrenches or an adjustable wrench, and a 5/16" masonry drill bit (Bosch multi-construction). Drilling the holes for the anchors requires precise measurement. I thought rough measurements would be sufficient, but it is critical if everything is to fit correctly. In addition, I used a power driver to drive the screws into the anchors. That is not a good idea as I stripped some of the Torx heads. I did measure the height several times and was relieved the connectors lined up correctly. Again, careful measurement is critical.With that bit of work completed, the assembly went together quickly and it was time to test it. I did not remove the flow restrictors and there is sufficient pressure to run both heads. I really like the selection system where one to four patterns can be selected. After one use, my favorite is the Bokoma Spray mixed with Rain. The Bokoma Spray is an interesting in-out center pulsing. The hand shower has the same selections and running both simultaneously is a truly luxurious experience. I did not want to get out of the shower.I will say that the main system is well constructed with a solid feel like I remember. The showerhead and hand shower, however, are not as solid. They appear to be plastic, which is good and bad. Good because they are lighter weight (compared to a Hansgrohe Axor Terrano showerhead and Danze hand shower we have in the master bath) but bad because they are not as durable. The pattern selection uses a light touch to select multiple patterns or a strong touch to select a single pattern. The plastic just does not feel as good as brass. But the system has a lifetime warranty so it might not matter in the end.

When I first tried this frame, I thought short of T-shirt surgery (cutting), this would not work for a large+ men's T-shirt. But I proceeded to follow their instructions and see for myself. It is possible to stuff an X-large shirt in there. It won't win visual display awards, but it won't incite fermented fruit flinging.It took me a few tries. The key for me was to stretch the shirt taut while paying close attention to the armpit areas. Since the back does not show, I did not worry about bunching up the shirt where necessary especially around the armpit. It seems a little expensive but it is well made. If I could do 3 + ¾ * that would be my rating.

Far be it for me to suggest any beauty products for my wife, but I asked her if she would like to try this out. She thought it looked interesting so I selected it. Overall, she likes it and noticed a definite difference after leaving it on overnight.It goes on evenly and does not feel greasy or grainy, unlike some other creams she has tried. Another feature she appreciates is that there is little to no scent. About the only critical point is its higher price.

Once you get used to controlling this contraption, it is a load of fun. The app does take some getting used to since the controls are not strictly conventional. But then, this is not my father's Oldsmobile.I wish it charged faster. More than once, I have had to stop the merriment while it sat and recharged. It seems the run time to charge time is about 1:3 or 1:4, which is somewhat disappointing. The WiFi connection is also a bit touchy at times, but once connected seems to be solid.I tried it using the Android and Windows Phone apps. Both worked similarly and I am pleased to see Windows Phone 8 support. The Road Plan feature is interesting. It allows the user to program a sequence that the Sumo performs. It can be programmed offline so this is something to do while the battery charges.The jumping feature is funny and interesting the first few times, but once the novelty has worn off, it probably won't be used often. It does not work too well on carpeting and undoubtedly consumes quite a bit of power.Altogether, this is a fun little remote control gadget that has quite a bit of potential. It could use a little better power management and maybe add a dart gun for good measure.

This was selected as a replacement for my daughter's Samsung Focus i917 Windows 7.1 phone. We were originally going to hold off getting her a phone but decided to let her have one when she started middle school.Just unboxing and setting it up, I could tell the BLU is a significantly better phone than the i917. For one, it comes with a cover and screen protector. While in and of itself not a big deal, this shows that BLU pays attention to the details. The dual Sim slots are another nice feature although we have not used it. I did install a microSD card and appreciate the expanded storage.Finding and loading Windows phone apps has not been as difficult as some have made it out to be. For one, we do not want her to load it up with games, so the main titles that are available have been more than sufficient. Hard core phone gamers will want to consider whether the titles they are interested in are represented. Xbox owners will be better suited for this environment than other game system owners.We also bought her a new laptop running Windows 8. It has very good integration with the BLU phone. As she gets more familiar with the phone and computer, I can see her entering quick notes or thoughts into the phone and transferring the data to her computer. One point about Windows Phone Cortana, it does not allow access to anyone under 13 years old, so she still has a few years to go.As far as the hardware, the phone feels nice and solid but not too heavy. We like the large display and the buttons are responsive. Sometimes, however, the touchscreen seems to require a few attempts before responding. It's difficult to determine if it is the hardware or software. The sound is good, although my daughter says it is almost too loud and there is not enough resolution at the lower range. Calls are clear and we have not had any reception issues.

This is the second book in the Mean Girl Makeover series. My daughter read and liked the first book, So Not Okay, so I selected this title to continue the series. The following is her review.This book is a continuation of the previous story from a different point of view. Now it is from the victim rather than a witness. This book does a great job of describing cyberbullying. I am sure that the victims of cyberbullying or even regular bullying will find this book to be a great help. Both books have an equally good amount of tips and information about bullies that readers can use.

Our LG front loading washer is about six years old and still working well. We have gotten into the habit of leaving the door open after washing and it has been relatively odor free.This product has a pleasant smell and is easy to apply. About once a week for the past few weeks, I have sprayed it inside the washer and left it there overnight. Although we have not had a large problem with odor, it has improved somewhat. As far as cleaning, I thought it would also help remove discolorations on the gasket but several applications have not seemed to noticeably reduce them.Regular maintenance is essential and this product should help to extend the time between cleanings.

The title says it all. My router is a Linksys WRT54G. This thing was easy to set up per the instructions, however it just would not maintain a connection. Literally every 5 minutes it would disconnect from my network, search for the network, reconnect, over and over again. Item returned.

I've had one of these for about a year, and liked it so much that I bought another to use at a different location. It works perfectly every time and I've had zero problems. I like the fact that it can run on either a 9 volt battery or the AC adapter. Both are included. I usually just keep it plugged in.One thing to pay attention to is the mode when you first turn it on. When you first turn on the scale, the default mode is Kg, not Lb, so if you want Lbs you need to hit the mode button to get a proper Lbs reading.I've weighed packages from as little as 6oz up to 70lbs, and it is very accurate. I've even compared it with another scale I have and it is right on.The thing I like most about this scale is that the reading screen can be moved out of the way so you can weigh large boxes and still be able to see the screen. You can also mount the screen to a wall if you like, and the mounting bracket is also included.

This movie is just fantastic. There is very little dialogue, and is much like a 90 minute nature film, but without the narrator and much more entertaining because there is a storyline.If you like nature shows at all, you will love this movie. My 11 year old and 4 year old both loved it too. I saw it in the theater when I was a kid and was very happy to be able to find this on DVD now. Very happy to have it in my collection.

I got these as a little gift for my wife and she loved them. Yep, they're $14 earrings, but they look good and come in a nice little box. I was a bit concerned that they were going to be a bit big, but I think they're a bit smaller than what the look like on the little mannequin picture. A good buy.

In the spirit of nonconformity, I thought I'd write an honest review, contrary to the 160+ lemmings and friends of the author that wrote glowing 5 star reviews.I decided to stop reading this book at page 92 because my eyeballs were getting tired from rolling up into my head every few pages.
