Tracers was a fine example of the best in the young adult genre. It really effectively balanced themes of fantasy/paranormal with youth/teen storyline. I also think that there is a lot to be gathered from what happens to our protagonist, Jerry. At the surface it's like a search for identity but it's really about accomplishing something for a greater good and not being so concerned with the self.I felt that the author, Jerome Gilden, was good at not over-packing too much, but allowing just enough meaning and heavy weight to keep the story quite strong. For young adults who want to get a taste of the fantasy genre, and vice versa, this is a stellar middle ground. There are plenty of unexpected events and high-stakes situations that really keep the reader engaged, so I liked it a lot. Great book, thanks a ton!

Stop the Fear seemed like it was speaking directly to me. I was impressed, from beginning to end, the extent to which the details of how these episodes were described. From the thoughts of how last they long, to how to get rid of them, I felt this book was right on target.The author, Jamie Richards writes very eloquently and from the perspective of real expertise. You can tell that a lot of time has been devoted to understanding these problems that many of us are facing. The solutions are described in a concise and direct manner. Stop the Fear is a very helpful book and with each chapter you feel more empowered and able to regain control of your emotions and episodes. Great resource and very well worth it!

This is such an awesome idea! Teach them while they're young. Not only will they retain it better, but the kids will be genuinely engaged and loving their new language. I can't wait until I can take my girls to Paris and there won't be some absurd language barrier. I'm very happy with this language tool and the unique methods of learning. It is so much fun and great for families.You can tell that the author Eileen Mc Aree is a knowledgeable author who has composed this as a tried, true, and effective way to achieve a great beginner level introduction to French. My skills as well as those of my family has improved so much. I don't think there could have been a better resource to use. Absolute marvel. I don't even have to think twice before recommending this to someone with kids!

There is a lot of very valuable information contained in this book. It will make a difference in a lot of people's lives. I truly think that it crosses a bunch of different categories of people as well. So whatever your struggles, weaknesses, and differing situations are, there is a way to fine tune the tips towards your own life. So many good points are made that will challenge your preconceived notions about self-improvement and self-help.I would also say that 5 Anytime Resolutions is incredible powerful, motivating, and all-around interesting. I learned so much from it about myself, my worldview, my vision for the future, and how I perceive the past. Highly recommended!

Wow, I do not get all the great reviews for this book.The writing is childish in the extreme, with everything stated in a linear fashion, no subtext or building up of any kind of tension. The heroine is fond of making speeches about everything, even though she's supposed to be a painfully shy,. abused math nerd. She also suddenly morphs into a party girl with the aid of one make-over, and lets guys hug and hang on her, although she's been alone and trusted only one person in her entire life.Just unbelievable.

I gave this book one star because of the moral character of ... well, everyone in the book. Except the baby.Also because there is a lot of angry sex, but absolutely no romance.The hero is a Mafioso criminal who breaks kneecaps for a living (Yeah, just how I love my heroes--not), the heroine is one of those old bodice-ripper gals who enjoys it when he humiliates her, is cruel to her, threatens her, makes her crawl, ties her up all day ... I dunno, any one of those would have me looking for the nearest sharp object, but not this sweetie. She craves her some Mr Bad Boy action.The worst part about their interactions is she's terrified one minute, then he gets her hot in a NY minutes. She's furious - same thing. He threatens to take her baby away - same thing. She tries to run away, he ties her up - it's all aphrodisiac to her. This is not good character development!I enjoy well-written BDSM with true character development. This is Jersey Shore revisited. I kept looking for Snookie and the gang.

What I liked: The premise is funny. The writer is really good ...What I hated: except that she drug out a high school drama/comic/tragedy for how many pages???? The hero, heroine are both pathetic with how they 'know what they should be doing but just fight it because ...(insert reason of the year)' Since they did so until they were both thirty, I wouldn't hold much hope for their marriage to last, or at least not happily. They both need serious counseling.Their 'best' friend is a sociopathic loser and ... they kind of deserve him with the unbelievably immature behavior they both exhibit.

So this girl has been living on the streets for 7 years and she's beautiful, with satin skin and hair, etc? Um, let's do the nutritional math. No. She's been living without basic cleanliness or nutrition, her hair and skin would be wrecked, along with her teeth. She would've also likely been raped, beaten, etc. Homelessness is nothing to romanticize. It's a heartbreaking killer of health, leaving the person with little sleep because of constant fear, no place to get clean and eating the worst kinds of foods.Then, there's Lev's family. They're tough, savvy and run a casino/bar or whatever. Yet they accept a homeless girl into their mansion, about whom they know nothing-including her record and the state of her mental health, because many, many street people have severe mental issues to deal with. They accept her into their home and leave her alone with the baby?? Seriously??Lev. Evidently he is supposedly on the autism spectrum. Whichever, he is normal one moment and in the grip of the syndrome the next. Completely uneven portrayal.I get it, this is a Cinderella tale. It's also unbelievable.

Not nearly as good as most of the body of Lanyon's work, and I've read it all, because IMHO he's one of the best writers today.The hero spends nearly the entire book mooning over his neighbor, who flat tells him that if his lover hadn't 'left', he'd still be with him. Okay, then.It just felt sloooow.

I'm a big fan of Melissa Olson's 'Boundary' series.This book, I struggled with. And yes, its personal. I'm a mother. 4 pregnancies to get two wonderful boys. And I'm a teacher, not a cop. I've never wanted to put myself in the line of fire to protect and serve - I admire those who do. But the way Lena did it ... I struggled very hard to like and respect her. I liked her family, her husband, and Nate the teen - to me he was the true hero of this story.She refused to tell her husband she was pregnant, because he might fuss. Uh, yeah? That's one of the joys and privileges of waiting 9 months to get that baby out, so get over your bad cop self.She put her baby in physical danger over and over - and that I can't forgive. Whether you want to be pregnant or not, once you are, you are completely responsible for that little beings's life. Because of her actions, the baby could have been born with severe disabilities, or died.Just no.

Fabulous story. I loved the heroine-spunky, strong and unsinkable despite the things she's gone thru. Her mom is a delight, as is her gay friend.The hero was a lot of fun, loved watching him grow. I thought the author gave us a great glimpse of what it would be like to exist in the glare. I loved the scene where he taught the heroine how to give the press what they want, not the truth.

I enjoyed this as much as any of Cherise S's stories, and more than some. (Her shifter tales will always be my strong favorites)The domme heroine is well-drawn, so we get to see her motivations. She's very sympathetic in her struggles to get equality while working as a skip tracer with a bunch of alpha-hole cousins & uncles.The hero is a delight. Loved how he challenged her at every turn to redefine their relationship and forge a new pattern that worked for them.I totally don't get the pain with sex thang, but for this story, I was willing to go along to get the rest of the story.

This author can write. She simply goes overboard here to create the perfect heroine, with lots of angsty pain for her to wade through in this tale of woe. I finished the book, because I wanted to know what happened, so yes, the story held my interest the entire way through.That said, I thought the hero completely self-centered! He only changes a bit when he finally realizes he wants the heroine ... and I have to say if she marries the guy, she's in for more, because people that selfish don't change at heart, they regress once they've got their caregiver locked in with a ring on it.The heroine? Meet Mary Sue. She's beautiful, an absolute angel to everyone even when they're mean to her, looooves the elderly and small children, who by the way gravitate to her and protect her because she's so wonderful, she works harder than anyone else around her, she goes to deepest Africa to help the down-trodden ... and she evidently does all this in stiletto heels and big hair.Mummy was physically and mentally abusive to her--dad did nothing. Some of her co-workers are mentally abusive to her--she does nothing, nor does loverboy. In fact, he joins the abuse fest.I think this author will produce some wonderful work, with her talent and enthusiasm, but this book is just a bit over the top.

Wow! Fell in insty love with this heroine, a wounded war vet with PTSD who is tossed into the dark world of the paranormal, and then required not only to keep her toddler niece safe from it, but serve a powerful vampiress who rules Boulder, Colorado. The heroine also discovers that she can affect life and death with more than bullets!The mood of the story despite the dark issues, remains positive and keeps one reading along to find out what the heck happens next.Also love Quinn, the vampire man-candy. He's a great addition to the story and complicates the heroine's life in some very fun ways.

A great story, her best work in my opinion. The hero is such a big, tough sweetie. His interactions with his little niece would make the story even without the wonderful romance as he sacrifices to care for his dead bro's widow and hold back his desire for her until she's ready.
Fabulous series, with high intensity and emotion. Love these books!

A fun romance. The heroine is a teeny bit 'poor little me', but James is good enough to pull off the billionaire trope. I will say the companion novel about the REAL Hemi, in her NZ rugby series, is in my opinion a better story.Don't miss her New Zealand rugby series  and her TV reality show series - both fantastic romance set in wonderful locales.

It's one thing to write fan fiction, and call it fan fiction. If that's where Vicky Dean began, she went too, too far when she put this work up for sale. This story is a blatant copy of author Pamela Kelley's work.Don't believe me? Read the opener of  'Six Months in Montana' by Kelley, published in 2013, then come back and read the opener of this book, published in 2015. You'll notice that while some sentences have been re-worked, and the names and locale changed the story is essentially identical.The sad thing is, Dean is a good writer! If she would only make up her own plots, her stories would sell well. Oh, and she may want to change her author name, as this will follow her ...

I guess I'm the ringer here. I thought this could've been such a wonderful book, if the travails and self-doubts of the heroine and hero had been dealt with in some depth. They were not - the heroine is a wide-eyed little precious angel in a long dress that I totally could not relate to. She was like a cartoon of what she could've, should've been.The hero was done with more depth, but I got nothing of normality from him, just such a blanket of raw ugly agony that I was done with a shudder.This author writes with such enthusiasm and imagination, I think she'll be really good, but not there yet.

This couple feels real from the first kickoff. A pair of strong but wounded souls searching for their other half among plenty of missed passes. Loved the way they fought for each other, friends above all.
A good addition to Cosway's series about the quirky, fascinating folk in and around the little European circus. Wounded hearts, looking for a place to belong.

I loved KULTI, the work showed maturity and a steadfast character in the heroine that truly carried the story thru her difficult journey as a professional soccer player in a relationship with her lifelong hero, a faded soccer star struggling to find his new path. Read it!This story is New Adult, but ends up being a rather juvenile pastiche of bathroom humor, physical smackdowns and romance that never quite gets off the ground. The heroine behaves like a 12 year old boy ... oh, wait, so do most of the males in the story.The hero is sweet, handsome and unfortunately lacking in personality.Facts are suddenly flung at us instead of being subtly foreshadowed and then introduced as logical outcomes of the characters and plot.I'll definitely be back to read more of MZ's work. I hope it will be better than this.

What I liked: The cover.What I didn't like: Everything else. This book is sick, sick, sick. It glorifies the sex trade, which victimizes underage girls and boys, by giving us a supposed 'romance' between one such victim and her two main abusers and rapists.Not only that, the writing is just plain awful. Do not waste a second on this mess.

Kristin Callihan can write superbly. Love her contemporaries, and her historical paranormal ENTWINED. Unfortunately, EMBER is not one of her good ones, and serves as a warning rather than enticement to the following series.The hero is on a long, long, long, long journey to discover a cure for his mysterious malady. During this time he meets person after person, all bent on harming him. He scrambles ineffectually, a victim instead of a hero who can make his own mark on the story.The heroine is at the mercy of an evil, weak father who uses her, abuses her, and lies to her. She has powers but instead of parleying them to help herself, she harms and then scrambles to help, doing neither effectively. She is also a victim of all the men in her life.Why read on? I stopped with a major roll of my eyes when the heroine suddenly appears in a sexual dream for the hero, which seems to have nothing to do with their current situation, but merely the author saying to herself, 'Hey, time for some sex to keep readers interested!'KC should stick to what she does well and drop this lumbering saga.
This person has been tagged as a plagiarist, taking other authors' works and changes a few details to rip them off. Do not buy this author's work

How I wish I could give negative stars and suck away the 5 star idiocy for this story.I guess one woman's nightmare is another's fantasy, but ick, ick, ick! So many publishers will not even publish rape and abuse, but TT has found an audience for violence porn. And by porn, I mean sex that is only for titillation, containing abuse and no redeeming qualities whatsoever. I like good erotic romance, but only if the hero is redeemable. This one is just a sick abuser.When I was a kid, I used to turn over a rock to see the squirmy things underneath. That's what the part of this book I read was like. I'll never be able to scrub the content from my brain. And not even well written.

4.5 stars for a sexy, naughty romp with plenty of surprises. This story kept me guessing all the way through. I never expected to sympathize with bank robbers, but the author finds a way to pull us firmly into their camp, and keep us there.Loved the sexy fun in the private 'crime nightclub' and how the guys made the heroine's life meaningful.Paris Hilton afghans ... who'd of thunk it?

4.5 Stars. I thoroughly enjoyed this book, a typical Ashley fairy tale set in the rough and tumble of Denver's supposed underworld, complete with MC hero who rides in,sweeps the heroine off her feet, and saves the day. The poor, plucky, but beautiful heroine needs help, and she gets it, along with plenty of sexy fighting and loving from the hero. He's a rough, tough MC biker with hidden depths, she's the one who can save him from his dark past.Nobody does this theme like KA. Hang on for the ride, it'll be a fun one.

Struggling to believe this writer is a NYT bestseller. Her writing is some of the most untrained and under-edited I've encountered in historical romance, and I've read a great deal. For example: Hero kisses heroine for the first time. 'When he finally decided to halt, a protracted amount of time had elapsed. (?) Really? This dude has grown up in London's slums? And notice how we are not in the hero's head, but outside of it admiring his big words? Not realistic or sexy.Author never lets us find out ANYTHING, but dumps all possible information, backstory and possible outcomes right out of the characters' mouths in each scene. No suspense here, folks. And subtext? What's that? Everyone says exactly what they think, in excruciating detail, in every single scene.The characters spend a great deal of time in other people's heads. Hero kisses heroine. Then he thinks '..her knees were weak ...' How the heck does he know her knees are weak? He's not inside her head. The author does this over and over, letting one character 'know' what another is thinking or feeling with no reason that they could possibly know, and not giving us any physical description that would SHOW us why they make these assumptions.She then has hero think 'He never made commitments. He was a liar and a fraud, and he never made promises because he never kept them.'Uh ... what? People don't think things like this about themselves. We're all the hero of our own stories. We believe our reasons for doing things are right, and other folks are wrong when they oppose us. Also, hero supposedly has a huge amount of loyal minions in London underworld, which he would hardly have if he never did anything good for others.Heroine is either schizophrenic or completely unrealistically written. I'm going with the latter. Ex. Hero kisses the daylights out of her for the first time. She's a virginal miss, but 'She broke whatever spell had been festering. Flashing a lazy smile, she said, "That wasn't so bad."A virginal miss of that century 'flashing a lazy smile' after her first kiss from a bad man?? Doesn't seem likely.Okay, moving past the bad writing. This hero is a truly loathsome individual. He blackmails the heroine into being his mistress, then confronts her with his fiance and treats heroine as if she's a hired whore who is completely unimportant. Then he can't figure out why either woman might possibly be upset.The heroine continues her schizo tendencies (maybe it's not just bad writing) by alternately standing up for herself in a way that makes us want to  cheer, and wilting like a cooked linguine in the face of the hero's incredibly loathsome behavior. We're supposed to excuse this because of his lost childhood. Sorry, hero. Either you have character or you don't.Couldn't finish

I think this writer has a future, because she has plenty of imagination and enthusiasm.However, not ready for prime time ... by a long shot. This author needs to learn her craft, and then sell her books.

Okay, the hero is kind of an over-the-top bad boy, but he's also a very reluctant hero. He comes thru for the heroine when it's really important, and stands up for her in the face of some very intense pressure.The heroine is a fun person to read. I liked her, I respected her, and understood when she gave in to temptation--who wouldn't?Good suspense, good love story.

May as well admit, I was shocked by how much I enjoyed this story. I don't usually read very dark romance, or capture romance.These two authors are really good together. They have created a hero who has such a dark, horrific past that his present actions are completely understandable. And that's saying a great deal, since he kidnaps the heroine and forces her to stay with him. The only part I couldn't get past is that he has sex with her the first time while she's drugged. That was pretty rapey, I thought. Just a short little step up from date rape drugs.The heroine also is far from the sweet innocent she at first appears, and her background lends itself to her understanding and sympathy for the hero. I liked her, and enjoyed getting into her head to see what she would do next. She is no dummy, and no pushover. She stands up for herself at crucial times, even escapes when she can.The hero's band of 'brothers' are really well-written, and I will read more if the two authors write more.

What the heck did I just read?Okay, I only read the first chapter, but that was enough to convince me that this author needs some serious training as a writer.First, the heroine wakes in hysterics and describes a weird, erotic dream to her husband in great detail. Very great detail Never heard a dream described in such detail--it was almost as if she was trying to titillate him, not get comfort. The first paragraph, and I'm already not respecting or liking the heroine. Ouch.Next, the husband cusses her out for waking him, refuses to touch her, sneers at her, and instantly goes back to sleep. WTF? I'm supposed to accept this man as the hero of a romance, and want to flash back to their early romance? I don't think so. Any man this cold and callous needs a swift kick in the nuts, not a romance novel in his honor.I got my .99 cents back
This is a fun story, with Navy SEALS who are now covert ops on their own, MC heroes, strippers and gritty adventure--yahoo!

Sick, ick, ick! This is not a romance, it is a thinly veiled rape-tastic capture nightmare fantasy.Read only if your dream is to captured and treated like an abused animal. I will be staying far, far away from anything written by this authors.

If you like sugar sweet and cutesy-wootsy shifters, this is your book. All the hero has to do is give the heroine a sexy look or touch her, and she's all over him like tan on a surfer. The writing is good, just not to my taste. I prefer characters with much stronger characters and deeper needs than to get laid, so I didn't care for it.

Cosway + Reid = SerendipityThese two authors were meant to write together. Together, they are greater than the sum of their parts.I love LH Cosway's books (Hearts of Fire series) and very much enjoyed Penny Reid's chem and knitting series.This book is incredible. The hero and heroine are incredibly unlikely and yet the perfect mesh to make each other whole ... hmm, kind of like our authors. :DAlso love how they knit (author joke, get it?) the perilous yarns of modern media and communication tech into a quirky, raw and beautiful garment.

This is one sick puppy of a book. And at first I laid it on the manipulative, amoral hero ... but then I realized it's all the author.This book contains extra-marital cheating, abortion of a child created by two people who supposedly love each other, manipulation, lies and ... that's all between the hero and heroine. I get that abortion has to happen at times. This was not one of those times. Lies must sometimes be told to avoid causing deep pain. I get that, but why wasn't this hero strong enough to live with what he knew, to save the heroine, instead of breaking her heart to avoid causing himself pain?Houston, the hero is weak, manipulative, amoral and completely self-serving. He lies to his 'great love', he lies to his wife ... and etc. His sister made a very bad mistake with an older man. She then killed herself. For some weird reason he used this to drive away the heroine, his 'great love'. I put this in somewhat satirical quotes because truly loving someone does not mean treating them like dog doo, which is what he does.It was at this point I realized the author was manipulating the characters according to some great soap opera plan of hers that involves the characters moving around like puppets to create the Great Drama and Mystery of the plot. Ick, ick, ick.Could not finish, which is too bad because I liked the heroine (when she wasn't cheating with a married man) and I loved her gay friend. He was the nicest person in the story. The store was well-described, and her dog was a complete love.

I loved the other series by Monica Murphy. This one? I hate  the cold, manipulative hero, the author spends waaaaay too much time with him and his revolting sidekick Pilar, and the heroine needs to grow a spine and kick hero-boy right in the b***.There's a fine line between bad boy hero and cold, manipulative jerk. This one is way over it, and he's not getting back.

I never quite understood how a hero who professed to love the heroine his whole life would treat her as badly as the worst school bully ... but as an adult he is likeable, warm-hearted and funny. The heroine is a character, very fun.
Unless you watch the Jersey Shore reality show and eat up that stuff, skip this tacky story. Neither the hero or the heroine are at all sympathetic or likeable, so why bother?

Hank is a great big doll! I loved this story of the muscle-bound frat boy who has his eyes and heart opened by the cosmopolitan newcomer. And when Hank's big brother takes him home as a guest to their very unconventional family, the fun begins. The parents are hilarious, the story delightful.

Sex with aliens, bring it. But ... after the kidnapped heroine spends days on a spaceship with no hygiene, and must deal with her fellow prisoners' vomit and other bodily substances, all described in great detail, during the crash ... the big, blue-horned alien wants to grab her and have oral sex??Has the author never smelled vomit or sh**??A big Euww! from this reader, and a quick return of the book to Amazon. I enjoy erotic romance, but this was just disgusting.

This debut romance delivers well-rounded characters, from adults to children. The heroine and hero are sympathetic and I was rooting for them to bridge their huge differences and make a go of it, despite old misunderstandings.The setting of Oregon town teetering between old-fashioned commerce and new tourism dollars is very well done.

My family already has the Nerf Super Soaker Zombie Strike Splatterblast Blaster and this little Supersoaker pistol has the same durability and option for batteries. It also has the same water reservoir cap, creating a nice seal that doesn't drip.My six year old does OK with the pistol, but his hands might be just a touch too small for the grip. It's not bad, but I can see that he struggles with holding on and operating the pistol with one hand.I've been impressed with the SuperSoakers. Although plastic, they are solid enough to take quite a bit of abuse. I've had no problems with leaking and the designs make them easy to hold.

I used this to replace my 3M Dual-Swivel Monitor Arm (MA140MB) and a Workrite Poise Heavy Duty Monitor Arm PA3000-S Silver.Comparison:1. The AmazonBasics model, a dual arm mounting arm, provides the same tension and the same level of adjustments as my more premium Workrite arm. I use a Samsung 27-Inch Curved LED-Lit Monitor S27D590C on the right hand arm and have more control of monitor height and tilt with the AmazonBasics arm.  From the bottom of my monitor, I have 11 inches of clearance to the surface of my desk. I also get about 10 inches more of forward placement on the Amazon side by side. The Workrite stretches from the back of my desk to about 18" toward me, but the AB model extends even closer; I can move it within five inches of the front of my desk, right above my keyboard.2. The AmazonBasics model, although it has a six inch shorter mounting base than the 3M arm, also provides 11 inches of lift to my 19-inch Hyundai screen. I even get an additional 10" of forward placement. My 3M, just like the Workrite mentioned above, does not come as far forward on my desk as the AB dual arm.For document management, I enjoy having the wider options provided by the Amazon dual monitor arm.Conclusion: The AmazonBasics dual arm reaches just as high as my other two independent arms. The AB model adjusts more back to front than my other two arms. The tension on the arms are just as good as my (very) premium Workrite arm. And instead of two mounts, I know have cleared up some surface space by going with the single point mount provided by the AmazonBasics arm.

Works as promised in the item description. Solid and durable for a plastic toy. Easy to fill twist top plug.Has a good 20' foot range. Water shoots when the pump is pulled. Creates four streams of water each time pump is operated. Solid streams, not just trickles.Trigger is for appearances only. Battery not required to operate the soaker.I tested this with ages 4-14. The four year old boy took a little time to get used to the pump, but he worked it just fine. The harder this is pumped, the farther the water shoots. The 4yo was shooting streams about five to six feet long. The 14yo had streams at about 20 feet. The other children's success at spraying depended on their strength in pulling the pump and their coordination with aiming while pumping.

I have always had a bit of a dry mouth. I'm known for always having some kind of fluid on hand.Although this toothpaste doesn't foam like most brands, I found the texture smooth and tasty. And unlike other brands, this paste isn't opaque. It isn't runny and holds well to the brush. The flavor (and residue) reminds me of a dental office visit. It's not harsh.The first few days was a learning period for me. I missed the foaming action of regular toothpaste, but at the same time, I appreciated the clean feeling and didn't miss the overly crisp mint flavors that I'd grown used to. I'm not sure if it has the abrasive ingredients that make regular toothpaste work as it should. It doesn't feel chalk-like or heavy.And it works well. I could feel the effects (freshness mostly) of the Therabreath throughout the day. Even after having lunch, I could tell that the paste was still at work. It lasts well.

I see many of the reviews here focus on the general content with a concern for avoiding spoilers. I would like to comment on my general experience as a reader who has never experienced Neal Stephenson's writing before.The story sounded intriguing. I'm more of a history and mystery reader, but the destruction of the moon sounded like an area where I've never (t)read. The first 20%, or so, of the book was nearly impossible for me to quit reading. I'm happy that I began reading at the beginning of a four day weekend. I was hooked on the author's ability to introduce what appears to be truly scientific content while keeping a pace that seemed at once exciting and compelling.The characters are rich, but not so much detail that it seems like biographical sketches. There is a fair balance between "action," science, struggle,  and tension. There is never a moment when the author conveniently introduces a fix to a sticky problem. There is really no deux en machina driving the events; no "fix" to calamity.The last 25% of the book doesn't maintain the same pace, but the creativity shown by the author and the writing ability demonstrated by Stephenson is well worth the admission price.Although I am an avid reader, I haven't committed this much time to a single book, large or small, since George R. R. Martin's books four or five years ago.Although I was learning an entirely different lingo than the genres with which I'm familiar, I rarely struggled with the concepts. The author does an impressive job of introducing terms and concepts without making me feel like I'm entering new territory.If you maybe think this is too large of a book, I would agree that almost 900 pages is daunting. As for me, I read the first 76% of the ebook in about two days. I finished the rest of the title in the last two days. I was overly ambitious and maybe you'll find that a more casual pace is better.

Surprisingly sturdy for a rubberized toy. Due to the size, I would recommend purchasing this item for small children. I have very petite little ones and can't imagine that this would be enjoyed by heavier set or tall children. Adults may want to avoid this one, just based on what seems like a short length of sliding area.

Though no fault of the manufacturer, I've run into a snag with signal. I'm building a shipping container home and am discovering that signal quality (wi-fi connection) is greatly diminished due to all the metal compartments.I am giving the product five stars based on the quality of the product design and functioning *outside* my structure. There are no problems when I try to use this outside, but with a new baby, we don't have many opportunities yet for outside-the-home activities with him.I bought a Monster Digital SDUSA-0008-A 8GB Micro SDHC Class 10 Safari Series Memory Card to use, but haven't installed them yet. I'll update this post after I've figured out if they work. I'm also going to buy a new router; I'm currently using a TP-LINK Archer C9 AC1900 Dual Band Wireless AC Gigabit Router, 2.4GHz 600Mbps+5Ghz 1300Mbps, 1 USB 2.0 Port & 1 USB 3.0 Port, IPv6, Guest Network and maybe the difficulties I've experienced rest with the router.

I have a new home building site with a cleared lot. In the places where activity has stopped, I have grass over 6" and a very nice deep green color with zero crabgrass.To be fair, it's hard for me to know if the product works since I don't see any signs of crabgrass in other areas. At least my lot is safe right now. Of course, the lack of CG *could* be due to this Scotts product. I think I'll stay on the safe side and continue applications as my lot is revived from the construction clearing.

+ Very simple setup. I used the CD that came with the package and then plugged in the Epson. This installs the Epson print manager. Push a button and the print menu comes up. I installed on Windows 8.1.+ This is extremely light and easy to manage. But it almost errs on the side of flimsy, not quite, but close. So this positive was almost a negative.+ I had to scan a page of medical information. I decided to give it a slip test. After placing the paper in the tray and closing the lid, I turned it on its side and scanned the image. Perfect! The paper didn't slide at all. I figured I may as well try it upside down and again, the paper didn't slide. I have no idea what this proves other than the lid does in fact close all the way and prevents light from entering the bed when a document is in there. And it was fun to scan upside down. That too.I don't really have any negatives. It does what it claims to do and the resolution was excellent. This is a light weight scanner and easy to manipulate.

There's really nothing here for me to dislike. It's extremely long and works perfectly on my Kindle.My last cable had to be moved ever so slightly in order for it to seat correctly, but this fits perfectly without any wiggle room.

What happens when our demons, seemingly at peace within us, raise their heads? What happens when the very demons who've shaped us to their will simply disappear to be replaced by the angels of our own affliction?Graeme Cameron seems to resolve the tension between our rising demons and our even more-so troubling angels. The anti-hero, a very well-developed character, slowly deteriorates into a sane madness in a nicely fluid and nicely crafted tale.Although this book is not for the timid, this book is a story of redemption from evils that have defined who we are. As terrifying as it can be, our normal is someone else's torture.

This is a beautiful design. The slats are nice and close with about the same space between slats as the Sleep Master Easy To Assemble Smart Platform Metal Bed Frame, Twin. That being the case, you might be able to do without a box spring and go straight to memory foam. The Sleep Master has metal slats and have a lock in feel, but can't be picked up to be moved from the ends. This Classic Brands model doesn't have the same issue since the outer frame is bolted together and forms a more permanent frame.The wood does concern me a little. They aren't weak and will likely support two adults, but I suppose the slightly curved shape does seem like a good reinforcement against too much stress in more weight centered areas.I like it. For ease of assembly, I prefer the Sleep Master. For sturdiness, I prefer this Classic Brands platform.

My experience with other mattresses can be summed up:*The Sleep Number never really felt just right.*The Sleep Comfort creased the mattress when elevated.*The Novaform is like a hot plate and wasn't a good choice for my hot climate.*The Dreamaway by Sleep Innovations 10-inch Memory Foam Mattress, Full has the right amount of give and firmness. I can sleep on this without trapped heat developing.The Dreamaway was heavy for its size. But it wasn't/isn't a heat magnet like the Novaform. It's deep enough to avoid pressure points (I sleep in one position all night without moving).This Classic Brands mattress is seriously thick and is very firm. It is well made, but I get more of a memory foam feel from the Dreamaway. This mattress feels like a better made, higher quality fabric and outer cover than all of my past mattresses except for the Sleep Number.If you're looking for a mattress without a box spring, this would be a good choice due to its size. If you want firm, this is definitely the way to go.

"Is Jesus God?" or is that even the right question. Although New Testament passages do speak to the issue, writers like James Dunn would say that other passages suggest otherwise and that the solution lies in the development of early Christology. But what if the intent of Paul and other Biblical writers was not so much to proclaim Jesus *as* God, but was intended to glorify the Father, Son and Spirit by defeating modalistic conceptions of God? Yes, the revelation of Christ was new. There's no dispute. Instead of seeing NT references as defensively positing the divinity of Christ, maybe we should be reading them with a view to offensively posturing the reality of Christ. Not so much "Jesus is God!", but "the God you know is not without Christ."As Wesley Hill demonstrates, the NT is replete with "the one who" language, after all. To understand God, we shouldn't conceive of God as one and three, but one who is three. So "the Father who sent me" and "the one who raised Him up" defines who Christ is in relation to the Father.Recently, scholars have attended to the New Testament liturgy and confessions to demonstrate a High Christology at work well within the first century. I've enjoyed this new line of reasoning, with its wonderful answer to the New Atheism. I still have some reservations, however. It seems that a truth claim as significant as including Jesus as God in the concept of the Trinity should be seen early and should be strong. There should be no doubt. There should be such overwhelming evidence that when Christ's name is mentioned in association with the identity of God, there is hardly any mention of doubt or hesitancy in accepting that claim. From the early confessions in church history, it seems as though when God is worshipped, there is no doubt that it is *through* Christ exclusively.I think Wesley Hill’s “Paul and the Trinity” has added to the discussion of the early acceptance of Christ's claims and Scripture's meaning, but with a different method and intent.My understanding of Dunn's argument, for example, is that the NT writings demonstrate a *development* of Christology and then lay in categories of high and low on top of a developmental Trinitarianism. Yet if we accept Wesley Hill's presentation, we don't see a gradual developmental phase of Jesus' Godhood, what we witness in New Testament teaching is the dawning comprehension and a growing confession of Christ's Godly station. The truth of God isn’t changing, but the impact of Christ’s self-revelation changes the understanding of His message.The Apostle Paul presented by Wesley Hill is not one struggling to maintain his monotheistic roots (his Rabbinical background) against the intrusion of a new teaching (Christ’s revelation). Rightly, Paul's writing is an example of a rapidly expanding, crushing realization of the fullness of God. Though the Trinitarian mystery of being and identity may never be adequately explained, we can see that none of the Triune identities function by themselves. It almost appears that Paul presents Christ as “the one who sends the Spirit” or “the Son sent by the Father,” always in relation with the other persons of the Godhead. Christ is identified by His relation to the Spirit and the Father at almost every turn. The Trinity in unity.If Hall’s approach is correct, it would suggest, for example, that in 1 Corinthians 8:6, Paul isn’t redefining the Shema, nor is he attempting to somehow dialogue with or retain his Judaism in the face of new revelation. In other words, Paul isn’t recasting the ancient confessional statement according to a newly found Christology. When Paul writes 1 Corinthians 8:6, he is not only forging Christology, he is smashing modalism.And though I should probably read the book once or twice more to make sure I understand the reasoning more fully, I am delighted by the tone and the writing style. I would recommend this title to those who enjoy reading Bauckham, Hurtado and Dunn.I truly hope I've written the review well enough. The material is fresh in my mind, but the implications are exciting and are still thrashing around.Forgive me if I've failed the author. This is an insightful and well-reasoned work.

One third of my way into this title, I knew that it was one of the top fifteen books I have read in 25 years of research, education and reviewing.The writing style is smooth and the subject matter is addressed clearly. Instead of thinking of a bland, academic and heavy-handed commentary, consider this as a fluid paraphrase with little knowledge nuggets deftly added, giving this work a deeply informative read.The author transitions between commentary and personal application in a graceful manner. Not only are the vast (read: staggering) amounts of insight into the details of Esther provided in a clear and lucid manner, but the unveiling of Esther's literary devices explode from each chapter. I am still boggled by the amount of material the author was able to squeeze into the book without turning it into a graduate level deconstruction.This is really good work. It was a thoroughly enjoyable and educational, well-spent time.This is excellence! Thank you for the experience and the wisdom.

Despite it's dozens of pieces, this is not a bad decision. While working in a mattress and frame wholesaler, I've had to manhandle hundreds of frames. My toes and shins have come under intensive battery. The problem with typical frames is how to transport and store them.There are always going to be sharp (ish) corners and edges. As simple as it sounds, many people don't realize that frames without edges have a huge effect on the perception of the mattress. The farther in the edge of the frame, the more the mattress sags when a person goes to lay down or even simply sit down. This frame comes right to the edge without much overlap of my mattress on my memory foam mattress (standard Queen).The same goes with the corners - without good corners, your feet and head will tend to fall off and you'll also have a tendency to roll inward, squishing your partner (if such is the case).The ends of the frame are also good. I didn't notice any sliding or tipping when applying my full body weight to the end. The support legs are in a good place. Too far away from the end and it would be like sitting on a bench without a counterweight...it tips! But this frame doesn't lend toward tipping.There are loads of pieces and I wasn't prepared for that, but with a little time, it's all good. These are tubes, not rigid bars. The weight is reasonable. The slats are just a little too far apart for me to be comfortable with using additional supports underneath a mattress and probably will ruin a good mattress over time. Recommendation: add a box spring.I like the design for storage considerations, but I had to deduct a star for quality of shipping. The box was destroyed in route.

1. Presentation and Packaging: Stellar. It feels like I'm opening an Apple product. Tight, white and solid. There is an outer box with a fold down side. The inner box contains the watch the the sleep band. The inner box opens like a large jewelry display case. The watch and sleep band are protected in two separate compartments. Both are fastened around small round leather pillows.2. The watch: Incredibly solid. The band is supple and has a silicone band. It is slick and feels a little like shark skin. While wearing it, I can tell that I won't have to worry about hair grabbing. It is snug and doesn't slid around my wrist as I move. The hands glow in the dark as does the Philip Stein symbol at the top of the display. I see three insets: 24-hour clock, days of the week and day of the month. At this point, I can't tell if it keeps a regular calendar of if I will have to change it for months with only 30 days (and of course, February). It's not evident from the photo, but the bezel slopes down to the clock face, giving a depth to the display of about 4 millimeters. As it slopes down so do the numbers, but at a lesser angle, which gives the numbers a nice 3d effect. The hours stand out against the interior nicely. It's very attractive. There are no sharp exterior edges. Even the the crown is rounded. Position one and two of the crown are easy to find, so I didn't have any issues setting the different time functions. The listing above does not say, but the watch is the "Fruitz" line. The line is marked on the back of the watch and on the clasp, but nowhere else, not even in the instructions. I see quartz movement. And it's hefty. This is not a light plastic watch, folks. There is a type of inset hole in the back of the watch about 5 millimeters wide with a depth of about 2mm. Around the hole, which is covered with a crystal face is written, "Natural Frequency Technology." I had to search for what this meant. The best I can find is that the "technology" is an electromagnetic field. Supposedly, this watch has been field tested by members of the Miami Dolphins and 93% of them reported positive reduction of aches and pains after sporting the watch for three weeks. It is water resistant to three atmospheres and is stainless steel.3. The sleep band: This piece is about half the size of the watch in total girth. It looks like an attractive memorial band. The word "Sleep" is printed on the steel where the band meets the piece. I have to admit that at first glance, this looks a little silly. In the middle of the piece is another small window-like, crystal covered space that looks the same as the one on the back of the watch. Since I have chronic sleep issues, I will be interested to see if I show any improvement. I'm willing to try it even if I can't adequately account for how it might work. Does an electromagnetic field work to induce sleep or aid in the reduction of pain? I don't know yet, but will try it tonight and over the next few weeks to see. I'll update this post as I go. The band on the sleeper unit feels different than the watch. It's like a felt material and has holes throughout which I believe is supposed to reduce the heat signature of the band.Both of the units have a unique quick release mechanism allowing the user to switch bands without having to resort to knife blades in order to exchange.Overall, I'm impressed with the quality of the set. The display case itself is an impressive addition. I think the package adds to justifying the price. After all, if I were to pay retail for this set, I wouldn't want a bubble wrapped plastic stand. The extra touch of the pillows and jewel case are bonuses and also might alleviate some of the price shock of the set.The big question is the price. Is it really worth it? I can honestly say that this is not a cheaply made watch. It is well built, has a beautiful display and feels great. The most I've ever paid for a watch was around $200 and it "lived" for about ten months in a combat zone. I took this Philip Stein around my property today, in the rain, and did a little work. I left my cell phone at the house so I would have to rely on the more traditional timepiece. I came back with a scratch-free watch that didn't interfere with the outing. Incidentally, I came back without any aches or pains that I would normally have (combat injuries that will never go away). Did the watch take away the pain? I don't know, but I'm not going to argue.I did not find a single thing that would convince me to take away stars on the rating. Everything has been a positive experience. I really do like this watch.

This is the perfect saw for straw bale construction! [Do not use the auto-sharpen feature around your bales. Sharpening does cast sparks, but normal operation is great!]I have a Delmhorst F2000 Hay Moisture Meter Tester 18 inch Probe Value Pkg already and needed a dependable non-combustion saw to cut frames and trim some of the bales.There is the answer. There is no way this will throw a spark as long as you keep away from wire twines around your bales.+ PROS +Quiet operation (great for safety around a build)Easy operation (low maintenance potential)Non-combustible (no fire dangers)- CONS -I can't really think of any. It's just what I needed.

-1 star for no case. This is really aggravating. I was getting tired of reading the reviews here go on and on about there not being a case. Sheesh. Until I started my project, bumped the tri-fold budget plastic and my pieces went everywhere. It's like the bits were spring loaded. Then after some choice words, it dawned on me that small sets SHOULD have a case. C'mon, how hard is that?-1 for the amount of torque I have to apply to get the bits to hold in the tool. I was only using this on a piece of PVC and found that I was having to slightly tighten the locking mechanism. It's difficult enough to get a solid bite on the bit, but just when I was adding some torque, I must have also slightly adjusted the lock and out came the bit. Frustrating.Minus two points overall for making me cuss.
I seem to be having a difficulty with either the movement of the device or the movement of my little one.I'm going to try some double sided tape and will post an update.

Bottom line up front (BLUF): This device enables a person to connect to the internet without wireless signal.Where: Tested between an RV and a shed (redneck office). Lots of metal. The router is in the shed, but the wifi signal is about one bar. RV power comes off the shed circuit.How: Modem connected to router by ethernet cable. Router connected to Netgear Powerline. Second powerline plugged into RV.Result: I have a reliable signal that doesn't cut out when a bird flies overhead or when a Texas longhorn walks by (yes, it does happen).+ PRO + Unlike my last one, this little feller has a plug in it enabling me to still use a plug on the same outlet. It works!- CON - Nothing yet.

Take a five year old boy and mix it with visual feedback and combine that with a video game (and a little bit of tech help) and you have a winning combination.I've seen these before, but am very satisfied with the controllers. Yes, they are easily held by little hands despite the large appearance.The ability for my son to watch himself playing is great. There is a little coordination issue, but he is figuring out his spacial awareness very well.Just don't stand close when your little one is in the zone.If you want good, clean indoor fun (especially during these cold snaps we are having), give this a shot.NOTE: Games can be downloaded, but for those of us way out in the country, a physical copy of the game is a must.

I have reached my lifetime quota of clickety-clicks. It was either find a quiet mouse or go mad from trying to be quiet in the middle of the night. I also work in a cube farm and really can't take my own clicketys any longer.Based on some of the reviews, I decided to try this one and I have a winner. It really is quiet. It's muffled and hardly makes any sound at all. The wheel makes more noise scrolling than either the right or left mouse buttons.By the way, the little red button between the keys (and below the wheel) changes the cursor speed. It has a sensitive setting and a normal. It's nicely designed and didn't result in inadvertent activation.Overall, this is an excellent solution. Now I just have to find a quiet keyboard.

I do not recommend this set.The image on the Amazon page is not the real item, to be fair. The real package is in a blue roll up case.Half of the bits have chunks of metal gouged out at the tip and where the initial bite on the wood would begin. Half of the bits have gouges like that. One of the bits has a very nice coat of rust all over the tip. There are burs on four of these items.I'm not a professional woodworker, but I know when a product is poorly designed.These bits will eat your wood. Beware.

Adam, the Fall, and Original Sin is a title that is striking in detail and thoroughness. While the chapters are individually authored by a range of respectable names, it is nonetheless one of the most cohesive books I've read. While the vision of the title seems overly ambitious, the philosophical, scientific and theological arguments put forward are impressive in scope and breadth.Seemingly a difficult task, addressing Adam, his fall and his sin in one volume is asking quite a bit of any team of authors. I think this work has demonstrated the talent of the general editors at keeping the group focused on their task. Many chapters seem to be unified under a good deal of editorial preparation while demonstrating a fair amount of latitude in the ability of the authors to add their own flair and personality.Although the age of Adam identified in the text is likely older than many Evangelicals would be willing to reach, I found the argument persuasive yet a little outside my reach as a reader of theological works.Chapters dealing with those who deny original sin and the Fall are presented clearly and generally, but with enough content to likely satisfy advanced students of philosophy. The history of the development of the doctrines of sin are smooth and clear as well.In all, I enthusiastically enjoyed the book. I believe the writing style is probably most accessible by a moderate to advanced philosophy/theology readership. The title will likely find an agreeable audience with traditional Augustinian or Reformed backgrounds.

Fascinating!I found this to be a compelling and lucid introduction to the subject of OT culture. After reading of the tehom/hovering tool used by Moses (in the Longman and Erickson Introduction to the Old Testament), I've been intrigued by the notion that there is something underlying the narrative.After finishing Against the Gods, I've come to realize more significantly how much Scripture has pierced the culture in direct confrontation.This is a superb read and will certainly satisfy seminarian and the back-pew observer.
Item not received as stated on page. I'm unsure of how this unit operates as I did not receive this particular item.I will default to 5 star since this is not the fault of the manufacturer.

I really wasn't sure what to expect. I have a Neptor 5600mAh 3.1 Amp charger and like it very much for its compact size and charging power.The AmazonBasics charger (this one) is the same in output, but only has 2.4 Amp output instead of the 3.1 compared to my Neptor. Both seem to take just as long to charge, but the Neptor seems to charge devices faster.As far as size, it's difficult to compare exactly. The Neptor is a 1/2 inch smaller in length (almost 13 mm) and a half inch wider. The Amazon charger is flat, which is my personal preference for techy portables, things just tend to fit better when they are similarly shaped. The Neptor is a half inch thicker and is shaped like an oval (from the end view). So this category, is for me at least, a tie. The Neptor is smaller, but the Amazon charger has more of the design I personally prefer.Price wise, it's about the same. Currently, the Amazon charger is $24 USD and the Neptor is $22.Color might be another issue. My Neptor is blue and is therefore pretty high visibility. That is definitely not something I prefer. I like my gadgets black or tech silver.All in all, I can't decide on my own between the two. I am partial to Amazon's policy on product warranties and am basically a fan of anything working better, but this is a dead even race when all options are compared.

There appear to be a few titles in the expanded Pines world attempting to recast the timeline of Crouch's original.This is one of those titles. Although not a negative in itself, I found this book lacking the suspenseful allure that I've come to anticipate.I've also noticed that many of the Pines Kindle Worlds titles are extremely short and at $2 USD, it is growing into an insulting trend to offer such minimal content for such a price.The title by Kim Izzy is riddled with grammatical errors. I couldn't finish reading the title due to them. As noted above, I found the length and content wanting.If you are a reader who enjoyed the Wayward Pines grittiness and suspense, I recommend Konkoly and Battles books.

I'm using Windows 8 on a Dell desktop. The visual experience is excellent. Excellent colors. I have not tried the gaming mode, but figured the following information would be helpful for Amazon customers.This monitor doesn't offer DVI (usually a white video cord), but does support VGA (D-Sub, usually blue), DisplayPort (flat with rounded side) and HDMI (rectangle).The driver was necessary for my system and can be found at www.samsung.com/us/support/owners/product/LS27D590CS/ZA and during the install, you are offered three choices: Analog, general and digital. If you use DVI or HDMI cables, select "digital." The model number on the box and on Amazon does not have the "L" at the beginning, but if you speak to Samsung support, they may tell you that model number doesn't exist. Add an "L" and they are happy.
Sound levels are determined by the sending unit. I have also learned that static is caused the charging while sending a signal.

Compact, light and seems to be dependable.The lid keeps the scale from being depressed while being stored. The "zero" works by simply twisting the scale.And the best thing is no batteries are required!

Four stars for being durable, but minus one for large turning radius at my location.It might not be fair to the manufacturer since winds are pretty steady where I am. The Fire Shot does fly flat and is surprisingly resistant to wind surges, but I'm thinking that the slow turn might be due to fighting the winds.It's just hard to judge since I'm in the country. I have a 100'x100' area which gives about five seconds of flight in a straight line before needing to turn. I am getting a flight ceiling of about 20' before it starts pitching.The vehicle has been stolen by dogs, flow into large cacti and has been prodded by a three year old. It still works. The extra set of blades has come in useful. I've only had to replace one so far. They do get brittle when cold (one broke in about 40 F conditions).

I have a problem reading books dealing with military operations or environments. I have no idea how many books and TV shows I've started only to end up disgusted with the creator's lack of knowledge concerning the tactics, technical language and equipment.Blake Crouch's series largely avoided those pitfalls (either that or he had a heck of an editorial review). And because I was so hooked on the Wayward Pines books, I decided to dabble in the fan fiction.To Steven Konkoly: Thank you for your excellent descriptions of equipment. Your WP books do a great job at showing action and avoid overly technical language and at the same time, you do a great job of getting things right. It doesn't sound forced.To everyone else: This guy can write vivid scenery and events. Although short, I would compare them with a movie rental: It would probably take you as long to watch any given movie, but you these books only cost half as much (at most). Value-wise, skip the movie and just read this series. :)

By the end of the second book, I was fully engaged with the series. The action is nicely described and there is quite a bit of action. I read the third book at a frantic pace.My only complaint is that I wish it was a longer book. I could definitely read more by this author if this is the style and pace to be expected out of other works.

Negative reactions: Everything required to power the camera must be supplied by the user.1. I was disappointed that the camera did not include any cables, power or video.2. I was also disappointed that there was not a larger storage device on board or included in the box.3. And there are no batteries.Positive reactions:Instead of hooking up the camera directly to my computer, I installed a 32gb SD card Kingston Digital 32 GB microSDHC Flash Memory Card SDC4/32GB with removable micro SD card so I can take my tablet and read it on site without making trips back to my desktop computer.Following the instructions, I set the camera to simply take photos on detection of movement. I have a 30'x30' clearing with two trails leading in to opposite sides of the clearing with mesquite bordering. Out of 27 photos, only three were triggered by wind. The others perfectly captured wild donkeys, my two dogs and a coyote. Six of the photos were taken at night; the black and white night photos are very clear and captured three wild donkeys at 25' with enough clarity to clearly identify the objects. The day time photos are full color and objects are easily identifiable.I have no problems with the camera and found it to outperform my expectations. Minus one star for no batteries, SD card or cables.

Excellent features and a simple, intuitive face, the Ambient Weather batter charger is light, compact and works well.NOTE: You must supply your own NiCad or NiMH batteries.Never wonder how much charge you have left or what the status is for amerpage.

I had a noticeable decline in suspended solids within almost a week or two. I used this in a small pond that catches debris during rain and I've had a difficult time keeping up.I like the product. A little goes a long way.
Sturdy, thick glass. The finger hook makes the weight of the bottle manageable. Thank you.

Incredible idea. Not as many options as I'd anticipated.I was under the impression that I'd be able to select the time based on the meal. Perhaps I'd read something around the same time, but I thought I'd be able to scroll to "pork," select the volume ("two pounds") and then be able to cook for those specifics.What I received is still an impressive smart device, but what I had in my head was different from what I received. Completely and totally my fault for not paying attention.That said, the cooker itself is dependable and produces consistent temperatures. I still have not adapted to the app, so I won't comment on it any further than this.It's a good size. This is my second WeMo device and both have worked exactly like the *manufacturer* states (despite my anticipations to the contrary).

It's great. It has a small footprint compared to my other drives, one of which is failing (Toshiba). It runs silently and it has software installation files already on the drive.However, it's always nice when the cable can reach my computer. I understand that many people will probably enjoy the shorter cable as it is less to manage when using a mobile device, but this is a USB cable. My iPad and Android do not have USB links.To the manufacturer: Please consider using longer cables. If you leave the cable short, please include an adapter for the microUSB or a lightning adapter.

"Somewhere Safe with Somebody Good" was exactly that.While the book seemed to start a bit slow, I was safe at 'home' in Mitford with the good friends we've all come to know and love.While Father Tim is still the central character, much of the storyline has to do with Sammy and his struggles with being loved and learning to trust.Thank you to the publisher for providing an advance copy.

I give the book (series included) 5 stars simply because I couldn't stop reading it.It's graphic. In places, obscene and/or violent. I'm pretty sure it won't be considered among the most remembered of literary works.However. Big however. The allusions to Biblical themes kept me thinking. The story line and the characters kept me glued. There's no other way about it.In an attempt to avoid spoilers, look for theological references. Ark. Chosen by "god." A group who at length considers hell, limbo, paradise. A small group kept from destruction. At places, I thought I had figured out what the author was shooting for only to then have him switch gears and throw me in a different direction.Mr. Crouch, thanks.

Bottom line up front (BLUF): The cable is working fine, but I am worried about fraying the end because of the tight fit.I have a "Nude" waterproof case. Plugging in this cable requires a little extra force. While that might not normally be a problem, taking it out is only possible by pulling on the cable instead of the plastic tip.The flipside of that is that the cord does not bump loose.

The publisher promises a book which will, undoubtedly with as little bias as possible, present the varied eschatalogical views held within the evangelical church.In this reviewer's experience, it is the multi-view books which have offered the most insightful comparisons and contrasts wherein representative authors are able to make their own cases and respond to their opponents or detractors.The author of "The 8 Great Debates of Bible Prophecy" has presented a thinly veiled defense of one eschatological position, namely, Pretribulational Dispensationalism.The arguments presented are not new, but they are presented with a little more style and a lot more accessibility than other attempts. The reader is not left to rifle through pages of materials; the arguments are plainly laid out, in context and with a good deal of explanatory material. Many of the views are decently presented and the author does not shy away from admitting to which view appeals to him the most. I found the honesty of that particular device refreshing.However, there are a number of views that are carelessly addressed, reminding this reviewer of material directly out of Scofield or Chafer, amounting to no more than straw man arguments.The author reminds the reader of the claim that three Church Fathers believed in a literal interpretation of Scripture, resurrecting the assertion that allegory reigned and saw it's eisogetical fullness in Augustine. Although this has been trumpeted for over a century in quite a few Dispensational publications, it is fallacy to restrict this time to a single interpretive method as winning the hearts and minds of the church at large.Some issues, orthodox preterism specifically, are treated to no more than one page, dismissed with the prefatory "evangelicals in general believe," as if that were representative of past or contemporary preterist enthusiasts. RC Sproul is mentioned, as is Gary DeMar. But none of their particular arguments are presented. Only their names are listed as advocates of a position that is untenable for no apparent reason other than the rejection of their interpretation of one word by "general evangelicals."Overall, I would not recommend this title to readers looking for an even-handed presentation of Protestant end-times positions. This would be more suitable for a Sunday School class or introductory college class for students who are already dispensational in confession.

"Got 'em."That should be the motto for this device. I love the background noise and the circulation is helpful too.I needed this for my shed/office. The nasty little flies creep in with ninja-like skills, blown on the wind from the neighbor's property. Disgusting creatures. Not the neighbors...the flies.Anyway, the Stinger does in fact work. And it works well. No chemicals, no odor. It also provides a nice, attracting light that allows me to navigate the shed late at night without breaking my knee caps.It works on the same principle as the "blue lights" that are installed in the cafes and fast food marts of the big box stores. And it works just as well.A note to the manufacturer: Thank you.

Notes on my experience:Setup was a breeze. Google login first, then Kindle. The rest of it, including a system upgrade, is on the user.If you want to feel as challenged as I did know this: the stylus is not the black piece on the left side of the device. And yes, that piece does come out. It just doesn't do anything. The stylus is found on the bottom right corner. And it's cool. It has an eraser! To get the eraser to work, I had to double tap it on the writing pad. When the stylus is removed, a small tutorial comes up. Don't close it. :)Another thing, I count only 11 gbs of storage. So the rest is either eaten up by system files or there really isn't 16 gb available, as promised.I installed my usual suspects of cloud storage (Mega, hubriC, Tesorit, dropbox, otixo, etc.) and was pleased to see that Google Drive, Onebox (Skydrive) and Box were already installed. A bonus HP cloud storage app is on there, but I can't get on, even after resetting the password. All in all, I'm sitting at around 100 gigs of storage through this little device and I'm linked to my desktop (which I don't really even use any more except as a file server).I really do enjoy the forward facing speakers. But they vibrated when I turned the volume to max. I had to back off about half way before the vibrations quit.And hot! This little thing can crank out the heat. About two minutes after booting and setting up, I noticed that the back of the tablet was heating up like an iPad 2. The heat diminished, but don't be surprised during your initial sequence when your leg starts burning.I also like the rubberized feel to the case. Everything except the screen has a ever-so-slight rubberized coating. I'm guessing that this will be a very nice feature when other devices might slide around on the seat next to me when I drive. Sliding devices are not happy devices. And I'm sure it will be much cooler after being subjected to hot summer days.And for anyone else driven absolutely bonkers with the clicky keyboard sounds, you can turn them off by going into "Language and Input," choose the levels symbol beside Google Keyboard and turn off "Sound on keypress." Took me a while to find that.

Pros: Superbly written and meticulously researched.Cons: Date and time references could be mentioned more.Having dabbled in the grounds of the military historian, I realize how difficult it is to present the information in an engaging but accurate way. Custer history is in itself particularly difficult.There are so many niche historians who concentrate their efforts on this one man, his career and of course, the Battle of the Little Bighorn, that even what may seem to be a trivial error in research can turn out to be monumental. I am firmly convinced that Thom Hatch should never have fear of being ostracized from that community. If anything, this present title should find a warm welcome across the spectrum of military historians, armchair generals and even out to a very broad audience beyond the realm of history buffs and Bighorn specialists.Style: The writing is fluid. The story is elegantly displayed as Custer goes from civilian life, through training at West Point and enters his place among the Army's superb tacticians of his time. Hatch is able to weave the romantic interests of Custer as it occurs without making them distinct periods; it occurs to me that most biographical exercises tend to compartmentalize the different aspects of the character in question. What the author has produced here is much more informative and develops very nicely.Content: Hatch does not set out to create a dissertation full of footnotes and quotations, instead, he blends the accounts together so that the content is ruled by his writing style.It's probably obvious that I am extremely pleased with Hatch's work. I think Glorious War adds a dimension to Custer that is rarely emphasized and often overshadowed by his defeat in 1876. I went to the effort of double-checking a few of the events and was pleased to find how the author directly addresses controversial points while avoiding taking a reconstructionist view of those trifles. He does not set out to create a new or different understanding, but expressly sets out to capture the pivotal events which demonstrate the bravado, cunning and occasionally even, the tactical errors of George Armstrong Custer.Hatch's work firmly demonstrates the character and drive of Custer.Audience: There are only a handful of titles on my shelves of Custeriana that stand above all others for their ability to weave history, external sources and narrative. Among them are A Terrible Glory, A Controversial Life of George Armstrong Custer andThe Day the World Ended at the Little Bighorn. I think it's fair to include Hatch's work in this group. But beyond this, I believe Thom Hatch's Glorious War will cross over to readers of other genres easily and with great acceptance.

Works well for preventing algae in run off collection areas.We have lots of small pits and streams which are great for the frogs, but the algae (and the odor) is horrible. After treatment, I've noticed a clean line around the edges of those run-off zones where the algae no longer grows. But I still have an issue with the algae above that line. I may have to wait for a hard rain to get my peak water line and then treat again with a smaller shot.As an aside, I would have appreciated a lid tool. I just about destroyed my hands trying to get it open. There is probably some strange little trick to make me feel like a moron, but I'm just not getting it. Ouch.

Works well. Very unique. Light blanket, but still a little much in my hot climate.Pump is easy to operate for 3-year old. Needs an adult to roll it up. Pretty much wrinkle free due to the fabric choice.Overall: Good. Easy to use. Highly portable.

I had to stop reading and then go back and add notes to locations where supposed evidence can be found tying the author's father to the Zodiac.The single biggest disappointment is the lack of material concerning the Zodiac. At one point, I had to look back to realize that only two out of 51 chapters at that point had even talked about the Zodiac's actions or behaviors. Everything else is family history and whining about what a horrible childhood the author had. Not quite true, the author does spend a lot of time on racism and anti-gay bigotry in San Francisco, the Manson Family connection, the Zodiac meeting the Queen of England, the Zodiac discovering a plot to assassinate President Ford and many more fascinating departures from the thesis.Not one time is anything of substance offered for the author's father being the killer. The first murder is in Riverside, CA. Well, Van (the author's dad) drove by there once. We think. And then without anything to indicate the dad was there, the author manufactures an entirely fictional what-if scenario that is without any grain of believability. Read it and consider the time it would take to accomplish all those things in one day without ever being seen or questioned.Here's more evidence:Van is an alleged "expert cryptographer" yet creates a simple substitution cipher that was cracked in less than two days. The cipher in question ends with "ebeorietemethhpiti," completely unusable and wasted text.Van is an alleged "expert marksman" yet was unable to kill five victims immediately. He had to resort to a knife, leaving Mike Mageau, Cecelia Shepard, and Bryan Hartnell alive. Shepard died two days later after her attack. Paul Stine was the only person to die from a single gunshot wound.The author claims to have found the full name of his father written completely, just backwards and without using code in one of the ciphers ("Earl Van Best Junior," written backwards in plain sight"). I found my own name (including full middle name without too much effort).The most complete description of the Zodiac killer (20 to 30 years old, sloppily dressed, big stomach, not intelligent with a slight drawl) completely contradicts the author's description of his father (40 years old, immaculate speech with slight British accent, highly intelligent).30 years later, the author asks the detective if he's ready for the media frenzy that will take place when the dad is proven to be the Zodiac. The detective is shocked. He's never thought about that before. Really?More evidence: All the women victims looked similar to one of the dad's ex wives. UPDATE: No other motivation has been given for any of the murders except that less than half of the victims appeared to look like Van's second wife.Even more evidence: The name found in the cipher is mentioned again. However, I found "Oreo Rocks" plainly spelled out in the cipher. Does that prove anything?And that's it. That's all the evidence.Not once is there anything mentioned as to why Van used astronomical or nautical symbols or even why he chose the Zodiac moniker.This was a horrible disappointment. I'm getting a refund! UPDATE: Amazon gave me a refund.-----Notes:(The following notes are based on Kindle locations).Location 2029: The first murder. The author's dad is alleged to have traveled three hours toward Mexico then for no particular reason, gets off the freeway, drives 20 miles northeast and finds the library on campus. He spots a girl go into the library and then with no one looking, opens the hood of her car and disables it without being seen. On campus. Then he goes and finds a desk in a room in the library, writes a poem, carves it into the bottom of a desk, then goes back and waits outside the library for the girl to exit. How many hours would this take? This is not a believable series of events. All of this without being seen.2033: The motivation for the murder is that Cheri Jo Bates looked like his ex wife.2117: The Z on the Zodiac letters is actually E and V (the first two initials of the author's father)? And one graphologist says the Z is E and V and would defend that conclusion "in a court of law" (see location 4838). UPDATE: Additional marriage documents filled out by Rev. Filger have now surfaced. The hand writing on the Reno marriage certificate is a match for Rev. Filger.

This turned out to be a little more useful than the iOS 30-pin charger since it offers multiple attachments for micro USB and iOS.The drawback is that phone cases like mine block the small connector.+PRO++ Small+ Multiple Connections- CON -Will not fit bulkier cases

Small and includes one battery. This came in very useful out in the country.I was slightly disappointed to discover that a single charge was all this unit was able to deliver, however, I realized that the best use of it was probably large events (fairs, concerts, etc.) where regular back up chargers are not so easily used.
