It's a good blade, sharp but I found the handle blocky and uncomfortable.The blade meets well in the handle. It's sturdy without any give in the locked position.Overall, it's sturdy and sharp. I just can't get past the feel. It's solid shape is only negated by the blocky design.

I use this at work to cut out background noise and cube-farm conversations. I had been using a TYLT TUNZ Stereo Headphones - Retail Packaging - Blue, but they grew uncomfortable after a few hours.I'm currently outfitted with this Corsair Vengeance right now and even though there is a conversation 10 feet away, I can't hear it. Just my music. And yes, I'm on my 15 minute break, so I'm not cheating the company. :)

I now have this hooked up as a backup. I'm an avid reader and thought it would be interesting to use this hard drive as an exclusive portable drive for all my media (mostly books though).I used a Dyconn 10 port hub and connected directly to this from the WD My Passport.I have not had any glitches except when I restart my system without powering on my hub. But as they say, that's just a user error.No glitches. Great performance. It hasn't failed at all and there were no additional drivers to install in order to connect.

This is my second Lexmark and my second laser printer for home use.It delivers as promised and easily connects to my home network.However, the cartridges seem proprietary. If you don't use licensed Lexmark cartridges designed specifically for this model, you're out of luck.I haven't personally put this to the test since I've not run out of time on my print allotment, but this is enough for me to deduct a star from the overall rating.In a day when maximizing usage and open hardware systems, this seems to be a step back in the wrong direction.

Sorry about the caps, but I love this speaker. It's easy to set up and the volume can really be pushed to the maximum without ANY fuzzy dampening.Syncing to my iPad was simple and because of shape, it doesn't roll around if I just want to watch a show when I'm laying in bed. It stays put.The one thing I don't appreciate is the incredibly loud noise on power up and power down. It is not quiet.There is just nothing about this speaker that I don't appreciate! Excellent. Excellent. Excellent.

As a lot of folks know, a lot of these project staplers have feeding issues and the grips usually are tough on the tendons, especially if I've been doing something like a screen assembly or similar lengthy project.This TacMate hasn't given me a single problem. No fatigue from rough metal edges and no feeder problems. Yet. I'm not saying I won't, but there hasn't been a single problem. And so I bought another pair for my brother-in-law for Christmas. I'm confident that he'll enjoy it for the same reason. Inexpensive and I don't feel like throwing it across the shop every two minutes.

Impressions: The packaging is very nice. The phone mic is a great feature in this price range also. I'm especially fond of the wires: Non slip and flat.Being a fan of headphones, I can tell you that these are dependable and feel great. This set comes with other sizes of gel ear adapters to fit the common ear canal sizes.There are just as comfortable as my $200 set (AKG K391), but of course don't have the same amount of depth. But for the price, this is likely a good investment. I would probably feel more easy carrying these around than I would my mid to higher end sets.

Good field of view. The metal is a good heavy gauge and the mirror clicks nicely out of the way when needed.The steel tube that grips the mirror to the inside of the bar becomes distorted on first installation so if you need to remove it and reinstall it it's a little difficult and you must try to reshape the tube with pliers so it will fit back in the bar for each subsequent installation. Thus it never really stays firmly in place anymore; it's either a little too loose and loses adjustment or it's too tight and will not adjust.The glue that holds the glass to the mirror body was inadequate so the glass fell out but fortunately didn't break and I could reglue it.

Pedro's claims they use tool-grade tempered steel on this tool. I've only used it once but the quality seems very good. If you look at the reviews of the other chain tools, broken and bent tips (the part that pushes the chain pin) is a very common complaint and has been my experience with other chain tools. Because it is so small and light it is a little difficult to use but the tip is hard enough that it deformed the chain pin slightly and made a sharp edge that cut me. I had to use a wire brush to smooth the sharp edge so I wouldn't get cut again in the future but I think that might be testament to the fact that they use hard steel, certainly harder than the chain itself.

Corn Mache comes in different varieties: green leaf, red leaf, small seed and large seed. Large seed is supposed to be heartier but it's widely know that it is difficult to germinate (my experience confirms this). These are the small seed, green leaf variety, shipped from Lithuania. These sprouted faster and easier than the domestic USA large seed brand that I had used previously. Shipping took about three weeks. Package indicates the seed are viable through 12/2017.

I purchased both lamps, the front (white light) and rear (red light). The rear red would a very good rear lamp except the amount of light emitted to each side (of both front and rear lamps) is very close to zero so they are effectively seen only from the front and rear -- not the sides.The front lamp has no conventional lens with which to focus and amplify the light so it spreads a very wide beam when mounted horizontally or a very tall beam when mounted vertically. Essentially, it casts light to places you don't need to see. The front beam casts only to about four or five feet. I have a very inexpensive single-LED lamp (two AA batteries) that has a focusing lens which casts a directed a beam that is a little brighter and casts a few feet longer.The lithium-ion batteries charge with a conventional mini-USB cable. A cable is included but no AC adapter is included.  They require 2 hours to charge. That it is rechargeable is not much advantage. At the highest intensity the batteries last less than two hours. Most modest LED lamps using convention AA or AAA batteries will last in excess of 40 hours or more. On an overnight trip or a bicycle tour a conventional AA powered lamp would be a far better choice.The manual states that "the battery may become ineffective at about 80% of its value after 300 to 500 charge/discharge cycles ... 5 years life span under good care." 300 charges sounds closer to 1- to -2 years in my cycling universe. The manual further states that the battery "loses 1% of its charge per day when stored at room temperature and 5% per day at temps over 104F degrees. Stored battery life decreases 50% at freezing and further degrades as temperatures decrease."The white front lamp is perhaps better used for other purposes, a dark closet or cupboard, for example. I returned the red lamp but will keep the front lamp for a cupboard. Now that I have it for that other use it will still see some limited use on my bicycle but next time I will make another choice for my cycling needs.

I leave this on my helmet all the time with the camera mounted. Why not? I can reach up and take either a still or a movie in a moment's notice. If it will strap to your helmet with velcro it will strap to just about anything as a mini tripod. But I just remove my helmet, place the helmet with camera on a rock or limb and get a very steady and stable shot.It's not super-durable so it's not worth more than the asking price <$8 but at that price this is an excellent value.Will purchase again and recommend to friends.

Size Large is close to an XL ... somewhere between.Really shows dirt and is difficult to clean. To get this "close" to clean I must attack it first with Dawn dishwashing liquid (which usually cleans anything) and a soft nylon-bristle brush. Then I put it in the washer and it's then "almost" clean. The dirt shows mostly around the sleeve cuffs so I started wearing the cuffs inside-out, but still... The labels indicate that there is some sort of stain-blocking technology used with this shirt but I don't see any such thing. Food stains are just as difficult.I'll keep it but I won't buy any more. Previously I used a yellow vest and will rely primarily on that. I really wanted to like this for the sweat-wicking but it's not worth looking like a dirtball all the time.

These tires are a little flimsy and the tread is not very deep so, after receiving them, I decided they would not last very long. I need them for a bicycle trailer so I need better quality. By luck I discovered motorized scooter and pocket bike tires in this exact size for just $8 more with free shipping. These scooter and pocket bike tires are far better quality -- like a motorcycle tire -- and are available in a variety of widths plus street and knobby treads. I opted for the widest knobby -- 2.75 inch -- and they improved the stability of my trailer by 150%. Seriously. Pocket bike tires are pricey here on Amazon but I found them for $20 each with free shipping on the big auction site.
For what it is, I'd expect to pay $15 -- not $29. It does an excellent job of organizing shelves and is sturdy enough. Overpriced but it does the job well.
Overpriced, not loud enough. I'd return it and get a trigger-type bell like on a kid's bike but I waited too long .

First, I had used these for decades. If the bike falls on the left side, any mirror is likely to break but I would always replace a broken mirror with this model.There is a thin brass threaded barrel inside the base. That threaded barrel is there to accept the screw. Twice now, on two different mirrors purchased a week apart, that threaded barrel has come out of the base. In theory it could be glued back into the base but the barrel is so thin that it breaks at the slightest pressure of a pliers needed to get the barrel off of the screw, so that it might be glued back into the base. It really should be glued at the factory but recently it seems it is not.By the way, the manufacturer sells replacement parts but asks $4 to ship what could be shipped for the price of two postal stamps. In my case it would cost $10 yet you can buy the entire mirror for $12 so what's the point of offering parts?Update: I grew tired of replacing plastic mirrors every time the bike falls on the side with the mirror so I opted to get a metal motorcycle mirror here: UNIVERSAL BAR END HANDLEBAR MOUNT MIRROR BLACK 6212041. I believe mountain bike handlebars are the same inside dimension as a 7/8 inch motorcycle handlebar (1 inch outside diameter) so most any motorcycle mirror should fit, especially the ones that mount in the bar end as this mirror does.

Guitar bridge pins come in a few diameters, lengths and tapers so one must do a bit of research before purchasing. The Graph Tech website will tell you the dimensions -- especially the diameter and taper -- of all their pins so you can match what you need.I measured my existing pins' diameter and length with a 6 Inch LCD Digital Caliper with Extra Battery and Case (great bargain here on Amazon for only $12, plus you can use this tool to measure nut and bridge spacing, string gauge, all sorts of things). I didn't have a protractor so I eyeballed the taper by drawing a straight line in MS Word and then drawing a second straight line, connected them, and then rotated the second line to 3 degrees. Holding my old pins up against my monitor to compare, I toggled the angled line a few degrees back and forth, plus and minus a few degrees. 3 degrees seemed like a match. Once I installed them they fit and stay in.I knew in advance that these would be shorter than my originals but the length, it seems to me, is the least important measurement, as long as they are within 1/4 inch or 3/8 or so. Diameter and taper seem to me far more important.My original plastic pins were so bad they were bending, distorting, and getting stuck to the point where I needed a small vice-grip to get them out. I thought they would break off inside the bridge and would need to be drilled out. No such worries with these as the material used is strong and the quality is very good.If they improved the sound the improvement was only slight. It makes sense that graphite is probably more resonant than bone, rosewood or ebony pins would be. All things considered, if I didn't have a good reason for replacing the the plastic I probably would have passed on this purchase but I don't regret getting these instead of bone, rosewood or ebony. The quality is very good.

Understand that this liner will lay approx. 1/2" from your red hot oven element. At some point this liner burned with the exact curved shape of my oven element, turned white, and fell apart in those burned places.Instead i line the bottom with oil and attached this to the oven door by removing the two screws that attach the oven handle to the door, laying this flat on the inside of the door and screwing the handle back on. Simple, effective and stays put.

The author of this book works for Stew-Mac; he knows his stuff and he's an innovator. The best part of this book is that the author has made all the mistakes and so he gives you additional steps for 'just in case' so if you follow his exact instructions (exactly!) you will avoid the pitfalls that you could have never have seen coming. Can you damage the finish by replacing a nut? Yes, it's very, very common and he tells you all the pitfalls and how to avoid them. This book will also tell you if you need to buy a specialized tool for the job at hand or if you can get by with a generic tool. Another big plus is that this is perhaps the only repair/setup book that gets updated periodically as new techniques, tools and innovations are introduced into the craft.Aside from things like truss rod and bridge adjustments on electrics, or saddles and replacing tuning keys, almost everything else requires that you purchase dedicated tools to do each of the jobs right. For example, yes you can shape a nut with a generic file and sandpaper, but to file the slots for the strings you must purchase at set of six graduated files that correspond to the gauge of each of the strings to be used (.10, .13, .17, etc). So if you're planning on doing nuts for your acoustics and electrics, you need close to 24 graduated files; (6 for a light acoustic set and 6 for a medium acoustic set) and the same for electrics (another 6 and 6). There's a little crossover on a few of the gauges and you can 'file wide' on a few but otherwise there's no way around springing for a bunch of slot files. It adds up fast. If you already own a fine woodworking shop and are a very experienced woodworker, you can maybe find alternate ways of doing things but for most of us, a specialized tool will be required. Really. Yes, the author works for the #1 luthier tool supply house and their tools are pricey but it's a niche market and even where there's competition, the prices are mostly the same.And it doesn't stop there with the $$$ for the specialized tools. That's why luthiers and guitar techs get the big bucks; they bought all the very costly tools and have the experience.I bought all the tools and measurement instruments to do the more mundane work on both acoustics and electrics -- up to and including fret leveling and fret polishing, and I estimate I dropped more than $350 on tools alone, not including the materials and parts like nuts, saddles, glues, electrical wire, etc, etc. And then it turned out that my $12 Radio Shack soldering iron wasn't good enough so it was another $100 for a pro soldering iron. Sometimes I wish I had paid a luthier instead. Again, it really adds up fast.The very best and cheapest tools to start with are the nut slot files and assorted measurement instruments like this 6 Inch LCD Digital Caliper, an incredible bargain at only $12. What size replacement nut do I need to buy? What are the gauges of the strings that are on this guitar now? What are the string spacings of the nut and saddle? This tool will tell you all that and much more. I end up using this tool fairly often on household projects too, on more things than I ever could have imagined.Mistakes happen so if you're making a new nut or saddle for example, buy two or three to cover your early mistakes; they're cheap and will get used eventually. Before I started working on my best guitars I went around to the pawn shops and bought one $50 acoustic and one $50 electric ($$$ again) to make mistakes on and after quite a few mistakes they eventually ended up being slightly better guitars.Some other reviewers complain that the book is not a good read or not well organized but hey, it's a reference book. Just look in the index for the job at hand and follow along carefully. Others complain that there's not much guidance for the more esoteric guitars but the techniques crossover perfectly. The most popular guitars are used as examples because ... they're the most popular guitars. And this again is why the pros demand the high fees. They have been forced to think long and hard about how to apply their existing skills to every new and esoteric challenge that comes into the shop. And they instill enough trust for you to permit them to do it. Experience is priceless. This distinction is what separates the pros from the amateurs.Overall a great book. You may never use half of it because the tools are so expensive but more knowledge is better than too little.

I was disappointed in these towels initially because they were thinner than what I had hoped for. I was trying to replace a very heavy weight cotton towel that I had used instead of a drainboard for the water dripping off a dish rack. It was an unfair judgement because the towel that I was trying to replace was too thick to be of any use otherwise.These towels are soft and pliable as a dish towel needs to be. Stains are infrequent and mostly wash out, although sometimes requiring a preliminary bleach soak.I cook a lot and I expect that I could go another few years before I would need to replace this dozen towels.Good product.

I did a lot of 'review' research before buying these and have owned them for more than two years. I haven't tried any others. I live in the Sonoran desert so I purchased this model because it claims to perform better in very dry desert climates. I bought 4 or 5 of these in the package that includes a digital hygrometer with each humidifier so I have the pair, humidifier and hygrometer in each of my guitars' cases. These never leak and keep my guitars humidified at between 45 and 55% humidity while the ambient humidity is usually between 10 and 20%, sometimes as low as 5%.The guitar needs to be in its case for this thing to work well and in extreme enviros this is probably true of any case-type humidifier. When the guitar is out of its case, the case must remain closed. Guitar humidity remains fairly stable while in its case; I've gone a few months occasionally without checking and refilling the humidifiers and the humidity then varies between 35 and 55%. The difference is probably the different design and materials of each individual brand and model case. As long as you don't live in a desert you should have zero worries for a few months at a time.There are water-absorbing and retaining gel pellets inside the cavity that increase effectiveness and longevity between fillings. If they run dry one must first fill the humidifier, cap it, and then wait some time so that the gels are re-hydrated. Then open it again to top it off. The fabric mesh succeeds at releasing the moisture slowly. The mfg. recommends distilled water.I like to rotate the humidifier periodically. I'll start with it tucked between the stings, pointed into the sound hole and then move it to the cavity where the neck rests so that the fingerboard gets its share. It really helps to oil the fingerboard occasionally but use a dedicated fingerboard oil from a respected luthier supply house. I recently took repossession of a guitar I gifted away in the 1980s. I had used lemon oil on the fingerboard in the 80s and it was still thick there on the rosewood like an oily paste.I am very satisfied with this product.

The exact dimensions are 10 3/8 inches diameter across the bottom and 11 3/8 inches diameter across the top lip.I purchased these primarily for 10 3/4 inch plant stands and they do not fit; they are too wide.I will keep them because the quality is good, they will serve a few of my existing containers and more in the future but I now must try to guess if the 8 inch will fit my 10 inch plant stands and containers and risk ordering more.I would have given 4 stars if not for the inaccurate dimensions. Made in China.

This thermometer works well, is good quality. It turns out the dial on my oven is way off so I'm glad I got this. It's somewhat difficult to see and read this inside the oven, especially if a pan is on a lower shelf, but this is a problem with any oven thermometer.
I haven't used a lot of these and so have little to compare with but this works well on both lemons and limes and cleans easily with just rinsing.

Great quality product for things like paper or hair. This is the incorrect tool for fabric. For fabric you need shears, not scissors. For fabric try Gingher 8-Inch Knife Edge Dressmaker's Shears. Great scissors, great shears.

These are very comfortable and rarely bunch against my privates as cotton briefs always do. I rarely need to adjust them in any way.I ordered the large even though my waist was a lot bigger than what was suggested the large should fit. I almost cancelled the order to reorder the XL but when the large arrived they fit without problem. These briefs stretch a lot without stretching out. They rebound to the original size and remain elastic, even after more than a year. Fit is better than expected.Very good product.

To prevent an old surgery site from becoming newly aggravated I wear both knee pads and shin pads all day every day except while sleeping. These knee pads are as good as I have used and are far better in many regards.I only really put these to the test while gardening and for that they might be overkill except, for my purpose, they will last a lifetime. A construction worker who is often on his or her knees might need to replace them more often but it would be worth it for the comfort and grip.The surface that contacts the ground grips very well and is similar to the Vibram-brand sole often featured on hiking boots. Beneath the contact/sole area there is approximately 3/4 inch of gel. The fabric on the outside is very hard and dense (the side that faces the ground) and very soft and flexible on the inside (the side that is exposed to your knee). The contact area is secured to the padding area twice -- with both glue and stitching.It kind of feels like there should be an additional pair of Velcro straps higher up on the pad but the single pair hold the pad well enough to the leg while standing and when kneeling it's never an issue.The Velcro straps are soft and elastic.As soon as I received these I searched the web the manufacturer's website to see what else I might need from them because these are high quality.For anyone who also needs or desires shin pads these Brine Lacrosse Goalie Shin Guard (One Size, Black) are of a similar quality and the best I have tried.Quality still exists in the world.

I bought these in three different colors/tones and they are every attractive. I have many bamboo pieces for tabletops and floors and the first thing I do is spray all bamboo with clear gloss paint to prevent mildew which always otherwise occurs. The vertical wood pieces on each end tend to slip out and are difficult to get back in but they still look okay if they are taken out and left out after slipping. These WILL mildew if not treated with a clear spray paint.

This trivet still looks new after almost a year of daily use. The construction is good and the wood is thick. When it first arrived one of the joints had not been glued in the manufacturing process but I glued it with common white glue and it has been fine ever since. Looks great and is highly functional.

I purchased this for leg elevation while sleeping to treat vascular disease but the wedge shape didn't work for me. I then additionally purchased the same pillow with the 7.5 inch height and now stack one on top of the other too create a complete rectangle with a flat, level surface. This combination works well for me.

The only better strainers I found here on Amazon were German-made in the $60 - $80 range so at those prices this is worth giving a try. The handle and the opposing lip are just spot/stamp welded in a few places, 4 and 2 places respectively and I can flex the handle while holding the handle and the lip with gentle pressure. It flexes at the handle's spot welds. Hopefully it'll hold up over time and won't rust. For the price it's worthwhile and a pretty good value.Nice feature: I have what I think is a standard size kitchen sink and the overall length of the strainer, lip and handle is long enough to place it directly across the depth of the sink to drain directly into the sink instead of needing a bowl to drain into.This strainer has turned out be my favorite device for steaming vegetables. Most larger pots are 10 inches in diameter and this strainer fits them perfectly.

Clear, durable with easy soap and water clean up.I'd say the only problem with this finish is that the dry times are too optimistic. To sand and reapply after just two hours, as the label suggests, seems optimistic. The label further states, "After final coat, allow 3 hours before light handling and 24 hours before normal use." If you should need to wait 24 hours before normal use you probably should need to wait 24 hours before sanding and additional coats. It just makes sense. I wait 24 hours between all coats and have zero problems.Note that this is also available in semi-gloss. The semi-gloss doesn't attract and hold as much dirt so the semi might be a better choice for many applications. Plus you can always make the semi-gloss satin by wet-sanding the final coat.

I was all set to purchase the Giro Atmos but when I selected my size the price jumped up to $162. No way. So I gave this a shot.Good helmet and the appearance is excellent (attractive). When clasped the chin strap lays on my ears which might be annoying over longer trips but otherwise not bad, it's light and comfy. I can fit a cotton cycling cap underneath for sweat absorption, no problem. The sun visor really works at blocking the sun. The Atmos model doesn't even have a visor at more than 5 times the price.Great value. I can't imagine needing to spend any more for a helmet; this is more than good enough.

These are heavy cotton but not so heavy that they impede movement. I found no loose seams or loose threads. The pants I received are somewhat different than what is pictured. The picture shows the drawstring on the outside but the pants I received have the drawstring on the inside. The elastic is strong enough but doesn't pinch.On to the company web page is a master size chart which helped me get the correct size first try. I'm a 44 inch waist but because of the elastic waist band, size 6/A4 fit me, even though the chart says 37 inch waist. I could have gotten the size 5/A3 and they still would have fit and allowed for some future weight loss.Based on the literature that accompanied the pants, Piranha Gear seems sincerely like a very good company, as if they're really trying hard to gain repeat business through high quality and good customer service. Shipping was fast. I will purchase their products again.

I bought the exact same sander without the case. It's good, better than the competing sanders costing just a few dollars less. I returned two before settling on this one. All these sanders are messy; most of the duct that is supposed to be collected in the bag never makes it there. Makita makes a vacuum hose attachment that collects approx. 85% of the dust that would otherwise become airborne making jobs much, much cleaner. See the reviews for Makita 192108-A 3/4-Inch by 10-Foot Hose.

I have used other Mirka papers from this same vendor and the quality is very good as it is here. It used to be these wet/dry papers were available everywhere but my big-box store had close to zero.I use wet paper whenever possible because there's no dust to breathe. Each sheet can be washed and reused a few times.If you add in the shipping it comes to $0.78 per sheet and that is fair based on my comparison shopping.

I guess I should have expected it but the mesh is woven too tightly; not even bar-soap residue will pass through it. It clogs with just soap residue within minutes.I'll keep it because I'm sure I can find some other use for it but as a tube/shower strainer it fails.

The heart rate monitor feature on the Suunto watches is worthwhile but the pods are mostly unnecessary. I bought both this foot pod and the bike pod and the mileage reported by the pods it is always almost identical to what Google Maps reports so you could just use Google maps.
The description says it includes a bead chain but it arrived without any chain. Otherwise the stopper works well enough.

I was previously using the $3 hardware store putty that mixes with water for refinishing furniture. I find the the water putty is okay for the sides and backs of furniture, areas that are not a work surface but for the top of a table, for example or shelves, this putty bonds far better and makes for a more durable work surface, It's worth the extra cost.

This kit gives you enough cable and housing to do the rear brakes twice.The cables are stainless steel.The housing is easy to cut with normal wire cutters without distortion.All the ferrules and associated doo-dads are included.\Good quality, good value

I used this to repair a broken plastic furniture castor. It needed to withstand at least 50lbs so I felt I needed to apply it somewhat thick to bolster the structural strength.Printed on the package are the 4 instruction steps: Prepare, Mix, Apply, Dry. There is an asterisk following step 4 that states you should wash the parts in detergent and file or sand the surfaces. I missed that asterisk on my first try. The instructions say it cures in one hour above 40F degrees so I let it cure for 5 hours at 75F because I had applied it somewhat thick. After 5 hours it fell right apart under weight. Partially my fault for not sanding/filing but the epoxy still hadn't hardened after 5 hours. The product I received dried completely clear and transparent.Tip: Score the surfaces with an Xacto knife. This should absolutely be step one. If you are repairing broken plastic, sandpaper will not likely reach all of the uneven, broken surfaces to be joined and a file would deform them, ruining the shape of the seam to be joined.On my second try I used the Xacto knife to deeply score the surfaces. I really recommend doing this as it gives much more surface area to adhere. I then scrubbed the parts with detergent and splashed them with 91% alcohol. This time I allowed it to cure over 48 hours and so far it's holding.My advise is score the surfaces well and let it cure as long as you possibly can.

I cycle daily so I ordered one of these in just about every color except red more than a year ago. The only color I didn't care for is chocolate; all the other colors looked great.I sweat a ton from the brow and so used to wear one bandana folded and tied as a headband and a second bandana draped and tied like a skullcap. This is a serious issue with me; that's what was required to keep the sweat out of my eyes.This cap absorbs almost as much sweat as I can produce. I still carry a single bandana as a backup for the hottest days/hardest workouts but the absorption of this cap is probably more than most people would need. I have machine washed and dried one or two of these hats by accident a few times and they held up but I would not recommend it consistently.I was lucky, the cap fits me perfectly. I can wear 7 1/4 or 7 3/8 depending on the hat.Most all of these hats ended up having loose threads here and there but I just burned them back with a lighter to prevent them from pulling any further except, even still, on just one hat, the brim began to separate within a few weeks. The brims are plastic underneath the cotton. Aside from that the construction and materials are high quality.I can position/spin this hat on my brow in any direction as the sun changes including all the way to the rear and out of the way. The brim is a good length.I'd say if it will fit you, you will probably like it and it will probably last a few years with daily use.

I cannot praise this product enough. I wear shin guards daily, all day, to protect an old surgery site from complications. I have tried too many shin guards to list here. These are the absolute best.*Lightweight*Highly Adjustable*Protective, of ankle, too!*COMFORTABLEIf you need to protect your lower leg for sports or any other reason, buy this product and YOU WON'T EVEN KNOW YOU ARE WEARING THEM. Again, I wear guards every day, 14 hours per day. I could leave these on in bed and still sleep soundly.For sports, because of the Velcro closures, these could fit a preteen or adolescent with room to grow into adulthood and last close to a lifetime.Sorry to gloss so highly, I rarely do, but this is one very exceptionally great product.

It cleans fairly easily with just dish soap and a kitchen brush. Yes, particles still get trapped and it requires a little elbow grease to clean but it is far easier to clean than mesh strainers.I've never seen any rust. It tolerates 'Barkeepers Friend'-brand cleanser which is an acidic stainless steel cleaner (culinary stainless steel's best cleaning product along with vinegar).Attractive.

My pantry is fairly full of Bormioli products because I don't want to tempt insects but these are my favorite.My use is for oil and vinegar and the only solution that could be better is if the glass was colored dark to prevent light from reaching the contents.I once knocked one from my countertop drain board and it did not crack or shatter.Very good product.

The scope itself is quite nice, though it would be better if there was some sort of gap so you could attempt to remove the offending particles while they are well-illuminated and magnified.  The swabs and solution worked well on the minimal bits that remained on the sensor after the vacuum failed miserably and I resorted to holding the camera sensor down and using my manual rocket blower.  I like the scope itself, but the vacuum is inadequate and mine came with a busted LED headlight.  As a kit, I don't think it is worth the money for the scope, swabs, solution and what is basically a miniature lens pen to "polish" the sensor all in a tidy case.  I will contact Delkin about the busted light on the vac, but I really don't think that will improve things enough to change my review.  I am disappointed with the kit but enjoying the scope.  I also have found it useful for checking my lenses for tiny smudges and dust.

Yes, this made my skin glow.  It made my skin glow so much that I looked like I had spent a day without sunscreen, on a hot beach.  I have read some good reviews of this particular preparation, but this was a bad match for my sensitive skin and it left it looking extra ruddy and feeling sore, tight, dry and generally like I had accidentally rubbed my face with a cat (I'm allergic to most cats).  Not for me.  The positives?  Nice packaging.  The bottle feels weighty and high quality and the dropper worked just fine.  I had high hopes for this one but my sensitive skin and mildly inflamed body (I have autoimmune arthritis) make this promising solution off limits for this chicky.

The build, materials, and quality plus the included little box made these seem ideal.  I was looking for plugs/filters to reduce sound slightly but not isolate me.  As a special needs mama, I need to hear my child's calls and I often use filters to dampen the other sounds around me particularly appliance noise and his dad watching tv and his music.  Theoretically, these would work well to quiet things a bit, just enough so I can get done what needs to get done, while still being aware of my surroundings.Unfortunately, the teardrop shape of the outer part of these were not comfortable for my ear shape (not the canal, the outer part of my ear) and when twisted to a more comfortable position, they are as isolating as regular rolled plugs, only uncomfortable.  These are just not for me.  I'll stick with my Alpine SleepSafes for reducing noise just enough and being wearable and not distracting.

I like the idea of having pepper spray on me, when I'm out and about solo or with my child.  Having it on my keychain means I'll be less likely to be without it when I need it most.  The canister is rather big and between my chunky car key, house key, garage key, mailbox key, and a similar set for my aging parents' home, I feel like I may need an extra purse just for my keys.  The plastic is very smooth and makes gripping it feel less than secure, especially in arthritic hands.  I'm glad this is not rubberized, but some texture would increase confidence in gripping, aiming, and deploying.  I hope I never have to use this, and I am glad the manufacturer offers safety classes to improve self-protection efficacy.  I also like that this is a gel formula, as the wind in our area ranges from breezy to hurricane and reducing blowback even a little seems like a good idea.

These are really great cacao nibs.  I have tried a few other brands and couldn't understand why anyone would choose nibs to snack on.The other brands tasted weak, a little stale, and so very crunchy.The Viva Labs Organic Cacao Nibs:  smooth but strong flavor and while they have that crunch and satisfying snap, they also give you a wee bit of that "teeth sinking into tasty, tasty chocolate" sensation which, for me, makes a big difference.  Cacao nibs will never satisfy the cravings of those of us who like a good milk or bittersweet chocolate, but it can temporarily tame them, it seems.The value is substantial, compared to our local health food shops (we do not have Whole Foods around here), especially considering how fresh they are.  I am looking forward to attempting making my own chocolate bars with these, though I may need another bag as my family has been grazing on this bag (with even some well known, national brands the nibs just got grosser and more stale as nobody wanted to eat them.  Not the case with these little, tasty gems).

C2O is not the first coconut water we have tried.  I've tried most of the typical natural-foods store refrigerator case brands (VitaCoco, Zico, O.N.E., etc) and I honestly concluded that I just don't like coconut water and would never choose to drink it with other options around.  This was confirmed when I purchased a couple of young Thai coconuts.  I found the liquids to be odd tasting, like something at the start of going bad rather than something fresh and vibrant.  Just not my thing.I continued to buy those brands, thinking they were an easier alternative to opening coconuts, when I needed liquid to add to my famous (in my own mind) raw coconut macaroons.  I always try to add a liquid with some nutritional value, even if it is mostly vitamins, electrolytes, yadda yadda yadda.  The other flavors in the macaroons eclipsed any weird taste of the coconut water, and all was good.Then I tried C2O and while I'm not going to be drinking coconut water daily, it is such an improvement over all of the other brands.  The flavor is fresh and sweet and pretty good when served fresh from the fridge.  As a type 1 diabetic, I did not the carb counts and I usually choose carb/calorie free fluids.  I will, though, reach for one of these next time I am feeling dehydrated, and I will use this as the base for my electrolyte "cocktail" I make for my family when we are ill.  As far as my macaroons, I would rather use this and have the flavor enhanced by all of the ingredients rather than feeling like I have to cover up anything, even in the slightest bit.I did take a star off as I'm not a fan of the packaging.  I prefer, even for this size, a resealable container especially when a product has more than one serving per container.  Also, a search revealed that these cans are, according to bloggers who contacted the company, BPA free.  I typically avoid goods in metal cans for that reason, but it's good to know that I don't have to compromise on this product.  I will, though, purchase their resealable tetra-paks the next go around.

I have tried three different palettes of the Neutrogena Nourishing Long Wear Eye Shadow.  The formulas are gentle, even for my very sensitive skin and reactive, allergic eyes.These are definitely shadows that work better for a "natural" or daytime look than a night out, but the effect really is quite lovely.These would probably be a poor choice for someone who prefers more exotic and louder eye makeup, but a good match for those who would like their eyes, rather than their makeup, to be the first thing people notice.  The colors are very neutral and not saturated.  On application, they remind me of a dry wash or tint.  At first I was concerned that the colors were disappearing into my skin, but once I had on all four colors, in the prescribed locations, the look was quite lovely (albeit neutral and not dramatic).My favorite palette is the "cool plum", which really brightened my eyes (along with some mascara).  My skin is very pale, very pink/ruddy, and my lashes and hair are dark blond (lashes bordering on black), and my eyes are grey (with a dark grey ring).  The other colors didn't work as well, as far as accentuating my eyes, but I would guess that others with different skin and eye tones/colors may find the other palettes to be more complimentary for them.As far as "long wear", I found these had faded quite a bit at around the 4 hour mark, though the darker accents in the crease and along the last line, were still visible they were not so fresh looking.  Sleeping in them for 8 hours found some dust and smudge on my lower lids, and little left on the top lids.  So not great for waking up and looking fresh for another person, but really, do we want to wake up next to someone who inventories such things?

I no longer have a toddler, but my whole family likes the more thorough clean provided by wet wipes.  These are comparable in size and strength, to the non-"Eco" store brand we usually purchase.  We have not had an issues flushing these (we have city sewer).  They are fairly gentle, though I found they sting mucus membranes and chafed skin about as much as other flushable wipes.  It isn't bad, but for mucus membranes and for raw skin, I will stick with the (non-flushable) saline wipes from Boogie Wipes. The one thing I am not crazy about is the packaging.  The sticker closure is unreliable and hard to close securely, to prevent drying out or for transport.  I keep the current, in-use package in a plastic zipper bag to prevent drying out.
Great, sunny yellow color.  Fit table perfectly. Great quality and style for the price. I will update after a few more shows and washings.

Nice, smooth, non-glossy but not too matte.  Longevity, wear is good and an improvement over my usual longer-wearing lipstick from Stila.  Shade 07 is definitely not my shade.  I gave dark blonde hair and very pale but pink/ruddy skin.  This is just too dark, as a lipstick. In the tube it looks almost like Black Honey from Clinique but as an opaque, matte it just doesn't work for me. I blotted it a bit and it was wearable but still very goth looking against my skin.  I will definitely try a different shade.  07 also accentuates any yellow in your teeth (mine are average white, and I do drink tea, but 07 made me reconsider smiling which is never a good thing!)

The OXO Good Grips Professional Utility knife is just right as an "all purpose" prep knife.The design, grip, and materials are typical of the range.It is comfortable in my (arthritic) hands and gives more of a feeling if comfort and control than my non-ergonomic knives.  The weight is actually quite wonderful, in use.My only issues are that 1.  The packaging is anything but arthritis friendly. And 2. The blade, out of the package, was not sharp enough to slice through a Honey Crisp apple.  I do have an Oxo steel on hand, so I gave it a good bunch of strokes and it seems to have improved a bit. It did cube some cheddar appropriately and it did make some fine ribbons of a boiled egg for egg salad, and the egg didn't try to escape, but I will have to test it on other foods, and I'll update as I explore.  I was just surprised that it was not properly sharp right out of the package.

I cannot get over how soft this Minecraft Baby Sheep is!The fur/fuzz is wonderful and so comforting.What a delightful addition to my son's collection of "buddies".I like that the features are embroidered on, so if a little one gets ahold of this, it is much more safe than sewn on bits that can be chewed off and swallowed/choked on.

Pinching, at the hands of my drawers, has not been an issue.Drooping, of the drawers, has been.I have been having some underthings troubles lately.  It seems like every pair I have tried succumbs to gravity because they just can't hold on to these curves.There's nothing quite as awkward as the covert attempt to fish for your underthings half way down your outer thigh, to try to gain a fingerhold to just urge them back into a reasonable height.  I thought I was going to have to resort to suspenders.Thankfully, a pair of these came straight to my door, from this purveyor of undergarments.These are not your Granny's drawers, Ladies.The fabric is delicate to the touch, but sturdy in wear.  It isn't intended to provide the same structure and support as a girdle, and it doesn't, but it does seem to smooth just a smidgen.The waist is thankfully high.  If you are looking for underthings which allow your rear split to wink from the hind of your jeans, these are not it.The waistband is made of the same silky material and it does not roll or shift or bunch.The legs are comfy and nothing needed extracting after wear.  Everything stayed where it was supposed to.So if you are looking for low hanging, low-rise jeans enhancing underthings, then just move along to the majority of underthings that are out there.  These are for those of us who demand curves and stretch in our Mom jeans.

I really enjoyed this.  It's chock full of dry, dark humor and quite enjoyable for those of us that get a kick out of such things.  The style embraces some of the finer points of noir, and the narration follows suit.  I would watch it again and again just for the dance numbers.

Nice cap!  I find that I am having some difficulty manipulating the "pinch" controls of most lenscaps, due to a loss of dexterity from autoimmune arthritis.  These I don't need to grip so finely, and I can maneuver them and turn them into place almost just using my palm and not relying on my sometime iffy fingers.I'm looking forward to putting these on more of my lenses.

I replaced a long since burned out CF globe bulb in my bathroom vanity with the Kobi K8L1 rather than another CF bulb (we have a few in our supply closet), just to compare and test it out with the other two bulbs in the 3-bulb fixture (one CF, one GE reveal C).The Kobi is instant on.  The moment you switch it on, it is nice and bright.  The moment I switch the CF bulbs on, they need to "warm up" to full light, which can take as long as a thorough handwashing or brushing my teeth.  It's annoying having to change my "routine" because of the technology in the lightbulbs. Plus, I can hear the CF bulbs when they are on (yes, I have wicked sensitive, hyper-hearing).I really like that this provides a consistent light throughout the whole bulb, the way the old white incandescent bulbs used to.  The CF bulbs I have don't offer that, and you can see the curly CF bulb inside the glass globe, which detracts from the overall appearance of the room and the light fixture itself.The Kobi light is bright and warm and perfect for my vanity.  The light isn't overly warm, or artificially warm.  It's just right.  I find it better for makeup application than the GE Reveal, as the Reveal is a smidge too blue and this is a better match for my makeup and the environment.It has a warranty, which definitely provides some comfort in trying out this brand which I had never heard of before.

This is my first pair of Bose headphones.There is no going back.I may not be an audiophile, but I do have have auditory processing challenges, my hearing is very sharp (I went blind from cataracts at age 20 and my ears super-compensated to help me navigate a new city in the months before  surgery), and I have hyperacusis.  My kid has ears that are even more finely tuned than mine and he wears isolating ear muffs to deal with sensory overwhelm but I had not found a workable, comfortable solution until now, and I needed one as even the sound of our dishwasher and clothes dryer were increasing my fatigue substantially,The QuietComfort 25 provides a much needed buffer between me and the world, while I am still present and interacting fully.I wear these without the audio cable attached, and noise canceling powered on.The first day, I wore them on a moderately busy street while waiting for a bus (during daylight, in a safe environment) and instead of feeling my body gradually tighten up from the cumulative sounds of cars, motors, air conditioning units, the buzz of the power lines, the shrill squawk of crows overhead I only heard the teenagers laughing as they jogged by, the birds tweeting at eachother, and a gentle, wavelike roll of automobile wheels as they passed me.I have not felt calm, like this, since I was a little kid, exploring the woods around out home, alone, in an environment without crisscrossing power lines, a/c, cell phones, fluorescent bulbs, etc...  These filter, but do not isolate.For me, these are a miracle.  I do not like listening to music via headphones because I am usually the only responsible adult here and my hypersensitivity to most sensory input means I never even sleep deeply, so escaping into music and not hearing something or someone is scary to me.  If I need to listen to something, I'll either listen over Bluetooth speakers or a pair of Audio-Technica open style studio headphones.  Audio Technica ATH-AD700X Audiophile Headphones.That being said, music sounds rich and wonderful, vivid, textured, nuanced.My only issue, with these, is the earcups padding is soft and comfortable but so sweaty after wearing for a relatively short time.  A cooler material may have not offered the same seal, but I would be willing to forego a wee bit of enclosure for a less sweaty, longer distance wear.For now, I'm just enjoying the silence  (and the sweet sounds of the world which filter, gently, through).

-Rapidly acquire and stack new skills for tangible and satisfying progress-Excellent resources in book and online-Plain language and explanations make this accessible to those of us who are big n00bs.My experience programming anything is pretty much limited to basic, "Hello World" messages gleaned from my playtime with a TI-99/4A, in the early 80's, as a child.  My kid, however, is intense about learning anything and everything about programming/coding and, of course, Minecraft.  He is eleven years old.I wanted to see if I could figure any of this out, as he is getting to a point where he is realizing that maybe his mom doesn't know everything.  I thought this Learn to Program with Minecraft Plugins might be a neat way to reconnect with him and refresh his faith in my knowledge.Andy Hunt does a fantastic job of teaching what is basically a foreign language, starting from the basics, and building on each newly acquired skill so that kids and adults can see progress which makes the process of learning feel easier, faster, more fun, and pretty mindblowing (to an old dog like me).You learn, by doing.  I learn better this way, as does my son (we have Asperger's).  This book was a great match and definitely sparked my interest, rapidly and fairly easily taught me a whole pile of new skills, and ignited a hunger for more.This is a good match for older kids and adults with an interest in Minecraft.I'm off to see what else I can learn from this series and Andy Hunt,

Pros:So much easier to handle than regular plastic cling wrap, especially for my clumsy and achy hands.More economical than using zipper bags.Custom fit, every time.Really does not stick to foods.Cons:Can't think of any.I have been using this stuff since it first came on the market. If is indispensable in my home and studio for storing food, covering containers, sealing away small parts for safe keeping, and corralling prepped ingredients for recipes to be prepared at another time.Last night I used some to refrigerate flattened disks of cookie dough overnight.  The dough came right up, this morning, without any sticking. I didn't have such luck with the silicone coated parchment the last time I made this dough!

The good:Suction is out of this world!  This got stuff off of tile that I thought I would need to chip off with a knife (hair removal wax, hardened and stuck).Adjustable brush roll.Easy to emptyCord rewindOn board toolsLong cordThe not so good:Handles like a heavier vac because of strength of suction (good for cleaning, not great for bad backs)Does not turn with the ease of the Dyson ball (more friendly for bad backs, in my experience)This is a sucking machine!The amount of pull this has on hard flooring is intense, and while it does get surfaces fantastically clean, my arthritic body (OA & RA) protested during vacuuming and the following day.  I have tried many vacuums, but none have performed this well on hard flooring.  This will be my go-to vac for our tile floors (1/2 of our home, all of the common, high traffic areas), or rather my able-bodied cohabitants will be using this as the go-to vac for cleaning those areas.On carpet, it pulls a surprising amount of debris.  It removed leftover Dyson Zorb Carpet Maintenance Powder, 26.5 oz. from a wall-to-wall carpet which had been vacuumed a few times since using the Zorb, with both my Dyson compact ball upright and a Panasonic upright.  There is a dial on the cleaning head, to adjust the brush roll based on flooring type and carpet depth.  I think that, plus the substantial suction are a good combo.I prefer the extension hose and tools on my Dyson, as this a Eureka does not seem to hold them as well on the body of the machine, for storage,  this machine requires two hands to activate the handheld feature/assemble the attachments and then turn the selector dial.I am very satisfied with this vac, overall.  Though, with my arthritis and back issues, it's a bit too much machine for me to use frequently.  I will likely use this, or have a physically adept person use it for me, for weekly cleanings and keep the lighter weight Dyson compact ball and a small handheld, toward the front of my vacuum "stable" for daily pickups and touch ups.

Cute design but this regular brief cut was not kind to my upper leg area, as the leg openings seem a touch too small.I ended up buying a similar design, from the same line, but it is "hi-cut", and it still fits like a brief, with lower belly coverage but the leg holes are sized more appropriately, at least for my body.

The fabric is lovely, but for me, the combination of wire free & fixed (non-adjustable) straps meant that the only difference between wearing this Bali Comfort Revolution bra and wearing nothing, is that i can wear nothing for free and it's less oppressive in this August heat.  Perhaps this bra would work well if your breasts are naturally perkier and not as pendulous and so very subject to the harshness of gravity.

Worked immediately on a small, but aggregating, encroaching army of ghost ants.More effective than traditional shoe vs. roach exoskeleton combat.  It does kill roaches, but I find it more effective than my shoe because roaches are unbelievably speedy and agile uninvited house guests and, well, my feet just don't dance that fast.We live in the subtropics and get occasional household visitors, though thankfully, it is rare these days.I have tried other "friendly" sprays, but their masking fragrances are overwhelming, and even those that use mostly insecticidal soap and essential oils & extracts can quickly turn a comfortable home into something which feels a bit like the sort of sinister contraption James Bond might barely escape at just the last possible second.This Safer Brand spray has a fragrance that, once the skitters are dead and any "I totally overreacted" overspray cleaned up, you might not even remember you used the stuff, after a good night's sleep.I'm going to safely dispose of the less effective sprays in our utility closet, as this seems to do the trick without making our home smell like a scented candle store barfed all over our domain.

Cea Sunrise Person takes us on the journey through her unique (for most of us, in modern times) childhood and the personalities and relationships she meets along the way.The ride feels almost as though it is over too soon, as her writing style has a comfort and ease to it that lets her story wind its way through the wilderness and back again.  Her storytelling, in North of Normal, is linear, which only makes the story that much easier to get sucked into (I had to set a timer, or else I would have read it all in one go).Her voice, as a child, is authentic.  She doesn't stop to reflect on her experiences, along the way, from her perspective as an adult retelling her memories, but rather reflects on them, very occasionally, as they occurred to her at the time, as a child, embedded smoothly in the story.  Her story reads as though we are walking paths and around lakes and riding stick horses right along with her, at the same age.  She really has a writing style that is immersive for the reader.Cea's story is relatable, not only for the other souls who were raised in similar circumstances, but also, perhaps, for people raised adjacent to (it's hard to say "by" for the most extreme cases) self-involved parents.  Her relationship with her mother reminds me a bit of Stockholm Syndrome (which seems to be the parenting philosophy of many disordered narcissistic parents and generally self-involved parents, whether they are just not ready for parenthood or just not ready for it even though they planned it).I really enjoyed her tale, and toward the end, she does step over some larger gaps in time, which perhaps were not crucial to moving the story forward, but considering the pacing and style of the rest of the memoir, that sudden shift in the passage of time is a bit jarring and feels a bit like girl-Cea has been grabbed away from us too soon.  It isn't a big problem, but it was the only thing that didn't feel authentic or organic about Cea Sunrise Person's memoir of her childhood and her family.

The quick version:-It's a chunky, squishy case-It makes your iPad Air look like a toy-It is super-snug and secure-The included screen protector film is a major PITA.-Possibly good for kids in dry, clean conditions (this is rugged for reasonable impact, not for exposure to dirt, sand, water, etc)-Heavy (better grip for arthritic hands, but overall heft negates benefit).-The red is vivid and saturated and quite a wonderful red.-Meets military-grade MIL-STF-810G standardsMy suggestions: If you need the loud, chunky, rubbery case than this may be the case for you.  If you are looking for a solid, sturdy case but want to preserve some of the iPad Air aesthetic, in a lighter weight body, you might want to take a look at this case, which offers the same military-grade standard:  Logitech Big Bang Impact Protective Thin and Light Case for iPad Air, Forged Graphite (939-001042)The longer thoughts:  I'm just not crazy about the aesthetics.  The Black Belt 2nd Degree Rugged Case makes the iPad Air look like a toy, which for some applications may be perfect.  If my kid still had trouble holding onto things and I thought he should be using my swanky new iPad Air regularly,  I would consider a cushiony, rubbery, chunky case like this.For that purpose, it seems to work just fine.I like the options provided by the build in easel/stand, but in practice I never use them and I would prefer a softer material encasing the back.The extra thick frame is easier to hold for my arthritic hands, but the case is so notably heavy that it bugs the rest of my achy body instead.  For a child, I don't think that would be an issue, but as a more ergonomic, arthritis friendly grip I find the trade off with heavy weight isn't worth it, but that's me and YMMV.The screen protector is the kind which requires epic effort to smooth out all of the bubbles with a credit card or business card.  It is annoying and I applied it before snapping it into the case.  When I snapped it into the case, the edges popped up.  Now, a month later, it seems like just a couple of spots of the protector are still clinging to the screen.  It looks crappy and I much prefer one of the bubble-free solutions for screen protection, though I am unsure if those will fit without peeling up, due to the precise snugness of the Black Belt 2nd Degree's snap-in frame.

Streamlined, protective, very thin case does what the perfect case should, ideally, do.It disappears.Sure, it's there.  Anyone can see that our iPad Air is in some sort of case and not just naked and exposed.It's in using it, daily, where it disappears.The shell (and the impact absorbing insert) is thin and light enough that it doesn't bloat the device and it is thin and light enough that I forgot it was there.  All functions are readily available and do not require additional effort to access them, while the iPad Air is snapped into the case.I have had other iPads and cases and shells etc but most of them add enough weight that it feels like a let-down having to hide the beauty of the bare iPad and those cases always popped into my conscience when my arms grew tired and achy after holding my iPad up for any length of time.This is thin and light enough that it is unobtrusive and the handy magnetic front cover folds so that the overall weight of device and shell become moot points as you can watch a movie handsfree or type with greater ease, depending on the setting/angle chosen.The one thing I am not over the moon about is the texture of the cover.  I find the exterior to be grippy, and helpful when carrying only my iPad, in this case, for any length of time.  I think the look is more rugged and of utility than one which would compliment the iPad Air in the same fashion as the rest of the Big Bang Case does.Overall, we are happy with this case and it is the first one which has stayed on any of our iPads, as it is so unobtrusive (especially compared to the parade of previous cases, since discarded).

The Five Star Hanging Locker Shelf seems to be very well made.  I expected the hooks to be plastic, but they are rigged and rubberized and they feel like they have sturdy metal inside.  Mead (the division of ACCO Brands which produces Five Star products) touts a 100lb weight capacity for this particular product.The fabric is sturdy and well stitched.  It looks and feels like the woven nylon traditional backpacks are made from.My favorite use for this, as I don't have a locker, is as a handbag holder in my closet.  We have 1.5" (the height of the front portion) wire shelving in our closets and this, with a little force, fits on those shelves and gives me two shelves for two larger handbags.Another review mentioned that this works for holding cereal and I will be ordering another one to put in our pantry (we have those same 1.5" lipped wire shelves in there) for that purpose.

The WORKSHOP Wet/Dry Vac vacuums up wet and dry material, as expected from such a unit.Just don't expect to vacuum up anything wet when you take it out of the box.You will need to buy a separate "wet" filter cartridge to use your "Wet/Dry Vac" as a wet vac.WORKSHOP does make other specialty filters (for Fine Dust, HEPA, disposable bags, etc) but I was rather surprised to find out I couldn't use my new "Wet/Dry Vac" for the functions advertised, without ordering another part:  WORKSHOP Wet/Dry Vacs WS24200F Wet Foam Filter, 5 to 16-GallonIt was a big letdown, but I set to work cleaning up our lanai and all of the soil which had blown out of the planters on a particularly windy day.The pickup, on dry dirt, worked fine, but was nothing spectacular, just on par with other vacs boasting similar horsepower.  The attachments worked ok, but I am happy I have the attachments from my other wet/dry vacs to choose from, as the selection with the WORKSHOP was minimal and only useful if you are detailing and not for thoroughly cleaning my shop floor.I am really hungup on that darn wet foam filter, though.  The two stars are because it works and it seems to have a fairly sturdy build, and it is very squat, so unlikely to tip over easily.My recommendation:  for the price, this vac doesn't offer anything special compared with similar vacs, plus you need to add on approximately $22 for a filter to be able to use it as a "wet" capable machine and the disposable filter vacuum bags (which are optional, but an option I like for certain pick-up jobs) are priced, for one bag, the same as a three pack for others.  I'm going to stick with my Vacmaster "can", which may be a little smaller and have slightly less HP (though I can't feel or see the difference between the 3 and 3.5 "Peak", but it is priced well, works like a charm, reminds me a little of R2D2, and is narrower so it glides through my space (unlike the wider, more squat, WORKSHOP 9 gallon).  Vacmaster VQ607SFD Stainless Steel Wet/Dry Vacuum, 6 gallon, 3 HP

We replaced an old HP  Photosmart C7200 with the Epson WorkForce WF-3620.Generally, I am pleased with our decision, as once the WF-3620 was up and running it did all of the things that old HP promised to do, but either never did well (scanning wirelessly) or just refused to do (it had a duplexer but choked at the mention of "double sided").It is quite a novelty to print something from one of our iPads, my laptop, or the family desktop and have it print perfectly the first time around, without having to move the heavy machine and take parts out to unjam little, crimped bits of paper.So far, I am finding, for printing from a device, the Epson WorkForce 3620 is what I have always wanted a printer to be.  Once it was set up, I didn't have to think about it because it just worked and aside from one issue, it did so without protest.We no longer fax, so I will not be using or reviewing that particular feature.Scanning and copying from the platen glass works well.Scanning and copying from the ADF?  It may just be my particular machine, but after feeding the machine a pile of papers once, it started jamming every time I used the ADF. I emailed Epson (seriously, don't bother, it was like playing "Who's On First" but with printer features).  I called their US support number and after an extremely long hold time, I did get a very helpful human named Markus, who walked me through some trouble shooting steps before determining that the best action would be to replace the machine.  They are shipping me a replacement along with a label to send the faulty machine back.  They said I should see the replacement within a few days and then I will return the broken one.  They do take a credit card number in case you do not return the defective machine, but it is just a hold and does not get processed as long as they get the machine back.Is this ideal? Of course not.However, I am fairly happy with the smooth operations this "all in one" provides otherwise, so I'm hoping that a fully-working machine will elevate this model printer into the realm of reliable workhorse, which would be a dream (a weird dream, but I have had my share of lemon printers at home and at work).The thing I find awkward about this is the combination of touch screen and arrows when choosing features on the (very clear and brightly lit) screen.  It's mostly touch screen, and has graphics for arrows up and down which you'd think you could tap to scroll, but they want you to use the physical arrow pads next to the screen to do so.  It's not a huge deal, it just seems a little awkward and less fluid than it should, ideally, be.  I tend to have difficulty with touch screens recognizing my input, but I haven't had an issue with this particular screen.  I do think the menus for administrative and network related features could be a bit more intuitive and straight forward.  Once set up, I found I rarely needed to access them, but when I did there was quite a bit of backing up and pressing the home button to "guess" where the selection could be in the menu.Setup was somewhat of a PITA as I do not have a CD/DVD-ROM drive on my laptop.  I found the appropriate software and drivers on the Epson site and connected everything and it works nicely.  I did find that certain features (like Epson Connect, which allows you to print and scan using other services) aren't just available but they require a little legwork to sign up and get them running.  This isn't a problem for me, but it could be more interconnected with other necessary setup processes (like offering a link to Epson Connect during registration, and not having separate registration procedures for each service) to make it much more end-user friendly.Since setup I am pretty content (other than that darn ADF issue which is being resolved).  Even without ADF functioning, the WF-3620 still actually does most of the tasks the HP C7200 promised to do but never actually did reliably.The PrecisionCore feature is not something I was in the market for or even particularly care about, but so far the "starter" cartridges which the printer came with have printed more than any other new printer I have had and they still have plenty of juice in them.I compared the specs, side by side, and for printing higher quality photographic prints (on specialty paper), I will continue to use my Canon and HP inkjets, but for everyday, household and home office tasks, the Epson is my top choice.

My technology:  I use a MacBook Pro 15" Retina (late 2013 model) and occasionally a MacMini (late 2007).What I use it for:  Processing RAW image files in Adobe LightroomDrive Use:  EXTERNAL DRIVE(NOTE: it doesn't work for Mac right out of the box, you have to initialize/erase it in Disk Utility.  When you plug it in, as an external, a popup will inform you of this. It took me around one minute to format the OCZ.)I am a nerd, but not when it comes to computers and hard drives.Benchmarks are important when evaluating very similar products, prior to purchase, but for me personal experience, performing my usual tasks, is paramount.I like technology that I can use and not think about, for the most part (except for my camera as I really like all manual settings).I was using the Samsung 250GB 840 EVO SSD on a daily basis.  I use it as a dedicated disk for nothing but my RAW camera files which I access daily in Lightroom from my MacBook Pro 15" Retina (late 2013).  I use these SSD as external drives by popping them into an appropriate enclosure.I have been using these:  Tool Free Screw-Less ORICO 2588US3 USB 3.0 2.5-inch SATA External Hard Drive Enclosure Adapter Case for HDD SSD SATA Drive - Black  and it works like any external HDD, though with the speed and finesse of an SSD.  On occasion I use them with a Lightning adapter (powered).For a couple of weeks, I swapped my Samsung with the OCZ Vector 150 to see if I noticed any difference.  I used them both with USB 3.0 adapters as well as a Seagate Lightning adapter.  I will disclaim that I do not know if these are geared for Lightning use (again, I'm not that brand of nerd), but for occasional large file transfer, I didn't find any issue at all.The only marked difference, for me, was when I'd jump from processing (in Lightroom) my RAW files from one year, to an earlier year.There was some lag in moving from mostly consecutively created (dates) and named adjacent files to ones which were outside of that "comfort zone" and more random.However, I typically work on files as I load them in from my camera/SD card (into Lightroom and the files onto my SSD), and the lag was more of a pause and nothing detrimental to my workflow or focus.-I do like that the OCZ has a 5 year warranty, whereas the Samsung has a 3 year warranty.-The OCZ does come with a 3.5" bracket, if needed.  Samsung also offers one and their drive with the bracket is called a "kit".-If you compare the pricing of the OCZ and the Samsung KIT, the prices are even more comparable.Otherwise, the two drives seem comparable to me and the deciding factor, for me, is price, especially because I don't need the 3.5" bracket for my use.I will continue to use my OCZ drive for daily workflow and I will post back if anything changes or if I need to contact OCZ for everything, but so far I have integrated it into my workflow.I will install my other SSD drive as an internal SSD in our MacMini to boost the speed a bit, but so far I'm satisfied with the OCZ Vector 150 and don't see any need in transferring all of my files back to the Samsung for my daily work as OCZ is working just fine.

It charges our Lightning devices, in our car, without hassle.  A charger with interchangeable cords to accommodate different devices might be a better option, if you have devices with different plug types.  The cord is coiled and our 2014 Kia Soul has a little bin below the two lighter/power sockets in the lower dash area, and the coil is the perfect length for charging the phone as it sits in that bin.  The cord could be longer, as I keep my iPad on the seat or on the seat and in my bag, and it's a little too short and tightly wound to reach the rear of my front passenger seat.  Also a longer cord may be a better feature, not so you can use your phone while driving and while it is charging, but so that when you are parked or waiting for someone that ability would be a plus.  It works well, doesn't stand out as it blends with the dark interior of our car.  I also like that it has a 1 year limited warranty.  I'll post an update if I ever need to use that warranty.

My son has finally outgrown the infant nail clipper we have been using for the past 10 years.However, the adult size ones are too big, too bulky, too hard to handle, and they scare him because they are so oversized compared to his fingernails so he panics that we are going to nip the skin too.I wanted to get him a better quality nail clipper, and I have the regular size Seki Edge and I really like it, so the Satin Slim seemed perfect for this purpose.It is well made and the perfect size for him.  He has taken over his own nail clipping once again and now that his dad doesn't have to corral him and wrestle with him to bring his nails back to a safe level, there is calm in our home once again.

I am a big fan of CeraVe products and regularly use the lotion, cleanser, and cream for my face, and the foaming cleanser in the shower as a body wash.  My skin is finally looking the way I want it to.I was thrilled to see CeraVe's new Baby Lotion, as the ingredients were similar to their regular lotion but without the paraben preservatives.  I thought that would make this a good match for my skin and my son's as well.I wish they made the Baby Lotion without adding Dimethicone 1%.  I know it's a skin protectant and works for some folks, but for me, at 1%,  it triggers an attack of contact dermatitis (blisters, itching, redness, cracking skin) on my hands and a much milder itching everywhere else.  If I did not have this issue, or if CeraVe had left out the dimethicone or used a lower amount of dimethicone, as they do in their other products (Dimethicone must, according to FDA rules, be labeled as an Active Ingredient once it hits 1%, lower than that it is just a regular ingredient and doesn't require the expanded monograph on the label), this would be my first pick for my son's sensitive skin as the rest of the CeraVe line has done wonders for me.

Pencil by FiftyThree is both an ordinary stylus and an enhanced one, depending on what application you are using.If you use the Paper by FiftyThree app, with the stylus, you are in for a treat.  It is intuitive and precise and an absolute joy.  More than once, my disbelief was thoroughly suspended, and I felt like I was making organic, tactile art rather than creating art digitally, without ever opening a tube of paint or a jar of ink.  It was a fantastic feeling and so relaxing because I really did not, for once, think "I'm using a stylus", as it does, within the Paper app, work so intuitively like a non-digital pen, brush, eraser, pencil.Set up was easy after I charged the battery with one of my MacBook's USB ports.  Connection was fairly straight forward and I like that whenever I pickup Pencil, it just works for me.  I have other devices (cameras, another stylus, printers, etc) that are hit or miss whether they will connect with my iPad mini.  Pencil seems much more reliable and I wish other manufacturers would catch on to make device integration as smooth and easy, so those of us who use such devices could get back to working and creating with them.I do wish there was a way to get the functionality, within the Paper app, to crossover to other apps (all apps!) as I think I would only put it down to recharge.The hand feel is fantastic.  The shape is like a carpenter's pencil, which is much easier for me to hold and create with than a regular, round barrel, due to arthritis in my hands.  The materials are lovely.  I have developed sensitivity to many rubberized coatings on other products, so I was thrilled that the Pencil only has anything rubbery on the tip, but the part that is in your hand is brushed aluminum which doesn't cause any issues for me at all.

I have been curious about Maca for some time, but never got around to trying it.This gelatinized incarnation tastes good, though I have nothing with which to compare it.The pros- mild taste, incorporates easily into smoothiesThe cons- a little concern about the CalProp 65 warnings & the (within legal limits) lead contentI was concerned about adding these to my smoothies as some of the powdered ingredients I augment my usual fruit, yogurt, chia, and hempseed with tend to cake onto the side of the blender cup.  Of course I can scrape it down but when you are rushing out of the house for an appointment, trying to listen to two other people at once, and trying to remember what you are supposed to cover at the appointment, it gets a bit chaotic and I'd really like to just blend the smoothie, throw on the travel lid, and run out the door without paying my breakfast any more attention.I do not know if people consume this powder just mixed with water.  I figured I'd test it out anyway.  When mixed with cold (refrigerated) water, it didn't dissolve so well and left big floating clumps (even after thorough, vigorous stirring) that left me grimacing and taking it that way is not likely to become routine, or a habit.  I mixed the same amounts but this time used hot tap water and with a little vigorous stirring, the Maca dissolved into the water almost completely.
