The mouth feel was smooth, grit free, and slightly soft - like drinking a cup of hot water with gelatin mixed in, but more like tea than mud, as it was with the cold water.  The taste isn't bad, with just the hot water, but I can't see myself seeking a hot cuppa Maca regularly.This gelatinized preparation does not leave any grit or clinging on bits on the blender cup and while there is a flavor and scent to it, they are not unpleasant.  I probably wouldn't choose to eat this without a smoothie to mask it, but the fragrance is slightly sweet and oddly reminds me of a not-to-sweet bran muffin. The flavor is slightly sweet at first, and then a bit more "earthy" (but not flat out dirt-earthy, tolerable and even pleasant, by itself but fantastic blended with other whole, fresh foods).I was, and still am, a bit concerned about the CalProp 65 notice on the label.  I went to the Gaia Herbs website and they have a pile of information in their FAQ section.  I suggest everyone go to the site and read it, to decide if this is acceptable to them.  For me, I'm on the fence.  As the amounts are well-within FDA limits, I think I may use this jar and decide if the benefits and results outweigh the lead contamination (usually from runoff and contaminated water from mining in Peru).I would be more concerned about this if my son would be sharing smoothies with me, but as Maca hasn't been explored enough in kids, I would likely pour off his smoothie portion, sans Maca, and then add Maca and blend some more for my portion.

I have not been using any heated tools on my hair for a very long time due to my schedule and pesky arthritis.Recently, I tested out a set curlers and was very pleased with the extra bounce they gave my very thick, very heavy, long hair. I did, though, want a bit more active control as I've always found curlers, especially the little clamshell ones I recently purchased, to have less of an intuitive feel and the results can be a bit choppy and require additional tools to make one look truly put together.I tried the Revlon Rose Gold Professional Curling Iron and was impressed with the amount of heat settings and the swivel cord, but having nothing but my middle school adventures with the crimping and curling irons of the 1980's to compare it to, I kept an open mind and set to work.I am happy with the Rose Gold Professional.  It didn't snag my hair and my hair released from the barrel as though it was non-stick.  The iron heats up wicked fast.  1" is perfect for me and my thick hair.  It gives me enough lift at the roots and takes my natural waves and slight curl, to a less motley and more consistent and polished look.  If I focus on a tiny bit of hair, and hold the iron perpendicular to the floor, I can get the boingy curls going but that would take forever (with my copious hair) and for boingy I'd probably go with the rollers and use this to fix any stubborn pieces afterward.  The barrel and the clip, without wrapping, also made my bangs clean up beautifully.I won't use heat on my hair on a daily, or even weekly basis.I will happily bust out this curling iron for special occasions and professional events requiring a more polished look.

I was hoping to use this on a sofa bed that is intended for my living room, and that I have slept on (rather uncomfortably), but the arrival has been delayed.But I just couldn't wait.I broke my foot a few months ago and it hurts even when resting on my relatively plush (euro top) mattress, I also have autoimmune arthritis and end stage arthritis in my spine.  I'm one achy lady.I needed relief and a solid, healing night of sleep.  Desperately.So we unpackaged this sofa bed mattress.  It came packaged in a very tall, narrow box and it was heavy.  The mattress was wrapped in plastic and compressed before being rolled up tight, fastened, and boxed.  Unwrapping it was a challenge but I enlisted the help of my resident kid and we handled it no time flat.  I've had other mattresses and pads with memory foam and I was expecting a chemical odor when we unwrapped this, but it was very mild and faded quickly.So, without a sofabed, we hoisted it onto my mattress.  My mattress is rather high to begin with, and the added inches do make fitted sheets an extra challenge, but I wasn't going for a design award, just some sleep.The cover is very nice and soft.  It feels like jersey knit cotton, or bamboo jersey knit, but quilted.  It zips off, for cleaning, leaving just the underside in place, so you don't have to wrestle with the heavy mattress before or after cleaning the cover. I put a mattress protector over the whole thing and then my sheets and I climbed on in.I've had memory foam mattresses and mattress pads before, but the 4.5" of sinking in really makes a huge difference, at least it did for me, when coping with a broken foot and cranky joints.  I don't know that I'd like that depth for non-sleep activities, as it can be a challenge moving around, but for resting and snoozing, it works well for me.At this rate, I might keep this one on my bed and pick up another one for the sofa bed.

My kid was thrilled with his Creeper hoodie.  I had read the other reviews saying that this version runs very small and I ordered a much larger size.  My son is smaller, in stature, and usually wears around a youth 10.  I ordered 14/16 and it fits him nearly the same as his size 8 hoodie from Lands End.  The quality is excellent.  I like that this doesn't have the Creeper face on it, so it looks funkier and cooler and not as costumey and perfect for chilly mornings over his uniform.

Tracy Fullerton's third edition of Game Design Workshop is not light, casual reading.  Other reviewers have described it as a textbook, and it does have some of the makings of an academic tome (namely some of the language and the sheer concentration of information wedged between the covers), however the title says it perfectly: this is a workshop.I think the best way to approach this volume is to read it and tackle the examples and actively workshop an idea rather than attempting to learn all of the steps needed to take an idea all the way through to production.I am not a game designer, nor do I have aspirations of becoming one (or any of the other roles involved in producing a game).  My son is into this stuff and often bounces ideas off of me.  I thought Game Design Workshop would provide the guidance and resources so I can tutor him and guide him through fleshing out his ideas.  This book is thorough and interesting and very detailed and an excellent resource and guide.

L'Occitan, upon initial spray, smells very fresh and it is heavily fresh (not dried) lavender for a few moments until it meets your skin.At that moment, the lavender smells less like a sachet or soap and definitely more of a soapy, fresh, and very slightly rosemary, minty without being pepperminty.  It's like the coolness of wintergreen without the medicinal smell.After wearing it for awhile,  as you go about your day, the soapy freshness fades and leaves behind the fragrance of warm wood and a little hint of cool air.  It reminds me of being near the beach, with a fire going, on a brisk afternoon, with a good, old book.I like that this is the sort of fragrance that needs the warmth of skin and physical closeness to really enjoy.I would love this on a man, but it can work just as well on a woman (and as a fragrance for one's home.  I sprayed a bit on my duvet and cover. So good.)

As I am raising a child with developmental delays, including gross motor skill challenges, I am a fan of the Oball, Rhino Toys Oball Original (Colors May Vary).  However, my kid is growing up fast and when we were ready to introduce some playtime focused on more traditional sports and to develop the skills needed to participate, we found he had outgrown his Oball, at least as far as playground sports go.The Nerf Bash Ball is a good alternative, especially for older kids with larger hands.  I'm not thrilled by the name and the packaging brought me back to some ugly rounds of dodgeball when I was a kid (with the same developmental disorder as my child).  The ball itself, is a bit easier to catch and throw thanks to the built in handles/holes all around the ball.  It definitely is encouraging and motivating for a child to pick up a ball and focus on the throwing action instead of only being able to hyperfocus on the challenges they have holding the ball and getting ready to throw.  I like that this ball allows him to develop a wider array of skills, but of course we will still work with the other skills and regular balls, but woohoo!  What a joy to see your kid light up because they threw the ball with all of their might and it went somewhere, or you tossed it to them and they caught it.  It's wonderful.It's also Nerf, so my kid is less likely to run away from the ball and knowing he can catch it has given him more confidence which is definitely a necessary skill when venturing onto the playground.  The other kids just see it as another Nerf ball.

I love popcorn.  I usually cook up white popcorn in one of these: Catamount Glassware CG4526 Classic Design Microwave Corn Popper, 2.5-Quart, Red with some olive oil and afterward I throw on some grey sea salt.  So good.However, thanks to having a few dental crowns, popcorn tends to leave me with little bits of the hulls that really work their way in to the point where my regular flossing and brushing routine doesn't just neatly eject them, and the pain.  Those little hulls are sneaky and can be as painful as a bad tooth in need of a root canal.The nice thing about Kernel Season's popping corn is that although I can see some hulls, they seem to break apart easily with regular chewing and I have been through 2 16oz bags so far and I haven't had one dental drama.I am more of a fan of white corn popcorn, but from now on I'm retiring our usual white corn for Kernel Season's as I can actually eat it and not hurt.  Which is a pretty nice feature.  Of course, your mileage may vary.  I cannot say this is safe for dental work, as I am not a dentist.  I am just someone who hasn't had good luck with one of her favorite foods, and it seems like my luck is changing.

I purchased a Raspberry Pi for my son when they first available for delivery in the United States.He is 10 and very adept and adaptable when it comes to computers, electronics, programming, etc...I am nearing 40, a happy Mac user, and an artist.  I am a scientific thinker, autodidact, pretty good with my hands and adept with tactile & spatial problem solving but when it comes to electronics and programming, once it heads out of the tactile, I'm pretty lost. When it comes to learning, I tend to be hands on and very visual, but rapidly lose knowledge gained without any sort of physical motion.Once I set my kid up with the parts needed to get his Raspberry Pi up and running, he pretty much taught himself the basics of it, some Python, and started playing with Scratch.Then he wanted me to set up WiFi for the Raspberry Pi.HA!Glad the kid still has faith in this relative luddite.Thankfully, Teach Yourself VISUALLY published this guide.It is clear, concise, and will have anyone, with pretty much any level of experience, up and running on the Raspberry Pi within the first couple of chapters.  It also provides step by step tutorials on some advanced concepts, and quite a bit of the book it dedicated to programming and changing code to make the Raspberry Pi do what you may want it to do.  There is a whole chapter on using Scratch, which is a pretty fantastic platform for learning programming for any age (it is from MIT's Lifelong Kindergarten).  There are also a few projects to try which provide a nice segue into the world of electronics and practical use of the Raspberry Pi.With this book on hand I finally feel like we can tackle some of the concepts in this book as a team (including getting Raspberry Pi hooked up to our network) and perhaps put both of our strengths to work on a project, together.

After putting the Able Life Universal Stand Assist together, I was thrilled with how sturdy it felt and I couldn't wait to install and adjust it on my favorite chair so I could employ my upper body to help lift me out of the chair and take some of the stress off my broken foot and aching knees (from all of my joints trying to compensate for the big ortho boot I had been wearing for weeks).First off, the description states:Stand safely from any couch, chair, or reclinerDual support cushion handles makes standing easyUniversal fit: on top of, or between chair cushionsFully adjustable in height and depthThe only part of those traits I found to be true are the dual support cushion handles.  Yes, it has cushioned handles.It does not fit any couch, chair, or recliner partly because it only has limited adjustment on height and depth and not all chairs have their seats at perfect right angles to their rise.  As far as any chair, I guess it might be more likely to fit an average, upholstered living room chair.  It does not seem to fit on any other sort of chair and in my experimenting it didn't work with my office chair, non-upholstered chairs of any sort, and sadly it also did not work on my Stressless lounge chair.  It did fit on the chair with the U shaped portion sitting on top of the seat cushion (the seat cushion is not detachable on the chair I have), however it still stuck out quite a bit in the front, creating enough of a gap to catch my ortho boot in as I attempted to stand and then maneuver around my chair.  After sitting in it for some time, the feel of the u shaped portion became very apparent and uncomfortable.  The Stand Assist did work a bit better on my more traditional living room chairs and loveseat, and in that capacity it protruded less, created less of a tripping hazard, and the bar was not noticeable as far as longer sitting comfort went.My advice?  This may be a workable solution for you if you have the sort of furniture pictured in the image (the brown loveseat with the lady with the yellow shirt rising to a standing position), but if you are looking for an assistive device for any other type of seat, you should probably investigate other models.

One of my bosses, fairly early on, told me that she had always kept notebooks to keep track of everything and also to be able to prove accountability, if required.  I adopted that habit immediately.  This book is perfect for that task and is more conducive to keeping this daily notebook a bit more organized while still allowing space for creativity.  I like to put notes on a new ideas in the unlined column on the left.I am also using the notebook to take notes when others are sharing ideas with me, when they would like my input.  I find the layout conducive to note taking, thought I do prefer Behance's Action Method products a bit more when it comes to goal setting and problem solving in which I have a more active role and a more personal stake or if I need a more permanent, organized record of what we have discussed.If you have used the Circa Annotation paper for the Circa system this notebook is similar, albeit without the handy Circa adaptability (and the Circa paper feels a bit more luxurious).

The Bankers Box SmoothMove Basic Moving Boxes are a bit nicer than the last moving boxes I handled, which were the "Free with move" boxes from the company which moved us from Boston to Southwest Florida.  I really like that they have spaces on the sides for listing contents.  That comes in handy more than I expected, especially when I have to send someone else down to storage to get a specific box as there aren't a bunch of markings from a box that was previously shipped and it's easy to spot the label and keeps things neat looking. I'm not planning on moving anytime soon, but I am in the midst of a big decluttering (home and garage) and these are perfect for filling up and marking with the contents and date so you can locate things you might need or in a year, you can just send the filled boxes off for donation.  This works well for my son's toys which he has outgrown, as he is very hesitant to part with anything but telling him that we are just relocating them to storage for a year to see if he really needs them is (hopefully) teaching him through our actions and by participating hands on.If I start packing up any books, I will likely choose a smaller size box as the 18 x 18 x 16 become quite heavy with such a dense load and I was concerned with the amount of tape I had to use to feel confident that the flaps would stay closed when being carried.I saw that some other reviews mentioned that these sorts of boxes may be available for less cost, at local brick & mortar shops.  That's great, but these came in a large square box that wouldn't fit in my car and I'm not supposed to be lifting anything heavy.  It was much easier, for me, to get these via Amazon.com, have them delivered in a matter of days, and I just pushed the box inside my home without having to lift or strain much.  I am thrilled that these are available here.  The convenience factor makes the price of these well worth it, at least for my family.

Convenient packaging and dispensing.Unfortunately, even when warmed in a tote in the sun, the texture is still too stiff and it really drags and pulls across sensitive skin.So SPF 50 and the ingredients are pretty appealing but I can't see my child sitting still to have this applied and reapplied.  I don't even want to put it on my face.  I do like it, though, for a quick sunblock application on my tattoo and so far, for that purpose (it's a small tattoo around the size of a quarter) it does what it is supposed to.

This is as soothing and cooling as any aloe gel.The relief lasted as long but so did the fragrance.  It smells like camomile tea and old citronella candles (though I'm not sure this has citronella in it, it smells like it though).This also has a slight tint to it from the ingredients and on my super-fair skin it winds up looking like my skin is dirty once it dries.

Caroline Clarke's exploration of her history, on all sides of the adoption triad, rings very familiar to me in some ways as I am an adoptee who has been through the experience of the reunion and claiming that part of my story.  The way she writes all of parts that make up that missing and then found history and moving forward really drew me in and made this a quick read.  I relished reading the facts and stories she learned along the way and her observations as much as if I was reliving my personal experience.Some readers might not find the backstory and family histories that interesting, particularly if they have lived their lives knowing that information.  For those of us who have to seek the information and find it elusive, it is breathtaking, even some of the more mundane seeming facts.  It's a nice ride with lots of ups and downs and a good blend of her inner voice and the voices of others who make up her family (that includes all of them- adoptive, biological, etc).

This review is for the John Frieda Glosser in Warm Red.The Glosser does not foam.  John Frieda makes a permanent hair color that does foam.  This is not that product.I have coppery red hair that, without color refreshing of some sort, reverts to medium, drab blond/light brownish.  Blah.I have used many color depositing conditioners (including John Frieda's conditioner for red hair) and they tend to be hit or miss and I wind up having to use them every single shampoo.  That's not a big deal for some but as they all tend to be very perfumed and I am very sensitive to perfumes and additives, it is a big deal for me.Glosser has surprisingly minimal ingredients.  The fragrance is less pervasive than John Frieda's conditioning and shampoo products but it is similar- vaguely floral and a bit powdery and perfumey but not freshly dyed in fragrance.  Once hair is dry it does persist but it definitely more muted and likely will meld with any other styling products.The color is pretty good.  I use Glosser a couple of times a week and really love how natural it makes my particular warm red/copper color hold up but also shine.I do have extremely thick hair that borders on coarse and I have more than a couple of greys coming in these days (I call my hair copper and platinum).  This doesn't color or cover the grays, but it adds a lovely sheen to all hair which makes it look more modern and youthful, at least on my hair.  It does rub off just a little on white towels while hair is wet.My hair does feel smoother, sleeker, and less bouncy after using this.  It just seems to take some of the body out of it, but after the next wash my hair is back to perfect.  For the lower body days I use big curlers or a blow dryer and diffuser, while I am usually a towel dry, clip, and go sort of a girl.

Well whats to say about a birthday gift card. It arrived on time and with Amazon's amazing selection of products I'm sure she got whatever she wanted. In addition because of shipping times between here and Europe this saved me as I was a bit late getting it out.

I use this as a tamping mat for my espresso machine. I like the way it captures stray grinds in the crevices and how fast it cleans up with just a rinse of water. I throw it in the dish washer every so often and get it really clean. Heat doesn't seem to bother it and while not thick it is adequate. I haven't tried it as a pot holder so can't review the ability to dissipate heat and protect your hands. However, I've used regular silicone potholders and they work very well.

I bought mine at Costco in 2012 and I've used this machine daily (sometimes three or four times a day) for the last three years. It comes with three frothing disks 1 for heating steamed milk and two for frothing. In addition there are three settings. One for cold frothing, warm frothing and the third for hot frothing. The unit shuts off when the frothing is done. Cleanup is easy as it has a Teflon coating. I just rinse it out with a pressure water stream and put it (the pitcher) in the dishwasher once in a while to give it a good cleaning. Some Teflon has come off in the bottom of the pitcher but after three years I guess that could be expected. While the unit is made of cheap plastic and the pitcher is Teflon coated aluminum it has held up very well and honestly when wiped clean looks new. Not bad after three years.Creates a nice consistent hot foam for cappuccino which is what I use. I've used it for lattes as well and found the best way is to use the frother exactly the same as for my cappuccino but wait approximately 2 minutes for some separation to occur and use the steamed milk underneath as well as a small amount of the foam that is on top (once used you will understand). I like my milk hot and this unit gets it right to the point where it will barely begin to "scum" the sides because of the heat. I use 2% and whole milk because they seem to work the best. Non-fat doesn't seem to do well at all. Its like trying to froth water. The froth isn't microfoam like a barista would make to do latte art so don't expect it to do that but it is rich and has full body and never burnt. I begin the pour into a couple shots of espresso from about 6-8" above to cause the cappuccino to blend somewhat and decrease the height gradually to float some foam on top.Pros: If it broke today I would buy another (in fact we did on sale just in case this one broke and set it aside).Cons: It does feel cheaply made (but has never broke).

Arrived fast and packed well. First time using Dezcal I've always used a weak vinegar and citric acid solution I made up. Thought I would try a commercial product this time. I mixed it at about 1.5 tablespoons per quart of water. Pack should be good for four cleanings or so.This seemed to work great following directions. Following directions, I cleaned and descaled two espresso machines. First I mixed the solution then pumped into the machine enough solution that I could tell it filled the boiler. Then I let it sit for half an hour. You could see the lime deposits flushed out as I pumped out the Dezcal after the half an hour. You must flush out the Dezcal several times with clear water because it tastes terrible.My machines are both over 8 years old but I do maintain them by using only filtered water and descaling every 6 months or so. This keeps them running fine and coffee tasting good.

Arrived very fast in perfect condition. I got these a few weeks ago to keep for the smoke alarms, emergency radio and whatever. I only used one and it is fine. The real purpose for these is the fact that alkaline and particularly Procell are supposed to last longer in storage. Time will tell if these are better. For now they seem to be a high quality product.

Bought for my 28 year old daughter who is a budding photographer. Smaller than the 65" would seem because the actual tripod is short with a long center post to get to the 65". This causes the tripod to be less stable when fully extended. The ball head is fine for short lenses and light DSLRs. Long lenses and rigs over 10lbs  are best left to sturdier setups. The good thing is this is portable and sturdy when center column is not fully extended. Leg locks are sure and tight. The conversion to a monopod is a nice touch as well.The bag that comes with it is nice and handy.All this is to say that it is much more than a department store tripod or one you get in a "kit". As always there are better and more expensive tripods out there. This tripod is worth what I paid.

They are what appear to be in the ad. They are easy to use and strong. My only beef (if it is one) is that the assortment of drywall screws should have come with ones for wood studs as well. When hanging one of them I hit a stud on one side and had to get one to use to go into the stud. The drywall one provided would not penetrate the wood. I didn't deduct a star as you can see what you get and can't expect more.Pros- strong and cheap, easy to install.Cons- could have had a better screw assortment.
Item arrived quickly and in new packaging. Great product. Fresh batteries. First time using Procell. I hope they are as good as hyped.

I had mixed emotions on how many stars I would give this so I'll let you decide. Incidentally the reviews about this grinder are accurate. Out of the box it doesn't grind fine enough.It arrived fast and was shipped and packed very well. I was excited to get this as all I had was an old blade grinder that would burn my coffee if I ground it fine and would as often as not make powder. I followed the instructions and set the machine to a middle setting. This was way too coarse a grind for a espresso machine so I decided to take it to the smallest setting. Push the button and grind for a little while and I couldn't see a lot of difference, still way too coarse. It was about the size grind from a grocery store grinder set to drip coffee. Now I'm thinking "this was a big mistake".Something isn't tight enough but all was at the finest grind so, disappointed the reviews were right.All the cheap grinders (under 100.00) use the same blades so why did this brand grind so coarsely? I took the upper blades out and checked out how close they got to the lower ones. WOW! There was a gap of about 1/16 inch. I thought if I can get them closer I can make the grind finer. So I began to brainstorm and came up with this solution. Review the photos at the end of this article while you are reading this.I build computers so I have these small washers that are made of fiber that is designed not to compact yet are softer than a steel washer. You can get them free from any computer store (see pic). I took apart the upper blade from the guard (three screws) and set the guard aside. Placing the washer between the guard and the blade I screwed the assembly back together. I tightened the screws going round the circle two or three times so that I didn't risk breaking the ceramic blade tightening slightly more with each round. When tight you can see a slight gap between the blade and the guard about 1/32 inch. I installed the blade and guard back into the machine. Done in about 2 minutes. In one of the pictures you can see the washer just peaking out from behind the blade.When you turn it back on don't put any beans in the machine at first. Test the mod at a wide gap gradually narrowing until you are at the finest setting. My machine just barely touched (you could barely hear it) at the finest setting. I just want to make sure that you don't burn out a motor by having the blades grinding against each other.When I was done testing I filled the hopper with beans and started in the middle settings just as when I first got it. Now I had a grind that was like a very fine grind a drip machine would use. Trial and error I finally found that my espresso machine liked 1.5. I could make powder if I wanted to. I put a picture of the grind with a push pin for reference so you can see the size and consistency (not powder but fine consistent granules).  I couldn't be happier. I only spent 29.00 on the grinder and about 15 minutes modifying it. The consistency of the grind is perfect and with good control if I want it finer or coarser.  I could have spent much more and gotten better, but for the price and slight inconvenience of the mod I feel I got much more than I paid.See the pics for the results. I couldn't get them in order but you get the idea.

This works to connect my Amazon Fire Stick to a VGA monitor thus a wireless connection from my tablet to monitor via screen share (Android 4.4 and above). So all is well in paradise. Well, not quite. It really heats up the Fire Stick so I assume it is using the Fire Sticks's HDMI port for a power source (kind of a vampire). Within a few minutes the Fire Stick was quite hot to the touch. I think that if I put a powered HDMI hub/switch in between it would work so if it does I will update.I give it three stars as it does allow a wired HDMI connection from a computer or tablet to a standard VGA port. Not very useful as most computers have a VGA output. However, if I don't mind being tethered to a wire I can use my tablet with micro HDMI to a standard monitor.
Simple and easy to use. Arrived fast.Works well to hook my tablet with a micro HDMI port to a standard monitor. Nothing fancy just works.

A great more 'advanced' coloring book. Lovely and fun scenes with a theme that sparks a young girls fantasy. Bought for my granddaughter who is preteen and she loves it. Its not my taste but she is able to color some nice pictures. The images are less detailed so there are times when she has to blend colors to make them work. Being young that is not always easy for her but having her mom an artist helps.

My granddaughter loves to paint/color and she loves cats. She is 11 now and this made a perfect gift (along with a artists paint set). The settings aren't so juvenile and it fits in those awkward in between ages before teens. Quality of the paper is nice and  removing them from the book is easy. A budding artist will have hours of fun with this.

It is a bit of a no frills tripod that is heavy duty (rated at 26lbs). I do have a lighter weight Carbon Fiber tripod made by Induro (it is rated at 11lbs) and have been very happy with it but as my equipment has grown so has the weight of my lenses. While I don't like flip locks in general and prefer twist locks these seem to be quality and with carbon fiber (it doesn't shrink and expand with the temperature) they are much more reliable and do not require adjusting often if ever. The same Oben tripod with twist locks is 200.00 more so I'll deal with the flip locks.  Twist locks are slightly faster too. I prefer to buy my tripods headless as I don't have to pay for a head that I will probably not use and replace it anyway.So here is the lowdown on ergonomics. It is taller than most and with center post down the height is 56". It holds (along with the tripod head) the camera at the right height to be eye level for me (approx 61" though that will depend on the height of the head you have). I'm not tall so you might have to extend the post an inch or three but no more than that. It has three leg sections which I prefer. While three don't break down as small it allows for a much sturdier tripod. In addition to this it has on the upper leg a 28mm diameter while on the smallest section it is 16mm. This is much beefier than anything else in the price range. The flip locks are sturdy and didn't need any adjustments but the tools are provided as well as a nice zippered bag. The legs can be used at different angles independently or together. With the proper head and reversing the post you can hold a camera at ground level as well.The setup I am using this with is a gimbal head. Canon 7d and 400mm f4 DO IS lens. For this lens it is rock solid even using a steadying weight of 5lbs to stabilize it in the wind. Lateral motion (twisting) is almost totally absent and the legs are completely stiff with NO flex.At its list price of 349.00 or so it would be an OK deal but at 149.00 its a steal. The twist lock version of this tripod is available for about 300.00 on sale.PROS: Fast setup, sturdy design, solid flip locks, heavy duty .28mm largest diameter tube, and taller than most in this price range.CONS: I'm not fond of flip locks.

I didn't purchase this through Amazon but at Costco when they had it on sale for 129.00 with a bumper case a few months ago.I do love this tablet and have been using for the last few months. The selling factors for me were the amazing screen, fast quad-core processor, 2 Mb ram, and the rugged build. 16 Gb of storage is light but with the SD slot (I put 32Gb in it) it is plenty (however see note below). Whenever you  compare this to other sub 200.00 tablets this shines. The looks of this are great too. It is slim, fits well in one hand and looks great with the white case and thin bezel. Sound is nice and no dropouts or static as some have stated. However, the speakers are not very loud.This thing is fast and very responsive. It will connect to your wireless with either 2.4 or 5.8 Ghz so there is no reason it won't connect via whatever Wi-fi your using. The micro HDMI out is a useful tool if you want to do presentations with it. I gotta say that the most impressive feature is the screen. Note that it isn't the brightest but resolution and color depth are superb. It's bright enough except in the sun but most fail here as well. All the apps that I have loaded work well without a problem including 3rd party apps that run my dslr that can give some tablets and their owners headaches.For the most part the ergonomics of this are fine. I would have preferred to have the USB/charging port on the bottom away from the micro HDMI because in the dark you can confuse the two. Likewise the headphone jack I would prefer on the bottom as the cable gets in the way if you are watching a movie. I have begun to use Bluetooth and no longer have that problem. But all of this is nitpicking and not even really issues at all. In fact I didn't deduct a star for this at all.Then why four stars? Acer itself. I have used and enjoyed Acer products for years. My first real laptop was an Acer and I have owned two since. Their service was always top notch. Until now. I called up tech support to find out why they haven't push out a Android 5 update since it has been released almost 9 months ago. I was told they didn't have any plans to do so. Acer only released this tablet barely 1 year ago and it is currently being sold at many outlets. Yes Android 4.4 is solid running but it has huge problems in using the SD Slot. This SD slot support has been restored in Android 5.xx and for most of us this is a big deal. Eventually, when the warranty wears out, I will have to root it to get SD support and 5.xx. What a pain. For a company like Acer to dump support on a current product is nuts.PROS: Everything in the hardware department. Fast, powerful, very high resolution it is as good as many tablets costing double.CONS: Acer support or lack thereofACER If you read this take it to heart. Most companies support their hardware for a few years at least. If you come out with Android 5.xx I will restore the last star.

Arrived quickly and packed well.My cats love the outdoors so we let them in and out during the day. That means we fight fleas. We take them to the vet for a commercial (prescription) medication that works well for the cat but I needed a spray to treat the bedding and the places in the house that they frequent. Pronyl (fipronil) is the active ingredient in many long lasting flea treatments so I though this might work well for my purpose. The good news is that it kills the fleas in and around the bedding. However, it doesn't seem to last long. We noticed fleas within four or five days so obviously there was a hatch and the treatment didn't kill the eggs or the young fleas. We treat with Pronyl every week so now is fine but wished it lasted longer.

I got this last year for a present for my wife and another for my grown daughter. They seem large for the sizes ordered. That is OK because a large robe is probably a good thing and certainly better than one too small. My biggest complaint is that it isn't soft and hasn't gotten any softer over time. The fabric is cotton but not soft cotton. Honestly I thought I was getting the kind that they give you in a spa hotel or the like. It isn't this one.Pros: Quality stitching and construction.Cons: Stiff scratchy material.

I have a Saeco espresso machine and have used a cheap plastic one of these for years. The results of this tamper are great. Good crema and better coffee.The quality of this is solid and the price is cheap. The instructions say don't dish wash it so I am sure that the dishwasher would ruin the chrome finish which is paper thin.Pros: Heavy weight and two diameters to fit about any portifilterCons: Chrome finish is paper thin and not dish washable.

Arrived FAST. Packed well.As I needed to replace the existing filter right away on receiving these I immediately installed one of the filters in my Refrigerator. No leaks and after a pitcher of water to purge the filter water was clear and tasted good.Pros: Inexpensive and fit well. Water tastes greatCons:  They do feel cheaply constructed but they do the job well.

These batteries arrived quickly and the packaging was fine.Right away I put them in two high speed chargers that I have. Even with the high speed chargers they took about 5 hours to charge. I guess this is due to their increased capacity. As an aside they got quite hot.  I use them in my camera flashguns. They (the flashguns) can quickly drain a set of alkaline batteries after a couple hundred flashes.  After a lot of use (I didn't count the flashes) they were still very good with short cycles to the flash. While cheap they are obviously quite good. Time will tell if they go bad quickly but for now 5 stars.If any die I'll update the review.Pros: Provide lots of powerCons: none right now.

Didn't want a lot of stuff on the counter or another appliance filling the cupboards. This one is small powerful and functional. Couple of smoothies a day and it works fine as long as you don't overfill the jars. About 1/2 way up is about it otherwise it can overflow. Pulverizes ice into snow fast and if you want to make salsa a couple taps do it. Tap it too long and you have salsa smoothie filled with lots of air.Pros: Quality and solidly built and does the job as expected. Much better than my HUGE Kitchen Aid blender. Two extra jars for food processing and grinding. Smaller than the machines it replaces.Cons: None that I can think of. Maybe the manual could have been better with a few tricks and tips. It has a learning curve to get the blends right.Now I can get rid of my blender and food processor and have less stuff around.
Crucial makes great memory and this is no exception. Put it in a stock build so no overclocking and I can't comment on that but has been running for a couple months with no issues.Recommended.
Arrived quickly and great price compared to local stores. No duds in container so all is well and recommended.

Packed well and arrived quickly. Seems solidly built and voltages tested correct. When build was completed computer ran flawlessly. Fans were quiet and the seemed to move plenty of air. Lots of connectors (almost too many as you have to dress it out to make the wires neat). Specs are fine so only length of time will tell but it has been up and running for a couple of months with no problems.Yes recommended

Arrived quickly and well packed.Very nice quality and being MVA the blacks are intense and colors vivid. Good sharp resolution too. No obvious bleed and the angle of viewing is quite wide. Slightly wider gamut give the person fairly accurate rendition of colors when calibrated (actually pretty close out of the box). The stand could be sturdier but all in all an easy to use solid package.The only con is that I wish it was in a 16 X 10 format instead of 16 X 9. There is a lot of real estate lost in this format (however it is good for wide screen video).Great buy for a photographer that wants a bit more color accuracy and wide viewing angles without color shift than a TFT monitor.

They arrived fast and were well packed. On opening the sandals were in the original box. These are not the Teva sandals I have gotten in the past. The materials aren't the same workmanship and quality. In addition the soles have an unusual design that places a weird ball like blob under the arch. This makes the arch overly stiff and after an hour or two makes my feet sore. I don't mind good arch support and need it but this is rock hard. I just can't wear them all day without soreness. Some others may be fine.Pros: For Teva the price is low but the quality is lowered too.Cons: Make my feet sore.

I've used this processor on a few machines and honestly if you are not doing a lot of multitasking it is fast and solid. With only two cores and no hyperthreading it is a bit slow for those that have many programs open at once. However, for those of us that like to use only a couple programs at a time no problem so why waste the money.Great value processor

Fast delivery! Set right up with no problems. I used this in a Windows 8.1 machine with great success. I assume it will outlast the computer as the last one I built with a Hitachi drive went obsolete before the drive gave out.Seems to be a quality product. I've never had to use Hitachi support.

Shipped on time maybe a little slow. Came only minimally packed and the box opened strewing canisters around the box. I've used a few and the product seems to be fine. I haven't come across any duds yet (as some have complained about) and they have worked in my whipped cream maker just fine.

Arrived fast and in good condition.OK, they are made cheaply but they are cheap. It is a spun glass filter with a light cardboard frame. The good thing about them is they keep the dust down (but not like a hepa filter) and the air flow high. Some of the new high filtration filters restrict airfow enough to cause a problem if you are like me and get a little lazy about changing all the time. It is a tradeoff yes but the others would clog in 30 days. With these I get 60 days and have a lot better airflow which translates into a more comfortable home without working the air conditioner so hard.

Arrived very fast and was packed well. My old adapter gave out and I needed a replacement. This one looked similar and had the power I needed. Comes with everything in the picture and can handle up to 8 cameras. Wiring it in is simple and only took about 5 minutes. As it is a replacement everything was already in place.  My old one used to get warm but lasted about 3 years. This adapter seems to be better made and stays much cooler to the touch. It has been in for about two weeks and all is fine.

Slow delivery almost two weeks. Packed well and arrived in good condition.Ok, I have a Floatron and the technology works. I was hoping at this reduced price I could get something at least similar to augment my aging Floatron. While the pictures are accurate they don't show scale because there is nothing to compare the size in the photo of this product. The Solaxx is about 1/2 the size of the Floatron and the annode is only about a tenth the weight of the Floatron. While it does produce some copper ions it is a toy compared to the real thing. This would probably be fine for a small vinyl pool or hot tub but to expect it to handle an in-ground pool is foolish.So, I will continue to use my aging Floatron and hope it keeps working (its three years old now). I have replaced the annode once in that time. Buy the Floatron its worth the difference.

I used to have to have a rooter company come out every 12 to 18 months. They (plumbers) recommended that I have my pipes replaced to permanently solve the problem.  I've been using this for 3 years now and haven't had them back.However,I did find out which tree was the main culprit as it is dying a long slow death. This year I will have to remove it. While I hate to remove a mature tree it would have to be done regardless as I can't have it destroy my pipes.

Delivery was extra fast. The cabin filter is identical to factory part (2010 Honda Insight). Extremely easy to install in less than 5 minutes with directions that are clear. No need to pay a dealer 40.00 to 60.00 for one of these.I replace mine about every two years but it is recommended yearly.

Great idea as it gives some performance boost to single drives systems that have no room for a separate SSD drive. In addition it makes housekeeping on the drive easier as it is a single drive. It's smart technology puts most the operating system in NAND memory while less used files reside on the platters.Is it as fast as a  SSD drive? No way. But it is much faster than a traditional drive. It is worth the extra few bucks.

Arrived quickly and intact. Very nice and easy to install. Very slightly undersized so it works well with a protective case. The only issue is that it has a slight imperfection on the screen on close examination. Nothing bad and not worth sending back but I deducted a star for that reason.

I really abuse these as I work in sometimes wet locations. Most days I walk over 5 miles in them and they hold up fine. For me to get 6 months out of a pair of shoes is great and I'm passing that now. The only obvious wear is on the soles of the shoe. While worn they are still intact with no separations. Buy these in confidence.

Arrived quickly and packed well. Attractive design and keeps the phone's slim size fairly well. In fact if the case were any less it probably wouldn't protect the phone at all. Installation is a breeze (just remember to put the top of the phone in first) and the phone just snaps in. The top has a bit more of a lip so if you put the bottom in first might be a problem. It isn't slippery and provides a good grip to handle the phone.Protection is good for a fall on its back or maybe the side but from the front is much less so. You can put it down on a flat surface and the case lip will protect the screen with a small gap but if the surface is uneven could cause a problem. In addition if you are a pocket carrier like me I would clean it out once in a while because debris could get between the case and the back of the phone causing some scratches.Why do I give it 5 stars? Because it is well made with quality cutouts that fit perfectly. It is slim and attractive and capable of protecting against the day to day banging around that a phone gets. It is not a military spec grade A protection device. But if it were it wouldn't be small and attractive. It would also be intrusive to its function.  I added a tempered glass screen protector and feel fairly comfortable about protecting the phone. If you need something bullet proof get an otter box or similar. I'll live with some risk for the convenience, slim feel and looks.

Arrived quickly and packed in a padded envelope. A perfect addition to my LG G3 phone. With it my phone now has almost 100 Gb of storage. I just slid the chip in and the recognized it immediately. Seems to be fast (moved over all my files in a few seconds). Under 30 dollars for a class "10"  64 Gb chip is a fantastic deal. A steal at $27.00.
Poor quality and plastic bearings. OK for a toddler or small child to sit on but for a child wanting to ride forget it.

There are so many books and stories about an apocalypse - with every book having its own idea on what the apocalypse will be - but not many books mention our four-legged or winged friends. When you think about this, it's strange, since I know so many people who consider their pets to be family members, but it's almost as if the world has come to the conclusion that pets will all be lost, or forgotten, when the zombies arrive or the world ends.Tails of the Apocalypse takes the opposite approach, giving us fourteen short stories that are either told from the point of view of the animals, or where our animal friends are a central part of the plot.Overall, I had to give this collection 4 1/2 Stars. Many of the stories will haunt me past reading this, while others were still great but didn't have the same impact. When reading a collection, I usually like to say something about each short story, but it's more difficult when you have a collection with this tightly-woven of a theme, since in some ways every story is alike, while still managing to keep its individuality, so I'm just going to say that I liked all of these stories, loved some more than others, but that there wasn't a single story that I disliked. Whether told from the eyes of a human or of an animal, the authors are able to reach deep into your heart and make you feel exactly what their characters are experiencing.Usually when we think "pets" we think of cats and dogs, but this collection also contains stories of wolves, parrots, bats, budgies, and others, along with feline and canine friends. And every stories contains some tale of the world's end, whether by zombies or volcanoes, war or disease.If you enjoy apocalyptic tales, and are a lover of animals of any type, I think you'll enjoy this collection. In addition, this book is being sold for a good cause as well, with $1.00 from every copy sold going to Pets for Vets.I received a copy of this book in exchange for an honest review.

While it's always fun to step back into the 'verse and visit the crew from Firefly/Serenity, this graphic novel was a bit of a disappointment. While the plot is good, it suffers from a bit of a cliffhanger ending. The worst crime, however, is the horrible artwork. The cover and the artwork on the chapter pages are beautiful, but the remainder of the artwork - which is 95% of it - is just terrible, with the characters all looking too much alike so that I had a difficult time sometimes figuring out who was supposed to be who.*Library Copy*

TALES FROM THE CANYONS OF THE DAMNED takes us into the mist, giving us three short stories filled with unknown - and sometimes unseen - horrors. After first having been introduced to the mist and what lies within in his short story TOWER, we now see the fate of others in what I have to imagine is the exact same mist.In Sandhogs, a work crew is stranded six hundred feet below the streets of Manhattan. The Penthouse brings us to a view from within the mists itself, as a man named Jack drinks alone while pondering his fate. The Harbor takes us out to a ferry, where a visitor just wants to go home with her daughter. All three of these locations have one thing in common... the mists, the creatures within, and the end of the world as they know it.Though I will admit that I liked TOWER better, the author's story that introduced me to the mist, this was a great collection and I enjoyed the chance to see the fates of others when brought face-to-face with a reality filled with nightmares.

When the lights went out, Nathan Farthen was high in the tower at One World Trade. With the memory of 9/11 fresh in their minds, the workers trapped need to regroup and plan an escape. But when the mist creeps in, bringing the tentacles, Nate realizes that this attack is far from mundane, the actions of something other than human.Would they be able to survive?This short story is delightfully creepy. With a Lovecraftian feel, the unexpected horrors that await our protagonist and his new coworkers will keep the readers on the edge of their seats, hoping for the best while wondering what will come next. I really hope to someday find out what exactly happened to bring these events to New York City.

Haven: (noun) A place of safety or refuge.Or is it?In this short story, written by Drew Avera, we learn that what you expect isn't what you always get. When the world is falling apart, the view through a young boy's eyes shows us the hope, despair, and corruption prevalent in a society where people are desperate to survive.Is this a haven in truth? I guess you'll have to read it to find out.I received a free copy of this book through the author's email list.

I've recently become hooked on anthologies, finding the experience of reading connected short stories to be an excited way to learn about new authors and become reacquainted with worlds I already enjoy. The newest addition to my kindle is The Time Travel Chronicles, part of The Future Chronicles. I have enjoyed every one of the Chronicles I have picked up, and this was no exception.The collection starts out with a bang... or rather, a blink. Extant, by Anthony Vicino, takes us into a world where the gifted can freeze time, race through it, or blink to the past. But not everything is perfect... can knowing that you're saving the world make up for the horrifying consequences? (5 Stars)Gambit by Rysa Walker is the second book of the collection, and asks the question that everyone wonders: can you safely change the past to make the future your own? And... if you can, should you? When I completed this story, I immediately bought the first 2 books of the author's CHRONOS series, which tells you how much this premise intrigued me. (5 Stars)Were unicorns supposed to be on Noah's Ark? Beasts of the Earth by Ernie Lindsey answers that question, and more. (4 Stars)Excess Baggage takes us into a whirlwind of a tale, where a boy is swept away into the past accidentally. The ending of the story leaves so many possibilities open to fuel the imagination, allowing the reader to wonder not only about the fates of the travelers, but also the world left behind. (4 1/2 Stars)Stefan Bolz's The Traveler made me cry... it's a bittersweet story about loss, and the lengths that someone will go through to say goodbye. (5 Stars)Eighty-Three is a story with twists and leaps through time, showing us a man who randomly jumps into his past and future, interacting with the world-to-be, or that left behind. But it is true, or just a delusion? (4 1/2 Stars)Everyone dreams of living forever... or to somehow jump into a better future. But what if the future isn't what you imagined it would be? Though I had a premonition of what the ending of Life/Time in the New World would be, it was so well-written and had such an edge of truth to it that I can confidently say that it was one of my favorites in the collection. (5 Stars)I've been a fan of Robert J. Sawyer's work since I picked up his WWW Trilogy a few years back, so I wasn't surprised that I enjoyed his short story, Just Like Old Times. This was a fun tale about an alternate death sentence, leaving us to wonder if the past could change the present. (4 1/2 Stars)Shades is the tale of a boy who can't stay still.. but not by his own choice. Every five years, since his birth, all proof of his existence is wiped clean and he finds himself ten years in the future, with no past, no family, and no hope of a normal life. Can he find the courage to take control back? (4 1/2 Stars)The smell of blood on the beach foretells a day of horror, when humanity will go back to try to change the past. The Nothing Gate is a morbid tale that leaves you to wonder about the fate of both the main character and the world itself. (4 1/2 Stars)Meddler by Ernie Luis is another favorite... when you combine a drug dealer with a conscious with time travel, nothing could possibly go wrong, right? I look forward to looking into more books by this author! (5 Stars)I'm still trying to figure out my feelings toward The Diatomic Quantum Flop. This is a story that will leave you thinking about the possibilities hidden within the human mind while simultaneously wondering what happens next. While I enjoyed this tale, it was a little chaotic to be a favorite of mine, but was still an excellent and intriguing tale. (4 Stars)Red Mustang is a standout piece in a collection full of stories that shine. What happens if an action of yours not only ruined your life, but the lives of those around you? If you could go back to that moment and relive your life, knowing that you do now, would you? (5 Stars)Hereafter by Samuel Peralta is a perfect story to close out the anthology, drawing us into a family tied together by time travel. Not only is the timing of the travel clearly thought out, but the impact on the people involved is so well described that this story made me cry as well... not once, but twice. This author will play with your heartstrings while making you wonder about what the future holds. (5 Stars)At the end of this collection, I'm left with fourteen outstanding tales, and nothing that I would rate less than four stars. I am very happy that I was given an opportunity to read this book, and I look forward to reading more by all of these authors in the future.While I received an Advance Reader Copy of this book for review purposes, I have also purchased the anthology because I loved it so much.

Sondrine never expected to find herself in the middle of a war, seemingly the only hope to defeat an immortal queen. In fact, all that she wanted was to avoid an arranged marriage and to somehow continue practicing her magic. But when Sondrine leaves her aunt's emporium and apothecary shop in the light of a full moon, she finds herself transported from London to Winterhaven, trapped by an insane king who somehow knows her name.The author has created a wonderful world that draws the reader into the middle of an adventure. This is a world where everyone has at least a touch of magic, where monsters and myths come to life, and where deception lurks in unexpected places. One thing that I loved is that the author doesn't just give you all of the answers. Though I was able to correctly guess some of the things that were brought to light at the end, they weren't obvious, and there are still some questions left unanswered for the reader to wonder about.Overall, this is a wonderfully fun book, full of humor and mischief, as well as danger. The characters are complex, for the most part, allowing the reader to peel apart the layers slowly throughout the book to finally reveal a well-developed personalty and back-story. Even the secondary characters are interesting enough that you want to read more about them. While this is the first book I have read by Jenna Nelson, it will not be my last.4 1/2 StarsI received a copy of this book for review purposes.

Have you ever thought about what it would be like to be immortal? After a while, what would you do? The quest to gather wealth would eventually grow boring, and with every movie watched and ever book read, after having watched all of your friends and family die before you, would you crave the cold caress of death?The Immortality Chronicles is a collection of stories all dealing with, well, immortality. It's not a comfortable book, but it is a good one, making you realize how sweet mortality is even as the days pass by. As children, we all want to grow up, but as adults many of us wish for the carefree days of our youth. This collection takes us into the minds and stories of the people who can't, who are doomed - one way or another - to live forever.I always have a difficult time reviewing collections, because while each story has its own merits and thrills, the book as a whole has to come together seamlessly, taking us from story to story in a way that makes us want to read more until we come to the end, sad that it is over. Samuel Peralta has once again gathered a talented group of authors to share their stories, and I'm happy to say that there wasn't one story I disliked.This collection has everything from time folds to immortality serums, from a plague that makes the world stop aging to a man who becomes more machine than human in his quest to live forever. If I had to pick a favorite story, it would probably be "Eternity Today" by Thomas Robins. In this story, an accident on Near Year's leaves humanity reliving January 1st over and over again, coming together to find a solution even though actions have to be restarted every morning. Another favorite is Harlow Fallon's "A Long Horizon," where we learn the tale of a woman destined to live hundreds of years, only to reach the end of her journey as one of the only survivors on a prison ship. A third favorite made me actually stop reading for a while - "Rememorations" by Paul B. Kohler caused me to think about how ever person and every decision is tied together in my past, and what the loss of one would do to everything else in my life.After reading this collection, as well as a few others in The Future Chronicles, I'm excited to read more by these authors. Not only did I find a book that actually made me appreciate my own life so much more, but I also was introduced to a few more authors that I hadn't yet looked into. This is a great 4 1/2 star book and one I would recommend to any fan of science fiction.*Borrowed from Kindle Owners' Lending Library*

Geekomancy is a book that will resonate with a specific subset of readers: Geeks, but more specifically Science Fiction, Fantasy, and Gamer Geeks. And not only that, you really do need to belong to all three genre subsets to understand the jokes and references that are threaded throughout the story. An average person, or someone who just tips their toes into Geekdom, will most likely find themselves lost and confused while reading this book.So now I have to bring out my geek fury about one thing that bothered me throughout the book. The authors introduces characters with D&D style stats, but instead of using Intelligence (usually abbreviated INT in the D&D world) the author uses IQ. Such as, this character has an IQ of 16. NO, this character would have an INT stat of 16. If they actually had an IQ of 16 it would be a really short book about someone sitting in a corner drooling on themselves...But I digress.Other than my continual frustration over the misuse of IQ in the stat section, I enjoyed the book. It's fun, the plot is somewhat over the top but still works, and I loved the references... Especially since I recognized 95% of them. Ree spends most of the book figuring out (pretty impressively) what she can do with her powers, and the twist of the bad (or perhaps just misled) character was also fun. There are enough surprises in the book to keep me happy and the plot was quick and never got bogged down.

Twenty years after the robot war, humanity is still healing from their losses. To protect themselves, anything even slightly mechanical or electrical has to be created in a simulation and approved first, to reduce the chance of another disaster. Joel, a simulation engineer student, finds himself thrown into a nightmare when he finds out that his new internship assignment is to work on a robot...But is Jerry a robot?The title of the novella claims that Jerry is not, but the reader will need to make his or her own decision based on the facts of the story. Tying Asimov's Three Laws of Robotics to human decency  - and perhaps even a little revenge - this short story is sure to please most lovers of science fiction, and shows that a tale can pack a surprising amount of information and wonder into just fifty pages.

I will start this out with a warning. In this short story, you will find violence, sex, and graphic language.Now that the disclaimer is over, I'll mention what else you'll find in this story. Fighting. Retribution. Ghosts. And a neat little twist at the end. Without giving away too much, I really enjoyed Ground and Pound. I've only read one other story by this author so far (Magno Girl and the Beast of Brooklyn) but this is just as good in a different way. Where Magno Girl and the Beast of Brooklyn is full of tongue-in-cheek humor about superheroes and villains, Ground and Pound is about your normal, everyday heavy-weight fighter. With a Ghost. It's darker. It's more violent and there is more profanity. But I LOVED the ending... maybe I'm just a little vindictive, but I found it satisfying. I smiled. It may have been an evil little "don't make the red-headed Irish woman angry" type smile, but it was a smile.So if you want a ghost story with a twist and don't mind sex and profanity, pick this book up. It's currently for free through BN.com for the Nook and also free on Smashwords, and if you're nice and contact the author if may even send you a MOBI copy for free since Amazon hasn't price-matched this yet.

Magno Girl and the Beast of Brooklyn is a fun short story about a superhero named Magno (short for Magnolia) Girl and a bouncer named Ron. When thieves steal large bags of rice from a Chinese restaurant, Ron was close enough to see the events but annoyed with the cops enough to give them some wrong information. His attraction for Magno is enough that he decides to help her find the real criminals, and the story takes off from there.While some parts of this story are hilariously absurd -- a super-villain named Bank Roll who was evicted for not paying his rent?! -- everything is just over the top enough to make it a fast-paced and amusing introduction to Mango Girl. Fighting, flying, and a superpower that affects the hero, along with a nagging mother, this story kept me laughing all the way through. After reading this, I'm excited to see what the author has in store for us in the full novel he's recently released, about Magno and Ron's continuing adventures.NOTE: I received a free copy of this book after signing up for the author's mailing list.

London Road is a collection of shorts all tried to the inhabitants of a boarding house in London. The collection starts and ends with Janice, a woman newly released from prison after serving five years for the murder (in self-defense) of her husband. On a recommendation of a friend who was released two weeks prior, Janice arrives at a boarding house... And so the collection begins.The individual stories are short but give an intimate view into the lives of the women who live there. Starting with Janice's quest for self-worth, we are then taken into the mind of a young girl on parole, one lift from jail, before watching a woman deal with an uncertain relationship, a child with her own need to be wanted, and then an older woman dealing with her feelings of rejection in a mind plagued by inner-demons.All of these stories are relatable, and the added touch of subtle British colloquialisms give it a feeling that problems are international, at least from a reader on the American side of the pond. The darkness is there, but with hope threaded through, making these enjoyable and thought-provoking.The one negative that I really have to say about this book is that the narrative is sometimes a little confusing. Each chapter/story if told about a different person, and yet sometimes it's told in first-person narrative and sometimes in third-person. This is a little disconcerting. I would have also enjoyed a longer book, but as the actual events take place over one day I can understand why it is so short.I received a copy of this book in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.

This is my third magnetic calendar, and this one works really well. It's a little on the larger size without being too large, but there is ample space to write notes in each day field.  The calendar is set up with a Sunday - Saturday week, with a spot to write the month at the top, spots for each date, and five rows for weeks. This is pretty standard, though some calendars are set up for Monday - Sunday and I prefer Sunday - Saturday.The calendar comes with double-sided foam tape and magnets to stick to the back, so this calendar can then go on the fridge. Some calendars are now coming with hook & eye fasteners on the back, but I prefer these with magnets so I can take the calendar off the fridge to write my monthly work schedule on it, and then put the calendar easily back on the fridge.This calendar also comes with a fine point black dry erase marker that fits in the little holder at the top of the calendar.This is a great purchase if you need to keep track of a schedule - this is useful for people with varying schedules, multiple jobs, projects, kids (for school events, sports, etc.) and pretty much anything else you might need to write down on a calendar. Since I'm pretty sure that everyone had a fridge, you really can't go wrong with this, and the price was great!

The stove at our new apartment doesn't have a time built in, so we needed to buy a kitchen timer. This one has an on/off switch, which is something I wanted, so I purchased it. This timer takes a AAA battery, not included, so please keep this in mind when purchasing it.The timer is not too large and has a magnetic back so it sticks to the fridge. The numbers on the timer are large and easy to see, with more minutes and seconds. The one negative is that it is VERY loud and there isn't a way to adjust the timer. The description states that the timer is loud and clear, but not deafening, but perhaps my hearing is more sensitive than the people who wrote the description since it is on the verge of being deafening... and my desk is about eight feet from where it lives on the fridge. If I could adjust the volume, of it if was a little less loud, this would be a solid 5 stars - so if you don't mind a really loud timer or if you're hard of hearing, this should be perfect for you! As I mentioned previously, there is an on/off switch on the side, so we can turn the timer off when we're not using it to extend the battery life even longer.

In the process of moving, our old vacuum died, leaving us vacuum-less. After checking out Amazon, I noticed this Eureka AS2113A vacuum on sale, and it had pretty good reviews, so we decided to purchase it. Thanks to Prime shipping, we got the vacuum two days later... when you have two cats and friends with allergies, it's never good to be without a vacuum for long!I'm happy to say that this vacuum deserves its high rating. The vacuum was easy to put together and isn't huge - it easily fits in the corner of our front closet. Using it for the first time, we noticed that there wasn't a lever to lean the body of the vacuum back, but instead there is a button on the lower part that it less noticeable. The vacuum suction is good, picking up pet hair and cat litter, and it's able to pick up particles from corners. It's not too loud either.We haven't had to use any of the attachments yet, but there is a brush attachment and an extender so that you can get into places where the base of the vacuum won't fit. This is a good vacuum that I was lucky to get for a good price, and I'm happy with this purchase.

This is a great portable battery charger. The case is durable and compact, the charger is easy to use plus it comes with instruction guides in five languages (English, German, Spanish, French, and - I think - Italian) so you won't be at a loss when using it. The instruction books come with a QR code and website on the front that unfortunately do not appear to work anymore, but since all of the information I'd need is in the booklet itself, I'm not too worried.The portable charger can itself be charged using an A/C Adapter or there is an included car charger. They recommend charging it completely at full use, and then re-charging it at least every 6 months, though it starts that more frequent charges won't hurt it... that's great to know! It also won't overcharge, so you can leave it connected to the A/C Adapter, so if you forget it unplug it once it's fully charged it won't damage the charger. You can check the charge on the portable charger at any time by pressing the "Function" button on top of the charger... there are 4 red LED lights that display the level of charge, with all four as "fully charged."With this, you can jump start your car or charge portable devices using the USB port or 12V/16V/19V port.Pretty much everything you need - at least power-wise - is included in this case for an emergency while on a road trip. Cell phone/Tablet/Etc need to be charged and you don't have a USB port in your car? Plug it into this. Left your lights on and your battery died? Jump it with this! This is a wonderful investment and I'm soooooo glad that I have one now to use!I received this item in exchange for an honest review.

Over the past year, I've become a fan of YogaAddict products. They're always well made and useful. When I was asked to review these yoga shorts, I accepted... but I got them in my husband's size so he could test them! I'm happy to say that they fit as expected, using the size reference chart in the product description. Make sure you use the size reference chart to make sure you get the correct size. The ones my husband has fit perfectly - not too lose in the legs or waist, but not tight either, making that they're pretty much perfect for exercising in.The seams are tight, there weren't any loose threads, the construction is very well done, and I'm told that they're comfortable to work out in. The material is a quick-dry material, and there is a drawstring waist. There aren't any pockets, but they aren't really needed. The YogaAddict logo is small and unobtrusive.Once again, I'm happy with a product received from YogaAddict. I received this product in exchange for an honest review.

I received this product in exchange for an honest review. While I didn't have the weight gain that some reviewers report, I did lose 5 pounds in three weeks. I've had a difficult time losing weight since I was on some medication that caused weight gain, so this was helpful in that respect. I also am happy to report that I didn't have any difficulty or bad side effects taking this. The pills are a little large, but vitamins are as well so I'm used to that. I didn't notice much of a change in sleeping, energy levels during the day, or even appetite suppression, but the "fat burning" part seems to have done something at least since I did notice a minor weight loss. There is the potential for a large weight loss over the full two month period that is included in this bottle, so I will update my review if I notice any additional benefits or an exponential change in weight loss.

2:49 Mins This is a review of the iHomeSet Amazing Laundry Folder, which I received in exchange for an honest review. In this review, I show you how to use the shirt folder as well as discussing the quality of the product. I received this item in exchange for an honest review.

I bought these when I lost my stylus for my phone, but I found that I haven't used them much before they just didn't register well on my device. I practically have to bash them down on my device to register it, so that just doesn't work for me, so I need something with a different tip. They've also a little fatter than I'd like in a stylus, but that's a personal preference. The colors are great, however, and they're light and seem well-made. These may work for you on your device, but they just didn't work as well for me on my Moto X (2014)

When the cable for my kindle broke, I freaked... oh no, I need my kindle! So I found this charger on amazon and bought it, and it's solved so many of my problems. Not only does it charge my kindle, but it also charges my android phone. It's long enough that I can plug it into the wall (using a USB adapter) and then still use my phone or kindle while it charges. You can also plug this into your computer but charging through a computer is always slower.It also works as a USB connector to your computer, however, not just as a charger, so if you need to side-load files onto your kindle or phone, or access stored material on a phone or tablet, this is great.

This is a great little charger/external battery that I use a LOT with my phone, especially when traveling or at a conference. It comes in a little mesh bag so you can put it and the cable into the bag and then stick it in a bag, purse, or pocket until you need it. I usually charge it up the night before I'll need it and then toss it in my bag, and I can normally get 1 - 1 1/2 full charges of my phone out of this, which gets me through days with even the heaviest usage.I've had this for almost 6 months now and it's stood the test of time so far, with no degradation of charging abilities.

This steamer gets a lot of use in our household. We've had it for a few months now, and it's still going strong. We use it for rice, to steam vegetables, eggs, and even for full ears of corn. It's easy to clean and it's nice so that you adjust the size for steaming multiple layers of veggies or to take the divider out to steam larger items. As my husband says, "It's awesome and does just about everything!" The only thing that you can't really steam is peas, because they fall through the holes to the bottom, and then you end up with random peas in your rice (if you're steaming rice at the same time.)We've had a few other rice cookers and steamers over the years, and this is our favorite.

My husband uses this egg slicer all of the time to make egg salad, and it's been great! Cheap to buy, small to store, and easy to clean, there isn't much we can say about this. After a few months of use, it's still sharp and ready to use. No complaints, and a highly recommended little kitchen tool if you regularly cut up egg for salads, egg salad sandwiches, etc.

This is a good looking fabric shower curtain. I use this with a separate liner, so this curtain by itself won't keep all of the water out plus it's light and blows up in the shower, so instead I leave it hanging outside the shower and use a liner on the inner section. I've only had this up for a few days but I've already received compliments on it. This is my second shower curtain from this same company (InterDesign Accessories) and the quality is up there and makes me happy. If you're looking for a shower curtain with personality, this is a great one. Since it's black and white, you can use it with pretty much every coloration in your bathroom without clashing, and the pattern is small enough that it works in any size bathroom.

This is a great little fan. It's a little louder than I would like on the highest setting, but it does a great job of pushing area around a small area. My husband wanted a fan to use as white noise while sleeping, so this is great for that. If you're looking to cool an entire room, you'll probably want a larger fan, but for cooling a small area you can't really go wrong with this.

This is a great chair, big enough that you can curl up in in, but not too big - it fits in the corner of my apartment. The downside is that is shifts when I get into it, sometimes making it a little difficult to get out. The construction is good - I've had mine for about 4 years now and it's still going strong.
