I've had to replace the cushion once due to wear/tear & spillage, but the actual chair itself will probably be good for many more years to come.Curling up in this chair leaves you supported on all sides, so it's great. I've accidentally fallen asleep in it before, though I don't recommend that since my back yelled at me in the morning.

I absolutely love my Zippi personal fans - I actually have two, one at home and one at work. I've had them for about three years now and they are still going strong. The one at work gets used two days/week for about 8 hours per day, and the one at home is used periodically, more so in the summer. Right now it's on almost nonstop whenever I'm working from home!The cloth blades are great because if I (or my husband... or the cats....) accidentally bump into it, we don't have to worry about injury. There are two speeds, and even on the highest speed it's so quiet that I forget that it's there.If you're looking for a personal fan, especially for use at a desk, this is the perfect fan!*bought at local store*

This is a great set of resistance bands, in 4 different tensions/resistances. Green gives a light resistance, blue is medium, red is heavy, and blue is XX heavy. I love having the different resistances, because some part of my body are stronger than others, and different exercises work best with different bands for me. I can use the Heavy for some leg exercises and medium for others, and my arms I fluctuate between light and medium. This means that I still have room to grow and strengthen with the different exercises!The set comes with a DVD that shows you some useful exercises to make the most out of the resistance bands. After watching the DVD a couple of times, you'll know the exercises well enough that you can then use the bands while watching TV or listening to music. If you are impatient and want to learn the exercises a little more quickly than the DVD is, just speed it up a little and you can still watch the exercises even without listening. Everyone learns differently, so there are a couple of different options for you!The bands comes in a great little drawstring bag so they don't get lost (or dragged away by my cats) and they're easy to travel with... just toss them in your suitcase and you can still exercise while on vacation. It's a great way to justify eating too much when you can exercise it off in your hotel room!I received this item in exchange for an honest review.

I absolutely love this yoga mat towel. It's no skid, and by that I mean it actually works... it didn't budge, even during a sweaty workout. It's also absorbent and washes well, and both the mat towel and the hand towel are soft and not scratchy.. I'm very happy with the construction of these two items and I'm very happy to use them! I have the blue set, and the color is very pretty and hasn't faded after washing it several times.I received this item in exchange for an honest review! Even if I hadn't received this for free, however, I would have still purchased it because YogaAddict products have proven to me to be durable, and the company has been a joy to deal with.

These ice pop makers are useful and easy to use. We did juice pops with apple juice and cranberry apple, and they froze quickly. To get the ice pop out of the mold, I would suggest running the outside of the mold under warm water to loosen up the inside popsicle, and you'll be good to go! Easy to clean and they are soft and don't smell or leave a taste on whatever you've made.I received these silicone ice pop molds in exchange for an honest review.

Miranda Kane has always felt that she is a screw-up, especially when it comes to magic. When her mother gives her an added incentive to do well at a spellcasting competition, she finds herself somehow in first place... and in more danger than she could imagine.While Spellbinder is a short story in the Shadow Falls universe, it's not necessary that you read the other books before reading this one, since enough background is provided that you are able to get into the story easily. I haven't (yet) read the other books in the series, but after reading this one I'm excited to start reading from the beginning! The author is able to write characters that seem read, even in a fantasy world, and while a short story doesn't give a lot of time for character development there are a few twists and turns in this story to make it interesting. Not only do we have mystery and murder in the plot, but we also dip into Miranda's past and her relationships with her friends and enemies alike. The story isn't perfect, but it's a fun and enjoyable short story.If you're a fan of magic, mystery, fantasy, and light romance, I recommend that you pick up Spellbinder by C.C. Hunter.

Set in an alternate Victorian era were magic lurks along with creatures that go bump in the night, Elle Black is a psychic investigator. Happy with her wife, her past intrudes when Elle sees a vision of her deceased husband... but how can he be found when she watched him be buried? Unsure if he is a ghost or a figment of her imagination, Elle jumps at the opportunity to investigate a potentially haunted house.Sundark is a well-written and fun novel that combines mystery and horror along with spirituality and LGBT relationships. I don't want to say too much, in the fear of ruining the book, but I will mention that I love the caring and supporting relationship between Elle and Faedra and the way that their marriage is quietly accepted by the other characters we meet, even though who might have looked askance at first. The plot of story is interesting and has enough twists that it isn't obvious what the ending will be, and the pace of the story is perfect, neither dragging nor feeling rushed.4 1/2 StarsThank you to the publisher and NetGalley for providing me with a free copy of this book in exchange for an honest review.

Not every supplement works for everyone, unfortunately, and while I would have liked this supplement to work for me, it did not. My goals for taking this supplement were to perhaps lose a little weight, and also to help with digestion. While I did not have any negative effects while taking this supplement, I didn't have anything noticeable positive either. This doesn't mean that there is anything wrong with the supplement, it just means that this one wasn't the right one for me!I would still recommend this supplement to someone who is willing to give it a try, just please keep in mind that everyone's body is different and that some supplements may work better for some people than they do for others.I received this product in exchange for an honest review.

This story isn't your normal alien novel, nor is it your standard dystopian tale. Instead, it's a mix, showing us a world where aliens arrived, but instead of taking over and killing everyone, they came with a mission to "save" the Earth. In this world, the Prodigies live with and are cared for by the ShaZha - jellyfish-like aliens with the power to praise and punish - as long as they obey the rules.But humans who cannot see or hear the ShaZha are not as lucky.I enjoyed this story, watching Zarah evolve from a naive and cherished Prodigy - a Pet - to someone who has had her eyes opened to the wider world around her. Without giving any spoilers, I will say that I liked the depth of the characters in the second half of the book more than the shallower characters in the first half. The groups you're introduced to feel real to their environment and upbringing, and while the action is more quiet that some readers may be used to, it just seems right.As for Zarah herself, I may not agree with every decision she made in the book, but I can understand why she made them.My only complaint about this book is that I wish it had been longer... perhaps someday the author can revisit this world to show us what happens next.Thank you to the publisher and NetGalley for providing me with a free copy of this book in exchange for an honest review.

I received this item for free in exchange for an honest review, and I was asked to post a review within seven days of receiving it. After a full week of taking these, unfortunately I'm not noticing any difference in my joint pain. I will continue taking these and will update my review if necessary.

Take a newlywed "Jewish American Princess" and send her to Japan with her new husband just days after the wedding, and you have the beginning of an amusing tale of clashing cultures. Lisa is not 100% a pampered princess, but she's close. She has cooked a meal or two in her life, and perhaps done some laundry, but that doesn't experience doesn't mean much when she finds herself doing laundry with a machine that only allows you to wash a few things at a time... and destroys them in the process. If that wasn't enough, there isn't even a dryer!The author has split up the books into different sections such as Laundry, Cooking and Transportation, but includes other antidotes in with the story to really share her first year living in a foreign county.This isn't a deep book on Japanese culture or etiquette, but it's a good and humorous book about an American Expat in Japan.*Library copy*

Girl from Above is a story that starts slowly, but before you know it you're wrapped into the thread of the tale and don't want it to end. It's the tale of a synth - a programmed machine with the soul of a girl, hidden behind layers of protocols and fail-safes.1001 shouldn't exist. Chitec was only supposed to make 1000 synths - 500 male and 500 female - to prolong the lives of those rich enough to afford it. So why was 1001 made? That is the true enigma of the tale, threading through with the stories of Caleb, the Mal Reynold-esque smuggler and his second, Fran.This story really does feel heavily influenced by the unfortunately canceled show "Firefly", especially at the beginning of the book, when we first meet Cale and Fran. Cale has a ship, a little beaten around, but it takes him around the universe where he can smuggle the goods needed. We have the evil corporation - in this case, we have both Chitec and Fleet, where in Firefly we had the Alliance as a whole, and we also have the stowaway and the bounty hunter.Once we get past the beginning, the tale goes in its own direction, giving us hints of who the characters really are, all leading up to the big reveal at the end of the book. While there were a few things that I was able to guess before they were actually explained, overall this book does a great job of weaving a fun and convoluted story together, leaving me anxious to read the next book once it's released.Thank you to the publisher and NetGalley for providing me with a free copy of this book in exchange for an honest review.

POINT OF NO RETURN is the third book in Olivia Luck's Point series, and concentrates on the story of Cam and Violet. Violet, Stella's best friend, is still grieving over the death of her husband. As a twenty-seven year old widow, she feels lost, trapped between a life with Max and a life without Max. When Stella and Dominic - Max's twin brother - convince Violet to take a job as an event planner for an upcoming Scrapers fundraiser, she is thrown back into the world she had been hiding from.This book is wonderful, with the point of view switching between Cameron and Violet in a way that allows us within the minds and hearts of each, without feeling disjointed. The story actually starts before Violet and Max get married, as Cam tells us about the first time he saw her... the day she got engaged. From that point, his heart was taken, though he was respectful and never tried to get between her and Max, and even waited for more than a year after his death to even bring himself to Violet's attention, understanding that she wasn't ready... and may wouldn't ever be ready.The author has done a great job of showing Violet in the greiving process, making it real: fraught with indecision, feelings of guilt, and sadness. But we also learn - along with Violet - that you can't let sadness overtake your life, and that your loved ones would want you to move on and be happy. There were several points in the book that I cried, feeling what Violet was going through. I felt that the author did a great job at bringing the character to life and fleshing out their feelings, motivations, and personalities.This is not a stand-alone book, and you really will want to read the first two in the series - NEW POINT and PRESSURE POINT - to fully understand and enjoy the events and characters.4 1/2 StarsThank you to the author and Book Enthusiast Promotions for providing me with a free copy of this book in exchange for an honest review.

Training the Alpha is the first book in a series about werewolves in Texas. In this book, we are introduced to Thomas, a man who was bitten and changed into a werewolf at a young age by Ceres, the daughter of the local Alpha. Set some time after he was changed, Thomas and Ceres now live together in a small town, Atropos, while Ceres finishes her schooling as a veterinarian and Thomas deals with his feelings for her. Intertwined with this story of their bonding are Thomas' trials to become the new Alpha of the sister pack being formed.The naming in this book can be clever and unusual in spots. For example, the story is set in Atropos - a town created by the author - which happens to be the name of one of the Greek Fates, specifically the Fate who cuts the threads. Given the events of the book, this town seems to be appropriately named.I really enjoyed this book. I first read it when it was published as the first part of a four part serial, but the author has since re-written the story and fleshed it out considerably, creating a wonderful culture and storyline that ties in with her other stories. If you've read some of her other books, it is great to meet and see references to characters you've already met and fallen in love with, and if you haven't it's a great introduction to the wider world of Vivienne Savage's shifter universe. The characters in all of the books are well-written, and Training the Alpha is no exception. You will quickly grow to love the main characters while hoping for the downfall of those who would hinder them, anticipating the next twist in the tale.Warning: This book contains explicit sex and adult language, menage situations, and violence. 18+ readers only.NOTE: This review has been re-written to accurately reflect the newly released book.I received this book in exchange for an honest review.

This is my favorite USB adapter, and the one I take with me whenever I travel. Not only is is a smart charger, able to recognize your device and provide it the best and fastest charge, but it also have 6 USB ports, each capable of up to 2.4 amps per port, so you can charge phones, tablets, handheld games... anything that is chargeable by USB.When I first started using this, I noticed that my kindle and phone both charged a lot faster than they generally do when plugged in... this is great because it eliminates the amount of time I have to have the devices plugged in, but it also doesn't let them overcharge, so you can safely leave your devices plugged in even after they're fully charged.There is a cable that connects this adapter to the outlet, allowing you to plug this in to those pesky plugs that are always hidden behind the bed in your hotel, or attached to a lamp. This is the only USB charger you will need while traveling... just remember to being your USB cables for each device since you'll still need those!NOTE: I received a promotional code for this product in exchange for an honest review.

This is a great USB adapter that allows me to charge up to four devices at a time. This is a smart charger, and will recognize your devices to give it the optimal charge. With four ports, each up to 2.5 amps, you can charge phones, tablets, kindles, and other handheld devices. I really love this one because it only takes up one plug (if you plug it in the bottom plug of the outlet) and you can plug the cables for four devices. It saves space, reduces the number of outlets that you have to use, and it also means that if you're traveling you only have to bring the cables for your devices, and don't also have to bring separate adapters for each.NOTE: I received a promotional code for this product in exchange for an honest review.

This is a great little USB adapter that allows me to charge two devices at a time. Useful for my office. where I regularly need to charge multiple devices but hate having to use an outlet for each one. This adapter has two ports, one up to 2.4 A (for tablets, kindles, etc) and the other up to 1.0 A for phones. This is a smart charger, and will recognize the type of devices you have to give it the best charge, so if you plug your phone into the 2.4 A port, it won't overcharge. This is a good space-saver and very convenient to have.NOTE: I received a promotional code for this product in exchange for an honest review.

Outside In, the second book of the Inside series, is the immediate sequel to Inside Out, where we first met Trella, the Force of Sheep, and the scrubs and uppers of Inside. Now that Trella and the Force of Sheep have taken over and put the Trava family in the brig, they find that there is still a lot more work to do. For years, the uppers have had the more technical jobs while the scrubs did the grunt work... with no one really taking control, the ship is quickly falling apart, with laundry stacking up and trash in piles.In the middle of all of this, the Committee (formed after the rebellion) loses control of this ship, and it's up to Trella to find out if the damage is coming from disturbances Inside... or from the Outside.Outside In is full of twists and turns, with the author switching up the plot every time you think you know what is happening. It is very well written, and the surprises keep you from guessing what the ending will be, and even the entirely of what is happening along the way. While Trella seems to lose her way for a little bit in the beginning, she is soon back to being the kick-ass reluctant heroine we first met. Minor characters from the first book suddenly become much more important, and I'm happy to report that we get to spend more time with Logan and Anne-Jade.Where this book falters a little bit is in the beginning, as the author spends the first third of the story setting the scene for the later action. This means, however, that the action rarely stops once it finally starts.

Easy to assemble, this scratching post is great. The post is wrapped with sisal, or something similar, giving the cats a rough surface that won't be destroyed easily. The post screws through the bottom platform, so all you need to put this together is a Phillips (crosshead) screwdriver. The ball is made of the same sisal-type material and makes a noise that attracts the cat's attention without being annoying when I have to hear it all day long! It sounds like there might be metal balls or something inside knocking against each other, creating the noise, but I'm not sure.It's a little short for my cats, who prefer a taller scratching post, but other than that it's great! Because it's smaller, and because the base and post are neutral colors, this doesn't look out of place in any room I put in it, and it's a fun activity for the cats.

I was first introduced to this author through her Study series, which I will be re-reading this summer, but Inside Out is a completely different book set in a completely different universe.Set at an unknown time when 100 hours equals a week and 100 weeks equals a  really long "year", we meet Trella, a scrub from the lower levels. Nicknamed the Queen of the Pipes, Trella yearns for silence away from the overcrowding on levels one and two. When a new prophet convinces Trella to retrieve discs from a hidden location in the upper levels, Trella soon finds herself in the middle of a revolution.I really enjoyed this book. Without it actually being said, the author manages to give the impression that this is set in the future by little comments interspersed throughout the story. This could, in fact, be our future someday. The characters we meet throughout the story are real, with their own personalities and motives, and we are able to learn about them over the course of the tale. Maria V. Snyder has always been wonderful about creating characters you grow to like - or sometimes hate - and this book doesn't disappoint.This is the first book in a two book series, and I'm excited to read the second!4 1/2 stars

I have mixed feelings about these headphones. I one hand, I like how stylish they are, and they fit well in my ears. On the other hand, there are some things that aren't so convenient about them... for example, the charging port. You really do need nails to be able to pull out the back of the right earpiece to plug the charger in, and even then it's not too easy. Also, I accidentally changed the language and now I can't figure out how to cycle it back... I've tried to hold down on the middle button - the function button? - again to try to cycle through, but with no luck. I'm apparently stuck at Chinese.I've also noticed some issues with receiving calls... I don't always get calls ringing through when I'm wearing these, even though I am connected to my phone and the phone is on, and when I do sometimes the voice prompt of Yes/No to answer/reject doesn't work. It defeats the purpose for me to have to find my phone to push the accept button. My callers also aren't able to hear me as well, though I'm able to hear them clearly enough. It's like the microphone part of the headphones just isn't that response, though the headset part of it works just fine.The headphones work great for me to listen to music when I'm sitting on my desk or just walking on the treadmill... I wouldn't want to test them with running since the fit isn't that great,  but they're decent for music. The volume starts out at maximum volume when you first get them, but it's simple enough to use the volume down key to adjust it.I love the case these headphones comes in, by the way. It's a soft-sided zippered case that has enough structure so that the headphones and charger won't get lose or crunched. It's small enough to keep the headphones always with you in a pocket or purse.I really want to lose these headphones, and I really hope that the issues I'm having with the microphone and calls being missed is corrected in a future version.NOTE: I received these headphones in exchange for an honest review.

EDIT from June 6, 2015 - After starting to use this bag, I would something so annoying that I dropped my review from 5 stars down to 3. It might not be a big thing to some people, but one strap is about 3 inches longer than the other. I can adjust them using the sliders, but then the sliders are not symmetrical, so my OCD kicks in and makes me upset that I'm using something that I feel is flawed. I don't know if this is a flaw with all of the bags or just the one I got, but it's something worth mentioning and worth updating my review for.-----------ORIGINAL REVIEW:I'm a HUGE fan of backpack bags, so I jumped at the change to get this once, since I needed a new one anyway. This bag is made of very soft material. The outside of the bag has two zippered pockets in the front, and another in the back. The top of the bag snaps shut and also has a drawstring once you open it, meaning that you can pull the drawstring and then also snap it shut, keeping anyone from being able to get into your bag. The inside of the bag is lined and has a zippered pocket.There is a little handle at the top of the bag, if you need to grab it quickly, plus it has the adjustable backpack straps that are wide enough and soft enough to be comfortable. They are sized for adults, not children, so this is a great bag.I have no complaints whatsoever about this bag, at least at this point. I'm sure I'll be putting it through some heavy use over the summer so I will update my review if needed.NOTE: I received this item in exchange for an honest review.

If you need a clear bag, this is probably one of the best that I have seen. Designed specifically for people who need to take in clear bags - into stadiums or other such facilities - it is well made, large enough to carry most of what you would need, and also has an opaque black pocket for your license and anything else you don't want public, as well as a carabiner for your keys. There is also an ID tag attached that you can fill out in case you accidentally leave the bag somewhere.The bottom of the bag is a reinforced black fabric, and the bag itself is made of a sturdy plastic that stays upright pretty well. There are black handles, a zipper to close the bag, and an adjustable black shoulder/cross-body strap.While I'm sure there may be better bags out there, I think this is a great bag for the price. The quality is decent and it seems like it will hold up well.NOTE: I received a coupon for this item in exchange for an honest review.

I'm middle aged, with combination skin. I tried this as a day moisturizer but didn't like it as well as my usual Trader Joe's Nourish Antioxidant Facial Serum Two Pack, which goes on less creamy and more matte. I moisturize at night only once a week at most (my bad), but as an occasional night creme, the Vichy Aqualinia works great! I am largely scent-free in my laundry products to spare my friends with environmental sensitivities, but I confess I do love my facial products. This one is noticeably scented, but I don't mind it. Using it twice a day would be way too much moisturizing for me, so I've set it aside for the occasional big burst from deeper application.

What a luxury facial oil. Unfortunately, within 4 or 5 days of starting to use this as a serum, I developed a deep subcutaneous pimple on one cheek (near the laugh line). I quit using it for more than a week and returned to my neutral skin care routine until my face cleared up. I think tried this oil again, and I got a pimple in the corresponding spot on the other cheek. So I can only conclude that this oil is too rich for my combination skin. I'm sorry, because I liked everything else about it -- lovely texture, mild scent, nicely thought out bottle for dispensing. Just didn't work for me.

Haven Travis is an abused wife with a shot at getting away. The book impressed me with the depth of the characters, the deep sympathy for abused women, the suspenseful situations on a number of different fields, and the insightful portrayal of malignant narcissists.Now, I’m generally a more “literary reader, but my friend Tamara Lush, author of Hot Shade, highly recommended that I  try this book once I had finished her book and had become curious about the romance genre. I’ve come to the conclusion that the passion and eroticism are only as convincing as the characters themselves, and this book delivers on both counts. With strongly drawn characters and a well-researched psychological situation, this book has opened up that neglected field of “romance writing” for me.

I never understood the premises of this book, so later scenes of danger and suspense bored me. Why was a character in danger? What was the future technology supposed to do, anyway? Sometimes characters hallucinated as a result of the future technology, so of course you couldn't take anything the author presented as definitive to the central storyline. Other times, a character would "know" the implications of an action, but I wouldn't, so it seemed random, but I plowed through to the big reveal (which, refreshingly, I did understand). I’ll have to read reviews to see if anyone can explain what was going on. For a more engaging sense of dislocation, I far preferred The Room: A NovelThe characters were intriguing and engaging, but the novel was overlong and padded with every stray thought the author ever invented about the future world. For some, it will be worth reading  as backstory to The Guild of Saint Cooper -- which has a trackable storyline and which was dumbed down enough for the likes of me -- and in which Forecast and its author make important appearances. But for me, summaries and reviews of this earlier novel would have sufficed, getting the gist like reading a synopsis of a Kilgore Trout novel, without having to plow through the whole damn thing.

Comparison of Island Fresh SUPERIOR Organic Extra Virgin Coconut Oil, Cold-pressed and Unrefined for Irresistible Aroma and Taste, 54 Ounce with Organic Coconut Oil - Kirkland - Certified USDA Organic - Pack of 2 - 42.3 Fl Oz. Plastic JarsThese are both high-quality, organic, cold-pressed coconut oils. The Island Fresh liquefied at a slightly lower temperature, and it also had a very slightly milder taste. The lids are the same size, with the Kirkland jar having straight sides, and the Island Fresh jar sloping wider under the lid, like a pickle jar. As a warehouse member, I get a better price on Kirkland, but that won't be available to all shoppers. For the price, Island Fresh is a bargain.Nutritional info is very similar, though the Kirkland calls a Tablespoon “14 grams” for 120 calories; Island Fresh calls a tablespoon  “15 mL” and 130 calories. This shouldn’t worry anyone, as it appears to be merely a difference in how different measuring systems are rounded during conversion.At this quality and price, I am very happy with the Island Fresh version, though I question the need to add all those adverbs and adjectives to the product names! With the products being virtually identical, the differences come down to availability, price, and packaging. Both are delicious, healthy, quality choices.

This eye cream is heavier-bodied than I typically use, so I have to rub it in rather than pat or "slide" it on. There's a slight tingle on application that goes away very quickly. It has made the circles under my eyes a bit lighter.Even though it's a thicker cream, the nozzle opening on the tube is TINY, so you can control how much you want to use and don't accidentally squirt out too much, thus preventing waste.

There are two distinct versions of this book: the "art" version of the book, The Hollow of the Hand: Deluxe Edition, and a simultaneously published, more affordable edition, The Hollow of the Hand: Reader's Edition. Sadly, Amazon's policy is to consolidate reviews, even when the editions are quite different.  Check out a classic like "David Copperfield" and see that critical editions with essays and beautifully illustrated editions are lumped together with cheap mass market versions in the reviews. I had hoped to review and rate the editions of this book separately, but, alas, I cannot.The two editions share the same content, but the Deluxe edition is larger and more rectangular, allowing the poems to "float" more on the page. The paper on both books is lightweight and textured; at this price, I do wish the Deluxe edition has been printed on glossy paper. Harvey's poems, which brought my attention to the project in the first place, are more like "snapshots" of particular moments than fully developed poetry. Murphy's photographs show day-to-day life in an unvarnished, insightful way. A more knowledgeable friend of mine who flipped through the Deluxe edition was impressed with the artistry of the photographs.As a coffee table book for fans of PJ Harvey or Seamus Murphy, the Deluxe edition is a treat, but for the money, I'd stick with the Reader's Edition.

My overpacked small hall coat closet was smelling funky. Throwing this charcoal bag in there didn't solve the problem, so I cleaned out the closet and got rid of some of the extra coats -- not to mention emptying out the box on the floor filled with old junk mail and other miscellaneous stuff from 2002. Honestly, I half expected to find a dead mouse in there, but no; maybe the smell was from one of the wool coats? The garments have room to "breathe" around them now, so that might help.Anyway, after cleaning out the closet, I chucked the charcoal bag back in there several days ago, and the improvement has been steady, but a lingering smell still remains. Perhaps if left longer, the odor will be eliminated, or maybe I just need to air out each of the coats until I figure out which one is the problem. (So happy there wasn't a dead mouse!)

Romance; what does that mean as a genre? In this debut romance novel, the author gives us maddening flirtation, irresistible attraction, and a soul connection expressing as hot sex. (Very hot sex.) The romance genre, however, has been so outside my previous reading experience, I don’t have a basis for comparison.  However, I’m acquainted with the author, and the book isn’t expensive, so I thought I’d give it a whirl.The genre hasn’t won me over, but even we more literary readers can revel in this authentic, inside look at the life of an ambitious young Florida reporter and her attraction to a jaded young Italian on the run from his country’s crime and corruption. The book also rewards the careful reader with a fair amount of humor. Besides the charismatic lead characters, there are well-defined side characters in an attorney uncle, the reporter’s friends on the newspaper staff, and an obsessed stalker character whom I loved to hate.  The characters have compelling back stories, and Florida’s humidity and weirdnesses are portrayed with affection. Given this good start, I’m eager to see what the author comes up with next.What surprised me about this first romance addition to my reading list was that, while the sex was electric, the arguments heated, and the characters astonishingly gorgeous, their hearts are pure, the love scenes were respectful, and the framing story was as important (or even more important) than the love scenes – though we readers must have faith that circumstances will work out for these lovers from different cultures who nevertheless find themselves to be true soul mates.

For several years, I've bought those staple-bound monthly office desk calendars for an "overview" of trends. Like most people, I have an online calendar for daily use, which is handy to share appointment information with my husband, and because I can get notifications on my phone when something's coming up.But I want to glance at ONE page and see which days that month I've exercised, chart my weight ups and downs, and remember the timing for larger events such as illnesses and vacations.The great thing about this little planner is that each month has a tab for the month-view calendar, followed by two-page spreads for each week of that month. And glory hallelujah, there are 8 squares for the week! They don't short Sunday; instead, they've titled the extra square for "notes." I'm often busier on the weekends than on weekdays, and I'm so pleased the weekend days have full squares.Details: The signatures are sewn in. The book opens fully and lies flat. The cover is a brown textured cardboard overlaid over a red spine, and there are two (count 'em, TWO) red satin bookmarks. Extra pages for "contacts" and "notes" are at the end.I entered one of my 2016 weekends on the one-page 2016 monthly overview page, using a fine-point Sharpie, and it did not bleed through.So what I'm going to do is use the full-month spread as usual for exercise and weight and such, then use the subsequent weekly pages for brief reviews of each day. My journaling habit is ingrained, but usually I write at length about once a week, so this will give me a chance to "check in" every day, not to mention giving a reliable source for my future biographer -- you know, after I become famous!

Parragon's "Essential" series, which was apparently produced to go straight to bookstore sale/remainder tables, features good-quality editions with glossy pages and short descriptions of the artists. Several pages are devoted to such influential artists as Pablo Picasso, Francis Picabia, André Masson, Max Ernst, and René Magritte, with several others also represented. The colors are bright, and the reproductions of surrealism's "greatest hits" are nice and clear. Some of the reproductions cross the spine onto both pages, with an adjacent sidebar about the artist. The book occasionally juxtaposes a smaller piece alongside a featured piece to point out parallels in the text, such as a smaller print of male artist Joan Miró's "Dutch Interior" placed with Salvador Dalí's "The Burning Giraffe" to compare the "automatic drawing" styles of the two artists.They've chosen interesting art for this book, but even though it was published in 1990, there is only ONE woman represented -- Dorothea Tanning. No Remedios Varo, no Leonora Carrington. This book was published rather late in the game for such a glaring omission. While not a "keeper" for the serious fan of surrealist art, the book is a good value as a general overview.

"Soothing Sea" is described as "the gentle sounds of seagulls as the caressing surf engulfs you."When I tried this disc in my car CD player, some doodling strings and piano came on, nice friendly chords, but it began to grate on me, so I soon popped the CD back out.Or, I tried to. My car CD player was stuck and I kept getting an "error" message display every time I tried to eject the disc, though it would still play. I quickly realized that I could be stuck with it for a long time. "I cannot listen to this vacuous music indefinitely!" I thought in a panic. I begged the CD gremlins to release the CD, with the promise that I would never risk it in my car again. Eventually the gremlins favored me, the CD was released, and I breathed a huge sigh of relief. Later, at home, I gave it another try. The music gets orchestral, like an inoffensive movie soundtrack. My husband thought the wave sounds were mixed too loud for the music, but I wished the music was altogether gone.If you enjoy New Age noodling with your nature sounds, you may well enjoy this. I, on the other hand, prefer my nature sounds "straight up."

This is a set of 3 "nature sounds" CDs. The description on the box says that the "Rain's Musical Massage" disc includes violins, saxophones, and cellos, and "Windchimes"  has gusty winds, birds, and thunder. "Soothing Sea" is described as "the gentle sounds of seagulls as the caressing surf engulfs you."I started with "Soothing Sea" in my car CD player, but almost immediately some doodling piano came on, nice friendly chords, but it began to grate on me, so I popped the CD back out.Or, I tried to. My car CD player was stuck and I kept getting an "error" message display every time I tried to eject the disc, though it would still play. I quickly realized that I could be stuck with this disc for a long time. "I cannot listen to this smarmy piano indefinitely!" I thought in a panic. I begged the CD gremlins to release the CD, with the promise that I would never risk it in my car again. Eventually the gremlins favored me, the CD was released, and I breathed a huge sigh of relief.If you enjoy New Age noodling with your nature sounds, this could be the set for you. I, on the other hand, prefer my nature sounds "straight up."

This story is set in the fictional town of Gravenstein. Now, the Gravenstein apple comes from Sebastopol, California. Sebastopol also has a Gravenstein School District. When I started the book and saw the Zip Code for "Gravenstein" was 95472, it confirmed it – this book is set on a farm outside of Sebastopol, California, a town I know well. Sophie’s family has inherited a farm from the late Great Uncle Jim, necessitating a dislocating move from urban Los Angeles to the apple trees and FFA clubs of agricultural Northern California. Sophie is of mixed heritage, and her sense of being an outsider is increased due to people’s preconceptions.Her mother is a freelance writer, and her father is job hunting, so Sophie is on her own for her first summer on their new farm. In poking around, she finds a chicken that has uncanny abilities, even though it’s no smarter than your average chicken.The first half of the book was slow for me, since Sophie was left to her own devices too much, and it was sounding like one of those "stranded on a desert island with only a chicken for company" stories. It picks up in the second half when Sophie starts meeting more people and some puzzling situations develop.The tale is told through Sophie’s letters to her late grandmother and dead Uncle Jim, as well as a correspondence course on raising chickens. The illustrations are educational and amusing and move the story along jauntily. (Readers will want to take the quiz to determine their own potential aptitude as poulterers.) If I may go out on a limb, I would suspect the feed store of the story is based on the old Frizelle Enos Feed store, which was destroyed in a fire in the summer of 2013 and subsequently rebuilt under different ownership as The Feed Store.While I personally have not raised chickens, my grandmother and her parents had a small farm with some chickens, but the real reason I ordered this book is because the Amazon page had a blurb from Daniel Pinkwater. I've met many of my favorite authors (such as Francesca Lia Block), but meeting Mr. Pinkwater is still on my life goals list -- though I suspect I'll have to get myself to New Jersey if it is to happen. Mr. Pinkwater, if you’re reading this, author Kelly Jones and I would like to meet you, and Kelly Jones went so far as to write a book in the Pinkwater chicken genre!

Update, May 1, 2015: Wow! I like this product and have ordered it before, but this time it was faster (a couple of days, instead of a couple of weeks); better packaged (a small box with packing popcorn vs. a padded envelope); and they included a handful of SAMPLES! Impressed in every way.Previously: I think Refinery29 had glowingly reviewed the Skin79 Hot Pink Super Plus Bb Cream 40g Spf25 Pa++_pump, but as an over-50 minimalist with a rather ruddy Caucasian complexion, I too went with this Gold version instead, and have been SO pleased. It took a long time to arrive from overseas, but it has been a pleasure to use it. My husband cracked, "Oh, you get rid of wrinkles by spackling your face?" Indeed, it goes on looking rather caulky, but a few minutes later my skin tone is even and I have a deceptively deep-looking glow, making me appear elegant and enigmatic behind this cure-all facial balm. When I want a little extra boost, I use Trader Joe's Nourish Antioxidant Facial Serum Two Pack first, which is also very reasonably priced and gives a nourished, matte look to my otherwise shiny face. I'm very pleased with this first foray into beblesh balm, and I've let my husband know that he can go spackle HIMSELF (heh!).

In the photo, this looks yellow-and-black, but the case was more tan than shown. It's thick, so the recessed buttons are harder to press. However, it IS bulky, and the black part is rubber, so this provides more protection than the wood-grain case from these folks that my husband ordered at the same time.

I  have both linoleum (in the kitchen and bathrooms) and v-groove hardwood flooring (in the living room and bedrooms), but the manuals for this Oreck hard floor washer as silent on its use with various types of flooring. So I phoned Oreck to ask about using this unit on the various flooring types – and the customer service representative said I should “ask the flooring installer” if it would be “recommended.”Next call: the local flooring guy. He said to be cautious, and that it would probably be OK on the v-groove hardwood, but to carefully dry any leftover water drops with a cloth afterwards – with the caveat that some folks say even damp-mopping wooden flooring carries the risk of buckling. (The floor guy’s wife actually uses Windex to clean their hardwood floors.)On our stained and textured old linoleum, this unit worked pretty well. It didn't dispense the water solution until I gave the trigger a mighty squeeze, but after you get the water to dispense, you can let go of the trigger until you need more fluid. We have a smallish kitchen, but it would take at least 2 batches of cleaning liquid to cover the whole floor.I still think the floor is cleaned more thoroughly the old-fashioned way, with rags and a bucket, but who wants to do THAT? If you don’t mind the effort and noise of vacuuming, it could be easier on the back and knees than grandma’s low-tech methods.However, when my occasional house cleaner came over and tried out this unit, she didn't like it. She has some back problems herself, and the vacuum cleaner style is actually more difficult to use for her than hands-and-knees scrubbing. She also pointed out that the head with the brushes doesn't let you clean all the way up to the edge of the floor, or in weird narrow crevices, and that the brushes can’t apply the same pressure as one can manually.After experimenting on the linoleum, I won’t be trying this on my wood flooring. When water dispenses, it dispenses a fair amount. The “dry” vacuum option worked well enough to suck up extra water, but I don’t trust that it has enough power to suction water out of the v-grooves of a hardwood floor.While this unit works well enough, I believe I’ll let my house cleaner do her thorough rags-and-bucket method when she’s here, while I go back to the sponge mop and Swiffer for touch-ups and weekly maintenance.

They say more people are wearing watches, and it’s even been offered as a productivity tip: “Wear a watch to check the time;” otherwise when you pull out your phone just to see what time it is, you may find yourself completely distracted by all the other features of your smart phone. If you haven’t worn a watch before, it can take some getting used to, like wearing glasses, but eventually one can start feeling naked without it.When I first tried on my new Kate Spade watch, it was loose and bulky. First stop: my local watch shop. The proprietor gave me a choice of having 2 links removed for a “bracelet” appearance, or 3 links removed for a more snug “watch” fit. I have a slender wrist, 6” in circumference, so I chose the latter and had 3 links removed. (Don’t try this at home; it cost me only $10 to have it done professionally while I waited, and he had the specialized tools so it didn't get scratched or broken. Save the links in case your tastes change, or you pass it along to someone else, or, god forbid, you gain weight.) These three links took off half an ounce of weight and left the watch weighing in at a tad over 3 ounces (88 grams). Though it’s a large timepiece, it wasn't too heavy for me; it just feels solid and substantial.And oh, the styling! I’m a watch-hound and have five perfectly serviceable, cute drugstore watches that I rotate depending on my outfit, so I originally thought to save this one for special occasions. But I also didn't think I was particularly materialistic until I got this watch! Now I know I’ll be wearing this gorgeous and versatile statement piece frequently.The booklet is generic, apparently written for many different styles, including digital watches, and those with date and stopwatch functions (which this watch doesn’t have).The Amazon product page also has a few mistakes; the watch weighs 3.5 ounces, not 16. And the bezel is stationary (unmoving) rather than uni-directional (rotating in one direction). The specs also say the watch face is merely “white,” but it’s much better than flat white. Against the gold Roman numerals, the face is iridescent, like white marble. The logo name is black with a discreet black spade symbol, and the red second-hand makes it easy to track the passage of the seconds. This is my favorite of the Kate Spade watches -- an elegant, classically styled timepiece.

"69. Defines a subject that may or may not exist."I read book reviews for enjoyment, even when I don't plan on reading the book, because book reviews tell much of what you want to know, plus they're a valid literary form all on their own. ART reviews, on the other hand, are a whole 'nother story. If an esteemed critic likes the work, he often appears to write stream-of-consciousness blather, signifying nothing but the contents of his own psyche.This book presents 101 such quotes, "culled from contemporary art reviews," each one spotlit on its own pristine page. Here's a sample. "64. While essentially nervous, the work possesses the gritty clarity of the irresolvable. It keeps turning out to be about something other than what's apparently being said." And this classic: "49. Plays with the polar opposites of presence\absence, reality\illusion, to develop vital points of contact & centers, accumulated energies."Critics, take note, but artists, you too must beware the transgression of the less academic but more trite blather known as the "Artist's Statement," which can run along the lines of "She is inspired by form and color, and by the interpenetration of consciousness with nature." If it could be said about every artist in the gallery, please please get a writer friend to edit it for you!"55. Introduces a possibility into consciousness that could enter the general domain. Confronted, the rational mind is extraordinarily clarified, and emotional responsiveness, stricken, falls in a hole."

I’m not of the culinary inclination, but the economy has led me gently down the path of less restaurant dining, and more home cooking. When my niece, who has worked in fine restaurants for years, mentioned that she hardly uses her standard oven any more since getting a countertop convection oven, I decided to try it.The initial impediments were frustrating. Right out of the box, you need to check the unit carefully – there was a strip of packing tape on the underside of the oven, for no apparent reason. You also need to wash the two racks and the tray. And it is BIG. (Did I mention that it’s big? From the description, I thought I would be getting a toaster oven, but this unit is bigger than my microwave.)And then, the cord! Sheesh, the cord! If you have the outlet on the right-hand side of the unit, you’ll be OK, but if your outlet has the misfortune of being on the left side of the unit, the cord will extend only a couple of inches past the unit itself. The manual says the short cord is on purpose – “a short power-supply cord is provided to reduce the risk resulting from becoming entangled in or tripping over a longer cord” – guys, the unit is 21” wide, and the cord is only 26” long.  Unless you have it on the counter but are plugging it in at the FLOOR, you are NOT going to trip over this ridiculously short cord. So, while most of us will need an extension cord, the manual gives only generic instructions about using “properly rated” extension cords. After irritated inquiries and digging around, I was able to determine that one needs an extension cord that can handle 1500 watts. (Now you know everything electrical that I know.) We ended up using a power strip that my husband had lying around.Finally, after washing everything, removing the cardboard inserts and random tape, and finding a proper extension cord, the next night I was finally ready to cook something.I used the “convection” setting to cook a pork roast and red potatoes in a “V” rack over the tray. I rubbed the roast with a spice mix, baked it, then drizzled with a sweet sauce for the finish. Payoff! I hadn’t browned the pork roast, but it came out like a pre-seasoned ham (as I said, I’m no great cook). The next night, I used the tray to bake breaded fish. Suddenly, I see what my niece meant. Why heat up the whole kitchen with gas heat, when this efficient unit can bake and broil through the miracle of electricity?There’s no number keypad, so the “bake” and “timer” functions start with presets (350 and 30 minutes, respectively), and you use an arrow key to increase or reduce the temperature and time. In fact, to “preheat,” you just heat the unit for 7 minutes; however, this is not a huge annoyance for an affordable unit such as this. There’s no inside light, but on the countertop, it wasn't difficult to check the progress of the meal.So, all that griping aside, I’m happy with my first foray into convection-oven cooking.

If you're like me and have been making do with a cobbled-together collection of various pots and pans, this set can replace nearly everything you need for daily use. Add a larger Dutch oven if needed, and whatever specialty pans you may require, and you'll be good for years. The weight is ideal; these aren't cheap or flimsy pans, but they won't break your toe if you do happen to drop one of them. The lids seal securely and are see-through so you can monitor the dish visually.With my glass-top stove, these didn't shift at all. I have a small apartment kitchen, and storing this set is also easy, as the pans can be stacked in one spot and the lids in another, without taking up much space.It's a joy to have a frying pan that can be used without butter, oil, or cooking spray, and have my bacon and eggs slide right out. Clean-up is as easy as a paper towel after most uses.  Because these pans can go from stovetop to oven, as you finish one dish, you can put it into the oven to keep warm while you cook another dish in another pan, and everything stays warm.This is a functional, attractive, and practical cookware set for newlyweds, single folks, and families.

My husband found the Scandinavian volume in a thrift store and got hooked. He's looked at other books of early country histories and says nobody writes like this guy. This next volume has not disappointed him either. The writing, though somewhat dated stylistically, is story-oriented and lively.

Why use this product instead of good old bulk turmeric from the natural foods store? I called New Chapter to ask.The powder has different parts "alive" (as the rep put it) than does Turmeric Force. Oils don't survive well in powdered spices that have been exposed to the air, but these capsules retain those potent oils. Strength-wise, each pill is equivalent to 4 grams of fresh ground turmeric - the average amount a person gets through daily meals in India.Turmeric Force is not manipulated to change the natural balances - for instance, there's the same ratio of curcumin, an antioxidant that is one of the active ingredients in turmeric - but the fiber has been removed. Some people take this product preventatively as an anti-inflammatory; others take it for a while for a specific problem. The rep said that either way is fine, but it was produced for safe, ongoing daily use.After my Kaiser doctor recommended turmeric for back pain, my husband started using a lot of it when he cooked. However, I don't want to eat quite that much Indian cuisine every day, so I'm happy to have these supplements to get the same effect. I'll be using up this bottle, giving it a rest, and seeing if there's enough of a difference that I want to either try another round, or start taking it regularly with my daily vitamins.

The book is organized primarily by topic, such as "How do you know anything exists?" and "What is a logical argument?" This should have been more stimulating than it was. Instead, it bogged down with stuffy, almost academic language that took the joy out of the inquiry.Here's a random sample: "Logic helps us to analyze an argument -- to see its structure, or logical form. We can then assess whether or not the conclusion follows from the premises. An argument is said to be valid when we can deduce [work out] the conclusion from the premises. Such an argument is known as a deductive argument. In a deductive argument, IF the premises are true, the conclusion must also be true. But being able to deduce the conclusion from the premises is not enough to prove that the conclusion is true; it also depends on the content of the argument." (etc.)While it covers the bases in presenting the major themes of philosophical inquiry through the ages, the book reads like a textbook, not like a general-interest book for the curious. The writing is dry, it doesn't convey the passion of philosophy, and the little sidebars and bubbles of info weren't enough to offset the plodding text. I enjoyed its occasional philosopher biographies much more, probably because each individual's life story includes challenges that are more than just academic.This book can't compete with Sophie's World: A Novel About the History of Philosophy (FSG Classics) -- a much more engaging introduction to the fascinating world of philosophy.

These would be rather expensive for my budget (fortunately, I received a free pair), but I was quite impressed. I'm short (5'4") and 145 lbs. The Large size fit me well, but with my extra belly fat, I expected them to "roll" down at the waist as other tights do. However, the broader design of the waistband kept them up, and I forgot that I was even wearing them. Super comfortable, and they added a little extra warmth and shaping under a long dress.

We're using this bulb in the lamp on my husband's bedside table. He often reads after I go to sleep, and the warm, diffused, yellow light doesn't bother me like the light from harsh compact fluorescent lights, which I've never liked. In fact, we had stocked up on a case of the old incandescent light bulbs, because fluorescent lights have given me migraines in the past, though the CFL technology seems to be improving in that regard.This unit is heavy, much more physically substantial than either the old incandescents or the curly CFLs. If this bulb lasts as long as expected -- Kobi warranties it for 5 years -- it will be a great payoff for what is admittedly a high initial investment.

A toddler is abandoned in a bookstore, eventually melting the icy heart of the unpleasant, widowed owner. A.J. Fikry. Silas Marner, anyone?Each chapter begins with a commentary by the bookstore owner on a famous short story, and it's amusing to look for the connection between the famous story and the subsequent events of that chapter in this novel. I would not expect this book's audience to make the literary connections on their own, however, because readers of classic fiction are more likely to be as annoyed as Fikry is with chick lit. Indeed, The Storied Life of A. J. Fikry: A Novel is one of the crop of disposable titles bookstore owner Fikry would stock only out of desperation.Bookstore clerks, English majors, and book industry workers will enjoy an unlikable "writer" side character, the author's obvious love of classic fiction, the scene of an over-the-top author reading, the theft of one of the world's most expensive books, and the Black Books - The Complete First Series type of eccentric bookstore owner.However, heavy-handed foreshadowing initially confuses the reader and then spoils any sense of suspense. Tongue-in-cheek, self-referential criticisms also become annoying, as when a promising young writer's story is criticized for avoiding contractions and writing in third-person present tense, both of which are quirks of Zevin's herself, or when the bookstore owner says he doesn't like "orphan books" or "supposedly clever formal devices" - both of which The Storied Life includes.The child character is the weakest link in the cast. (Practical impediments to a contemporary single man being allowed to adopt a toddler were easily dismissed.) The child begins as a bright 3-year-old who speaks in one-word commands, like precocious baby talk, as if young children who can say "downstairs" ever just stop there. The orphan, who naturally becomes a voracious reader, is an idealized nerdy, compliant, and insightful child -- just what you want for a book that seems written expressly to be a movie adaptation, to pander to both chick-lit and chick-flick audiences.I disliked this book for the same reason I disliked The Bridges of Madison County; it's a pretentious, title-dropping book for a type of popular fiction reader who imagines herself a serious reader. This book offers a little more hope for the earnest pop fiction reader than does "The Bridges of Madison County," though, with a cop character who is slowly introduced to literary fiction via police procedurals. Literary snobbishness is mentioned often enough to wonder if the author takes herself seriously, believing she can successfully lift elements from classic novels and plop them into what is, in the final analysis, a chick-lit book, one in which plot "reveals" depend on characters keeping important (and trivial) secrets from each other ... forever. As in soap operas, "talking criminal" scenes eventually clear up all ambiguity (which is a characteristic that discriminating Fikry admits he likes, though "most readers" don't), again making it appear the author is mocking both her Fikry character and any readers nave enough to take her book to heart.Author Zevin appears determined to disprove character Fikry's idea that "literary should be literary, and genre should be genre, and crossbreeding rarely results in anything satisfying." Here, Zevin is hoist by her own petard, unless the point is that great literature only makes one fusty and unpleasant, and that when one's heart opens, one can embrace chick lit like "The Storied Life of A. J. Fikry" and consider it a book of literary merit.

Wasn't sure how this was going to work out for us, but we like it. Our dashboard was pretty dusty, so the pad lost stickiness fairly quickly. We washed it in mild soap and warm water, replaced it, and now it's just fine. Didn't love it for the phone, because it's not really flexible enough for touch-free driving, but the "Bell+Howell 9434 Clever Grip Air Vent Portable easy phone mount good for all smart phones" solved that problem, and now we use the DashGrip for everything else -- magazines, keys, sunglasses, and the Kleenex box!

I tested this unit out over the course of several weeks with my 4-year-old niece and her mom, who have a lot of experience with the previous LeapPads, and the Leap Pad 3 is light years better than its predecessors!With the connection to Wi-Fi, you can purchase games from the pad itself, as well as use cartridges. Also, the games are just better! The touch is more comprehensive and the games very entertaining to my little niece, who loves playing with it.You can do a lot more with your "pet" in this generation of LeapPad as well -- more games, and more options to customize.  The electric charger vs. the old battery-powered LeapPads is a great improvement. The previous generations used 4 AA batteries, and they wore out FAST. The charge on the 3 is amazing. My niece gets to use it 2-3 hours a week and it still has a good charge -- haven't charged it once in the 3 weeks she has played with it.It seems to be very durable -- as durable as all the other LeapPad products. We don't have a case for it and it has been dropped (a LOT, heh!) and it still works great.The only downside to the LeapPad 3 and its predecessors is the addicting video game component, but it sure does make a great distraction if mom or dad just needs to get something done without the kiddo getting in the way for an hour. All in all, my little niece, her mom, and I give it 5 stars.

This is a charming story, beautifully illustrated, of a fox and a rabbit stuck on either end of a teetering log precariously balanced over a river. If they move, they could both fall into the river. Blustering and posturing turn into conversation and caring. The text went a little long for my tastes, but it's a fine, leisurely story about tribal enemies who discover much to like about each other. This would be a great addition to church and school libraries.

Sewn binding with a vintage cover. Lines are not dreadfully dark and are fairly close-spaced, so it doesn't look like a child's notebook. The pages are also perforated along the spines. While this would be a sweet little gift for a student or traveler, one can also travel internally, and it would be a handy bedside dream log too. Despite being inexpensive, it urges the writer to adventure!

I like to sit on the porch with my phone and stream radio stations, and you've got to have a better speaker than the phone speaker if you don't want to insult the music. For the price, this is a functional low-end Bluetooth speaker that works fine, though the whole party/color-changing feature seems overly ambitious for the quality of the unit. Theoretically you can tap a button and get it to stay on one color, but I couldn't get that feature to work and just turned off the color feature. At the default white & black, it really does look like cheap plastic. Well, I suppose that's fair, because the casing IS cheap plastic and lacks any aesthetic appeal. I can see it in a pre-teen's room with stickers all over it, which would be an improvement.The price seems to be all over the map, but I'd probably go around $30 as my top-end purchase price.

I use this lightweight conditioner when I don't need deep conditioning.What impressed me most is that it is truly fragrance-free. I'm not environmentally sensitive, but I have friends who are, so my laundry detergents are fragrance-free, for instance, and my nose is "awake" to chemical scents.But when I put this conditioner into my hand and sniffed it in the shower -- NOTHING. It was like smelling water. Very impressive that they not only didn't add scents, but the ingredients don't have a nasty smell that needs to be covered up.

There's a big difference between WordPress.org and WordPress.com. If you've blogged by choosing a "theme," you've been using WordPress.COM, the free site.WordPress.ORG, on the other hand, is for self-hosted blogging. Your ISP may include blogging and website capability with your account -- mine, Sonic.net, does -- but you don't get all the preset themes and functions of WordPress.com. WordPress.org is a DIY project. You can't place ads of your choice on the free .com version (though WordPress reserves the right to include their ads with your blog), but you can with the .org version, and using the .org version gives you the ability to choose your own domain name, without the "***.wordpress.com" ("wordpress" added to domain name).If you're a novice blogger, you may want to get your feet wet with WordPress.com and then decide if you eventually want to take the step to self-hosting with WordPress.org. And if you take that leap, you'll want this book! It walks you through the programming codes so you can replicate the functions that the .com "themes" give you as a package.The author also reveals the power of WordPress for other functions, such as nonblog uses, e.g., a Content Management System (CMS) for database management.This is not a "dummies" type book, however; it would be very useful as a college-level blog design textbook. There's a lot of power here, but it won't be for everyone. If the mere appearance of a line of code like:function smashingtheme_exclude_category ( $query ) {makes your eyes roll around in your head, this book may be more than you need. But if you're up for the power and control and adventure of a self-hosted WordPress.org blog, this book will be well worth the investment.

Comparing the Schick Hydro 5 Sensitive Razor to my old Schick Hydro 3 Blade Razor, much is the same. The handles are similar and both versions have swivel heads. While the handles look very similar, the cartridges are NOT interchangeable (I tried!). Both types of cartridges have a row of tiny dots at the top so you can see how much life is left in them.I had to decide between the Hydro 5 and the  Schick Hydro Silk Sensitive Razor, but the reviews on the latter suggested there would be more gel than I wanted, and I believe I made the right choice with the Hydro 5 Sensitive Razor.I did get razor burn on my underarms the first time I used the Hydro 5, so perhaps it's sharper (or just newer), or I was overzealous. Take it easy with this baby right out of the wrapper.If you dry the blades to extend the life of the cartridges, as I do, tap only the metal blade part against a towel, because the moisturizing gel top on the top of the plastic cartridge is sticky on the towel.One distinct advantage to the Hydro 5 is that the cartridges have a "trimmer" function. You can flip back the bulky top of the cartridge that has the gel, which allows the blades to sit closer to the skin. I tried this on my bikini line and it worked as described. Just watch it when you flip the top back so you don't cut yourself.  (Drunken shaving is not recommended in any case.)

Well, our Victor TIN CAT Live Mouse Trap M310 caught several mice, but that one had loosened up somehow, so the mice got in, ate the seeds, then got back out.So we ordered this one, and it's great -- there's a clear lid so we can see if we caught anything -- but even though we can still hear a mouse under our oven, it just isn't interested in exploring this trap. It may be that the last mouse is the smartest mouse, but it's been two weeks, and none of those sunflower seeds has been eaten, so we know the room has not been occupied, so to speak. Does the clear plastic lid possibly deter the mouse from exploring the inside? I'll revise my review if the mouse ever decides to go into this trap ...

I like this conditioner, but it was too heavy as a leave-in conditioner for my light brown wavy/curly hair. However, when I used it like a traditional rinse-out conditioner but didn't over-rinse, it was a very nice, softening conditioner that gave enough definition to my wavy curls.

This is a good, solid vacuum cleaner - very strong, very powerful, and multi-directional. It can go under beds and into corners that standard vacuums can't reach.The foot on/off switch is hard to press and the controls are rather stiff. The cord is very long and wonderful for large rooms. Just don't run over the cord -- the motor is so strong it actually might suck up the cord. (It also really begs for an automatic cord-winder.)However, I had my elderly mother-in-law give it a try, and she found that it took some strength to both turn it on, and then to hang onto it, but she loved the power and suctioning ability. It wouldn't be good as the only vacuum cleaner for a two-story house, however, because it's quite heavy and would be difficult to carry up and down stairs. In fact, when her caretaker gave it a try, he said he wouldn't buy one because it was too hard to maneuver.Still, this vacuum cleaner is very well made and we found it much more effective as a cleaning tool than the current flimsy plastic models.

Always on the lookout for "the" miracle product, I was happy to try this one, since I like the Olay line in general and I kept seeing it at the Costco warehouse.So many grandiose claims are made about so many products, I have naturally become jaded, so I was quite pleasantly surprised at the quick difference this cream made in my complexion. I have mixed oily/normal skin that tends to red splotchiness, and I soon was rather surprised to see a noticeably lighter, more even, brighter tone to my skin.My go-to morning moisturizer is Aveeno Positively Radiant Skin Daily Moisturizer SPF 15, 4 Ounce, but I left off with that for the Regenerist review period. A big difference is that the Aveeno is SPF 15, and Regenerist doesn't have any sun protection. However, Physicians Formula Mineral Wear Talc-Free Loose Powder, Translucent Medium, 0.49 Ounce, my other standby, just added SPF 16, so I'm covered there (though I wonder how well SPF coverage works in powder).I sometimes use Trader Joe's Nourish Antioxidant Facial Serum before I put on the moisturizer, and they don't clash.I dislike the sticky feeling of the Regenerist on my hands after applying it and always wash my hands afterwards; still, this could become a staple of my morning facial routine, except that the price is significantly higher than the Aveeno moisturizer.

This is a delicate, lovingly hand-produced artist’s book. A vellum wrap-around band is printed with laudatory phrases from Herb Caen, Jack Hirschman, and Jack Micheline. 15 pages, with four rubber stamped images, as well as tipped-in ephemera items (a map, 2 photos, “INS FORM No. 187-4U2b” envelope with “permission to exist” ticket). The poetic story concerns the narrator as a young girl traveling by train with her brother between parents' homes in Southern California, and the regular INS deportation raids on the train.The artistic ephemera, including a bit of a map and a Day of the Dead rubber stamp, convey both a more adult understanding and a condemnation of her assimilated father's dilemma.

I loved The Barter System but if it's possible I loved this even more. Be warned... Make sure you got time to read all this as you won't want to leave it for even a minute.One of the great things about this book is we get to read more about the characters from The Barter System. The characters in this book are fantastic. The story gripped me from the start to the finish. It was non stop action in this book. Did I mention Hudson is oh so hot?? They females are also fit as f**k.I HIGHLY recommend this book.Why oh why have I not heard of this author before? I could keep gushing about this author but instead I'm gonna go see what other books she's written.Received in return for honest review.

Oh my dayz!! I received this for a blog tour & I'm so glad I did.Riya O’Connell requests applications from men around the country willing to participate in the research she needs for her dissertation on Male Sexuality. This is the start of an emotional and exploratory journey for her.I totally loved Riya. Such a strong character.As for the men they were totally hot... All of them. Although Riya left a little piece of her heart with each of them she became stronger as the time passed.Although at first I found this a bit surreal I totally loved this book. Storyline was brilliant and I was totally delighted that this was a long story. I had to message author during part of it to say she made me cry!! I really didn't want it to end. However I loved the ending.This is the first book I've read by this author but it won't be the last. I was totally glued to this book.

How did I not know before starting this that this is an m/m read. What a great surprise this read was for me.I never read book one Wait for Morning but I'll certainly be going back and reading it.This is Ryan and Zs story. The security business is Ryan's family business. One of their long term employees is Z who Ryan has been lusting over. However from a past experience that went wrong Ryan doesn't want to mix business with pleasure. When these two are on a mission will things change?Brilliant well written story about two alpha males. I totally loved it. Really need to get 1-clicking and read more of this authors books.

I love finding new authors and this was a great surprise for me. This is book one in The Colloway Brothers.As soon as Gray saw Livia he knew she was the girl for him. He chased her for a date and life seemed to be good when they got engaged. Suddenly Livia disappears. Five years later they meet again. Gray wants answers but Livia is afraid to open up.Lies, deception and betrayal. This book has it all. If your looking for an emotional roller coaster then I highly recommend this story. I totally loved this book.

Oh my dayz. I'm sitting here in shock at what I've just read. From page one it sucked me right in. I felt as if the air in me was being sucked out too. All I wanted to do was keepreading until I'd finished.I'm not gonna recap the storyline. The synopsis gives you enough of a teaser to know its a forbidden romance(kinda) in a prison. To me it wasn't a dark read. The story is based in a prison so obviously it isn't gonna be all sweet and roses.As a blogger who reads non stop I crave an original storyline. This author dropped an original storyline in my lap and rocked my world.Amazing read that ill be re-reading again. Need to read more from this author as this was epic.

This was a super fun read. I rarely read 'funny' books as a few have disappointed me in the past. This book found my sense of humour and had me cracking up laughing.I thought when I started this book that it was gonna be a hot sexy book. However I was wrong.. It was so much more than that. This book had a combination of sexy, romantic and downright laugh out loud moments. Yes I may have snorted a few times.Aubrey is on a road trip. Fate steps in and drops the luscious sexy Chance into her lap (or should I say her car lol). What starts as giving him a lift turns into so much more.Really brilliant storyline. If I could give more than five stars I would.Have I mentioned the great names in this book... Esmerelda Snowflake. Let's not forget Philomena. Yes of course I'm gonna mention her lolFabulous funny read. Get 1-clicking:)

Make sure you read King first. Tyrant continues from where King ends. I did a re read of King before jumping into Tyrant. After the way King ended I couldn't wait to jump into this and wow I was blown away.I could not read this book fast enough. It sucked me in. There were parts I felt as if I couldn't breath, other parts had me cursing at my kindle.Totally unpredictable storyline. My heart was in my mouth throughout.I really can't do this book any justice with my review. These books are brilliant. They'll be staying on my kindle for a re-read.

Wow. This is a truly beautiful heartfelt story. I thought I was about to start a novella. Then I see in the acknowledgment stat this is the story of how the author met her husband. What I didn't expect was all the emotions that I felt while reading this.This story is told through Stephens point of view. He tells us how he felt the first time he saw Ashleigh.Although this was a really quick read it was pure perfection. I totally adored their story and the goosebumps it gave me.

Ah I really enjoyed this quick read. Johanna seems to be in a rut. When her parents have a heart to heart chat with her as they want their daughter back she realises she needs to get her life back. A few life changes seems her finding her own self. A friend years ago told her 'never settle'. She's found out that when she ignored them words she wasn't happy.Can she find happiness again?I found this to be a cute quick read that I really enjoyed.

This is the second part of this saga. I liked how the author gave a good introduction to where the story is so we can pick this book up and keep reading.Jason is left heart broken when his childhood sweetheart May leaves for college. He finds himself falling in love with their friend Abby. He marries her and starts a family. His happiness is short lived when Abby dies.When May comes back all his feelings for her come back. However the secret she is hiding could jeopardise their happiness.This is a quick short read. Personally I'd like to re read this as a full story. That said I enjoyed the story.

This is the fourth book in this series about The Marino Bros. I recommend you read these in order as they really are super great reads. I thought it was perfect that the author left Andreas story until last.I read book one last December. I signed up to review all four for a blog tour so I re-read book one and literally inhaled the rest of the series.This is Andreas 'Andy' Marinos story. He's the eldest of the brothers. He took over responsibility of his brothers when his parents were murdered. He can't seem to move on until the killer is caught.Cats a great character. She's strong and independent. When she needs help she reaches out for Andys help.Although these two try to keep it professional they get more than they bargained for.This is a super ending to the series. One word-perfect. Absolutely love this book and the full series. Highly recommend these books.

Oh wow. This series has me in a tizzy. As I read each book I love them even more. This story just blew me away.Lisa broke Gios heart years ago. He's never forgotten her.
